The aim is to create a single submission system for investors, reducing the complexity and red tape in the investment process.

site_title: Hyundai Merchant Marine to invest 470.3b won in new oil carriers
summary: Hyundai Merchant Marine plans to invest 470.3 billion won (S$568.4 million) in new oil carriers, including five very large crude oil carriers (VLCCs) and two container ships. The investments aim to boost competitiveness and are expected to be completed by September 2019 and May 2018. This move is part of the company's efforts to enhance its fleet and services.

images.alt_text: South Korea's largest shipper, Hyundai Merchant Marine, will invest 470.3 billion won (S$568.4 million) in five new very large crude oil carriers (VLCCs), the company said on Thursday.

site_title: BOE's Saunders says Brexit risks don't justify record-low rates
summary: Bank of England policy dissenter Michael Saunders said Brexit risks don't justify record-low interest rates. Saunders voted for a 25-basis point rate hike at the BOE's last two meetings, citing a "trade-off" between above-target inflation and below-potential output. He believes the necessary monetary policy response is unclear, but a modest rate rise would help ensure sustainable inflation returns to target over time. Saunders also noted that the BOE is not indifferent to faster inflation caused by the pound's depreciation.

site_title: Sterling slips on Brexit negotiation uncertainty
summary: Sterling slipped 0.25% to US$1.2891 on Thursday due to Brexit negotiation uncertainty. Investors downplayed comments from Commerzbank AG's Thu Lan Nguyen, who suggested interest rates may rise soon. Nguyen stated that prolonged sterling weakness could prompt policymakers to support the currency, potentially pushing up inflation.

site_title: Eurozone inflation rises, unemployment at 8-year low
summary: Eurozone inflation rose 1.5% in August, nearing the European Central Bank's 2% target, signaling a tentative economic recovery in Europe. This confirms the ECB's efforts to boost growth and inflation, which may lead to the bank rolling back its crisis-fighting policies. The jobless rate remains stable at 9.1%, the lowest level since 2009, with slight increases in France and Italy, but a decrease in Germany.

images.alt_text: Eurozone inflation rose closer to the European Central Bank's two per cent target in August confirming a tentative economic recovery in Europe, official EU figures showed Thursday.

site_title: South Korea's SK Innovation starts production of batteries with more nickel
summary: South Korea's SK Innovation has begun commercial production of lithium-ion batteries with a higher nickel content, aiming to reduce costs and extend battery life. The company has reduced the use of expensive cobalt, following rising prices. Typically, lithium-ion batteries use a 60:20:20 ratio of nickel, manganese, and cobalt. SK Innovation's new batteries feature a higher nickel proportion, a move sought by Asian battery makers to develop more cost-effective electric car batteries.

site_title: Six big banks join blockchain digital cash settlement project
summary: Six major banks, including Barclays, Credit Suisse, and HSBC, have joined a blockchain-based digital cash settlement project led by UBS. The project aims to launch a "utility settlement coin" (USC) by late 2018, which would allow for fast and secure transactions via blockchain technology. The USC is backed by central bank cash assets and convertible at parity with major currencies. This move aims to make payments faster, more reliable, and easier to audit, with no need for third-party verification. The system is expected to launch in late 2018.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish higher as North Korean worries recede
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% over the four-day period, rebounding from a 12-point loss on Tuesday due to North Korea's missile test. The Straits Times Index recovered its losses, closing at 3,277.26. Thursday's rally was driven by a 0.4% increase, despite ongoing geopolitical concerns. The market reacted negatively to Yanzijiang Shipbuilding's private placement announcement, but overall investor sentiment remained positive.

site_title: German unemployment falls as nation braces for general elections
summary: German unemployment fell by 5,000 to 2.532 million in August, the lowest level since reunification, with the jobless rate remaining at 5.7%. Chancellor Angela Merkel's record of falling unemployment and stable growth has helped her maintain a double-digit lead in the upcoming general elections. The German economy continued its expansion in the second quarter, with rising employment encouraging private consumption.

images.alt_text: German unemployment extended its decline in August, underpinning a robust upswing in Europe's largest economy less then four weeks before general elections.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end down on profit-taking
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.44% on Thursday, led by profit-taking, despite a positive lead from Wall Street and US economic results. The Hang Seng Index closed at 27,970.30, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.08%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.31%. The losses came after a strong start to the week, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's next move.

site_title: Singapore is second biggest Asian investor in offshore real estate, after China
summary: Singapore was the second-largest Asian investor in offshore real estate in the first half of 2017, with US$6.8 billion invested globally, up 20% from the previous year. This followed China's lead as the largest Asian investor. The increase in investment is attributed to Singapore-based institutional investors, property companies, and private equity firms.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Thursday, following gains in Tokyo and on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.2%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index rose 0.8% and Paris' CAC 40 index rose 0.5%. However, French supermarket group Carrefour's share price slumped 12% after publishing disappointing results and warning of a drop in earnings.

site_title: BAT restructures as e-cigarettes go mainstream
summary: British American Tobacco restructured its regional management structure to integrate its vaping and heated tobacco products into the main business following the acquisition of Reynolds American. The company aims to double its sales of vaping products in countries this year and next, and plans to simplify its regional management structure into three main regions. This move is part of its strategy to tap into the growing e-cigarette market and challenge rivals like Philip Morris International.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge down, autos weaken
summary: South Korean shares closed down 0.3% at 2,363.19 points on Thursday, driven by foreign investors taking profits, particularly in the transport equipment sector. Kia Motors' shares fell 3.5% after a court ruling in a labour dispute, while Hyundai Motor and Hyundai Mobis dropped 1.8% and 3.5%, respectively. Offshore investors sold 112.6 billion won worth of Kospi shares, contributing to the market's decline. The South Korean won also weakened 0.3% against the US dollar, closing at 1,127.8 to the dollar.

site_title: Troubled Nam Cheong to convene second informal meeting with noteholders on Sept 7
summary: Troubled shipbuilder Nam Cheong will convene a second informal meeting with noteholders on September 7, 2017, to provide updates on its restructuring options. The meeting will be facilitated by the Securities Investor Association Singapore, allowing noteholders to ask questions about the restructuring. This comes after Nam Cheong announced it would not make coupon and principal payments due on certain notes, consistent with its debt standstill. The company has formed an informal steering committee to represent noteholder views.

site_title: LG packs image, audio features into new flagship phone
summary: LG Electronics introduced the LG V30, a slimmer and lighter flagship phone with advanced camera and audio features, including a 13MP wide-angle front camera and 16MP rear camera with an f/1.6 glass lens. The phone offers a cinematic mode for making movie-quality videos and is equipped with Google Assistant and Voice Recognition. Pricing and availability details were not disclosed, but the phone is set to be released in South Korea on September 21, followed by targeted markets in North America, Asia, Europe, Africa, and the Middle East.

site_title: Motorcycling: MotoGP to make Thai debut in October 2018
summary: MotoGP to make its Thai debut in October 2018, with the Buriram provincial city hosting the three-year event. The Sports Authority of Thailand (SAT) signed a deal with Dorna Sports to hold the race, with winter testing set for February 16-18. The event is expected to bring significant investment to Buriram, a previously impoverished province, with the Thai junta subsidizing a portion of the event's costs. Newin Chidchob, a local politician, has played a key role in securing the deal and developing sports facilities in Buriram.

site_title: Taiwan passes special budget for infrastructure stimulus plan
summary: Taiwan's parliament passed a special budget of NT$107 billion for an infrastructure development plan, cutting the original proposal by 1.7% to address concerns about the country's export-driven economy. The plan aims to boost domestic demand and rebalance the economy. Taiwan's economy is showing signs of recovery, with the government raising its growth forecast for 2017 and predicting further gains in 2018. The domestic infrastructure development bill was passed after a four-day debate between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang Party.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on Wall Street gains, weak yen
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.72% on Thursday, tracking US stock gains, as the yen's weakness provided additional support. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 19,646.24, while the Topix index increased to 1,617.41. The US economic figures boosted confidence, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia shares end higher on boost from China PMI; NZ up for 8th month
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Thursday, driven by a survey showing robust Chinese factory activity and a boost to the mining sector. Metal prices gained, lifting the S&P/ASX 200 index to a three-year high, while the metal and mining index surged 1.06%. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose for the eighth straight month, driven by gains in the utilities, healthcare, and industrial sectors. Global miner BHP Billiton jumped 1.7%, while shares of Australia and New Zealand Banking Group rose 1.2%.

site_title: Yuan dips, but set for best month since China took it off peg in 2005
summary: China's yuan weakened slightly on Thursday, reversing a 0.8% gain from the previous day, after the US dollar rebounded following strong economic data. The yuan has gained 2% this month, on track for its best month since July 2005 when it was revalued and taken off a fixed US dollar peg. The People's Bank of China raised its official yuan midpoint to 6.6010 per US dollar, its strongest since June 24, 2016.

site_title: Frankfurt luxury flat prices rise on hopes of Brexit banking bonanza
summary: Luxury flat prices in Frankfurt have surged 25% in the past year, reaching up to €1 million (S$1.62 million) for a two-bedroom flat, driven by hopes of London bankers relocating to the city post-Brexit. The influx of high-end finance professionals is expected to boost demand and prices in the city, making Frankfurt one of Germany's most expensive.

site_title: Family-owned Indian drug factories erode US generic prices
summary: Family-owned Indian drug manufacturers are significantly impacting US generic prices, with some companies slashing dividends and profit targets. The FDA is approving new generic drug applications at a record pace, favoring products with few competitors. India's 6,000 drugmakers are intensifying competition, with 32 Indian firms receiving US approvals to sell new generics in the first half of this year. The US is seeing a 8% decline in generic drug prices, with wholesalers citing generic pricing as a reason for shrinking margins. Indian companies are offering deep discounts to gain market share, forcing incumbent players to match them.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang, Sembcorp, Cosco, Sincap
summary: Chinese shipbuilder Yangzijiang Shipbuilding plans to raise S$208.8 million by issuing 137 million new shares for funding new investments and business expansion. Sembcorp Industries acquired a stake in Sembcorp Green Infra for S$301 million. Cosco Shipping International's minority shareholders approved a S$300.3 million divestment of its loss-making yard operations. Sincap Group plans a placement of up to 450.25 million new shares to raise about S$8 million.

site_title: Gold inches lower as US dollar gains on strong US economic data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.4% to $1,302.84 per ounce, despite holding above $1,300 due to safe haven demand amid North Korea tensions. The US dollar gained on positive US economic data, including a 3.0% annualized GDP increase and 237,000 jobs added in August. Investors shifted to riskier assets, with Asian shares rising. Gold is on track for a monthly gain of over 2%.

site_title: Thai private consumption, investment up m-o-m in July
summary: Thailand's private consumption and private investment rose in July, with the private consumption index increasing 0.7% and the private investment index rising 0.9%. The Bank of Thailand reported a US$2.77 billion current account surplus and an 8% rise in exports, boosting the economy. The central bank forecasts 3.5% economic growth this year, with exports expected to rise 5%. This recovery in exports is a positive sign for Thailand, which has lagged its regional peers in growth.

images.alt_text: Thailand's private consumption and private investment rose from the previous month, central bank indexes showed on Thursday, indicating economic recovery is gaining more traction.

site_title: Blackmores cuts reliance on China's daigou grey market
summary: Blackmores Ltd, an Australian vitamin maker, is shifting its focus away from China's daigou grey market, where personal shoppers sell imported products to consumers. The company now generates half of its mainland revenue directly, thanks to a China export unit. This move comes after the company's shares lost half their value since 2016 due to China's tightened scrutiny of imported supplements. Blackmores' stock rose 19% after releasing its results, with analysts attributing the turnaround to the Asian growth story.

images.alt_text: Australia's Blackmores Ltd, which has relied on the Chinese personal shoppers known as daigou for access to consumers in Asia's largest economy, is breaking free.

site_title: Australia shipwreck tale clue to French explorer disappearance
summary: An Indian seaman's account of being shipwrecked on a remote Australian island may hold clues to the 230-year-old disappearance of French explorer Jean-Francois de La Perouse in 1785. La Perouse was on a mission to chart the globe and map unexplored lands when his ship was wrecked off the coast of New Holland, then New South Wales. The seaman's tale could provide new insights into the explorer's fate, one of maritime history's greatest mysteries.

site_title: AstraZeneca sought to buy Japan's Daiichi Sankyo last year
summary: AstraZeneca reportedly offered to buy Japan's Daiichi Sankyo in 2017, but the Japanese drugmaker declined the offer. AstraZeneca may have targeted Daiichi Sankyo for its expertise in antibody drug conjugates. The deal, if accepted, would have been valued at around $16 billion. The news led to a 13% surge in Daiichi Sankyo's share price and triggered a trade suspension. The offer was made amid AstraZeneca's efforts to revive its fortunes following patent expirations on its biggest products, with the company relying on cancer treatment to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Britain's AstraZeneca offered to buy peer Daiichi Sankyo last year, a business magazine reported on Thursday, sending the Japanese drugmaker's share price soaring as much as 13 per cent and triggering a trade suspension.

site_title: Alan Chan reappointed LTA chairman; six new names join board
summary: COORDINATING Minister Khaw Boon Wan appointed 14 persons to the Land Transport Authority (LTA) board, effective September 1, 2017. Alan Chan remains as LTA chairman, and Richard Lim as deputy chairman. Six new board members join, replacing six stepping down members.

site_title: UBS is said to be leaning towards Frankfurt for EU trading hub
summary: UBS is considering Frankfurt as its EU trading hub after Brexit, with the potential to move 250 jobs from London to Frankfurt and other European locations. The Swiss firm has notified the German regulator of its plans and has discussed creating multiple hubs across the EU. Frankfurt has emerged as a key location for investment banking jobs, with Standard Chartered, Morgan Stanley, and Nomura Holdings also expanding their presence in the city. A decision has not been made, but UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti has stated that Frankfurt is a "location of choice."

site_title: Bank of Korea stands pat as household debt, North Korea eyed
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, kept its key interest rate at a record low of 1.25% despite concerns over household debt, which accounts for over 90% of the country's GDP. Governor Lee Ju-Yeol declined to provide guidance on future policy, but hinted that the bank may raise rates to contain debt. Analysts predict the bank will tighten policy next year, while the government plans to unveil measures to manage household debt and curb speculation.

site_title: Gasoline hits US$2/gallon as Harvey wreaks havoc on refiners, crude stable
summary: Gasoline prices in the US reached $2/gallon for the first time since 2015 due to flooding from Hurricane Harvey, which shut down nearly a quarter of US refineries. Crude prices stabilized after a sharp decline the previous day. The closure of refineries has resulted in a slump in demand for oil, leading to a $5.39 million barrel drop in US commercial crude oil stocks. Analysts estimate it could take several months to bring all production back online, with potential economic losses from Harvey estimated at $100 billion.

site_title: Trump needs rethink on China, ex-North Korea negotiators say
summary: Former US negotiators on North Korea say US President Donald Trump needs to rethink his approach to China, which has historically supported North Korea. The US and its allies have condemned North Korea's provocations, but leaders are urging China to use its economic leverage to pressure the regime. China has been reluctant to risk North Korea's downfall by cutting off food and fuel sales, but wants the rogue state to stop its provocations. Experts say a comprehensive approach is needed to engage China, rather than just pressuring it to solve the problem.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won tentative before domestic, US data; North Korea worries linger
summary: South Korean shares and the won remained steady early Thursday, despite US stocks rebounding, as investors remained cautious about North Korean risks and awaited domestic and US economic data. The Bank of Korea is expected to hold its benchmark rate at 1.25%, and investors are watching South Korea's trade data and the US jobs report. Industrial output rose in July, driven by new car production, while Samsung shares rose on expectations of rising refining margins. Foreign investors were net sellers, and Kia Motor shares slumped after a court ruling ordered the company to pay unpaid wages.

site_title: Hong Kong's record-breaking home prices grow at slowest pace in 16 months
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices reached a record high in July, increasing 0.09% from June, marking the weakest growth pace in 16 months. The index rose 19.6% from last year, with nine consecutive months of record highs. This growth is attributed to a strong demand for housing in the city.

site_title: SIA, Alaska Airlines to launch codeshare flights
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Alaska Airlines have signed an agreement to codeshare flights, effective September 27, 2017. The partnership will expand SIA's presence in the North American market, adding its "SQ" designator code to Alaska Airlines-operated flights on 18 US and Mexican destinations. Existing codeshare flights with Virgin America will also be included, and frequent flyer program members will be able to earn miles on both carriers. The codeshare flights will be progressively made available through SIA's booking channels. Regulatory approvals are subject to approval.

site_title: Australia's Harvey Norman profit surges 29% on overseas sales growth
summary: Harvey Norman Holdings Ltd, Australia's largest electronics retailer, reported a 29% surge in annual net profit to A$449 million, driven by sales growth at its overseas businesses and higher property valuations at home. This exceeded analyst forecasts of A$414 million. The company's overseas sales growth contributed significantly to the profit increase, despite higher tariffs and tariffs-related costs.

site_title: British PM says no plans to quit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has denied plans to quit, stating she will lead the Conservative Party into the next general election in 2022. Despite reports of her preparing to step down when the UK leaves the EU in 2019, May told Sky News she is committed to the long term. She emphasized her focus on delivering a brighter future for the UK, including a good Brexit deal and ensuring "global Britain" can trade and address domestic injustices.

site_title: Temasek's Vertex adds Kasikornbank for new venture capital fund
summary: Temasek's venture capital arm, Vertex Ventures, has added Kasikornbank as an investor in its new South-east Asian fund, Vertex Ventures SEA III. This is the first time Vertex has raised money from a Thai investor. The fund, which aims to invest in startups across South-east Asia and India, has already exceeded its target size of $150 million. Vertex plans to allocate 75% of the fund to South-east Asia and 25% to India, following its previous investments in Singapore-based financial technology startups.

site_title: Prudential speeds up sales process with new real-time chatbot
summary: Prudential has launched an industry-first chatbot, askPRU, to improve productivity and customer service. The cognitive-powered chatbot, built on IBM Watson technology, provides real-time data to insurance agents, including policy cash value and claim status. Since its pilot launch in July, over half of Prudential's 4,000 agents have started using the chatbot. The new chatbot complements PRUONE Express, an enhanced digital point-of-sales portal launched earlier in August, allowing agents to respond to customers' queries more promptly.

site_title: Toshiba says three groups vying for prized chip unit
summary: Toshiba has confirmed three groups are vying for its prized chip unit, including a Bain Capital-led consortium and a Foxconn-led group. Western Digital, Toshiba's US-based chip factory partner, has tried to block any sale. The sale is seen as crucial for Toshiba's survival, as the company struggles with multi-billion-dollar losses at its US nuclear power division. Apple has reportedly joined the Bain-led consortium, seeking to maintain a supply of memory chips for its iPhones and iPods. Talks will continue with possible bidders, with a decision expected at the earliest possible date.

site_title: China August official factory PMI rises to 51.7; beats expectations
summary: China's manufacturing sector experienced unexpected growth in August, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 51.7, beating expectations. This marked a reversal from previous months' contraction, with the PMI exceeding the 50-point growth threshold. The unexpected acceleration in growth defies concerns about the impact of rising borrowing costs and regulatory clampdowns on the economy.

site_title: Air China net profit up despite rising fuel costs
summary: Air China reported a 3.3% increase in first-half net profit to 3.92 billion yuan, despite rising jet fuel costs. The airline earned higher revenue from growing Chinese travel demand, but fuel costs surged 40.1% in the first half, eroding revenue gains. This is in line with other Chinese carriers, which have also been affected by the recent fuel price rebound. Air China's shares fell 3.18% in Hong Kong and 1.91% in Shanghai following the announcement.

site_title: AIA Singapore sets up new financial advisory firm to drive growth
summary: AIA Singapore has launched AIA Financial Advisers (AIA FA), a new financial advisory firm aimed at driving growth in the market. Led by Tan Chuan How, a 19-year industry veteran, the firm will offer personalized and quality financial advice to customers. The move comes as several other players, including Manulife and Aviva, have also set up affiliated financial advisory firms to cater to consumers' preferences for choice. The new arm is seen as a strategy to strengthen AIA Singapore's distribution network and empower individuals with financial guidance in the digital age.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong shares declined at the open on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.46% to 27,964.78, due to profit-taking following a recent rally. The Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.06%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.04%. The decline comes despite positive US data and a strong lead from Wall Street.

site_title: Brazil proposes new rules for fintechs, peer-to-peer lending
summary: Brazil's central bank proposes new rules allowing fintechs to lend money without taking deposits, similar to the UK's "sand box" approach. The rules, set to be assessed in public hearings, aim to provide access to banking services without risking the financial system. Fintechs have already facilitated lower interest rates for Brazilian borrowers, and the new framework could enable peer-to-peer lending platforms. The proposal is designed to address the country's high interest rates and emerging fintech industry, which has grown six-fold in the past couple of years.

site_title: Australia shares higher led by financials, materials; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 5708.1, driven by gains in financials and materials sectors. The big four banks, including Commonwealth Bank of Australia, advanced 0.5-1.0%. Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton Ltd also rose 1.7% and 1.9%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.2% to 7,792.38, with gains in healthcare and industrial stocks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, tracking rallies on Wall Street, following rosy US economic figures. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.61% and the Topix index rose 0.60%. The gains followed a strong US market performance, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariffs.

site_title: China Construction Bank profits lifted by economy, debt crackdown
summary: China Construction Bank reported a 3.7% year-on-year profit rise in the first half, earning 138.34 billion yuan. The bank's non-performing loans ratio decreased to 1.51%, thanks to a government crackdown on bad debt. The bank attributed its improved results to the country's stabilizing economic fundamentals and faster-than-expected 6.9% economic growth. The bank's shares dipped 2.14% in Hong Kong and 1.42% in Shanghai, but still benefited from improved sentiment among major Chinese financial institutions.

site_title: How Trump's immigration crackdown could slow flood-hit Houston's efforts to rebuild
summary: Houston's efforts to rebuild after Tropical Storm Harvey may be hindered by an immigration crackdown by the Trump administration, which has cast a wide net and spooked undocumented immigrants. Many construction workers in Texas live in the US illegally, with estimates suggesting 28-50% of the workforce are undocumented. The state's governor has vowed to appeal a federal judge's temporary injunction on a law banning sanctuary city policies, which could further deter migrant workers. The city's construction industry is facing labor shortages, with builders warning that the shortage will worsen and potentially slow down the rebuilding process.

site_title: Modi cash ban a 'total failure' as 99% of banned notes are back
summary: India's cash ban, implemented by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in 2016, has been deemed a "total failure" as 99% of invalidated currency notes have been deposited, denting the central bank's profit. The Reserve Bank of India received 15.28 trillion rupees, or 99% of the banned notes, and the government's annual dividend payout was cut in half. The move is seen as a blow to Modi's efforts to unearth unaccounted wealth and has slowed economic growth, with economists blaming the government for the slowdown.

site_title: Houston airports reopen as Harvey moves out
summary: Houston's two major airports, George Bush Intercontinental and Hobby, reopened on a limited basis after floodwaters receded and skies cleared following Hurricane Harvey's passage. Runways and roads were cleared for operations to resume at 4pm, with domestic flights expected to resume first. Thousands of flights were cancelled or delayed due to Harvey, but most stranded passengers were evacuated to connecting flights in Dallas, Chicago, or Detroit. The airport reopens signal a step towards normalcy and a call to airlines to resume service, with Southwest Airlines planning to resume flights on Saturday.

site_title: Singapore July bank lending falls 0.5% m-o-m
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in July fell 0.5% from June to S$632.6 billion, primarily due to a decline in business loans. Bank lending rose 5.9% from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Singapore's total bank lending in July fell 0.5 per cent from June, due to a decline in loans to businesses, data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) showed on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.6% up on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.6% higher on Thursday, rising 18.89 points to 3,284.15, driven by US stocks' stronger-than-expected economic growth of 3% and rising overnight. This followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: France seeks 600m euros in taxes from Microsoft: report
summary: France's tax authority is seeking 600 million euros from Microsoft's local subsidiary for billing French customers from Ireland. Despite Microsoft's significant presence in France, the company paid only 32.2 million euros in corporate tax there last year. This is the second-largest amount France has sought from a high-tech multinational, following a 1.1 billion euro case against Google. The French government, led by President Emmanuel Macron, has campaigned on requiring internet firms to pay taxes on business conducted in the country.

site_title: Sembcorp to fully own India renewable energy business Sembcorp Green Infra
summary: Sembcorp Industries announced the acquisition of IDFC's remaining stake in Sembcorp Green Infra (SGI) for 14.1 billion rupees, becoming the sole owner of the Indian renewable energy player. The deal, valued at about S$301 million, is expected to be completed in Q1 2018 and will allow Sembcorp to drive SGI's growth. SGI's net asset value and net profit were S$427.6 million and S$39 million, respectively, as of end-2016. The acquisition is part of Sembcorp's commitment to a long-term presence in India's renewable energy sector.

site_title: Over 2m Muslims begin hajj spiritual journey
summary: Over 2 million Muslims from around the world began the hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia, a spiritual journey considered a duty for all able Muslims. This year's pilgrimage marks the return of Iranian pilgrims after a hiatus and comes amid a diplomatic crisis between Saudi Arabia and Qatar. Tens of thousands of air-conditioned tents have been set up in Mina to house pilgrims, and Saudi authorities have mobilized over 100,000 security personnel to ensure safety. The pilgrimage is part of Saudi Arabia's "Vision 2030" plan to boost the economy through religious tourism.

site_title: Harvey to cost Texas US$58b in losses: report
summary: Hurricane Harvey is estimated to have caused US$58 billion in economic losses in Texas, making it the world's 9th most expensive natural disaster since 1900. The damage is primarily due to flooding, with 90% of the estimated losses attributed to this factor. Estimates vary, with other organizations putting the total at US$3 billion, US$10-20 billion, or above US$30 billion. The disaster risk specialists used data from the US Bureau of Economic Analysis and building and replacement cost data to calculate the losses, which are based on the world's largest database of natural catastrophes.

site_title: Noble Group seen picking oil unit buyer in Sept: sources
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-listed commodities trader, is expected to sell its oil and liquefied natural gas (LNG) units by mid-September to cover debts and reduce credit exposure. The firm has lost US$1.9 billion in the first half of 2017 and is facing a US$2 billion credit facility expiration in October. Interested parties include rival trading firms Mercuria Group, Vitol Group, and Castleton Commodities International. The sale includes Noble's LNG business, which delivered 2 million tonnes of LNG in 2015.

site_title: Southern hospitality shines through Hurricane Harvey
summary: In the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, Texas residents have demonstrated "southern hospitality" by coming together to help those affected by the record floods. Neighbors have opened their homes to stranded strangers, and many have volunteered their time and resources to aid emergency services. Locals have also risked their own lives to rescue those trapped in their homes, including babies and elderly individuals. The community's can-do spirit and sense of duty have been on full display as they work together to support those in need.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Thursday for holiday
summary: Malaysia's stock markets were closed on Thursday due to the country's national day. In contrast, Singapore's markets continued their 5-day rally ahead of the release of GDP data. Meanwhile, in Asia, traders seemed to brush off new Trump threats, and US stocks edged towards fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion, and the STI rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks bounce back as strong earnings in focus
summary: European stocks rebounded on Wednesday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 gaining 0.7% after a day of selling sparked by North Korea's missile launch. Banking stocks rose 0.4%, while mining companies gained 1.7%, leading sectoral gains. Earnings news drove the rally, with shares in Biomerieux, RTL, and Baloise jumping after positive forecasts and revenue reports. Broker upgrades also spurred gains, including a 4.3% rise for Ocado. The market's focus shifted away from geopolitical concerns and toward encouraging earnings growth, with Thomson Reuters estimating a 16% year-on-year increase in earnings for the second quarter.

site_title: New Uber chief sees IPO in its future: report
summary: Uber's newly appointed CEO Dara Khosrowshahi hinted at a possible initial public offering (IPO) for the company, stating that it could happen in 18 to 36 months. Khosrowshahi, who replaced co-founder Travis Kalanick, shared his vision to steer the ride-sharing service away from controversies and expressed his willingness to advocate for women's leadership opportunities. The company's valuation is estimated at $68 billion, and Khosrowshahi will face challenges in navigating conflicts with regulators and investors.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon David Tang dies at 63
summary: Hong Kong businessman and socialite David Tang, founder of Shanghai Tang, has died at 63. Tang, known for his high-end fashion brand and China Tang restaurant, recently hosted a farewell party in London after being told he had a month to live. Born in Hong Kong and educated in Britain, Tang was a prominent figure in Hong Kong's business and social circles, known for his witty humor and outspoken views on politics and social issues.

site_title: Trump vows to right 'self-destructive' tax code
summary: President Donald Trump vowed to reform the US tax code, calling it "self-destructive" and citing job losses and trillions of dollars in costs. He proposed a 15% corporate tax rate, aiming to boost the economy further. Trump argued that the current tax code disadvantages ordinary Americans and benefits special interests. However, details on the proposed reforms remain unclear, and the White House's goal to adopt tax reform by the end of the year is considered ambitious.

site_title: Workers strike at VW plant in Portugal
summary: Volkswagen's Autoeuropa plant in Portugal has been paralyzed due to a 24-hour strike by workers over a planned Saturday shift to produce a new compact SUV model. The strike, involving over 3,500 employees, is the first at the facility in its 20-year operation. The shift change is aimed at meeting production demands for the T-Roc SUV, set to be in dealerships by early 2018. The strike highlights concerns over working conditions and the impact of the shift on employees' personal lives.

site_title: Airline profits may drop as Harvey threatens to cripple Labor Day holiday travel
summary: Tropical storm Harvey has caused thousands of flight cancellations in Houston and surrounding areas, potentially crippling Labor Day holiday travel and impacting airline profits. The storm has dumped several feet of rain, forcing the closure of three airports. Delta Air Lines recently offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand, but the disruptions caused by Harvey may still affect airline profits.

site_title: Drones, planes banned in area hit by Harvey to avert risks to rescue work
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has banned hobbyist drones and civilian aircraft from flying in the area affected by Tropical Storm Harvey in Texas due to concerns about potential interference with rescue efforts. The ban, effective across hundreds of square miles around greater Houston, allows exceptions for search and rescue teams, the military, and law enforcement. The move comes after concerns were raised about the potential for drones to pose a hazard to rescue crews operating in crowded skies.

site_title: Macron promises 'ambitious' labour reforms
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has promised "ambitious" labour market reforms, aiming to reduce unemployment and liberalize France's rigid labour laws. The reforms, set to be announced by Prime Minister Edouard Philippe, will give employers more flexibility to negotiate pay and conditions with workers. Macron faces criticism and mass protests, but vows to push on with the overhaul to drive growth and bring down unemployment, currently at 9.5%. The reforms are part of Macron's plans to transform the economy and are expected to be unveiled on the eve of the planned nationwide strikes and protests on September 12.

site_title: China's wealth managers look to profit from risk and capital crackdowns
summary: China's private wealth managers are capitalizing on the country's regulatory crackdowns and capital outflows to tap into the growing wealth market. Wealth managers like Noah Holdings and China Merchants Bank are targeting affluent clients in smaller cities, where high-net-worth individuals traditionally relied on shadow banking products. This move aims to increase their share of the growing onshore private wealth market, which is expected to reach $28 trillion by the end of the year. Despite concerns about risk management and due diligence, wealth managers see this as a significant business opportunity.

site_title: Yangzijiang to raise S$208.8m via share placement to fund new investments
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding plans to raise S$208.8 million by issuing 137 million new shares at S$1.53 each to institutional investors. The placement represents 3.6% of existing and 3.5% of enlarged share capital. The company aims to use up to 50% of the net proceeds for new investments and business expansion, while the remainder will be used for working capital and general corporate purposes.

site_title: Gilead purchase of novel cancer treatment raises cost issues again
summary: Gilead Sciences has acquired Kite Pharma, raising concerns about the high cost of a novel cancer treatment. The treatment, which uses CAR-T therapy, could cost around $500,000 per patient, making it a potential replay of the Sovaldi scandal. Gilead's CEO, John Milligan, declined to set a price, citing research from Kite's team. Insurers, including Aetna, will review the treatment after FDA approval, and some analysts predict the price will be high due to the complex manufacturing process and potential for failed batches.

site_title: STI rebounds as Dow stages surprise rise
summary: The Straits Times Index rebounded 15.92 points to 3,265.26 on Wednesday, driven by Wall Street's unexpected rise and easing tensions surrounding North Korea's missile test. Banks, Singtel, and Wilmar led the gains, while Golden Agri Resources and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding also saw significant increases. Analysts attributed the rebound to a cyclical recovery in the banking sector, margin expansion, and strong nominal GDP growth in the region.

site_title: Job Space
summary: BT launches a Telegram channel for daily updates and weekend content. Thevar 2.0 showcases mod-Indian cuisine, while NCSS rallies partners to better engage volunteers. The Social Kitchen sets up at Bank of Singapore, and CMC Markets partners with Sophia Women to drive financial literacy for women. BT also explores the concept of corporate purpose, which aims to define a company's social and environmental goals beyond profit.

site_title: Artificial intelligence takes spotlight at Berlin's IFA fair
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is taking center stage at the Berlin IFA fair, where gadgets and devices are becoming smarter and more intuitive. Smart home devices, voice-controlled speakers, and personal assistants like Huawei's new AI-powered assistant are expected to make daily life easier. TV manufacturers are also showcasing high-definition screens and smart TVs that respond to voice commands. The "Internet of things" is becoming a reality, with devices like smart fridges and rubbish bins that can help with daily tasks, and TV sales are predicted to increase due to the latest technologies becoming more affordable.

site_title: Nissan brings a tiny bit of self-driving to the masses
summary: Nissan unveiled its ProPilot Assist system, a semi-autonomous driving feature, in its 2018 Leaf electric vehicle. The system allows the car to steer and brake on its own, but only up to a certain level of aggressiveness, and requires clear lane markers for optimal performance. It's designed to reduce driver fatigue, particularly in congested city traffic. While it's not a full self-driving system, ProPilot Assist represents a step towards autonomous capabilities in more affordable vehicles, with Nissan aiming to make it accessible to a wider audience.

site_title: M&S to transfer HK, Macau stores to franchise partner
summary: MARKS & Spencer (M&S) has initiated talks to sell its wholly owned Hong Kong and Macau stores to franchise partner Al-Futtaim. The move follows a strategic review by M&S last November, which aimed to shut over 80 stores and explore joint ventures and franchise partnerships. The Hong Kong and Macau stores will continue to operate under the M&S franchise, with Al-Futtaim expected to take over the stores after several months of negotiations.

site_title: Harvey storm death toll reaches 33
summary: The death toll from the Harvey storm in Texas has risen to 33, with 10 confirmed deaths and 23 additional deaths potentially related to the storm. The storm's record-breaking rainfall caused widespread flooding in Houston and surrounding communities, with some areas receiving up to 132 centimeters of rain. As floodwaters recede, officials fear the death toll could rise further, with the full extent of the damage and loss of life still being assessed.

site_title: Thumping vote for Cosco's 1.46b yuan yard divestment
summary: Cosco Shipping International (S) Co has received overwhelming approval from minority shareholders for the divestment of its loss-making yard operations. At an EGM, 98.42% of votes representing over 162.8 million shares were cast in favor of the 1.46 billion yuan (S$300.3 million) divestment to Cosco Shipping Heavy Industry (CSHI). The approval paves the way for the divestment to be completed later this year, subject to regulatory approvals, allowing Cosco to exit a business that has sustained substantial losses for the last two financial years.

site_title: IPO aspirant Deskera to help SMEs transact more digitally
summary: Deskera, a smart cloud-based business management software specialist, aims to reach S$100m in revenue by 2018. The company, which drew in S$42m in revenue in FY2016, is targeting an IPO on the Singapore Exchange. Deskera plans to aid SMEs in digital transactions through the National Trade Platform (NTP), a nationalised marketplace. The company has partnered with Alibaba Cloud and is working with major banks to ease payments challenges for SMEs. With 100,000 users, Deskera is poised to become a key player in Singapore's Smart Nation initiative.

images.alt_text: Deskera wants to grow in size before an IPO. "We look at IPO as a destination," says CEO Shashank Dixit.

site_title: First cancer gene therapy gets US go-ahead
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved the first gene therapy against cancer, Kymriah (tisagenlecleucel), a personalized treatment for children and young adults with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL). The treatment, developed by Novartis, uses a patient's own immune cells to fight cancer, with an 83% success rate in studies. The treatment costs $475,000 per dose, but most patients will likely be covered by insurance. The approval marks a new era in the fight against cancer, with many questions remaining about the long-term effectiveness of this novel treatment.

site_title: Bird group keen to bid for Air India's ground services unit
summary: BIRD Group, an Indian aviation and hospitality company, is interested in bidding for Air India's ground handling division, which is part of the government's plan to privatize the state-owned flag carrier. The government is considering selling the division separately or as part of Air India, with IndiGo, India's largest airline, also expressing interest in buying the overseas operations. A decision on Air India's sale will be made after completing due process, with Finance Minister Arun Jaitley stating that the process needs to be done "expeditiously".

site_title: Maybank Q2 profit soars as loan provisions fall
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest bank, reported a 43% increase in net profit for the second quarter, reaching 1.66 billion ringgit (S$527.2 million). The result was driven by lower loan-loss provisions, down from RM982 million in the same period last year to RM830.3 million. Net interest income rose 10% to RM3.04 billion. Maybank expects 2017 earnings to be "satisfactory" and targets a return on equity of 10-11%. The bank aims for loan growth in line with the industry, following a challenging 2016.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KITCHEN Culture Holdings reported a net loss of S$6.4 million for its financial period ended June 30, 2017, despite an 86.4% revenue increase to S$49.6 million. Oxley Holdings' subsidiary redeveloped a 99-year-leasehold property, while TTJ Holdings terminated a deal to manage a foreign construction workers' dormitory due to unexpected complexity. Sincap Holdings plans a S$8 million placement to raise funds for current businesses and working capital.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sing Holdings' private residential project at Fernvale Road is expected to launch in the next two quarters, potentially selling well given recent property market trends. The company's revalued net asset value is estimated to be S$0.77, leading to a "buy" recommendation with a fair value of S$0.54. OCBC Investment Research upgraded Sing Holdings from a "hold" to a "buy" after extending the land lease for Java Supermall units, increasing the fair value to S$0.455.

site_title: Asia a transaction banking goldmine for StanChart
summary: Standard Chartered Bank's transaction banking business has seen strong growth, with revenues increasing double digits in the first half of 2017, driven by the booming economies of Asia. The bank has added new clients, including the German insurer Allianz, which expects business in Asia to more than double by 2020. Asia now contributes to the third-largest revenue stream for StanChart, after Germany and the US. The bank's transaction banking business is also becoming more profitable, with a focus on advisory work and less financing, amid keen competition.

site_title: Theresa May to try to allay Japan's fears on trade with UK post-Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May arrived in Japan to reassure businesses about the UK's post-Brexit trade prospects, acknowledging uncertainty over the UK's future relationship with Japan. May aims to replicate trade deals the EU has with countries outside the bloc and is pressing for an EU-Japan trade deal to be used as a model for a future British-Japan agreement. Her visit comes as the UK's Brexit negotiations are ongoing and the UK's future attraction as an investment base is uncertain.

site_title: US dollar gains on bets ECB could weaken euro, strong US data
summary: The US dollar rose on Wednesday due to speculation that the European Central Bank may weaken the euro. The euro dropped 0.7% against the US dollar, its largest daily percentage drop in nearly four weeks, after strong US economic data boosted expectations for a solid US jobs report. Analysts believe ECB President Mario Draghi may be concerned about the euro's rise, despite making no mention of it at a recent central bank gathering. The euro last traded at US$1.1890.

site_title: Toyota unit invests in Grab to power big data push
summary: Grab and a Toyota unit have partnered to share driving data to improve car services for Grab drivers. The collaboration aims to provide access to connected car services, including insurance, financing, and vehicle maintenance. Toyota will analyze driving data to offer personalized services to Grab drivers, enhancing their experience. This move is a strategic step for Toyota to expand its presence in the Southeast Asian market, where Grab operates. The partnership will also help Grab improve its services for drivers, setting a new standard for ride-sharing platforms in the region.

site_title: US growth revision drives Wall Street higher
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday after a revised 3% annual growth rate in the second quarter, driven by robust consumer spending and strong business investment. The positive sentiment was also boosted by a 237,000 jobs added in August, the largest monthly increase in five months. Despite concerns over North Korea and Hurricane Harvey, investors remained optimistic, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: ETF giants turn sights from US fee war to Europe's cash trove
summary: US-based ETF giants, including BlackRock, Invesco, and Eaton Vance, are shifting their focus to Europe's lucrative pension savings market, seeking to gain ground on domestic managers who charge higher fees. The European ETF market is expected to grow to $1.1 trillion by 2020, driven by indexing gains and a surge in exchange-traded fund issuance. Firms are adapting to revised MiFID regulations and navigating the uncertainty of the UK's exit from the EU. With fees under pressure, providers of low-cost funds like ETFs are poised to win market share, offering investors a range of investment choices.

site_title: Diana's legacy continues to be a mixed one for royal family
summary: The legacy of Princess Diana remains a mixed one for the British royal family, 20 years after her death. A YouGov poll found that only a third of the UK public believes the royal family has shown sufficient respect to her memory, with Prince Charles facing criticism for his popularity ratings. The poll also showed that the Queen's approval ratings have largely recovered from the 1990s, but significant uncertainties remain about the post-Queen Elizabeth II period, particularly with Prince Charles set to inherit the throne.

site_title: 'Relax': Nobel Laureate's advice to Singaporeans anxious about jobs
summary: Nobel Laureates Michael Spence, Robert Merton, Roger Myerson, and Peter Diamond visited Singapore, addressing concerns about job losses due to technological disruption. The group believes Singapore remains relevant, citing its size, openness, and education system, which will equip its next generation with survival skills. They emphasize that AI complements human jobs, not replaces them, and that Singapore's flexibility and adaptability will help it navigate uncertainty. The Nobel Laureates advise Singaporeans to "relax" and focus on education, while governments worldwide must consider pension systems and safety nets for displaced workers.

site_title: China's 14.1t yuan of shadow lending in rust belt poses contagion risks
summary: China's shadow lending in rust-belt provinces has raised contagion risks, with smaller regional banks using informal lending to hide bad loans and circumvent lending restrictions. A UBS study found that shadow loans grew 15% to 14.1 trillion yuan in 2017, equal to 19% of economic output. Analyst Jason Bedford estimates that Chinese banks' non-performing loans could be three times higher than officially published levels. Authorities have renewed their campaign against financial leverage, and banks with high shadow loan exposure are most vulnerable to drastic regulatory changes.

site_title: Hurricane Harvey wreaks havoc on US petrol supply and prices
summary: Hurricane Harvey has severely impacted the US fuel distribution network, causing at least 3.6 million barrels per day of refining capacity to go offline. The storm's relentless flooding on the Gulf Coast, particularly in Texas and Louisiana, has led to refinery closures and dwindling supplies. This disruption is starting to be felt at the pump, affecting US drivers' wallets.

site_title: Google, Apple face off over augmented reality technology
summary: Google has unveiled ARCore, a tool to create augmented reality apps for mobile devices using the Android operating system, setting up a showdown with Apple's ARKit technology. The tool will be available on Samsung Galaxy S8 and Pixel phones, with Google aiming for 100 million users. Apple, meanwhile, plans to release ARKit this fall on "hundreds of millions" of devices. The competition is seen as a key development in the growing field of augmented reality, with potential applications in eyeglasses, car windshields, and other surfaces.

site_title: More than 1,000 die in South Asian floods; toll climbing
summary: More than 1,000 people have died in South Asian floods, with the death toll climbing. The floods, caused by monsoon rains, have affected at least 41 million people in Bangladesh, India, and Nepal. The United Nations warns that the death toll will rise with the floodwaters. The floods are part of a larger natural disaster affecting the region, which is usually hit by monsoon rains from June to September.

site_title: No licence renewal for 2 bunker suppliers following breaches
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has announced that it will not renew the bunker supplier licences of Panoil Petroleum Pte Ltd and Universal Energy Pte Ltd, effective August 31, 2017, due to breaches. As a result, these two bunker suppliers will be forced to stop operating at the Port of Singapore.

site_title: US economy beats expectations with second-quarter growth of 3%
summary: The US economy experienced its fastest growth in over two years, with a 3% increase in the second quarter, beating initial estimates. Higher consumer spending and business investment contributed to the growth, surpassing analyst expectations of 2.7%. Despite this, the first half of the year saw a 2.1% growth rate, below the 2.2% average of the last three years. The strong growth may relieve pressure on the Federal Reserve, which has been divided over monetary policy, but the Trump administration's growth agenda remains stalled in Congress.

site_title: Hiring in South-east Asia finance sector stays cautious
summary: The finance sector in South-east Asia, particularly in Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines, has reported a cautious hiring outlook, with slow recruitment growth rates. Singapore saw a 9% year-on-year increase in online hiring activity in the BFSI sector, while Malaysia and the Philippines reported 6% and 4% growth, respectively. Demand for Finance and Accounts roles declined in Singapore, while Engineering and Production roles saw the highest year-on-year growth. Experts attribute the cautious hiring to the need for talent with strong data comprehension and commercial acumen in a rapidly changing market.

site_title: Elon Musk's battery demand boom lifts Japan supplier Tanaka
summary: Tanaka Chemical Corp, a Japanese battery materials supplier, is increasing output to meet surging demand for cathode materials in electric vehicles. The company plans to invest 500 million yen (S$6.21 million) to boost output capacity by 1,000 tonnes a year, driven by Elon Musk's push for electric vehicles. This investment follows a 93% share price rise for Tanaka since the beginning of the year, as the company aims to boost sales to 16,000 tonnes for lithium-ion and nickel metal hydride batteries.

site_title: Brexit delays endanger UK's fresh food supply, retailers warn
summary: The UK's fresh food supply could be severely impacted if it leaves the EU without a deal, with inbound shipments of goods requiring checks potentially quadrupling to 255 million per year. Retailers warn of delays and increased costs, particularly for perishable foods like Spanish oranges and Irish beef. The British Retail Consortium calls for investment in roads and ports to prevent delays, and a system that minimizes checks on goods. Without a frictionless customs arrangement, retailers fear huge delays and costs, and upward pressure on prices.

site_title: Cityneon owns Jurassic World exhibition
summary: Cityneon Holdings has acquired the global rights to Jurassic World Exhibition for US$25 million, acquiring full ownership of JP Exhibitions LLC. The exhibition, inspired by the Jurassic Park franchise, brings dinosaurs to life through life-size animatronics and computer-generated imagery. The acquisition is Cityneon's third IP acquisition, following Disney's Marvel Avengers S.T.A.T.I.O.N. and Hasbro's Transformers Autobot Alliance. The company plans to expand the exhibition to more markets in Asia and the world, with a second immersive experience set to be constructed immediately.

images.alt_text: Jurassic World: The Exhibition is a licensed spin-off from the blockbuster movie Jurassic World (above), and it brings dinosaurs to life through life-size animatronic and computer-generated imagery (CGI) effects.

site_title: Trump surveys devastated Texas as Harvey rages on
summary: US President Donald Trump visited devastated Texas on Tuesday to survey damage from Tropical Storm Harvey, which has caused catastrophic flooding and killed at least 13 people. The storm has brought record rainfall to Houston, with nearly 50,000 homes suffering flood damage, and nearly a third of Harris County underwater. Trump called for an exemplary relief effort, saying it was of epic proportion and comparing it to Hurricane Katrina. Damage is expected to run into the tens of billions of dollars, with the city of Houston facing a potential loss of up to $50 billion in economic activity.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump visited Texas on Tuesday to survey damage from the first major natural disaster to test his leadership in a crisis, as record rainfall from Tropical Storm Harvey lashed Houston and tens of thousands of people fled deluged homes.

site_title: Trump in for hard time when Congress returns from recess
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to face significant challenges when Congress returns from recess, with many Republican lawmakers losing support for his plans. Despite initial optimism, Trump's conduct in office, including his tweets and personal attacks, have strengthened the anti-Trump movement. The White House's failure to deliver on tax reform and infrastructure spending, as well as the looming debt ceiling and spending legislation, may lead to a fiscal crisis and government shutdown. The Republican-controlled Congress may struggle to gather support for Trump's agenda, and a majority of 60 votes in the Senate may be required to pass tax legislation.

site_title: Property prices a hot-button issue in NZ election
summary: New Zealand's housing affordability crisis is fueling voters ahead of the Sept 23 general election. Property prices have risen 34% in the past three years, with average prices exceeding NZ$607,000. The government is under attack for failing to respond to price surges, with opposition leader Jacinda Ardern promising to ban property sales to non-resident foreigners and build 100,000 affordable homes. The ruling National Party has made more land available for development, but critics say its efforts are too little, too late, and that disillusioned home buyers may turn against the party.

images.alt_text: Houses in Lyall Bay, a suburb of Wellington. Home prices across New Zealand have risen 34% the past three years, fanned by record immigration, historically low interest rates and a supply shortage.

site_title: OEMServices, Thompson Robbins tie up to seek growth in Asia-Pac
summary: OEMServices and Thompson Robbins Components Pte Ltd have partnered to explore growth opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region's components services for the airline industry. The partnership aims to capitalize on the expected surge in air travel in the region, driven by Asia's increasing population and growing middle class. The two firms will focus on the aviation value chain and infrastructure, seeking to provide expertise and operational customer-proximity in key markets. The partnership is seen as an opportunity to support the aviation industry's growth in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Trump's plan to rebuild US infrastructure hits a snag
summary: US President Donald Trump's plan to rebuild US infrastructure with $1 trillion in spending over a decade faces a significant snag: a lack of skilled workers. The construction industry struggles to find enough people to fill current openings, with about 225,000 unfilled posts in June and three million workers expected to retire or leave the industry over the next decade. Companies are responding by offering incentives, such as faster payment and student debt relief, to attract workers, but the industry warns that labor conditions will remain tight.

site_title: Spacecraft to end 13-year probe and dive into Saturn
summary: The US space agency's Cassini spacecraft will end its 13-year mission to Saturn in mid-September by transmitting data until its final plunge into the planet's atmosphere on September 15. The spacecraft, which provided groundbreaking discoveries on Saturn's rings and moons, will burn up as it enters the gas giant's crushing atmosphere. Cassini's final data will include information on the rings' mass, atmosphere, and rocky core, with scientists expecting to study the planet's rings, which are younger than previously thought.

site_title: Euro pulls back on fear of rally losing steam
summary: The euro slipped below US$1.20 on Wednesday, as investors worried that its 14% gain since the start of the year might be losing steam. The dollar recovered from a four-month low against the yen, boosted by easing concerns over North Korea's missile test. The euro had surged to a 2½-year high on Tuesday, but investors believe European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi is concerned by its strength, leading to a drop in the single currency.

site_title: Restaurants turn to data-mining to serve up enhanced dining experience
summary: Restaurants are turning to data-mining to enhance the dining experience. Startups and established companies are merging existing data with external sources to track sales, customers, and staff performance. This technology aims to disrupt the food industry by providing real-time insights and personalized experiences. Companies like Tender Greens and Oriole are using data analytics to recognize regular customers, predict wait times, and improve overall service. The goal is to create a more efficient and customer-centric restaurant experience, with one system managing all aspects of operations.

site_title: A vibrant turnaround for a long-neglected Charleston suburb
summary: A property developer, Stephen Zoukis, and his partners spent over $70 million to transform a neglected neighborhood in Charleston, South Carolina, known as the Upper Peninsula, into a vibrant office park development. The 131,000 sq ft Pacific Box & Crate and 90,583 sq ft Half Mile North developments now house tech companies, restaurants, and shops, bringing vibrancy to the area. The projects, which began in 2012, have created jobs and put properties back on the tax rolls, revitalizing the neighborhood.

site_title: Axiata nears US$1b deal for Veon's Pakistan towers
summary: Axiata Group Bhd is in advanced talks to acquire Veon's 13,000 wireless towers in Pakistan for approximately US$1 billion. The deal would make Edotco Group Sdn, Axiata's infrastructure arm, the largest independent telecommunications tower operator in Pakistan. The acquisition aims to expand Axiata's overseas infrastructure operations and help the company meet its goal of increasing its phone towers in South-east Asia and South Asia to 26,000 within three years.

site_title: Three applications already in the bag
summary: Singapore's presidential election is set to be historic as it's the first to be reserved for people from the Malay community. Three applications have been submitted so far, with former Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob being the latest to submit her forms. The Elections Department will inform all applicants of the final decision by September 12. If two or more candidates are successful, there will be nine days of campaigning before the election on September 23, with over 2.5 million voters casting their ballots.

images.alt_text: Madam Halimah arriving at the Elections Department with her supporters.

site_title: Hyundai resumes production in China after supply hiccup hurts sales
summary: Hyundai Motor resumed production in China after a supply disruption forced a halt in operations last week. The production stoppage, due to a fuel-tank components supplier's refusal to provide parts, adds to concerns about the company's sales in the world's biggest car market. Sales from Hyundai's Chinese factories plummeted 64% to 105,000 vehicles in April-June. The company's third-quarter results are expected to be lower due to weak performance in China, with analysts citing Hyundai's weak brand image as a disadvantage in the market.

site_title: AI in investment is here to stay, and we should embrace it
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is increasingly being adopted in the financial world, with big firms investing heavily in AI systems to inform decisions. AI can analyze and predict market outcomes with better accuracy, providing wealth management and investment advisers with actionable insights. Despite concerns about bias, privacy, and regulatory issues, AI is expected to remain a key player in the industry. As computing power and data storage continue to increase, AIs are capable of handling complex tasks, such as beating human players in games like Go. However, experts caution that AI systems are still in their infancy and lack the sophistication to handle human complexities.

site_title: Regional bourses may soon be pressured to adopt dual-class shares
summary: Regional stock exchanges may be pressured to adopt dual-class shares (DCS) following Singapore and Hong Kong's consideration of the move. Critics warn it could disenfranchise public investors, but the practice is seen as a way for exchanges to boost their profile and attract new listings. As exchanges compete for listings, companies are increasingly choosing foreign markets for their initial public offerings. This trend could lead to a "race to the bottom" among exchanges, potentially forcing others to adopt DCS to remain competitive.

site_title: Japan right to tell China to act like a major power
summary: Japan's newly appointed Foreign Minister Taro Kono has taken a firm stance against China, criticizing Beijing's military construction in the South China Sea. Kono's comments were seen as a departure from his father's diplomatic approach, which had improved China-Japan relations. China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi responded by expressing disappointment and attempting to use Kono's father's reputation to influence his views. However, Kono rebuffed Wang's efforts, stating that China should learn to behave like a major power. The exchange has raised hopes for improved East Asia relations.

site_title: Huge potential for bilateral cooperation, says China ahead of Modi's visit
summary: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that China and India have great potential for cooperation ahead of Indian Prime Minister Modi's visit. The two nations agreed to de-escalate their disputed border stand-off, coinciding with the start of the BRICS summit. This move aims to cast a positive light on their complicated ties, seeking to enhance bilateral cooperation. The visit is set to take place next week.

site_title: After US fines firm, Taiwan looks to turn the corner on money laundering
summary: Taiwan has taken steps to improve its anti-money laundering measures after being fined US$180 million by US authorities for lax enforcement at its New York branch. The island has passed laws to meet international standards and implemented rigorous training programs for staff. Companies across Taiwan are also working to get staff and systems up to speed. Taiwan has been targeted by money laundering and cybercrime, and is in the process of pushing through a cybersecurity bill. The country will undergo a review by the Asia Pacific Group on Money Laundering in 2018 to demonstrate its compliance.

site_title: Smaller UK manufacturers already feeling Brexit strains: survey
summary: UK small and medium-sized manufacturers, accounting for 40% of the industry, are feeling the strain of Brexit, according to a quarterly survey. 41% of respondents believe the Brexit process has had a negative impact on their business, citing rising material costs and uncertainty over trade arrangements. A free trade agreement with the EU is the top priority for 50% of respondents. The survey also found that investment intentions have slipped, with growth sources like net trade and investment yet to compensate for a consumer-led slowdown.

site_title: Revenue, debt revamp boost for Swee Hong
summary: Swee Hong, a Singapore-based construction player, reported a net profit of S$30.2 million for its full financial year ended June 30, reversing a net loss of S$10.2 million in the previous year. Revenue surged 44% to S$58.9 million, driven by increased progress on ongoing projects, including the ER382 Project and the Nee Soon tunnelling project. The company's debt restructuring and a S$22.4 million scheme creditors write-off contributed to the turnaround.

site_title: Federer passes five-set test at US Open
summary: Roger Federer outlasted Frances Tiafoe in a five-set thriller at the US Open, boosting his hopes for a deep run in the tournament. Federer, dealing with a back injury, won 4-6, 6-2, 6-1, 1-6, 6-4, advancing to the second round. The 19-time Grand Slam champion credited the win with giving him confidence and said he was "extremely well" after the match. Federer will face Mikhail Youzhny or Blaz Kavcic next, as he chases a record sixth US Open title.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat after Trump's comments on North Korea
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday following President Donald Trump's comments on North Korea, reigniting concerns over escalating tensions between Washington and Pyongyang. Despite data showing a stronger economy, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.88 points, while the S&P 500 lost 0.52 points. The Nasdaq Composite rose 6.23 points, however, marking a fresh record. The comments did not seem to deter investors, with stocks continuing their rally.

site_title: M1, StarHub offer unlimited-data mobile plans
summary: M1 and StarHub have launched new mobile postpaid plans featuring free unlimited data, a move seen as an attempt to retain or gain market share before new players enter the Singapore telco market. M1 offers an unlimited 4G plan for S$98/month, while StarHub provides free unlimited data on weekends and 3GB-15GB data on weekdays. Analysts believe the telcos aim to capture and lock customers in on 12- to 24-month long contracts before new entrants, including TPG and MyRepublic, launch their services.

site_title: American Express targets debt-leery consumers with new card features
summary: American Express is introducing new features on its credit cards to appeal to debt-leery consumers. The new option allows customers to borrow for big purchases and separate those balances from everyday items, with installment plans and finance fees similar to interest charges. The move aims to attract young, budget-conscious consumers who have avoided credit card debt due to the Great Recession. The features are part of American Express' response to losing market share to competitors, and the company hopes to increase revenue and customer usage.

site_title: Nissan brings a tiny bit of self-driving to the masses
summary: Nissan unveiled its ProPilot Assist system, a semi-autonomous driving feature, on its 2018 Leaf model. The system, set to launch in the US on September 5, allows the vehicle to steer and stop itself, but not fully drive autonomously. The feature requires clear lane markers and has limitations in terms of aggressiveness. While it's not a full self-driving system, it's designed to reduce driver fatigue and is intended to make autonomous technology more accessible to budget-conscious buyers. The system will be available on select SUV models, not the Leaf.

site_title: SBI Offshore has yet to deal with the elephant in the boardroom
summary: SBI Offshore, a loss-making firm, has faced ongoing uncertainty a year after appointing four independent directors to its board to investigate serious allegations over a past transaction. The company's CEO, Chan Lai Thong, was suddenly ousted without a three-month notice, and another independent director, Ahmad Subri Abdullah, resigned. Despite the efforts of a special investigation committee, the final report on the Pricewaterhouse Coopers' audit findings has yet to be released, leaving minority shareholders seeking clarity. The company's strategy to scale back its offshore and marine activities has yet to bear fruit, and its boardroom remains plagued by issues.

site_title: FCT subscribes for its full allocation in Hektar Reit's rights issue
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust subscribed for its full allocation in Hektar Real Estate Investment Trust's rights issue, funding the deal with S$6.78 million from internal resources. FCT now holds 143.9 million units, a 31.15% stake, in Hektar Reit. The trust acquired Hektar Reit's sixth property, a 223,438 sq. ft. retail shopping mall in Malaysia, after the rights issue.

site_title: New Uber CEO expresses fear about leaving Expedia after 18 years
summary: Uber officially welcomed its new CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, who previously led Expedia Inc for 12 years. Khosrowshahi, who has been with Expedia for 18 years, expressed concerns about leaving the company. His appointment was announced on Tuesday evening after a board vote on Sunday, following ongoing contract negotiations.

site_title: Yongnam bags three contracts worth S$70m
summary: Yongnam Holdings secured three new contracts worth S$70 million in Singapore and Myanmar. The contracts include a project for JTC Logistics Hub @ Gul and Woodlands Health Campus in Singapore, and an extension project for Japan Tobacco International in Myanmar. These contracts are expected to positively impact the group's financial performance for 2017 and 2018.

site_title: Freeport, Indonesia to end years of wrangling over mining rights
summary: Freeport-McMoRan Inc has reached an agreement with Indonesia to end years of wrangling over mining rights for its giant Grasberg copper mine. The US company will retain control over operations and governance of the mine, while ceding 51% of its Indonesian unit to a local entity. The deal includes plans for a second smelter in Indonesia and investments of $17-20 billion in Grasberg through 2031. The agreement reduces the risk of another stoppage to copper concentrate exports and brings an end to labor unrest at the mine.

images.alt_text: Freeport can immediately apply for a 10-year permit extension to mine at Grasberg beyond 2021, says Indonesian Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Ignasius Jonan, and a second extension could be proposed before 2031.

site_title: Otonomy's ear disease drug fails key trial, shares nosedive
summary: US drugmaker Otonomy announced it will stop developing its Meniere's disease treatment, Otividex, after a late-stage trial failed to meet its goals. The trial aimed to significantly reduce vertigo episodes, but the drug missed its primary and secondary objectives. Shares plummeted 75% to $5.20 in premarket trading. Meniere's disease affects about 600,000 Americans, with no FDA-approved specific treatment. Otonomy will withdraw its 2017 operating costs forecast pending an internal review of its product pipeline.

site_title: Singapore cannot afford to slow down
summary: Singapore must invest in skills, infrastructure, and research to succeed in the digital revolution, which is changing the way economic value is created and societies communicate. The government must focus on humans, not technology, and provide user-friendly digital services. It must also make a quantum leap in enterprise efficacy and create new products and services that are competitive globally. The government can set the right foundations by equipping the population with the right skills, providing digital infrastructure, and investing in research and development. By working together with the public and private sectors, Singapore can harness the digital revolution and create jobs and grow a new digital middle class.
