site_title: Louisiana soaked, Houston flooded in Harvey's wake
summary: Tropical Storm Harvey caused catastrophic flooding in Texas and Louisiana, killing at least 17 people and displacing tens of thousands. The storm paralyzed the US energy hub of Houston, with damage estimated at tens of billions of dollars, making it one of the costliest US natural disasters. Forecasters predicted an end to torrential rain after five days, but relief efforts were hindered by the need for federal assistance to homeowners and displaced individuals. Nearly a third of Harris County was underwater, with thousands more expected to flee, and the economic cost was estimated to be between $51 billion and $75 billion.

images.alt_text: Flood waters from Tropical Storm Harvey put a power sub-station in Iowa, in the Calcasieu Parish of Louisiana, under water. A few hundred people have been rescued from their homes in Lake Charles in the state.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher as North Korean tensions ease
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 15.92 points to 3,265.26, driven by easing North Korean tensions and a rebound from Wall Street's Tuesday rise. Turnover improved to 1.9 billion units worth S$1.02 billion, marking the first time this week the S$1 billion mark was surpassed. The broad market followed the index, with 242 rises versus 186 falls, excluding warrants.

site_title: Almost 1 in 20 smaller German banks fail national stress test
summary: Almost 5% of small and medium-sized German banks failed a national stress test conducted by the Bundesbank and BaFin, with about 1,500 banks participating. The test found that the impact of the simulation would have been higher if it had considered contagion effects. Bundesbank board member Andreas Dombret stated that the results highlight the need for banks to strengthen their capital requirements to ensure stability in the financial system.

site_title: Coming: A platform to ease small suppliers' cash-flow woes
summary: A platform is set to launch in Hong Kong, aiming to ease cash-flow woes for small suppliers by providing financing solutions. The platform, led by former investment banker Rajah Chaudhry, will help clients manage delayed payments and improve cash flow. This move is expected to benefit small suppliers who often struggle with managing their finances due to client delays.

images.alt_text: Over 30 Hong Kong suppliers use Mr Chaudhry's Paycelerate to serve corporates across industries.

site_title: Sincap to conduct share placement to raise S$8m
summary: Sincap Group, an Alumina and thermal coal trader, plans a share placement to raise S$8 million. The firm has entered into a conditional agreement with KGI Securities, agreeing to procure subscriptions for up to 450.25 million new shares at a discounted price of 1.8 Singapore cents per share. The placement will be used to support current businesses and working capital, with 90% of the proceeds allocated for business development and 10% for working capital.

site_title: Singapore's MPA will not renew Universal Energy's ship fuelling licences
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) will not renew Universal Energy's ship fuelling licences when they expire on Aug 31. The MPA cited Universal Energy's delivery of fuel with too much air and "stoppages" during its operations as reasons for the decision. Universal Energy Director Hua Tan stated that the MPA did not provide a reason for the decision. The move affects one of Singapore's biggest suppliers of bunker fuel.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares rose on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 12.020 points to 1,773.160. The index saw 1.825 billion lots traded worth RM2.210 billion, with 480 gainers outnumbering 375 losers.

site_title: AA Reit obtains TOP for property redevelopment in Tuas
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit has received the Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) for the redevelopment of 8 and 10 Tuas Avenue 20 in Singapore. The two land parcels have been amalgamated into a three-storey contemporary industrial facility, increasing the property's gross floor area by 35.2% to 158,853 square feet. The redevelopment is in line with the Reit's strategy of unlocking further value in its existing portfolio, with the property valued at S$24.1 million. The Reit plans to announce a tenant once the development is complete.

site_title: US economy grew 3% in second quarter: Commerce Dept
summary: The US economy grew at a 3% rate in the second quarter, surpassing initial estimates and meeting the White House's growth target for the first time under President Trump. The revised GDP figure, released by the Commerce Department, was higher than analyst expectations of 2.7% due to increased consumer spending and business investment. However, growth in the first half of the year was 2.1%, below the 2.2% average over the last three years, and the Trump administration's growth agenda remains stalled in Congress.

site_title: Apple is said in talks with Bain for Toshiba chips business
summary: Apple is in talks with Bain Capital to bid for Toshiba's memory chips business, competing with a group led by KKR & Co and Western Digital. Apple, which relies on Toshiba for flash memory in its iPhones and iPods, aims to secure a continued supply to avoid dependence on rival Samsung Electronics. Toshiba, facing financial struggles, must sell off its chips business by March to avoid delisting from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The bidding process has been complicated by legal action from Western Digital and negotiations with the Japanese government.

site_title: Thailand plans 1.62t baht public-private partnership projects
summary: Thailand plans a 1.62 trillion baht (S$66.18 billion) public-private partnership investment plan for 2017-2021, mainly to improve infrastructure and lower logistics costs. The plan, which accounts for 94% of the budget, aims to boost the country's economy, which lags behind its peers. The government expects steady investment over the next four to five years, with 63% of the investment budget already spent. This comes as the military government ramps up investment to lift growth in the country.

site_title: Esports: a growing big business
summary: The Esports Arena in Santa Ana, California, has become the country's first venue specifically for esports competitions. The venue, which opened in 2015, hosted the Universal Open Rocket League Grand Finals, a US$100,000 tournament broadcast on NBCSN. The arena's expansion is fueled by a multi-million-dollar investment from Chinese sports and entertainment companies, with plans to open additional arenas in Oakland and Las Vegas. The venue also hosts amateur competitions and open play, and is working to improve its facilities, including adding alcohol and food options, to attract more fans.

site_title: Employee share scheme irregularity a one-off event: Ipco
summary: Ipco International has stated that a recent irregularity with an employee share scheme was a one-off event. Two partners were added to the implementation vehicle for the scheme without the board's knowledge or approval, granting them a 5% indirect interest in HZLH, a cash-generating unit. Ipco is confident a solution can be reached in due course.

site_title: Cityneon acquires 100% stake in Jurassic Park exhibition
summary: Cityneon Holdings acquired 100% global rights to Jurassic World Exhibition for US$25 million, entering into a partnership with Universal Studios. This marks Cityneon's third IP acquisition and association with a blockbuster movie franchise, following Disney's Marvel Avengers S.T.A.T.I.O.N. and Hasbro's Transformers Autobot Alliance. The acquisition will allow Cityneon to construct a second immersive experience set immediately, expanding the exhibition to more markets in Asia and worldwide.

site_title: Harvey seen nicking US economy before rebuilding lifts growth
summary: Hurricane Harvey is expected to have a modest impact on the US economy this quarter, with damage estimates ranging from $43 billion to $100 billion. Analysts predict a 0.2 percentage point decrease in the third quarter's GDP growth, but a subsequent boost in the fourth quarter from reconstruction efforts. The impact of the storm is expected to be relatively neutral, with short-term economic damage typically small and often matched by a subsequent surge in GDP. Rebuilding efforts are expected to give growth a bump in the fourth quarter, with wage inflation in affected areas unlikely to rise significantly.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Grab launched a peer-to-peer fund transfer feature, enabling customers to transfer GrabPay Credits. The Public Transport Council in Singapore started a fare review exercise, and M1 and StarHub introduced unlimited mobile data plans. Two international schools in Singapore opened a shared 50,000 sqm mega pre-school. Uber hired Dara Khosrowshahi as its new CEO, replacing Travis Kalanick. The Straits Times Index rebounded 15.92 points, driven by easing North Korean tensions.

site_title: Mumbai heeds warning to stay home after worst rain in 12 years
summary: Mumbai, India's financial capital, experienced its worst rain in 12 years, with 33.1 centimeters of rain recorded in 24 hours. Authorities advised residents to stay home due to predicted "heavy to very heavy" rainfall, leading to empty streets and decreased trading volumes in stock and bond markets. The city's Santacruz weather centre recorded the highest rainfall since 2005. Residents heeded the warning, staying indoors as the city braced for the severe weather conditions.

site_title: Oxley unit exercises options for Yio Chu Kang property
summary: Oxley Holdings' subsidiary, Oxley Garnet Pte Ltd, has exercised options to purchase six units at 208 Yio Chu Kang Road for a total purchase price of S$8.4 million. The 99-year leasehold property, with a 1,313.3 sqm land area, will be redeveloped subject to necessary approvals. The purchase will be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings. Oxley Garnet paid S$420,000 upfront, with the balance due upon completion of the purchase on Nov 23.

site_title: Sharp asks US trade body to probe Hisense in patent dispute
summary: Japan's Sharp Corp has requested the US International Trade Commission (ITC) to investigate Hisense Group, a Chinese firm accused of patent infringement. Sharp claims Hisense is selling low-quality TVs under the Sharp brand in the Americas. This dispute escalates a patent infringement case Sharp filed in the US this year. Sharp aims to expand its TV sales in China and re-enter the Americas market, with plans to double global TV sales to over 10 million sets. Sharp is owned by Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest contract electronics maker.

site_title: In smartphone age, the hajj is for sharing
summary: The hajj, a sacred Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca, is now being shared in real-time through smartphones and social media, allowing pilgrims to experience the journey remotely. Over 1.7 million foreign pilgrims are traveling to Saudi Arabia for the annual hajj, which began on August 30, 2017. With the help of mobile internet and video sharing apps, pilgrims can share their experiences, photos, and videos with friends and family back home, creating a global community of hajj-goers.

site_title: Singapore's Public Transport Council starts fare review exercise
summary: Singapore's Public Transport Council (PTC) has started the 2017 fare review exercise, calling for train operators to submit fare applications by September 29. The fare adjustment quantum is -5.4% based on the existing formula, aiming to balance affordability and long-term viability. The PTC will announce its decision in the last quarter of 2017.

site_title: TTJ unit and BCA end deal on workers' dormitory
summary: TTJ Holdings' wholly owned subsidiary, TTJ Design and Engineering Pte Ltd, and Singapore's Building and Construction Authority (BCA) have agreed to terminate a deal to manage and operate a foreign construction workers' dormitory in Upper Jurong Road. The termination is due to unexpected complexity in building retrofitting works. The agreement, which had a capacity for 500 workers, was set to run from August 2016 to July 2019. The termination is not expected to have a material impact on TTJ Holdings' financial and operating results for the financial year ended July 31, 2017.

site_title: UK consumer credit growth hits more than 1-year low in July, mortgage approvals surge : BOE
summary: UK consumer credit growth slowed to 9.8% in July, the weakest pace in over a year, amid a squeeze on household finances. Mortgage approvals surged to 68,689, beating forecasts, but the value of mortgage lending decreased. The data reflects Britain's slowest start to the year since 2012. Economists predict a subdued housing market outlook over the next couple of years due to the weak consumer-led economy.

site_title: ICBC's H1 profit up 1.8%, bad loan ratio down
summary: ICBC reported a 1.8% growth in its first-half net profit to 153 billion yuan, driven by stable net-interest margins. The bank's non-performing loan ratio decreased to 1.57% and net interest margin increased to 2.16%. The second-quarter net profit was 77.2 billion yuan, beating analysts' average forecast of a 1.7% increase.

site_title: 1,000 'treason' complaints against Merkel since 2015: report
summary: More than 1,000 complaints for high treason have been filed against German Chancellor Angela Merkel since 2015, according to a local media report. Most complaints come from supporters of the right-wing Alternative for Germany party, which is expected to win seats in the federal parliament in the upcoming general election. However, federal prosecutors have determined all complaints to be baseless, and Merkel's support has recovered in the polls. Despite protests and jeers at her campaign rallies, Merkel enjoys a double-digit lead over her rival in the polls.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally after previous day's losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied 1.19% on Wednesday, rebounding from previous day's losses fueled by North Korea's missile test over Japan. The Hang Seng Index rose to 28,094.61, while the Shanghai Composite Index inched down 0.05% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.35%. The rally follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Investors file 51 lawsuits against EU for shutting Banco Popular
summary: Disgruntled investors have filed 51 lawsuits against European Union regulators for shutting Spain's Banco Popular, citing the EU's new bank rules that forced investors to bear the costs of the rescue. The lawsuits, filed with the European Union's General Court, claim the EU's Single Resolution Board and Commission made a decision that unfairly affected bond and stock investors. The rescue, which was carried out on June 7, resulted in investors losing around 4 billion euros. The EU is facing its largest legal challenge yet, with similar cases being heard by EU judges, and talks are underway to overhaul the EU's bank rescue regime.

site_title: Draghi seen putting a lid on euro as traders test pain threshold
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is seen taking action to curb the euro's appreciation, which reached its strongest level in over two years versus the dollar. The currency broke above US$1.20 and may experience profit-taking, but its trajectory remains bullish. The ECB's next policy announcement is on September 7, and Draghi's intervention could ease market concerns about a tightening of financial conditions in the euro region.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after North Korea sell-off
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.74% on Wednesday, rebounding from a four-month low, after North Korea's missile launch over Japan led to a sell-off the previous day. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 19,506.54, while the Topix index rose 0.62% to 1,607.65. The rally was driven by bargain hunting, as investors sought to capitalize on the decline.

site_title: Cambodia PM woos garment workers with cash and pay rise vow
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen has launched a policy charm offensive in the garment industry, handing out cash to hundreds of pregnant workers and announcing annual pay rises, including a commitment to increase the minimum monthly wage from $153 to $160 in 2018. The move aims to capture support from the industry, which has been at the forefront of labor protests and strikes. The policy shift comes ahead of national polls next year, when the opposition party is gaining popularity amid corruption and inequality concerns.

site_title: Australia's Telstra axes A$5.5b fundraising plan after state partner's veto
summary: Telstra, Australia's largest telecoms operator, has scrapped a plan to raise A$5.5 billion through an income securitisation deal after a government-backed business partner, National Broadband Network (NBN), rejected the move. The plan aimed to secure upfront cash for Telstra's growth businesses, but NBN cited concerns about the risk of long-term impediments to its decision-making capability. As a result, Telstra's shares sank 6.3% to their lowest since 2012.

site_title: Hyundai halts China production after failing to pay supplier
summary: Hyundai Motor Co suspended production in China due to a supplier halting deliveries after not being paid. The halt affects four of the company's five factories, impacting over 1.6 million vehicles per year. The crisis is the most serious faced by Hyundai in its biggest market, amid declining consumer sentiment and increased competition from Chinese automakers. The factory shutdowns add to the challenges faced by Hyundai in China, which has been struggling with a sedan-heavy lineup and heavy discounting by foreign brands.

site_title: M&S in talks to transfer Hong Kong and Macau stores to franchise partner
summary: Marks & Spencer has initiated talks to sell its wholly owned Hong Kong and Macau stores to Al-Futtaim, a franchise partner. This move follows a strategic review by M&S last November, aiming to shut over 80 stores globally and explore joint ventures and franchise partnerships. The stores will continue to operate under the M&S franchise, with Al-Futtaim managing them. The talks are expected to take several months to complete.

site_title: Bank of China quarterly profit surges 23% as bad loans curbed
summary: Bank of China reported a 23% surge in second-quarter profit, reaching 57.04 billion yuan, due to curbing bad loans and expanding lending margins. This exceeded analyst estimates of 48.05 billion yuan. China's economic recovery has fueled loan growth at the four largest banks, which control a third of the nation's banking assets. The government's campaign against financial leverage has also driven up interest margins, benefiting the banks.

site_title: Brexit-led pound drop tests how 'indifferent' Carney can be
summary: The pound has fallen to its lowest level since October 2016 due to Brexit-fueled decline, prompting Bank of England Governor Mark Carney to re-evaluate his stance on the exchange rate. The currency's weakening may test Carney's "indifferent" attitude, as sustained declines could lead to inflationary concerns and potentially influence monetary policy decisions. The BOE's next decision falls on September 14, and policy maker Michael Saunders is set to speak on sterling, potentially adding to market scrutiny.

site_title: Grab plans to enable customers to pay merchants using GrabPay in Q4
summary: Grab has launched a peer-to-peer fund transfer feature allowing customers to transfer GrabPay Credits to one another. The company plans to extend GrabPay to over 1,000 merchants, including those in the food and beverage, retail, and entertainment industries, in Q4 2017. Singapore is the first country to trial this feature beyond transportation. Grab has also introduced a new six-digit PIN as a second-factor authentication to make its GrabPay mobile wallet more secure.

site_title: Hong Kong businessman David Tang dies at 63
summary: Hong Kong businessman David Tang, founder of Shanghai Tang and China Tang restaurant, has died at 63. Tang, known for his "Agony Uncle" column in the Financial Times, hosted a farewell party at the Dorchester Hotel in London after being told he had a month or two to live. Born in Hong Kong, Tang was educated in Britain and founded Shanghai Tang in 1994, selling it to luxury group Richemont. He was also a philanthropist and a cigar enthusiast, being made a Knight Commander of the British Empire in 2008.

site_title: Australia: Shares close flat to end three session run of losses
summary: Australian shares closed flat on Wednesday, ending a three-session losing streak, as a 9.3% increase in construction spending and gains in the real estate and consumer staples sectors offset losses in the telecommunications sector. Telstra's shares dropped 6.3% after dropping a plan to raise A$5.5 billion, while consumer staples stocks like Bega Cheese Ltd rose 3.3%. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.01% to 5,669.7.

site_title: M1, StarHub unveil unlimited mobile data plans
summary: M1 Limited and StarHub have launched new mobile data plans featuring unlimited data access. M1's mySIM3 98 plan costs $98 for unlimited data on a 12-month contract, while StarHub's plans offer free unlimited local data on Saturdays and Sundays, with bundled data of 3GB-15GB on weekdays. The new plans aim to cater to changing digital usage, enabling customers to use their smartphones freely and at faster speeds. Sign-ups for the new plans started on Thursday.

site_title: Japan deputy PM Aso in hot water over Hitler remarks
summary: Japan's Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso has retracted comments that cited Adolf Hitler, saying he did not mean to praise the Nazi leader. Aso made the remarks at a meeting of his party, referencing Hitler's legacy in politics. He later apologized, stating his perception of Hitler was extremely negative and his motivation was wrong. This is not the first time Aso has made controversial comments, including criticizing women and old people, and praising Hitler's economic policies in 2013.

site_title: Europe: Stocks bounce back as strong earnings in focus
summary: European stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday, rebounding from a sharp dip due to North Korea's missile launch, as investors focused on strong earnings news. Banking stocks led the gains, with the Italian bank-heavy index outperforming. Earnings growth for the second quarter is estimated at 16% year-on-year, supporting the rally. Despite geopolitical concerns, European stocks have been supported by global investors' confidence in the region's economic growth and relatively cheap valuations compared to the US market.

site_title: Two international schools open mega pre-school on shared campus in Singapore
summary: Two international schools in Singapore, the Australian International School and Stamford American International School, have opened a 50,000 sqm shared campus, Early Learning Village, for children aged 18 months to six years old. The campus, equivalent to seven football fields, features a 20m swimming pool and indoor gymnasium, and can accommodate 2,100 pupils from all nationalities. The Reggio Emilia-inspired pre-school is a first-of-its-kind collaboration, supporting each school's education philosophy and pathways. The campus is seen as a timely addition to international school provision in Singapore, with its innovative design and scale.

site_title: South Korea's fertility rate plunges to 7-year low
summary: South Korea's fertility rate has reached a seven-year low of 1.17 babies per woman in a lifetime, according to Statistics Korea. The average age of first-time mothers has increased to 31.4, and around 6.5 million of the country's 50 million population are 65 years or older. Soaring property prices and limited job prospects have led to many young women delaying marriage and having children. The government has invested over 100 trillion won in programs to encourage marriage and large families, but more policies are needed to accommodate working mothers.

site_title: Icahn Quadruples his money in US$600m Las Vegas resort deal
summary: Billionaire Carl Icahn has sold the stalled Fontainebleau resort in Las Vegas to a partnership led by Steven Witkoff for $600 million, quadrupling his initial $148 million investment. The resort, 70% complete, is located on 27 acres of land near the Las Vegas Convention Center. Witkoff praised the property as one of the best physical assets in the US, while Icahn called it a "hidden gem" that resulted in a $457 million gain for his company.

site_title: Malaysia's Maybank Q2 profit up 43% on lower loan-loss provisions
summary: Malaysia's largest bank, Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), reported a 43% increase in net profit for Q2 2017 to RM1.66 billion, driven by lower loan-loss provisions. Net interest income rose 10% to RM3.04 billion. The bank expects 2017 earnings to be "satisfactory" despite a challenging global environment.

site_title: North Korea's missile launch: Why Japan?
summary: North Korea launched a ballistic missile over Japan on August 29, 2017, sparking international condemnation. The missile, which traveled 2,700 kilometers, was likely intended to demonstrate its range and deter the US, rather than provoke a response from Japan. The launch was also seen as a message to Japan, which was colonized by Japan from 1910 to 1945, and a reminder of the past tensions between the two countries. Japan has exhausted its diplomatic options and is likely to boost its missile defense system, while the US has already imposed sanctions on North Korea.

site_title: Mumbai braces for more rain after heaviest downpour in 12 years
summary: Mumbai experienced its heaviest downpour in 12 years, with 33.1cm of rain recorded in 24 hours. The city's Santacruz weather center reported the highest amount of precipitation since 2005. Authorities advised residents to stay indoors due to waterlogged roads and slow traffic. Trading volumes were weak, with the NSE 50 Nifty Index 27% below the 30-day average. Despite the challenges, the Nifty Index rose 0.8% and the rupee advanced 0.1%. The rain is part of a 4% below-normal rainfall across the country since June 1.

site_title: Japan seeks new US missile radar as N Korea threat grows - sources
summary: Japan is seeking the US to provide a powerful new radar, known as Spy-6, for its missile defense system, citing the threat from North Korea. The US has declined to share the radar, which Japan needs to effectively counter North Korean missile advances. Japan plans to install a land-based Aegis ballistic missile defense system by 2023, but without Spy-6, its capabilities will be limited. The decision has raised concerns about Japan's vulnerability to North Korean attack and may blunt US efforts to reassure Japan of its commitment to defend its ally.

site_title: China's postal bank plans Shanghai listing, seeks to raise US$785m
summary: China's Postal Savings Bank is planning a Shanghai listing to raise around $785 million, following its successful Hong Kong listing last year that raised $7.4 billion. The bank reported a 14.5% year-on-year increase in first-half net profit. The offering aims to optimize corporate governance and develop domestic and overseas financing platforms.

site_title: Australian number plate sells for A$2.45m
summary: A rare black-and-white Australian number plate with the digit "4" sold for a record-breaking A$2.45 million at a Sydney auction, more than twice the average cost of a Sydney home. The ultra-collectible plate, one of only nine ever issued, was sold to Chinese-Australian billionaire Peter Tseng, who made his fortune in the sex toy industry. The sale shattered pre-sale estimates and broke the previous Australian auction record set in 2003.

site_title: May pledges £160m to life sciences sector ahead of Brexit
summary: The UK government has pledged £160 million to support the life sciences sector ahead of Brexit. The funding will be used to support innovation in manufacturing, vaccine development, and small company research. The £4.7 billion increase in research and development spending over four years aims to boost the £64 billion sector. The government's plans were announced alongside recommendations from the life sciences industry, which include funding for basic science and tax policy to support growth. The funding will leverage £250 million of investment from businesses and includes £14 million for medical technology research centers.

site_title: Diana: fashionista who shook up the royal dress code
summary: Princess Diana revolutionized the royal dress code with her bold and elegant style, collaborating with top designers to convey her personality through clothes. She mastered the art of wearing the right attire for the right occasion, from hospice visits to state events. Diana's daring outfits, including androgynous pieces and trousers, helped modernize the royal wardrobe. Her style continues to inspire designers and the public, with her legacy still celebrated through exhibitions, fashion collections, and social media tributes.

site_title: China launches anti-dumping probe into some rubber imports from EU, US and Singapore
summary: China's Commerce Ministry has launched an anti-dumping probe into hydrogenated butyl rubber imports from the US, EU, and Singapore, citing price dumping that hurts China's domestic industry. The investigation, set to last a year, covers imports between April 2016 and March 2017, primarily used to produce heat-resistant materials. The move aims to protect China's rubber producers from unfair competition.

site_title: Asia: Markets rebound but North Korea concerns remain
summary: Asian markets rebounded on Wednesday, reversing losses from the previous day as investors calmed down over North Korea's missile launch. Donald Trump's measured response and the UN Security Council's gathering helped ease concerns, while Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called the launch a "grave threat." Markets edged up, with Seoul and Tokyo rising 0.1% and 0.6% respectively, while Hong Kong and Singapore also gained. The dollar bounced back against the yen and euro, and oil prices remained subdued due to Hurricane Harvey's impact.

site_title: Six die in rains lashing India's business hub
summary: Heavy monsoon rains in Mumbai, India's financial capital, caused widespread flooding, resulting in the deaths of at least six people, including two toddlers. The city's low-lying areas were inundated, causing vehicle pile-ups and disrupting traffic. Authorities shut schools and colleges due to forecasts of more rain. The city's airport experienced flight delays, and the government offered crisis-mitigation assistance to the affected state. The floods revived memories of 2005 floods that killed over 500 people, highlighting the city's vulnerability to storms due to poor infrastructure and construction.

site_title: Australian court dismisses allegations against health insurer Medibank
summary: Australia's competition watchdog lost a Federal Court case against health insurer Medibank Private Ltd, dismissing allegations that the company failed to notify customers about changes to pathology and radiology benefits while in hospital. Medibank had argued that notifying customers could lead to a loss of initial public offering business. The decision was made in 2014, and the ACCC had alleged the company breached consumer laws.

site_title: Bulgaria seizes contaminated eggs from Germany
summary: Bulgaria's food safety agency announced the seizure of a tonne of contaminated powdered eggs from Germany, which were used to make mayonnaise and ice cream. The eggs contained the insecticide fipronil, banned in the EU food industry. This discovery comes after millions of eggs were recalled across Europe and dozens of poultry farms closed due to fipronil contamination, which was first reported on August 1. The issue has sparked a row between Belgium, the Netherlands, and Germany over how long officials knew about the problem.

site_title: Eurozone yields rise as inflation defies currency strength
summary: Eurozone government bond yields rose as forecast-beating inflation in Spain and expected similar data in Germany defied the euro's recent strength, despite a decline in the currency's value against the US dollar. Analysts attributed the shift in focus to the bloc's economic health, following the initial shock from North Korea's missile firing. The euro's 14% gain against the US dollar this year was expected to hold down prices, but inflation concerns took precedence.

site_title: Houston hotel market, worst in US, faces pain from Harvey
summary: Houston's hotel market, the worst in the US, is expected to face further challenges due to Hurricane Harvey. The storm has created a temporary housing emergency, with some hotels offering discounts to alleviate the crisis. Texas Governor Greg Abbott has suspended the state and local hotel occupancy tax for relief efforts. The longer-term impact is likely to be negative, with occupancy and room rates expected to decline. Hilton and Marriott have waived cancellation fees for affected hotels, and the industry may see a boost in demand for hotels outside of Houston.

site_title: Aussie at 1-month high after construction data; kiwi muted
summary: The Australian dollar reached a one-month high of US$0.7985 after second-quarter construction spending rose 9.3%, the largest increase on record, exceeding forecasts. This boost is expected to lift economic growth above initial expectations. The New Zealand dollar remained steady but slipped to a 5-1/2 low against the Australian dollar, ending the month down 3.3%. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's neutral stance on interest rates has contributed to the kiwi's decline.

site_title: Trump's planned building boom bumps up against worker shortage
summary: President Donald Trump's $1 trillion infrastructure plan faces a significant challenge as the construction industry struggles to find enough skilled workers. Companies like AECOM, Skanska USA Inc, and Turner Construction Co say they can't fill current openings, let alone the millions of jobs envisioned by Trump. With 3 million construction workers set to retire or leave the industry over the next decade, and unemployment rates near full employment, the industry is hard-pressed to find enough people. The administration's immigration policies may further exacerbate the issue.

site_title: Harvey seen nicking US economy before rebuilding lifts growth
summary: Hurricane Harvey is expected to have a modest 0.2 percentage point dent in the US economy's third quarter growth, with reconstruction efforts likely to boost growth in the fourth quarter. Damage estimates range from $43 billion to $100 billion, and nearly half a million people were affected. Despite speculation that the rebuilding efforts will lead to upward wage inflation, economists believe this is unlikely, citing the US's robust emergency response systems and high levels of private insurance. The national economy is expected to remain volatile, with Federal Reserve officials monitoring economic reports for signs of a new trend.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares start the day lower
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.57 points to 1,758.57. The market saw 99.1 million lots traded worth RM39.8 million, with 124 gainers and 107 losers.

site_title: Moody's says G-20 GDP growth to exceed 3%, warns of geopolitical risks
summary: Moody's Investors Service forecasts G-20 economic growth exceeding 3% for this year and next, citing strong data in the first half of the year. However, the agency warns of geopolitical risks, US protectionism, and spillovers from global monetary tightening and China's deleveraging measures. Key forecasts include: China at 6.8%, South Korea at 2.8%, Japan at 1.5%, and the US at 2.2% in 2017. The agency also notes event risks related to the Korean Peninsula and Middle East, and warns of increased volatility in markets.

site_title: Porsche Cayenne gets sports car flair with fat rear tires
summary: Porsche's refreshed Cayenne SUV features fat rear tires, sharper handling, and brawnier engines, drawing inspiration from its 911 sports car. The third-generation Cayenne boasts a sleeker look, wider rear tires, and improved cornering. The base model starts at nearly $121,713 and features a 340-horsepower engine, while a plug-in hybrid version is also available. The enhancements aim to counter growing competition and boost profits for Porsche, which has been affected by the diesel-cheating scandal.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks resume rally after open
summary: Hong Kong stocks resumed their rally on Wednesday, adding 0.83% to 27,994.12 after a one-day decline linked to North Korea tensions. The Hang Seng Index rose for the fifth consecutive day. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.05%. The rally in Hong Kong follows a similar trend in Singapore, where the Straits Times Index rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Billionaire Hui is Asia's second-richest on Evergrande rise
summary: Chinese property tycoon Hui Ka Yan has become Asia's second-richest person after a US$9 billion surge in the past seven days, surpassing India's Mukesh Ambani. Hui's net worth has risen 360.6% to US$34.1 billion, driven by a boom in Chinese real estate assets and Evergrande's shift to a low-debt strategy. This surge has added US$26.7 billion to Hui's fortune, making him the fastest-growing billionaire on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index this year.

site_title: Ancient whales were predators not gentle giants say scientists
summary: Scientists in Australia have found that ancient whales, the ancestors of the Southern Right and Blue whale, had extremely sharp predator teeth, not the filter-feeding teeth of modern whales. Using 3D scanners, researchers created digital models of fossil and modern whale teeth, discovering that ancient baleen whales' teeth were much sharper and had a single function - cutting flesh. This contradicts previous theories that ancient whales filtered feed using teeth that formed a sieve. The discovery suggests that whales' feeding biology "turned upside down" when they evolved to filter feed.

site_title: Oil dips as US floods cause large-scale refinery shutdowns
summary: Oil prices dropped as US refinery shutdowns due to Hurricane Harvey's flooding reduced demand for crude. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 9 cents to $46.35 per barrel, while Brent crude futures decreased 7 cents to $51.93 per barrel. The largest US refinery, operated by Motiva Enterprises, shut down on Tuesday night, affecting 603,000 barrels per day. Total reduced production to 53% of capacity at its Port Arthur refinery. At least 3.6 million barrels per day of refining capacity are offline, or nearly 20% of total US capacity.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Koda, ISOTeam, ASL Marine
summary: Koda Limited reported a 147% increase in net profit to US$4 million, driven by improved economies of scale and supply chain efficiency. ISOTeam secured 15 projects worth S$24.18 million, while ASL Marine Holdings posted a net loss of S$62.4 million in its fourth quarter, impacted by higher impairments and lower revenue.

site_title: Swee Hong back in the black with S$30.2m profit for FY2017
summary: Swee Hong Limited reported a net profit of S$30.2 million for FY2017, reversing a net loss of S$10.2 million in FY2016. Revenue surged 44.4% to S$58.9 million due to increased progress on ongoing projects. Earnings per share and net asset value per share also improved. The company noted the completion of a creditors scheme of arrangements, marking a new era for the company. This reversal comes after a significant loss the previous year.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks rebound as North Korea worries ease
summary: South Korea's won and shares rebounded on Wednesday following North Korea's latest missile launch, with the won rising 0.4% to 1,121.8 and the Kospi index up 0.1% to 2,366.09 points. The United Nations avoided new sanctions on North Korea, easing market anxiety. Foreign investors were set to buy Kospi shares, and tech major LG Electronics rose 4.7% after joining a bidding for ZKW Group. Hyundai Motor's shares fell to their lowest in four months due to supply disruptions.

site_title: Australia: Shares steady despite Telstra tumble; NZ rebounds
summary: Australia's benchmark stock index rose 0.04% to 5,666 points, despite a 5.2% drop in the telecommunications index led by Telstra's 8% slump. The US market's gains from geo-political tensions eased, but the Aussie market steadied somewhat. The consumer staples sector led gains, with Graincorp Ltd rising 8.1%, while the metals and mining index gained 0.4% due to rising copper and nickel prices. New Zealand's benchmark index rebounded 0.5% after four days of losses.

site_title: South Korea discount store sales rise for fifth month in July
summary: South Korea's discount store sales rose 1.7% in July, marking the fifth consecutive month of growth, driven by an uptick in consumer sentiment. Demand for fresh food and home appliances increased 4.8% and 3.7% respectively. This growth supports Asia's fourth-largest economy, with private consumption more than doubling in the second quarter to 0.9% from 0.4% in the first.

site_title: North Korea says more missiles to come as UN condemns launch
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong-Un has promised more missile flights over Japan, following the launch of an intermediate-range missile on Tuesday, which the UN Security Council condemned as a threat to all UN member states. The US has warned of severe repercussions, with President Donald Trump stating "all options" are on the table. The UN has backed the US-drafted declaration, but no immediate new measures against Pyongyang are expected. North Korea views its military exercises with South Korea as a rehearsal for invasion, and has vowed to take "resolute countermeasures".

images.alt_text: North Korea leader Kim Jong-Un has promised more missile flights over Japan, insisting his nuclear-armed nation's provocative launch was a mere "curtain-raiser", in the face of UN condemnation and US warnings of severe repercussions.

site_title: Kitchen Culture posts S$6.4m loss for 18-month financial period 2017
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings reported a widening net loss of S$6.4 million for its 18-month financial period 2017, compared to a net loss of S$5.3 million for the preceding year. Revenue increased 86.4% to S$49.6 million, driven by higher revenue from residential projects, distribution, and retail segments. Loss per share worsened to 6.4 Singapore cents, while net asset value per share dropped to 1 Singapore cent.

site_title: Peru opposition chief Keiko Fujimori faces graft probe: lawyer
summary: Peru's opposition leader Keiko Fujimori is under investigation for suspected links to a corruption scandal involving Brazilian construction firm Odebrecht. Prosecutors claim a note on the company's jailed ex-boss's phone indicated payments to Fujimori, which she denies. She is the daughter of ex-president Alberto Fujimori, who is in jail for human rights atrocities. Fujimori's lawyer says she is ready to cooperate with investigators and denies any wrongdoing.

site_title: Japan retail sales slow in July, still top expectations
summary: Japan's retail sales growth slowed in July to a 1.9% annual increase, but still met expectations. Despite a slowdown in household spending and spending on clothes and cars, economists remain optimistic about consumer spending due to a tight labor market. Demand for labor reached a 43-1/2 year high, supporting the outlook for domestic demand. However, tensions with North Korea may undermine consumer confidence, and some economists predict a possible fall in retail sales in August due to heavy rains.

site_title: Toyota invests in ride-hailing firm Grab, to install recorders in rental cars
summary: Toyota Motor Corp. has announced a partnership with Singapore-based ride-hailing firm Grab, investing in the company and installing driving recorders in 100 rental cars. The TransLog device will analyze driving patterns and provide access to connected car services. This move marks Toyota's expansion into new driving services, as the automaker aims to leverage data from the pilot program to improve its own vehicles and services.

site_title: US looking into whether Uber bribed foreign officials
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating Uber for potential violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which bars bribing foreign officials to promote business interests. Uber confirmed it's cooperating with the investigation but didn't disclose details. The probe comes after the company was accused of bribing foreign officials in the past.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, recovering from the previous day's sell-off following North Korea's missile launch over Japan. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.51% and the Topix index rose 0.41%. A weaker yen boosted Japanese shares, making exporters more competitive overseas. Key gains included Fast Retailing, Sony, and Panasonic, while Toyota rose 0.73% and Nissan edged down 0.04%. Despite geopolitical worries, investors were relieved to see gains in New York.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE hits 16-week low after North Korea's missile launch
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index hit a 16-week low on Tuesday, closing 0.9% lower at 7,337.43 points, after North Korea's missile launch over Japan shook global markets. Financials sector led the decline, with lenders and consumer staples firms falling 1-2%. Precious metals miners, however, rose 2-7% as gold prices surged. Investors sought safe-haven assets, driving the dollar down and sterling and euro strength.

site_title: Under investor pressure, Goldman to explain trading strategy
summary: Goldman Sachs will explain its trading strategy to investors next month after facing pressure from large investors due to a 40% decline in bond-trading revenue. The move is a departure from the bank's traditional practice of providing little information about its business. The decision comes after Goldman's core bond-trading unit reported a significant decline, worse than its rivals.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.4% up on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.4% higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 14.1 points to 3,263.44. This followed a positive finish on Wall Street, which reversed losses from earlier in the day due to a lack of concern over North Korea's missile launch. Gainers outnumbered losers 79 to 50, while Japan's Topix and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index also rose, with the Kospi edging up.

site_title: Uber hires Dara Khosrowshahi as chief
summary: Uber has hired Dara Khosrowshahi as its new CEO, replacing Travis Kalanick. Khosrowshahi, former Expedia boss, is credited with turning the travel services company into a global behemoth. Uber is hoping he will steer the ride-sharing service in a positive direction, after Kalanick's departure due to controversy and pressure. Khosrowshahi is known for his experience, talent, and vision, and is expected to bring a more collaborative approach to the company. He will meet with Uber employees at the San Francisco headquarters in an 'all-hands' gathering.

images.alt_text: Uber said on late Tuesday that it has hired Expedia boss Dara Khosrowshahi as its new chief executive.

site_title: Gold extends rally to '17 high as North Korea test adds to angst
summary: Gold prices rose to a 17-year high after North Korea fired a ballistic missile over Japan, boosting demand for haven assets and extending a rally fueled by declines in the US dollar. The metal gained 0.3% to $1,314.23 an ounce, its highest level since November 9. Analysts at Goldman Sachs attributed the rally to the possibility of conflict in Asia and the Federal Reserve's expected slow pace on interest-rate increases. Gold has surged 15% this year, with precious-metal stocks outperforming the market.

site_title: US dollar recovers from 2-1/2-year lows as North Korea fears ebb
summary: The US dollar recovered from its 2-1/2-year lows against a basket of major rivals after North Korea's missile launch over Japan was largely dismissed by traders. The dollar jumped more than half a percent against the Japanese yen to a 12-day high, while the euro remained flat against the dollar after hitting a 2-1/2-year high. Investors shifted their focus to upcoming US non-farm payrolls data, and concerns about North Korea's missile launch began to fade.

site_title: Private drones ordered to stay away from Harvey rescue efforts
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has imposed a ban on hobbyist drones and other civilian aircraft flying in areas affected by Tropical Storm Harvey in Texas. The ban, which prohibits flights up to 3,000 feet altitude across hundreds of square miles around Houston, aims to prevent interference with rescue efforts and ensure the safety of crews operating helicopters in the region. The FAA has made exceptions for search and rescue teams, the military, and law enforcement, but warned that civilian drones pose an "EXTREME risk" to rescue pilots and crews.

site_title: British princes mark anniversary of Diana's death with low-key tribute
summary: British princes William and Harry are marking the 20th anniversary of Princess Diana's death with a low-key tribute. They will visit Kensington Palace, where Diana lived until her death, and meet representatives from charities she supported. The princes will also tour a newly planted White Garden in the palace's public gardens, which was created in her memory. This year's tribute is more discreet than in previous years, as the princes contributed to documentaries honoring Diana's memory. The occasion comes as fresh revelations about her life and TV documentaries have renewed public interest in her legacy.

site_title: California schoolchildren help to build homes in LA
summary: California schoolchildren helped build tiny, portable homes in Los Angeles to aid the city's homeless population. Over 100 children aged 9-11 worked on the project, which has seen around 135 children involved in shifts over a year. The homes, built on wheels, are legally considered recreational vehicles, allowing for more flexibility in placement. This initiative comes as Los Angeles struggles with a homeless population of around 58,000, and the school raised nearly $6,000 of a $19,000 target through crowdfunding to support the project.

site_title: Saudi Arabia shortlists 25 bidders for major wind plant
summary: Saudi Arabia has shortlisted 25 companies to bid on a 400 megawatt wind power project in Al-Jouf province, the country's first utility-scale wind project. The project aims to diversify Saudi Arabia's energy mix and achieve 9.5 gigawatts of renewable energy by 2023. The bidding process is set to close in January 2018, with a 300 megawatt solar facility in the same region expected to be completed by November. The renewable energy program is estimated to be worth up to $50 billion and is expected to create over 7,000 jobs.

site_title: Z-Obee seeks voluntary delisting from SGX
summary: Z-Obee Holdings, a Singapore-based mobile handsets solution provider, is seeking voluntary delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to save on administrative costs. The firm plans to focus on business operations and conduct future fundraising activities through the Hong Kong Exchange. Trading on the SGX has been suspended since July, and the company has submitted a proposal to resume trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Z-Obee has also entered into a share subscription agreement with investors and is working on restructuring plans.

site_title: Trump praises Texans on trip to Harvey disaster zone
summary: US President Donald Trump visited the Harvey disaster zone in Texas, praising the state's ability to handle the storm. Four days after Harvey made landfall as a Category Four hurricane, thousands remain stranded, and the US Gulf Coast braces for another onslaught. Trump sought to strike a unifying tone, saying "Texas can handle anything" and expressing his support for the state's response efforts. Despite his visit, Trump and his wife Melania did not visit Houston, which remains underwater, and the storm's danger is far from passed, with rising floodwaters breaching a levee and a "thousand-year flood event" predicted.

site_title: SGX Regco needs backing from better enforcement
summary: SGX RegCo, the new regulatory unit of the Singapore Exchange, is set to begin operations in a month, aiming to oversee listing and regulatory issues, conduct surveillance, and enforce market discipline. However, concerns remain about its independence, with calls for it to be truly independent of the exchange and not influenced by profit-driven objectives. SGX RegCo will have an independent board of directors, but its ability to issue harsher penalties, such as fines or bans, will still be limited. The regulatory system faces challenges in addressing concerns of true independence and ensuring equal-handedness in enforcing rules against all players, big and small.

site_title: Vitamin-maker Blackmores posts 41% full-year profit drop
summary: Blackmores Ltd, Australia's top vitamin maker, reported a 41% drop in full-year profit due to a decline in demand from Chinese shoppers in Australia. Exports to China failed to offset the decline, and the company reduced its final dividend by a third. The result fell short of market expectations as the company shifts focus to direct exports.

site_title: Tips for managing risks
summary: KPMG's head of risk consulting, Irving Low, recommends that companies embed good risk and control habits into daily activities to effectively manage risks. The risk function plays a key role in reviewing processes to ensure this. This approach helps companies develop a culture of risk management, enabling them to identify and mitigate potential risks.

images.alt_text: Irving Low

site_title: Fiona the baby hippo and how animals go viral
summary: A Cincinnati zoo has created a viral sensation with Fiona, a baby hippo, following the success of other internet-famous animals like Bao Bao and Bei Bei the pandas, and April the Giraffe. Critics argue that animal parks are prioritizing social media over animal welfare, but the zoo says Fiona's popularity is helping to raise awareness and support for conservation efforts. Fiona's online presence has sparked a national conversation about the ethics of keeping animals in captivity for entertainment purposes.

images.alt_text: Fiona was born prematurely in January, weighing just 13kg. For the premiere of The Fiona Show, a never-before-seen video of its birth is featured.

site_title: North Korea says fired missile over Japan on Tuesday
summary: North Korea fired a missile over Japan on Tuesday, marking the first time it has acknowledged doing so. The Hwasong-12 intermediate-range missile, supervised by leader Kim Jong Un, traveled 2,700km and reached a maximum altitude of 550km. The launch was timed to coincide with the 107th anniversary of the Japan-Korea treaty of 1910, and Kim expressed "great satisfaction" over the launch. North Korea claims the drill had no impact on neighboring countries and vowed to conduct more ballistic rocket launching drills in the future.

site_title: America's biggest security threat now is lack of political unity
summary: The US's biggest security threat is now the lack of political unity, according to James Mattis, the newly-nominated Secretary of Defense. Mattis cited a growing divide between liberal urban centers and conservative rural populations, leading to increased polarization and volatility in politics. This division has resulted in Americans questioning the legitimacy of President Trump and making it difficult to reach agreements on domestic and international policies. As a result, Americans are losing a sense of being part of something bigger, making it a pressing concern for national security.

site_title: N Korean missile test rattles markets
summary: North Korea's missile test on August 29, 2017, sparked global tensions, causing the Straits Times Index to drop 18.28 points. US domestic politics also weighed on investor sentiment, leading to low turnover and a weak opening for Wall Street. Safe havens like the euro benefited from the spike in geopolitical worries. The property sector was seen as a potential area for recovery, with analysts expecting a larger fall-off in supply.

site_title: What secure digital banking needs is your face or thumbprint
summary: Biometric technology is gaining traction in the financial services industry, expected to reach a $30 billion market by 2021. Its convenience and high security make it an attractive alternative to traditional passwords, with many consumers embracing biometric authentication for mobile payments and online transactions. Banks are already introducing biometric solutions, such as fingerprint recognition, and new technologies like facial recognition and voice biometrics are emerging. However, to achieve benefits, biometric technology must be implemented correctly, with a strong security policy and multi-layered authentication methods to prevent credential theft and fraudulent attacks.

site_title: US warns 'all options' open after North Korea launch
summary: US President Donald Trump warned "all options" are open after North Korea launched a ballistic missile over Japan, prompting a US emergency meeting of the UN Security Council. The missile, identified as an intermediate-range ballistic missile, was fired from a land-based mobile launcher and did not pose a threat to the US mainland. Trump's statement came after North Korea resumed test launches and defied Washington's bid to lure it back to talks. Japan and the US are considering tougher action against Pyongyang, including new sanctions, amid concerns over the North's nuclear program and regional stability.

site_title: Scottish Labour party leader quits
summary: Scottish Labour party leader Kezia Dugdale resigned on Tuesday, citing the need for a "new leader with fresh energy" as the party prepares for the next Scottish Parliament elections in 2021. Dugdale, who held the position for two years, will remain an MP but stepped down to allow for a new leader to take charge, aiming to improve the party's chances in the upcoming elections.

site_title: China's Bond Connect trade up sharply as yuan strengthens
summary: China's Bond Connect scheme saw a sharp increase in trading by offshore investors, with total settlement value nearly quadrupling to 11.8 billion yuan (S$2.4 billion) in the week of Aug 21 to 11. A strengthening yuan may be contributing to the program's growth, with investors drawn to high-yielding negotiable certificates of deposit (NCDs) and potential currency appreciation. The yield on AAA-rated three-month NCDs stood at 4.53%, 89 basis points above 10-year treasuries.

site_title: S'pore ready to help in Hurricane Harvey relief efforts
summary: Singapore is ready to send CH-47 Chinook helicopters to assist in Hurricane Harvey relief efforts, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong told US President Donald Trump in a phone call. The helicopters will be deployed from the Republic of Singapore Air Force's Peace Prairie detachment in Texas. The two leaders also discussed North Korea's ballistic missile launch and the ongoing situation on the Korean Peninsula, with Singapore condemning the provocative action and urging the DPRK to cease all provocations.

site_title: ASL Marine Q4 loss shoots up as impairments soar
summary: ASL Marine Holdings reported a significant Q4 net loss of S$62.4 million, up from S$6.37 million a year ago, due to higher impairments, lower revenue, and poorer margins in the global marine industry. Revenue fell 21% year-on-year to S$77.8 million, while losses per share rose to 9.92 Singapore cents. The company attributed the downturn to weak oil prices and low charter rates in the container and bulk cargo market.

site_title: Traders rush to ship oil from Louisiana as Harvey looms
summary: Oil traders are rushing to ship crude and fuel supplies through ports in Louisiana as Tropical Storm Harvey approaches, threatening to close the US Gulf Coast's last major oil terminals. Harvey has dumped record rain on Texas, forcing refinery shutdowns and pipeline closures. Louisiana's ports are being used to discharge fuel and load exports, with buyers from Latin America and Asian refiners trying to secure cargoes before conditions deteriorate. US crude prices have fallen due to reduced refining, making it cheap for international refiners, and prices in the Gulf have soared above benchmark prices in New York Harbour.

site_title: Harvey may wash away Houston hotels' revenue
summary: Hurricane Harvey is expected to further devastate Houston's hotel market, already struggling with low occupancy and room rates for three consecutive years due to depressed oil prices. The storm has created a temporary housing emergency, with some hotels offering discounts and Texas Governor Greg Abbott suspending the state and local hotel occupancy tax for relief-effort personnel and storm victims. The long-term impact is likely to be negative, with occupancy and room rates continuing to decline, and some hotels suffering damage from the storm, potentially leading to permanent closures.

site_title: US petrol prices jumps 4%, oil mixed as storm hits more refineries
summary: US petrol prices surged 4% on Tuesday after a hurricane shut down over 19% of the country's refining capacity, curbing fuel production and increasing crude inventories. The storm, Tropical Storm Harvey, has set a record for rainfall in Texas and has disrupted oil production in the Gulf of Mexico. Crude prices were mixed, with US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) edging down 13 cents to $46.44 a barrel, while International Brent crude futures rose 11 cents to $52.00 a barrel.

site_title: Millions of infected Brazilian mosquitoes to tackle dengue
summary: Brazilian scientists released millions of mosquitoes infected with a bacteria meant to prevent the transmission of dengue, Zika, and chikungunya viruses. The mosquitoes, carrying the Wolbachia bacteria, were released in Rio de Janeiro to breed and spread the bacteria, aiming to dent the insect population's ability to spread these diseases. The Fiocruz institute plans to release 1.6 million mosquitoes a week, with the goal of reducing virus transmission. This project, developed by Australians, follows the 2016 UN declaration of an international health emergency due to Zika.

site_title: 'Interests of people before party colours'
summary: Former Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob, a former member of the People's Action Party, has announced her candidacy for Singapore's presidential election, vowing to prioritize the interests of Singaporeans over party affiliations. With nearly 40 years of public service experience, Halimah aims to unify the nation and promote a progressive, inclusive community. Her campaign slogan, "Do Good, Do Together," emphasizes the importance of collective action and unity in building a better Singapore.

site_title: US: Wall Street shrugs off North Korea worries, forges higher
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, reversing losses from earlier in the day, despite North Korea's missile launch, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% to 21,865.37. Oil stocks took a hit due to Hurricane Harvey's impact on US production. The broader S&P 500 and tech-heavy Nasdaq also moved higher, with the Nasdaq gaining 0.3% to 6,301.89. Investors were relieved by President Trump's measured response to North Korea's provocation, with some analysts citing a desire for non-military solutions.

site_title: This Thai cuisine might bug you
summary: Bangkok's high-end restaurants are incorporating insects into their menus as a sustainable alternative to traditional protein sources. Insects are abundant, protein-rich, and require less energy and cost to farm than livestock. Many Thais, however, view insects as unappetizing and dirty due to cultural and social status connotations. To address this, restaurants are presenting insects in a sophisticated and appealing way, such as in watermelon salad or ant egg sauce, and some entrepreneurs believe this trend could help alleviate global food shortages and environmental damage.

site_title: Singapore dollar rallies further as investors seek refuge
summary: The Singapore dollar surged to S$1.3515 against the US dollar, its fourth consecutive rise, amid heightened North Korea tensions and uncertainty over US monetary policy. Investors flocked to safe-haven assets, including gold, Japanese yen, and US Treasuries, driving down the US dollar and boosting the Singapore dollar. This rally has contributed to a 7% year-to-date gain for the Singapore dollar, with its 10-year bond yield falling to 2.06%. Experts attribute the move to risk aversion in the market, with geopolitical risks remaining heightened.

site_title: Maritime week - too good for its own good?
summary: London's shipping week, the London International Shipping Week (LISW), is expected to draw over 15,000 industry leaders to over 140 events from September 11 to 15. However, the sheer number of events poses a challenge for shipping journalists, who must carefully select which events to cover due to the difficulty of attending multiple events simultaneously. This can result in missed opportunities for media coverage of key conferences and events. Experts warn that LISW may be verging on being too successful, and its organizers should consider the logistical challenges and potential drawbacks of hosting such a large event.

site_title: DBS launches digibank in Indonesia
summary: DBS launched its digibank in Indonesia, marking a claim on the country's emerging wealth by leveraging the surge in internet usage. The mobile-led bank uses technology like biometrics and AI to serve customers, with no minimum balance required. Customers can earn up to 6.25% interest and make cash withdrawals in Singapore without fees. This follows DBS's successful launch of digibank in India, which secured 1.5 million customers since April last year.

site_title: Scotland accomplishes mammoth engineering feat with new bridge
summary: Scotland's new Queensferry Crossing bridge, the third to link Edinburgh and the north of Scotland over the River Forth, was formally completed on August 29, 2017. The 2.7km-long bridge, standing 210m above high tide, is the longest of its type in the world. Construction took six years and required 35,000 tonnes of steel and 150,000 tonnes of concrete. The £1.35 billion project is £235 million under budget, and Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon described it as a "symbol of a confident, forward-looking Scotland" and a "feat of modern engineering."

site_title: Facebook whiz kid leaving to join Google
summary: Facebook product manager Michael Sayman, who was hired at 17 and turned 21, is leaving for Alphabet Inc's Google to join the Assistant team. Sayman, who taught himself to code at 13, worked on experimental products for teens and advised on trends at Facebook. At Google, he will focus on voice-based services and aims to lower the barrier of entry for kids to learn programming. Sayman praised Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, calling him an "incredible inspiration" and "absolute pleasure to work with."

site_title: Singaporeans cut back on shopping, entertainment, holidays
summary: In the second quarter of 2017, Singaporeans cut back on discretionary spending, including shopping, entertainment, and holidays, as they became more cautious about the economy and job prospects. Despite this, overall consumer confidence index edged up to 89 points, indicating optimism. Only 51% of respondents believed the country was in an economic recession, down from 62% in Q4 2016. Singaporeans are also mindful of job security and the economy, with 31% concerned about job security and 29% worried about the economy.

site_title: Hard-drinking Lithuania battles the bottle
summary: Lithuania has increased alcohol tax and raised the legal drinking age from 18 to 20 in an effort to curb heavy drinking. The country ranks among the world's heaviest drinkers, with an estimated average annual consumption of 18.2 liters of pure alcohol per person in 2016. Despite previous attempts to reduce consumption, the government's measures may not be enough, as experts suggest that other forms of help, such as medical treatment and support groups, are also needed.

site_title: Comcast changes channels to 'smart homes' as cable shrinks with cheaper options
summary: Comcast is expanding its "smart home" offerings to increase revenue and customer loyalty as traditional cable TV subscriptions decline. The company has seen success with its Xfinity Home security service, with subscribers doubling to over 1 million in the last two years. Comcast is now turning to home automation, including cameras and thermostats, for consumers in apartments and condos. The US smart-home market is expected to grow to $47 billion annually by 2020. Comcast aims to find out if a monthly subscription model can take off with a pilot program offering a video camera for $10 a month.

site_title: French use of gas to beat the heat could backfire in winter
summary: France is facing a potential energy crisis as the country's natural gas storage levels remain near a five-year low. The low storage levels are partly due to the use of gas to cool people down during the current heatwave, which could leave the nation without enough fuel to warm everyone up in winter. An infrastructure bottleneck that drove up gas prices last winter remains unresolved, further exacerbating the issue.

site_title: Ipos, Deloitte to help 100 firms grow intellectual assets and go global
summary: Singapore's Intellectual Property Office (Ipos) and Deloitte have partnered to help 100 growth-stage enterprises develop their intellectual property (IP) strategies and compete globally. The partnership aims to enhance innovation, boost IP-centric firms, and establish them as future global market leaders. Ipos and Deloitte will provide technical expertise, global business networks, and financial advisory services to companies in the biomedical, healthcare, manufacturing, and deep tech sectors. The partnership is expected to enrich the local innovation ecosystem and help companies monetize their intangible assets, ultimately driving business growth and competitiveness.

site_title: AirAsia to expand fleet as Q2 revenue hits record on travel demand
summary: AirAsia plans to increase its fleet by 21% in the second half of 2017, adding 22 planes, following a record quarterly revenue due to rising travel demand. The airline reported a 73% year-on-year drop in net profit to RM92.45 million, but a 2% point rise in load factor to 89%. Revenue hit an all-time high of RM2.38 billion, driven by strong demand and stable fuel prices. The airline's fleet expansion is expected to be one of the fastest in recent years.

site_title: ChargePoint plans IPO as it expands to take on e-car boom
summary: ChargePoint, operator of one of the world's largest electric car charging networks, plans an initial public offering (IPO) within the next five years. The company, which operates 40,000 charging spots in the US and Mexico, aims to expand further into Europe, where it faces competition from utilities and carmakers. ChargePoint's expansion is driven by the growing demand for electric vehicles, particularly in Europe, where the Volkswagen diesel scandal has increased awareness of the need to switch to electric vehicles.

site_title: Venice readies for Hollywood royalty
summary: The 74th Venice Film Festival is set to kick off on Wednesday with the world premiere of Victoria & Abdul, starring Judi Dench and Ali Fazal. Hollywood royalty, including George Clooney, Robert Redford, and Jane Fonda, will attend the festival, with Redford and Fonda receiving lifetime achievement awards. The festival features seven US productions in the main competition, including Downsizing, Suburbicon, and mother!. The winner of the Golden Lion will be announced on September 9.

site_title: Trump's 'America first' would inflate cost of houses in the US
summary: US homebuilders face significant costs due to President Donald Trump's "America first" policies, including increased tariffs on Canadian lumber and a crackdown on immigrant labor. The shortage of Hispanic-dominated framing labor and tariffs on Canadian lumber are expected to drive up home prices by slowing the supply of new houses. The cost of building a new US home could add tens of thousands of dollars, with a 40% tariff on imported parts adding only $7,000 to the cost. This policy change may have little to no effect on American jobs.

images.alt_text: The dearth of framers has got worse under Mr Trump because framing has one of the highest concentrations of immigrant Hispanics in the industry.

site_title: Harnessing collective genius for innovation
summary: Singapore aims to be a Smart Nation, driven by its innovation ecosystem. The government is rolling out recommendations to strengthen innovation, including Industry Transformation Maps and encouraging collaboration between startups, enterprises, and academia. Business leaders recognize the need for a bold strategy to navigate technological advancements, but only 16% of companies have adopted a proactive approach. A successful innovation ecosystem requires a balance of cooperation and competition, and leaders must foster an open culture that encourages collaboration and experimentation. By harnessing collective genius and creating collaboration structures, Singapore can accelerate innovation and achieve world-class solutions.

site_title: What is business partnering?
summary: Business partnering between risk management, finance, and internal control is crucial in ensuring complementary activities and minimizing overlap. This coordination facilitates the sharing of results, coordinated timelines, and reduces resource wastage. The three functions assist in good corporate governance, ultimately enhancing share price and shareholder satisfaction. By working together, these functions can identify significant risks, optimize efforts, and avoid duplication, ultimately benefiting the operating business and the organization as a whole.

images.alt_text: BILL Bowman.

site_title: Clinical research coordinators get S$35m boost from MOH
summary: The Health Ministry of Singapore has allocated S$35 million to fund the salaries of 100 clinical research coordinators (CRCs) for the next five years. The funding will also support the implementation of national training and certification programs to ensure a steady supply of qualified CRCs. The programs aim to address the challenges faced by CRCs, including those with limited experience and knowledge of medical terms, and the increasing complexity of precision medicine trials.

site_title: Uber's new CEO a dealmaker, not 'tech bro'
summary: Uber's new CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, brings a dealmaking and leadership background from Expedia, not the typical "tech bro" profile. His outsider status may help Uber rebuild its culture, which has been described as toxic and sexist. Khosrowshahi's experience in acquisitions, partnerships, and managing class action lawsuits will benefit Uber, particularly in Asia. However, his lack of tech expertise and potential clash with ousted CEO Travis Kalanick are concerns. Analysts and investors express optimism about the decision, but some question whether Khosrowshahi can turn around the company's troubled culture and financial issues.

site_title: Ad shock a warning for Google-Facebook juggernaut?
summary: Global advertising giant WPP's revenue decline and concerns about its outlook have sent shockwaves, potentially foreshadowing a similar fate for Google and Facebook. The two tech giants' dominance in the digital market, with nearly a third of global digital media and 20% of worldwide media, raises concerns about their monopolistic power. Regulatory scrutiny, including antitrust investigations, and pressure from advertisers to deliver results are also weighing on their shares, with market capitalization exceeding $1.2 trillion.

site_title: Brexit? Britain's still part of a world community and outward-looking
summary: A UK Foreign Office official, Mark Field, stated that Britain's departure from the EU does not mean it's turning its back on the rest of the world. The UK remains "outward-looking and global" and a "partner of choice" in many areas, including trade and education. Despite Brexit uncertainty, Field believes there is a strong relationship between the UK and Singapore, with £10.9 billion in trade in 2015. The UK and Singapore share values and collaborate on various issues, including combating the illegal wildlife trade.

site_title: Japan's household spending falls unexpectedly in July
summary: Japan's household spending unexpectedly fell 0.2% in July from a year earlier, contrary to market expectations of a 0.7% increase. This decline follows a two-year high in June, casting doubt on the sustainability of domestic demand-driven economic recovery. Despite a tight labor market, jobless rate remains flat at 2.8%, and strong job growth continues to support household incomes, but weak price and wage growth persist. Core consumer prices rose 0.5% in July, still below the Bank of Japan's 2% target.

site_title: Cloud technology for financial services well past proof of concept
summary: Cloud technology has proven to be a transformative technology for the financial services industry, surpassing on-premises data centers in capabilities, resiliency, and security. Cloud vendors offer robust cybersecurity capabilities, granular access management, scalability, and high availability, making it an attractive option for firms looking to lower internal infrastructure costs. Despite initial complexity, cloud migration can be effective with detailed strategies, and cloud technology has outpaced individual firms in cybersecurity, providing cost savings, IT resilience, and new opportunities for simplification and upgrading business services.

site_title: Getting ready for Industry 4.0 takeoff
summary: Singapore aims to preserve and enhance its manufacturing industries through Industry 4.0, with digital transformation expected to add US$310-550 billion in economic value to the global chemicals and advanced materials industry. However, a talent gap is a major barrier to digital adoption, with 89% of senior tech leaders believing they lack the right skills within their organization. To address this, the government and industry must collaborate to identify emerging digital skills, develop hybrid talent, and create industry-focused training programs. A strong and collaborative ecosystem is crucial to bolstering Singapore's manufacturing workforce and enabling the nation's digitalization and advanced manufacturing vision.

site_title: EU's Juncker slams UK on Brexit as fractious talks resume
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker criticized the UK for failing to prepare adequately for Brexit talks, calling its position papers "unsatisfactory."
