Juncker joined EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier in expressing frustration over the remaining issues to be settled. Talks between the UK and EU resumed, with Juncker stating that a significant amount of work remains to be done.

site_title: E-payments use in Singapore only scratching surface: PayPal
summary: A survey by PayPal found that while Singapore is one of the world's most digitally literate countries, its e-payment usage is only scratching the surface. Despite 98% owning smartphones, 90% prefer cash as their primary mode of payment, citing concerns over privacy, cash availability, and accessibility of ATMs. PayPal hopes to address these concerns through education and collaboration with industry players and government regulators to promote the adoption of digital payments.

images.alt_text: Eighty-five per cent of merchants surveyed who have turned to selling goods and services on social media - of which digital payment is a key transaction method - are seeing positive effects on their financial health.

site_title: Best time to unlock value of our workforce
summary: Business leaders are embracing the modern workplace, characterized by flexible and mobile work arrangements, digital tools, and collaborative teamwork. To unlock the value of their workforce, they need to empower employees, transform their organization, and shape culture. This requires integrating three key pillars: people, place, and technology. People involve managing performance, not presence, and focusing on evaluations and outcomes. Place involves empowering collaboration and creative thinking across teams, breaking down silos, and fostering a dynamic workspace. Technology involves democratizing access to productivity and insights, using mobile and cloud tools, and ensuring secure data protection. By adopting these principles, businesses can compete in increasingly competitive global markets and tap into the potential of their young and technically adaptive workforce.

site_title: Merkel, Macron eye deeper eurozone integration after German election
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron are pushing for deeper European integration, particularly in the eurozone, following Brexit. Merkel endorsed a European Monetary Fund, while Macron pledged to announce proposals after Germany's election. They aim to strengthen the single currency union and improve economic coordination. Merkel also called for more European cooperation on migrant policy and pressed Turkey to release German citizens. The two leaders aim to overcome challenges such as Brexit and authoritarianism in Poland, with Merkel ruling out an expansion of the EU's customs union with Turkey.

site_title: GLP sells four properties in Japan for 51.6b yen
summary: GLP sells four properties in Japan for 51.6 billion yen (S$642.4 million), continuing its capital recycling strategy. The 100% leased, single-tenant facilities have a total gross floor area of 206,000 square meters. The sale price is 5% higher than the latest appraisal values, equating to a weighted average cap rate of 4.5%. GLP expects to receive US$266 million upon completion on September 1, 2017. This sale is part of GLP's US$39 billion global fund management platform and follows a 28.9% year-on-year fall in its first quarter net profit.

site_title: Sharapova sparkles on return to Grand Slam stage
summary: Maria Sharapova made a strong comeback at the US Open, defeating second seed Simona Halep 6-4 4-6 6-3 in a two-hour and 44-minute match. Despite still shaking off the effects of a 15-month doping ban and injuries, Sharapova's skill and determination helped her secure the victory in front of a packed Arthur Ashe stadium. The win marks a promising start for Sharapova's Grand Slam campaign.

site_title: Koda full-year profit more than doubles
summary: Koda Ltd, a Singapore-based furniture maker, reported a 147% increase in full-year net profit to US$4.05 million, driven by higher revenue and gross margins. The company's retail brand Commune expanded, contributing to the growth. Despite a fall in other income, the improved efficiencies in ODM (original-design manufacturing) were key to the profit increase.

site_title: Consumer confidence up, but no reason to party
summary: US consumer confidence jumped 3 points to 122.9 in August, surpassing expectations, driven by a more positive assessment of the present situation. However, short-term expectations remained flat, with consumers expecting little improvement in the economy. The present situation index reached a 16-year high, while the expectations index was just 1 point higher than the previous month. Despite a slight improvement in the labour market assessment, the outlook for the next six months is less optimistic, with fewer consumers expecting improvement.

site_title: US cracks down on dodgy, or even fake, stem cell clinics
summary: The FDA has cracked down on two large stem cell clinics and a biotech company for using unapproved treatments, including injecting stem cells into patients for various ailments. The FDA cited actions against StemImmune Inc and US Stem Cell, and seized 500 doses of live Vaccinia virus vaccine. The agency also warned US Stem Cell for impairing its inspection ability. The FDA is taking action to shut down "unscrupulous actors" in regenerative medicine, while also easing the path to approval for legitimate treatments.

site_title: China to create world's biggest power company
summary: China is set to create the world's largest power company, China Energy Investment Corp, through a merger of Shenhua Group Corp and China Guodian Corp. The move aims to reduce industrial overcapacity and overhaul state-owned enterprises, with the goal of lowering China's reliance on coal and expanding the use of renewables and natural gas. The merger is part of a larger consolidation effort in China's energy sector, which could include US$1 trillion in assets and fundamentally reshape the power utility landscape.

site_title: Singapore looks into common QR code for cashless payments
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is exploring a common QR code for cashless payments, aiming to implement a universally-accepted code by the end of this year. This move is part of the country's goal to become a Smart Nation with easy, fast payments via smartphones.

site_title: NY cracks down on smoking, bans tobacco sales by pharmacies
summary: New York has implemented a seven-point package of laws to combat smoking, including a 24% increase in the minimum price of a pack of cigarettes to $13, a cap on tobacco sellers, and a ban on pharmacies selling tobacco. The city also requires explicit smoking policies in apartment buildings and prohibits smoking in common areas. The measures aim to reduce tobacco use and smoking-related diseases, with a goal of reducing smokers to 12% of the population in the next three years.

site_title: Singapore an overlooked gem, say panellists
summary: Singapore is poised to capitalize on South-east Asia's demographic growth as the region's services centre, according to panellists at the SGX-Smarkarma Singapore Research Forum. The country's leading infrastructure, quality of life, and stability make it an ideal hub for regional services. With the US dollar expected to fall, Singapore's purchasing power will increase, attracting investments in the region. Panellists also noted that countries with weaker demographics will look to South-east Asia and South Asia for growth, positioning Singapore as a key player in the region's economic growth.

site_title: Harvey costs seen rising to US$42b as flooding intensifies
summary: Hurricane Harvey's estimated damages are rising to US$42 billion, up from Monday's projection of US$30 billion. Risk modeler Chuck Watson attributed the increase to more damage to drainage and flood-control systems. Analysts, including Imperial Capital's David Havens, estimate costs could exceed US$100 billion, potentially surpassing Hurricane Katrina's US$118 billion in losses. However, insurance brokers note that only 47% of Harvey's costs are insured, and homeowners' policies typically don't cover flood damage.

site_title: Domino's tests pizza delivery by self-driving cars in Michigan
summary: Domino's Pizza and Ford Motor Co. will test self-driving cars in Michigan to deliver pizzas to randomly selected customers in the Ann Arbor area. The test vehicles will initially be piloted by human drivers and will use GPS tracking and text messages to guide customers. The companies aim to explore the feasibility of self-driving delivery technology, but will not attempt to provide true door-to-door delivery service. This is not the first experiment with advanced pizza delivery technology, as Domino's has also tested drone and self-driving robot delivery in New Zealand.

images.alt_text: Domino's will deliver pizzas to randomly selected customers in the Ann Arbor area of Michigan in a Ford Fusion Hybrid equipped with self-driving technology.

site_title: Plans for CBD underground road network shelved
summary: Singapore's plans to build a massive underground road network, the Singapore Underground Road System (SURS), have been scrapped. The project, estimated to cost S$4.8 billion, was envisioned to reduce traffic congestion in the central business district (CBD) but is no longer needed with the expansion of the public transport network and decentralization of offices. The decision aligns with the government's vision of a car-lite society, prioritizing liveability and reducing the need for travel into and out of the city centre.

images.alt_text: Plans to build the Singapore Underground Road System (SURS), an extensive subterranean road network linking Singapore's central business district (CBD), Marina Bay Downtown and Southern Waterfront District, have been called off.

site_title: Facebook to reject ads from pages touting 'fake news'
summary: Facebook will reject ads from pages repeatedly sharing false news stories, a move aimed at reducing the distribution of 'fake news'. The update, effective immediately, will prevent repeat offenders from advertising on the platform. This follows Facebook's existing ban on ads linking to false stories determined by third-party fact-checkers. The social network hopes this change will reduce the harm caused by false news, which can erode trust and make the world less informed.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Two brokerages, DBS Group Research and UOB Kay Hian Research, initiated coverage on NetLink NBN Trust with a "buy" rating, citing a solid investment case due to growing distributions and potentially higher regulated returns. Wing Tai Holdings was also upgraded to "buy" by OCBC Investment Research, citing a compelling valuation and healthy balance sheet. The companies reported Q4 FY17 results, with NetLink's profit after tax increasing 4.6% and Wing Tai's profit after tax increasing 406% year-over-year. The upgrades were made despite a rising interest rate environment, with brokers citing growth opportunities in the telecommunications and property sectors.

site_title: US consumer confidence jumps in August
summary: US consumer confidence jumped to 122.9 in August, surpassing expectations, driven by a more optimistic assessment of present-day conditions. However, short-term expectations remained relatively flat, indicating consumers do not anticipate significant economic improvement in the months ahead. The present situation index reached a 16-year high, while the expectations index was only up a point, suggesting a mixed outlook.

site_title: New generation of day traders making money from fear
summary: A new generation of day traders is making money by betting on Wall Street's volatility index, the VIX, which measures investor expectations of market volatility. The VIX has been declining since its introduction in 1993, and investors can now easily trade VIX-linked investments, such as exchange-traded notes, on public exchanges. These investments have attracted over $14 billion in investor flows since 2012. Day traders like Seth Golden, who consistently short the VIX, are profiting from the index's decline, with Golden's net worth increasing to $12 million in about five years.

site_title: Seoul plans record spending to fund welfare, create jobs
summary: South Korea's government plans a record 429 trillion won ($516.7 billion) in spending for 2018, a 4.6% increase from this year, to fund rising welfare costs, create jobs, and boost domestic consumption. The budget proposal includes a 34% allocation for welfare and a 6.9% increase in defence spending. The plan aims to address the country's rapidly ageing population and stimulate economic growth, despite concerns over the financial burden on young South Koreans.

site_title: Evergrande profit surge brings share price gains to almost 400%
summary: Evergrande Group reported a surge in profit, resulting in a 7.2% share price gain in Hong Kong. The developer announced a shift to a low-debt strategy, reversing its high debt levels that had drawn short sellers. The profit surge comes after Evergrande faced financial challenges, with its shares previously declining. The company's announcement is seen as a positive move, boosting investor confidence and driving up its share price.

site_title: Insurers count cost of Harvey and climate change
summary: Hurricane Harvey's damage is estimated to be lower than expected, with insured losses likely to fall short of $75 billion, according to insurance executives. The storm's impact will still weigh on the industry, which is struggling to contain prices amid low interest rates. Climate change is predicted to result in more intense storms, with Ernst Rauch, head of Munich Re's Corporate Climate Centre, stating that storms are becoming more severe, not just more frequent. Insured losses from Harvey are estimated at $1.2 billion to $2.3 billion, with flooding not yet included in the estimate.

site_title: Toshiba may not finalise chip unit sale by Aug 31 deadline: sources
summary: Toshiba may not meet its August 31 deadline to finalize the sale of its $17.5 billion memory chip unit due to disagreements with Western Digital over details of the deal. Talks between the two sides are ongoing, with Western Digital's head in Japan attempting to hammer out specifics, including how to limit the company's future stake in the business. A deal has yet to be reached, and it remains unclear if the deadline will be met.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Geo Energy Resources, an Indonesian coal-mining group, has established a new unit, PT Geo Online Indonesia, to invest in an online e-commerce portal. The unit, with an authorized capital of 10 billion rupiah, will engage in e-commerce, IT, and communication businesses. This marks the group's first foray into a non-coal-related business since its establishment in 2008. The investment aims to capitalize on Indonesia's growing demand for online shopping and access to a growing internet consumer base in the country.

site_title: LVMH looking to turn historic Paris grounds into theme park
summary: LVMH, led by billionaire Bernard Arnault, plans to transform the 157-year-old Jardin d'Acclimatation in Paris into one of France's top three amusement parks. The 60 million euro project aims to increase annual visitor numbers to 3 million by 2025, with 17 new attractions, including steampunk-themed rides. The renovation, starting Sept 4, 2017, will be completed by May 1, 2018, with the park's concession contract running for 25 years.

site_title: StarHub unveils 'mesh network' Google WiFi
summary: StarHub has partnered with Google to bring its high-powered WiFi solution, Google WiFi, to Singapore. The mesh networking system, made up of multiple nodes, offers wider coverage and is available at S$0 upfront for new customers signing up for selected plans. The system costs S$15 per month over 24 months, and additional nodes can be purchased for S$199 each. This exclusive deal is the first in South-east Asia and the eighth globally, and it's expected to provide faster and more reliable internet connections to homes.

site_title: Euro extends gains after key US$1.20 level
summary: The euro strengthened to a 6-month high above the US$1.20 level, driven by a general sell-off in the dollar against major rivals. The US dollar's trade-weighted index fell 0.6% and benchmark 10-year Treasury yields dropped 6 basis points. The euro's rise was seen as a "green signal" by traders following ECB president Mario Draghi's comments at the Jackson Hole conference. Geopolitical tensions, including North Korea's missile launch, also contributed to the dollar's decline, with the euro up 0.6% on the day.

site_title: Staying one step ahead of risk
summary: Top management must prioritize a company-wide approach to risk management in a fast-changing business environment. With technological advancements and heightened security threats, organizations are regularly evaluating risk scenarios to avoid being blindsided. However, experts suggest that companies should focus on human factors, which often cause non-compliance with risk management practices, rather than solely on new controls. This shift in approach can help prevent risks from materializing and ensure effective risk management.

site_title: China's dividend superstars mask stinginess of state companies
summary: China's state-owned enterprises (SOEs) have announced lower overall dividends in the past two years, with a 4.4% decline, despite Beijing's calls for increased payouts. Less than half of 334 tracked companies have raised dividends since 2014. Debt has increased by 37% among SOEs, while cash levels have grown by 8%. Exceptions, such as PetroChina and China Mobile, have boosted dividends, but experts say widespread changes are unlikely until SOEs improve their balance sheets and profits. The government's efforts to boost dividends have been met with limited success, with many SOEs struggling to repay debts amid economic slowdowns.

site_title: More needs to be done to digitally empower workers
summary: A recent Microsoft study found that while 62% of Singapore respondents consider themselves mobile workers, only 37% feel empowered by their organization's culture and managers to work productively and collaboratively. The study also revealed that 26% of respondents agree that their organization is committed to closing digital skills gaps. Experts emphasize the need for organizations to rethink their approach to empower their workforce, address cultural and management challenges, and invest in new workplace practices, tools, and technologies to maximize productivity and collaboration in the digital age.

site_title: Levee breaches due to Harvey at Houston suburb forcing evacuation
summary: A levee along the Brazos River in Houston suburb Brazoria County breached due to heavy rains from Tropical Storm Harvey, forcing evacuations in low-lying areas. Residents of the Columbia Lakes neighborhood were ordered to leave for higher ground in Angleton. Harris County officials also warned residents of six northern Houston neighborhoods to evacuate due to overflowing water reservoirs. The flooding in the Houston area has started to worsen, prompting officials to take immediate action to protect residents.

site_title: Germany reports outbreak of H5N8 bird flu in swans
summary: Germany has reported an outbreak of the highly pathogenic H5N8 bird flu virus in three swans in the central state of Saxony-Anhalt, according to the World Organisation for Animal Health. This is part of a growing concern of the highly contagious virus in European countries, which has already led to the culling of over 700,000 poultry in Germany last year.

site_title: Tiong Seng, Ocean Sky clarify proposed acquisition of Sloane Court Hotel, Balmoral site
summary: Singapore property companies Tiong Seng Holdings and Ocean Sky International have clarified their proposed S$80.5 million acquisition of Sloane Court Hotel and a nearby site in Balmoral Road. The proposed acquisition only covers the properties and land, not the vendors' businesses or goodwill. The companies plan to form a joint venture, TSky Development, to redevelop the sites into a 12-storey condominium with about 80 units.

site_title: Oil prices dip as market grapples with hurricane damage
summary: Crude oil prices dropped on Tuesday as 13% of US refining capacity was shut down due to Hurricane Harvey, leading to a surge in gasoline futures. International Brent crude futures fell 32 US cents to $51.57 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude edged down 5 US cents to $46.52 a barrel. The damage assessment may lead to more volatility, with refineries in Asia expected to run harder to compensate for US closures.

site_title: Deutsche Bank names Postbank CEO to management board
summary: Deutsche Bank has appointed Frank Strauss, CEO of its Postbank unit, to the bank's management board as co-head of private and commercial banking starting September 1. Strauss joins current board member Christian Sewing, marking the lender's commitment to integrating its retail arm in Germany. This move comes after Deutsche Bank acquired Postbank in 2015 as the European debt crisis unfolded.

site_title: Google delivers an answer to Apple on augmented reality
summary: Google has released ARCore, a mobile developer tool that enables Android phones to run augmented reality features without costly hardware upgrades. The software helps track physical objects and overlay virtual images, and will be available for developers to preview on Google's Pixel phones and Samsung S8 smartphone. Google plans to add more devices and fully launch the software this winter, with the goal of getting AR on over 100 million phones quickly, and imagines a broad range of applications, including improved digital services and commerce uses.

site_title: New digital piggy bank helps Swiss kids save
summary: Credit Suisse, Switzerland's second-largest bank, has launched a digital piggy bank called Viva Kids, designed to teach children under 12 about financial planning and saving. The app-based piggy bank allows kids to set savings goals, track balances, and make payments, addressing concerns about financial education in the country. A recent study found that 90% of Swiss parents want their children to learn how to handle money, and most Swiss children are frugal with their pocket money, highlighting the need for effective financial education.

site_title: China Kangda Food Company eyes pharmacies in China to grow business
summary: China Kangda Food Company plans to open or acquire pharmacies in developed Chinese cities to expand its business in the retail healthcare and pharmaceutical sectors. The move aims to supplement existing sales channels for its high-value-added healthcare products and venture into the retail healthcare industry, which has shown strong growth potential. The company will engage medical personnel to ensure pharmacy operations and services, and may establish a management company to manage and operate the pharmacies. This expansion is expected to enhance the company's business portfolio and acquire an additional source of income.

site_title: Traffic gridlocked as monsoon rains flood India's financial capital
summary: Heavy monsoon rains brought India's financial capital, Mumbai, to a standstill on August 29, 2017, with thousands stranded due to flooding and poor visibility. Over 100 mm of rainfall caused widespread disruptions, including paralysed train services and airport diversions. Authorities launched a rescue mission, but faced challenges due to the heavy rains. The city is vulnerable to flooding due to poor infrastructure, including storm-water drains and waterways clogged by plastic garbage.

images.alt_text: Heavy monsoon rains brought India's financial capital to a grinding halt on Tuesday, with authorities struggling to evacuate people before a high tide was expected to add to the chaos.

site_title: Qatar downgraded at Fitch with negative outlook on Gulf spat
summary: Qatar's sovereign rating was cut to AA- by Fitch Ratings, citing little progress in ending the Saudi-led embargo. The rating downgrade is due to Qatar's slowest economic expansion since 1995 and a decline in foreign deposits. Fitch analysts stated that the negotiating positions of Qatar and the boycotting countries remain far apart. The negative outlook is attributed to the ongoing geopolitical tensions and abnormal events.

site_title: EU, Polish row on judicial reform heats up, Merkel to meet EC chief
summary: The European Commission is set to discuss Poland's judicial reforms with EU leaders, amid a row over the changes which the Commission says threaten the rule of law. Chancellor Angela Merkel has expressed concern, saying she takes the issue "very seriously". The Commission may launch legal action against Poland if the reforms are not revised, which could lead to suspending Poland's voting rights in the EU. The Polish government has denied the Commission's concerns, calling them "groundless".

site_title: China's Greenland Holdings discloses overdue debt in first half
summary: China's Greenland Holdings reported overdue debt of 457.5 million yuan (S$93.537 million) in its units in Liaoning province by the end of June. The company attributed the issue to weak real estate market and management problems. This is not the first time Greenland has faced debt repayment problems, with an affiliate defaulting on 2 billion yuan of notes last year. The overdue loans have led to a drop in Greenland's share price and 2024 bonds, with investors urging the company to improve transparency and communication.

site_title: Dortmund bus bomber could face 28 counts of attempted murder
summary: German prosecutors are seeking 28 counts of attempted murder against Sergej W., who is accused of the April 11 bomb attack on Borussia Dortmund's team bus. The attack, which injured several people, including Spanish defender Marc Bartra, was not deemed a terrorist attack by federal police. W. had planned to profit from the attack by betting on a drop in Borussia's share prices. The case is expected to be decided by a regional court in Dortmund by the start of 2018.

site_title: Apple, Accenture team up on iPhone, iPad apps for businesses
summary: Apple and Accenture are teaming up to help businesses build iOS apps for iPhone and iPad. Accenture will create teams to assist customers, including banks and retailers, in writing new software and adopting new technology. The teams will focus on apps used by front-line workers and consumers, such as retail banking and augmented reality apps. This partnership aims to win over business clients and make iOS more useful in corporate settings, with features like drag-and-drop file management and improved productivity. The collaboration will also enhance Apple's position in the corporate world.

site_title: AirAsia to consolidate regional units as expansion plans take off
summary: AirAsia plans to consolidate its regional affiliates under a new holding company, AirAsia Group Bhd, to streamline its structure and expand its fleet by 20% in the second half. The airline reported record-high quarterly revenues, but a 73% drop in net profit due to a one-off tax charge. CEO Tony Fernandes aims to further simplify the group structure to facilitate future spin-offs. AirAsia is also exploring a sale of its leasing arm and a potential IPO in Indonesia.

images.alt_text: AirAsia Bhd (AAB) plans to consolidate its various regional affiliates under one holding company, in contrast to a scattered structure now, as the airline takes off on a rapid expansion path in its core Southeast Asian markets.

site_title: DBS launches digibank in Indonesia
summary: DBS launched digibank in Indonesia, leveraging the country's high mobile phone penetration to provide a paperless banking experience. The mobile-led bank uses biometrics, artificial intelligence, and security features to serve customers, offering benefits such as no minimum balance and 3% interest. DBS cited Indonesia's 91% mobile phone ownership rate and 47% smartphone ownership as key drivers for the launch, following its successful introduction of digibank in India over a year ago, which has attracted over one million customers.

site_title: Koda Ltd FY earnings up 147% to US$4m; EPS rockets to 14.39 US cents
summary: Koda Ltd reported a 147% increase in net profit to US$4 million in its full financial year, driven by improved economies of scale and supply chain efficiency, as well as higher revenue from its retail subsidiary. Revenue rose 33.4% to US$49.5 million, with earnings per share increasing to 14.39 US cents. The company's net asset value per share expanded to 100.7 US cents, and a dividend per share rose to three Singapore cents. Despite this, Koda shares finished 2.4% down at S$1.23 on the Singapore exchange.

site_title: ISOTeam clinches 15 projects worth more than S$24m
summary: ISOTeam Ltd secured 15 projects worth approximately S$24.18 million, including three new addition and alteration projects worth S$16.84 million and two mechanical and electrical projects worth S$3.15 million. The company also secured five repair and redecoration projects, two coating and painting projects, two interior design projects, and one general cleaning project under its Malaysian subsidiary. The projects are expected to be completed by November 2017, with ISOTeam's shares closing at S$0.345 on Tuesday.

site_title: North Korea accuses US of driving peninsula to "explosion"
summary: North Korea accused the US of driving the Korean peninsula towards "an extreme level of explosion" after firing a ballistic missile over Japan's Hokkaido island. The country's ambassador to the UN in Geneva, Han Tae Song, blamed US "pressure and provocative acts" for escalating tensions. The US and its allies, including South Korea and Japan, condemned the missile test, calling for North Korea to resume talks on giving up its nuclear arsenal. The US warned North Korea of "fire and fury" in response to threats, while the UN Security Council was set to discuss the issue.

site_title: US: Dow drops 100 points on North Korea missile test
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, with the Dow losing 123.16 points, or 0.56%, to 21,685.24, due to heightened tensions with North Korea following a missile test over Japan. President Donald Trump warned that "all options are on the table," sparking market concerns. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 losing 15.85 points, or 0.648463%, to 2,428.39.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer for its data center business was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding initial expectations. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned its second-quarter revenue might fall short of targets, with a similar operating loss to the first half. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In other news, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and Singapore's stocks continued a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Uber pays out 490m pesos to get back on Philippine roads
summary: Uber has paid nearly $10 million in fines and drivers' compensation to return to the Philippines' roads after being suspended for defying the government's order against accepting new driver applications. The company paid 190 million pesos in fines and 300 million pesos to drivers, lifting a month-long suspension. Uber resumed operations after agreeing to comply with the requirements outlined by the transportation agency. The decision came after a public backlash, with commuters criticizing the government for taking away a trusted ride-sharing app, particularly in Manila. Uber has about 66,000 drivers in the Philippines.

site_title: Singapore dollar rallies for the fourth day on safe haven appeal
summary: Singapore's dollar surged to S$1.3515 on Tuesday, its fourth consecutive day of gains, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid North Korea's latest missile provocation. The currency is up almost 7% year-to-date, with bond yields falling and demand for Singaporean bonds rising. Analysts attribute the rally to a risk-off environment, with investors seeking assets like gold, yen, and US Treasuries, and a weakened US dollar.

site_title: Most lucrative currency strategy borders on becoming Fed proof
summary: The US dollar's weakness, driven by political disarray and stagnating inflation, has made a "Fed-proof" foreign-exchange trading strategy profitable, particularly for emerging-market currencies. This strategy, known as a carry trade, involves financing purchases of higher-yielding currencies with US dollars, generating significant returns. Despite the Federal Reserve's intention to hike US rates, the dollar's decline is expected to continue, offsetting higher funding costs. Volatility in major currencies has decreased, making emerging market carry trades even more lucrative, with returns of 12% in 2017.

site_title: Air Berlin says deadline for offers is Sept 15
summary: Air Berlin has set a deadline of September 15 for bidders to submit their offers for the airline's assets. The airline will complete the investor process quickly, according to a spokesman. Several airlines, including Lufthansa, easyJet, and Ryanair, are interested in purchasing Air Berlin's business or parts of it. German aviation investor Hans Rudolf Woehrl and former F1 driver Niki Lauda are also exploring bids for Air Berlin's assets.

site_title: China Southern Airlines first-half profit falls 11.6%
summary: China Southern Airlines reported a 11.6% fall in first-half profit to 2.77 billion yuan, despite a 11.5% increase in revenue to 60.3 billion yuan. Higher fuel prices and lower international yields contributed to the decline, despite a 12.5% growth in revenue per kilometre. The airline expects 14.8% growth in outbound Chinese passengers in the second half, driven by a resurgence in global cargo traffic. The company faces pressure on international yields due to rapid capacity expansion and travel curbs enforced by Beijing.

site_title: EU moves to close share trading loophole
summary: The European Union has moved to close a loophole in its "MiFID II" law, which could have allowed banks to skirt transparency rules for share trading. The amendment, set to come into force in six months, pushes more trading onto regulated public platforms, tightening transparency requirements. This move aims to prevent banks from exploiting a loophole that could have undermined tougher regulations.

site_title: Singapore shares finish lower after North Korea fires missile over Japan
summary: A North Korean missile test on August 29, 2017, sparked geopolitical tensions, causing the Straits Times Index to drop 18.28 points to 3,249.34. The missile flew over Japan and landed in the Pacific, prompting Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to describe it as a "most serious and grave" threat. Safe-haven currencies, such as the euro, gained value, while US dollar futures dropped 144 points. The incident led to a low trading volume and a weak advance-decline score.

site_title: Z-Obee seeks delisting from SGX
summary: Z-Obee Holdings is seeking a voluntary delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to save on administrative and compliance costs. The firm has a primary listing on the Hong Kong Exchange and a secondary listing on SGX, with low trading volume on the latter. Z-Obee intends to carry out future fundraising activities through the Hong Kong Exchange, citing the lower costs and increased efficiency. The company's decision comes as part of a broader effort to optimize its operations and reduce expenses.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has de-safeguarded land previously allocated for Singapore's Underground Road System (SURS), allowing for redevelopment. Meanwhile, a report by Nielsen found that Singaporeans' concerns over the economy and job prospects eased in the second quarter. In international news, Vietnam expressed surprise over US tariffs, while the Asian garment industry braced for increased costs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Uber insures 450,000 India drivers against accidents
summary: Uber has launched a free insurance program for over 450,000 drivers in India, partnering with ICICI Lombard General Insurance to cover drivers against accidents. The policy includes accidental death, disablement, hospitalization, and medical treatment, with coverage limits of up to 500,000 rupees. This move comes as the ride-hailing company competes with local rival Ola, which recently introduced a medical benefits program for its drivers. Uber's initiative aims to attract more drivers and address their demands for accident insurance and better working conditions.

site_title: China says weather a factor in building roads along disputed India border
summary: China has stated that weather was a factor in building roads along the disputed India border, particularly in the Doklam plateau. The construction was intended for border protection and local livelihoods. After a two-month standoff, the two countries have ended the confrontation. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying confirmed that Chinese border troops are still patrolling the area, but did not provide details on the terms of disengagement. The development comes after India's troops intervened in June to stop China from building a road in the Doklam area, citing a threat to its northeast region's security.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop as North Korea fires missile
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined on Tuesday after North Korea launched a ballistic missile over Japan, sparking global alarm. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.7%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropped 0.8%, and Paris' CAC 40 declined 0.9%. Investors sought safe haven assets amid the escalation, which raised fears of a conflict. The missile test was the latest in a series of provocations testing US President Donald Trump and his counterparts, leading to a global response.

site_title: UK seeks to rein in boardroom pay with new corporate rules
summary: The UK government has proposed new corporate rules to rein in boardroom pay, requiring companies to justify the gap between average worker and CEO salaries. The plans, which will apply to all listed companies by June 2018, include publishing the CEO-to-worker pay ratio and encouraging companies to adopt stronger corporate governance arrangements. However, the proposals fall short of Prime Minister Theresa May's initial plan, which aimed to put workers on boards and give shareholders binding votes on executive pay. The plans have been welcomed by business lobby groups, but criticized by the Trades Union Congress as "bottled" due to business lobbying.

site_title: Singapore to grow 100 innovative enterprises through IP commercialisation
summary: Singapore has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Deloitte to grow 100 innovative enterprises through intellectual property (IP) commercialization. The partnership aims to build a strong base of innovation-driven companies that can become global market leaders. IPOS and Deloitte will focus on strengthening these enterprises' competitiveness through IP as a strategic business asset and helping them expand into international markets. The move reflects IPOS's efforts to build a vibrant innovation ecosystem and position Singapore as an IP and innovation hub.

site_title: Japan won't lower guard of whaling as Sea Shepherd changes tactics: official
summary: Japan will not lower its guard over its whaling despite the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society's statement that it won't disrupt its fleet this year due to limited resources. The Japanese government remains skeptical, citing concerns that the group's tactics could still be employed. Japan's whaling fleet took 333 minke whales in the Antarctic during the 2016-2017 season, and the country continues to claim its whaling is for scientific research purposes, with a long-term goal of commercial whaling. The Sea Shepherd's decision not to send ships to the Southern Ocean this year is seen as a strategic reevaluation.

site_title: Credit Suisse sued by billionaire in Singapore and New Zealand
summary: Credit Suisse has been sued by Georgian billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili in Singapore, New Zealand, and Bermuda, alleging the bank knew about a former employee's forgery of trades to cover losses. Ivanishvili filed the claims in Auckland on August 7, then in Bermuda 10 days later, and in Singapore on August 25. The lawsuits demand documents related to Ivanishvili's case against a Credit Suisse banker and unspecified claims for losses.

site_title: China's US$1t power industry overhaul is just starting
summary: China has created its first government-managed mega-merger, China Energy Investment, combining Shenhua Group and China Guodian to create the world's largest power company, valued at over $1 trillion. Analysts predict this is the beginning of a wave of massive consolidations in China's energy sector, aiming to cut industrial overcapacity and accelerate the overhaul of state-owned enterprises. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to reduce China's reliance on coal and expand the use of renewables and natural gas, with the goal of reshaping the power utility landscape.

site_title: Japan's economic recovery rivals past expansions, except for pay
summary: Japan's economy has seen six straight quarters of expansion, with a seventh on the way, making it the best performance since 2001. If this streak lasts, it will be the second-longest post-war expansion. However, despite the economic growth, workers have not seen significant improvements in pay, with average monthly wages rising only 0.4% in June and core consumer prices increasing 0.5% in July. Experts say the recovery feels "phony" due to a lack of demand compared to supply, and wages and inflation are struggling to rise.

site_title: Euro rises above US$1.20 for first time in more than 2 years
summary: The euro surpassed $1.20 for the first time in over 2 years, driven by risk-off sentiment and a desire for safe assets amid North Korea's ballistic missile launch. European bonds rallied, while US Treasuries and German yields declined. The euro's 14% gain against the US dollar this year is attributed to speculation of the European Central Bank scaling back quantitative easing measures. Analysts believe the euro will continue to rise, despite being overvalued by most indicators, as investors seek a haven from global uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.350 points to 1,761.140. Volume reached 1.456 billion lots worth RM1.831 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 622 to 274.

site_title: BOC Aviation H1 profit rises 13%
summary: BOC Aviation, Asia's second-largest aircraft lessor, reported a 13% rise in half-year net profit to US$240 million. The company expanded its fleet to 297 aircraft, with most deployed with Asian airlines such as Cathay Pacific Airways and Lion Air Group. BOC Aviation also changed its dividend policy to increase payouts to up to 35% of net profit, citing growing demand for travel and long-term revenue opportunities. This move underscores the region's importance to the airline industry, which accounts for 40% of the world's fleet.

site_title: Renault-Nissan to set up new China electric car venture with Dongfeng
summary: Nissan and Renault are launching a new electric car venture in China with Dongfeng Motor, as the country aims to make at least a fifth of its auto sales electric by 2025. The joint venture, eGT New Energy Automotive, will be owned 25% by Nissan and Renault, and 50% by Dongfeng. The companies will design a new electric vehicle on a subcompact crossover SUV platform. This move follows other global automakers, including Tesla, Daimler AG, and General Motors, as they prepare for China's stringent electric vehicle quotas.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor and its partner Renault will build electric cars in China in a new venture with Dongfeng Motor, as global automakers scramble to get ready for stringent electric vehicle quotas being introduced by the nation.

site_title: ST Electronics, Alpha Ori sign MOU to build smart fleet management system
summary: ST Electronics and Alpha Ori Technology Holdings signed a memorandum of understanding to develop a smart fleet management system, dubbed Starri, which aims to consolidate smart data and apply analytics to improve fleet management. The platform will provide ship owners and operators with smarter fleet management systems, enabling better resource allocation and improved fleet utilization. The two companies will also co-create a data analytics engine with machine learning solutions and anti-collision capabilities, while strengthening cyber security for shipborne systems.

site_title: UK house price growth cools to 3-month low in August
summary: UK house price growth cooled to a 3-month low in August, with Nationwide reporting a 2.1% year-on-year increase, down from 2.9% in July. This marks the slowest growth since May 2013. The slowdown is attributed to a squeeze on real wages and reduced mortgage rate declines, with prices expected to struggle to rise further due to inflation and decreased consumer confidence.

site_title: German students hit 201mph in SpaceX hyperloop contest
summary: A student team from Germany's Technical University of Munich achieved a record speed of 201mph in a hyperloop contest sponsored by SpaceX, surpassing a capsule built by Hyperloop One. The feat occurred during a test on a nearly one-mile track, exceeding the 192mph speed of Hyperloop One's previous test. The team used wheels instead of levitation technology, described by SpaceX executive Steve Davis as a "very fancy version of an electric car." The achievement marks a significant step towards Elon Musk's vision of a hyperloop transportation system, with SpaceX now moving ahead with plans to build its own system.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower after missile test
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.35% lower on Tuesday, following five consecutive gains, amid heightened geopolitical tensions fueled by North Korea's latest missile test. The Hang Seng Index fell to 27,765.01, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.08% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.24%. Traders were spooked by the fresh tensions, leading to a decline in Hong Kong's market.

site_title: Juncker warns Brexit divorce terms before trade ties
summary: European Commission head Jean-Claude Juncker warned that Britain must agree its divorce terms with the EU before discussing post-Brexit ties. Juncker stated that the UK's position papers were unsatisfactory, and that a March 2019 deadline for progress in three key areas (citizen rights, Northern Ireland's border, and the exit bill) looms. EU leaders will decide in October whether sufficient progress has been made, and the UK's demand for post-Brexit talks may be delayed. Juncker expressed disappointment with the British government's approach to negotiations, calling for flexibility and imagination.

site_title: North Korea's 'reckless' missile launch over Japan sharply escalates tension
summary: North Korea launched a ballistic missile over Japan's northern Hokkaido island into the sea, escalating tensions. The test, one of the most provocative ever, drew a sharp reaction from Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US President Donald Trump, who agreed to increase pressure on North Korea. The missile, believed to be an intermediate-range Hwasong-12, flew 2,700 km and reached an altitude of 550 km. The UN Security Council will meet to discuss the test, amid calls for China to ratchet up pressure on North Korea.

site_title: Taskforce set up to develop a common QR code for Singapore
summary: A taskforce co-led by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) aims to develop a common QR code for Singapore, known as SGQR, to facilitate domestic and international payments. The taskforce targets completion by the end of 2017, considering governance and implementation strategies. A common QR code would simplify payment transactions, making them swift, seamless, and safe for everyone, according to MAS Chairman Ravi Menon. The goal is to make the payments experience efficient for businesses and delightful for consumers, including the young and elderly.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend losses
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% on Tuesday, led by financials and healthcare stocks, amid escalating tensions on the Korean peninsula after North Korea fired a missile over northern Japan. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5669, extending its five-session losing streak. The financial sector, including Commonwealth Bank and CSL Ltd, dropped 1.2-1.3%, while gold miner Newcrest Mining Ltd rose 2.2% on rising gold prices. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 1.1% to a two-week low.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares fall on North Korea missile worries
summary: Australia and New Zealand shares fell on Tuesday, following global market declines due to North Korea's missile launch over northern Japan. The launch, which follows a threat to Guam, has heightened geopolitical tensions and investor worries. US stock futures also dropped sharply overnight, with investors concerned about the escalating tensions between the US and North Korea.

site_title: Thailand has no plan to revoke passports of former PM Yingluck, minister says
summary: Thailand's Foreign Minister stated there are no immediate plans to revoke former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra's passport, following her fleeing the country ahead of a court ruling in a negligence case. Yingluck, 50, who was Thailand's first female prime minister in 2011, skipped a hearing at the Supreme Court, with senior party members claiming she fled to Dubai. The decision not to revoke her passport indicates Thailand may not pursue extradition.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower after North Korea missile test
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.49% in the first few minutes of trade on Tuesday, August 29, 2017, following North Korea's ballistic missile test over northern Japan. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 27,727.41. Global tensions heightened the market's response, with other Asian markets also experiencing declines.

site_title: Ford, Domino's to test consumer appetite for robotic delivery service
summary: Domino's Pizza and Ford Motor Co are testing a robotic delivery service in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Customers will receive their pizzas in a heated compartment in a Ford Fusion driven by a company engineer. The goal is to examine how customers react to receiving their food at their doorstep, rather than having it delivered to their home. The trial will run for several weeks and will help Ford understand the business opportunity for autonomous vehicles to support the movement of people and goods.

site_title: LTA frees up land meant for Singapore Underground Road System
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has de-safeguarded land previously set aside for the Singapore Underground Road System (SURS), allowing for greater flexibility in development plans. The decision comes as Singapore shifts towards a car-lite society, with a comprehensive public transport network already in place and future projects such as the Thomson-East Coast Line and Circle Line Stage 6 set to improve connectivity. The need for SURS has been removed due to enhanced public transport and changes in land use policies.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia attorney generals ink MOU on cooperation
summary: Singapore's Attorney-General's Chambers and Indonesia's Attorney General's Office signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on cooperation, marking a milestone in their relationship. The MOU outlines training, experience exchange, and information sharing on laws and policies. It was signed by HM Prasetyo and Lucien Wong in Bali, Indonesia, during Wong's working visit. The agreement aims to enhance cooperation between the two countries' legal institutions.

site_title: BMW softens electric i3 city car's boxy look to counter Tesla
summary: BMW is revamping its electric i3 city car to counter Tesla's growing presence, with a sportier design and optional driver assistance systems. The updated i3 will have a wider track, elongated front end, and a less boxy rear end. The car will still have a limited driving range of about 100 miles per charge. BMW aims to boost sales of electric cars as the industry faces increased pressure to meet environmental rules and respond to Tesla's lower prices and longer range. The updated i3 will be available from November, with a sporty version boasting a top speed of 160 km/h.

site_title: GLP sells four properties in Japan for 51.6b yen
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has agreed to sell four properties in Japan for 51.6 billion yen (S$642.4 million), following its capital recycling strategy. The four 100% leased, single-tenant facilities total 206,000 square meters and equate to a weighted average cap rate of 4.5%. The sale price is 5% higher than the latest appraisal values.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks start the day lower
summary: Malaysia's stock market began the day lower, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 2.62 points to 1,766.87. The market saw a higher volume of 65.6 million lots worth RM37.2 million, with 156 losers outweighing 96 gainers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars falter on yen as risk-off sentiment dominates
summary: Australia's Australian dollar and New Zealand's New Zealand dollar plummeted to multi-week lows against the Japanese yen, dropping 0.9% and 0.8% respectively, amid escalating tensions over North Korea. The yen's safe-haven status drew investors, while riskier currencies like the Aussie and NZ dollar took a hit. The Australian dollar fell to 86.20 yen, its lowest since August 11, while the NZ dollar hit a level not seen since May 30. Market concerns over North Korea's missile launch and potential US tariffs also weighed on the currencies.

site_title: US, S Korea pledge tough response to Pyongyang's missile launch
summary: US and South Korean military officers agreed to a strong response to North Korea's latest ballistic missile launch, including unspecified military measures. The Joint Chiefs of Staff chairmen discussed response measures to demonstrate the alliance's strong will. There is no immediate plan to change joint military drills, but a response will be taken "at the earliest possible time."

site_title: 3 more NZ farms test positive for cattle disease
summary: New Zealand's Ministry for Primary Industries has reported three more farms testing positive for Mycoplasma bovis, a bacterial cattle disease, bringing the total to six. The affected farms belong to the Van Leeuwen Dairy Group and another unnamed South Island farm. The disease, common in many countries, poses no food safety risk or risk to humans, but can cause conditions like udder infection and pneumonia in affected cattle. The government is tracing and testing to prevent further spread, with no evidence of the disease spreading without close contact to infected animals.

site_title: Australia offers to train Philippine troops in IS fight
summary: Australia has offered to train the Philippine military to combat Islamic State militants in the southern city of Marawi, which has been besieged for almost 100 days. Foreign Minister Julie Bishop stated that Australia would provide advisory and training support, similar to what they are doing in Iraq, without deploying troops on the ground. The move comes as the threat of Islamic State in the southern Philippines is deemed "deeply concerning" by the international community, including the US, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The Philippines has declared martial law across Mindanao island in response to the crisis.

site_title: HSBC appoints ex-Barclays banker as head of commercial banking in Singapore
summary: HSBC appoints Alan Turner, a former Barclays London banker, as its new Head of Commercial Banking in Singapore, replacing Steven Cranwell. Turner will oversee large corporates, SMEs, and various finance solutions. He will report to Tony Cripps, CEO for HSBC in Singapore, and Stuart Tait, Head of Commercial Banking for Asia Pacific.

images.alt_text: Mr Turner will be responsible for HSBC's large corporates and Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) banking segments. He will also lead the bank's Global Trade and Receivables Finance, and Global Liquidity and Cash Management solutions businesses in Singapore.PHOTO:HSBC

site_title: Peru sees 'ambitious' trade deal with Australia as early as 2018
summary: Peru and Australia are set to finalize a "very ambitious" free trade deal covering goods, services, and investments as early as 2018, according to Peru's Deputy Trade Minister Edgar Vasquez. The deal comes after a successful first round of negotiations in July and is seen as a step towards reducing trade barriers in the Pacific region, following the US withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The agreement is expected to benefit sectors such as mining, agriculture, and professional services, with Peru aiming to increase exports to Australia.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls to 4-month low after North Korea fires missile
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell to a near four-month low, closing at 19,304.76 after North Korea fired a missile over northern Japan, sparking a sharp escalation of tensions on the Korean peninsula. The broader Topix also dropped 0.5% to 1,592.77. The move followed a series of North Korean missile tests, raising concerns about regional stability and global markets.

site_title: Google faces Tuesday deadline as clock ticks toward new EU fines
summary: Google faces a Tuesday deadline to propose how it plans to comply with an EU order to stop discriminating against rival shopping search services, with fines of up to 5% of daily revenue at risk. The European Commission gave Google 60 days to propose changes and 90 days to implement them by September 28. The deadline comes after a record 2.4 billion-euro penalty for violating antitrust laws. Regulators are also investigating Google's Android software and AdSense service, with further probes possible. Google has declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down after NK missile flies over Japan
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 0.45% on August 29, 2017, after North Korea launched a missile over Japan, prompting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to call it an "unprecedented, serious and grave threat." The Nikkei 225 index fell to 19,362.55, while the Topix index declined to 1,597.76. The launch heightened regional tensions and sparked concerns about global security.

site_title: Hollywood royalty and British monarchy to rub shoulders in Venice
summary: Hollywood stars and British royalty will converge in Venice for the 74th film festival, which kicks off on Wednesday. The festival features the world premiere of "Victoria & Abdul" and the opening slot of "Downsizing," both of which have the potential to boost international success. Legendary actors Robert Redford and Jane Fonda will receive lifetime achievement awards, while Judi Dench stars in "Victoria & Abdul" alongside Ali Fazal. The festival will run until September 9, with the Golden Lion award and other prizes to be announced.

site_title: S$35m boost for Singapore's clinical research coordinators
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has allocated S$35 million to fund the salaries of 100 clinical research coordinators (CRCs) for five years, along with national training and certification programs. This move aims to maintain a steady pipeline of qualified CRCs. The SCRI Academy, a virtual training platform, was also launched to house training efforts for CRCs. The first program under the academy is set to start by March 2018.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% down on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.3% lower on Tuesday, losing 10.42 points to 3,257.2, amid mixed US markets. The US energy and bank sectors were lower due to Tropical Storm Harvey, while tech and healthcare boosted the Nasdaq. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei and South Korea's Kospi also fell. Losers outnumbered gainers 88 to 41 on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: Facebook to reject ads from pages touting 'fake news'
summary: Facebook announced it will reject ads from pages that frequently share false news stories, a move aimed at combating "fake news" on its platform. The policy applies to pages that repeatedly share stories marked as false, and they will no longer be allowed to advertise on Facebook. This move is part of Facebook's ongoing efforts to address misinformation and deceive users.

site_title: Call to change, not tear down, Australia's colonial statues after several defaced
summary: Australia's colonial-era statues have been defaced, sparking debate over their removal. Following American protests over Confederate statues, Australians are re-examining the role of early British explorers, such as Captain James Cook, and the treatment of indigenous people. Calls for adding plaques acknowledging indigenous history have been made, with opposition Labor MP Linda Burney and leader Bill Shorten supporting updates to Captain Cook's plaque. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has rejected the idea, stating that changes would "reward vandalism" and instead advocate for building new monuments to reflect Australia's history.

site_title: Moon plans South Korea's biggest spending boost in a decade
summary: South Korea's government plans to spend a record 429 trillion won (S$380 billion) in 2018, a 7.1% increase from the initial plan, to boost welfare benefits and jobs. President Moon Jae-in aims to reduce inequality and shift the economy from export-led growth to one driven by higher income and consumption. The government expects the economy to grow at around 3% and maintain fiscal soundness. Revenue is expected to rise 7.9% and government debt will decrease to 39.6% of GDP.

site_title: Winding up of Rickmers Maritime completed, notes to delist on Aug 30
summary: Rickmers Maritime's winding up has been completed, with notes to be delisted on August 30. The trust's final distribution to unsecured creditors was completed on August 15, resulting in a 12.1% recovery. The outstanding amount due on the notes has been paid, and the trust has been wound up as of August 16. The notes trustee will credit the distribution amount to noteholders based on CDP records.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Geo Energy Resources, Keppel Corp, New Silkroutes
summary: Geo Energy Resources Limited set up a new unit to invest in an online e-commerce portal in Indonesia, its first non-coal related business venture. Keppel Corporation priced S$150 million in notes due 2023, while New Silkroutes Group reported a widened net loss of US$1 million in its fourth quarter, despite a 227.2% surge in revenue.

site_title: Asia: Stocks tumble, yen gains after North Korea fires missile over Japan
summary: North Korea fired a missile over northern Japan, prompting a sharp escalation of tensions on the Korean peninsula. US stock futures and Asian shares tumbled, while the yen jumped to four-month highs against the dollar. Japan's Nikkei fell to a four-month low, and South Korea's Kospi shed 0.5%. The incident is a rare instance of North Korea firing projectiles over mainland Japan, sparking concerns of a potential crisis.

site_title: Singaporeans' apprehension over economy, job prospects eases in Q2: Nielsen
summary: Singaporeans' apprehension over the economy and job prospects has eased in Q2, according to a Nielsen Global Survey. The consumer confidence index registered 89 points, down from 62% who thought the country was in an economic recession in Q4 2016. Job security and the economy remain top concerns, but perceptions of excellent job prospects have improved. The country's economy has seen steady growth, driven by manufacturing and services sectors, according to Nielsen's managing director Johan Vrancken.

site_title: Tim Cook reaps US$89.2m stock award as Apple outshines S&P
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook received a US$89.2 million stock award, half of which is performance-linked to the company's performance relative to the S&P 500 Index. This is his fourth consecutive payout at the top threshold, following Apple's 71% stock return over the past three years, ranking it in the 81st percentile among index members. Cook, 56, will receive the rest of the award as long as he remains on the job.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall, won sags on North Korea tensions
summary: South Korean stocks fell to a one-week low, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) down 1% at 2,347.63 points. The won also slumped 0.6% to 1,127.0 against the US dollar after North Korea fired a missile over Japan, escalating tensions on the Korean peninsula. The South Korean finance ministry will monitor markets and act to stabilize them if needed.

site_title: Japan's 'highway doctor' does checkup on ageing roads
summary: Japan's Metropolitan Expressway is using 3D technology to inspect its ageing roads. Cars equipped with cameras and laser sensors capture images of highways, which are then analyzed by desk-bound technicians using special software to create 3D images. This helps identify problems more quickly and efficiently, reducing the need for on-site inspections. The system also aims to address Japan's worker shortage, particularly among older workers. Testing of the system is underway in Thailand, with plans to export it globally.

site_title: US tech startup plans up to US$150m token sale for environmental credit market
summary: US tech startup Veridium Labs plans to raise up to $150 million by selling tokens backed by forest carbon offset credits and other environmental credits. The tokens will enable trading of assets tied to natural capital, estimated to be worth over $120 trillion. Veridium aims to make pricing more transparent and use blockchain technology to track assets. The startup will issue two types of tokens: VERIDIUM membership tokens and TGR tokens representing actual environmental mitigation credits.

site_title: Facebook's 21-year-old wunderkind Sayman leaves for Google
summary: Facebook's 21-year-old product manager, Sayman, is leaving for Alphabet Inc's Google. Sayman, who joined Facebook at 17 and became a product manager at 18, will work on Google's Assistant, a top priority for CEO Sundar Pichai. Sayman, who taught himself to code at 13, praised Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg as an "incredible inspiration" and "absolute pleasure to work with." He expressed his desire to help Google lower the barrier of entry for kids to learn programming. Sayman's departure marks a significant move within Facebook's young engineering talent.

site_title: European shares hit two-week low as euro surges
summary: European shares fell to a two-week low on Monday as the euro surged against the US dollar, with the Stoxx index declining 0.4% and the DAX index falling 0.3%. ECB chief Mario Draghi expressed no concern about a strong currency, contributing to the decline. Almost all sectors suffered losses, with materials and construction stocks leading the way. The euro reached its highest in over two years, weighing on stocks and prompting analysts to cut their target prices for some companies.

site_title: Geo Energy Resources to invest in online e-commerce portal in Indonesia
summary: Geo Energy Resources Limited, an Indonesian coal mining group, has set up a new unit, PT Geo Online Indonesia, to invest in an online e-commerce portal in Indonesia. The unit has an authorized capital of 10 billion rupiahs and will engage in e-commerce, IT, and communication businesses. The proposed investment aims to capitalize on Indonesia's growing online shopping demand, but discussions are still at a preliminary stage and no certainty exists that the investment will take place.

site_title: Changi scores 4.5% rise yoy in passenger traffic for July
summary: Changi Airport reported a 4.5% year-over-year increase in passenger traffic to 5.42 million in July, driven by double-digit growth in passenger traffic from India, Germany, the UAE, and the US. Aircraft movements rose 3.6% and airfreight throughput increased 11.2%. New restaurants, shops, and technology stores have also opened, catering to the growing number of passengers. With over 100 airlines operating at Changi, the airport remains a key hub connecting Singapore to 380 cities worldwide.

site_title: Uber's new CEO faces daunting fix-it list as crises abound
summary: Uber's new CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, faces a daunting list of challenges upon taking over the embattled global company. Crises abound, including a need to fill executive ranks, repair employee morale, and turn a profit. Khosrowshahi must also address controversies surrounding the company's culture, relations with drivers, and lawsuits, including a high-profile case involving a rape in India. Additionally, he will need to navigate a major investment deal with SoftBank and prepare for a potential exit.

site_title: China to build rental housing in suburbs
summary: China plans to launch pilot rental housing projects in 13 major cities, including Beijing and Shanghai, to address a housing supply shortage. The projects will be built in suburban areas, where land is collectively owned by rural villages, reducing the need to expropriate land. This move aims to ease the shortage and provide rental homes for megacities like Beijing.

images.alt_text: A worker at a Beijing construction site. The move to boost rental supply comes as China seeks to contain bubble risks in its hottest markets.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes little changed as Harvey pummels Texas
summary: US stocks closed little changed on Monday as Tropical Storm Harvey crippled the US energy hub in Texas, causing refinery shutdowns and flooding. Energy and bank shares fell, while tech and healthcare stocks rose. Despite the human drama and infrastructure devastation, market analysts believe a massive rebuilding effort will offset the negative economic consequences. Gold rose to its highest in nearly 10 months as investors sought safe-haven assets, while Home Depot and other companies likely to benefit from rebuilding efforts rose.

site_title: Thai online shopping binge is sign of Southeast Asia market size
summary: Thailand's online shopping has surged, with online retail sales growing over 100% in recent years, outpacing traditional stores. The country's strong internet speeds and social media usage, estimated at 6 hours a day, have contributed to this growth. While online sales in Southeast Asia still account for less than 4% of overall retail purchases, Maybank economists predict e-commerce sales could reach 5-10% over the next five years. This growth has caught the attention of Alibaba Group founder Jack Ma, who is involved in a government panel in Indonesia to steer the e-commerce industry in the region.

site_title: Houston races to rescue flood victims before storm's return
summary: US President Donald Trump pledged federal assistance to Texas as rescue teams scramble to reach hundreds of Texans stranded on flooded streets in and around Houston before monster storm Harvey returns. Since Sunday, six deaths have been confirmed, with more families still stranded or packed into emergency shelters. The 911 emergency line has received over 75,000 calls, and city officials urge residents to remain on the line for help. Dams have been opened to prevent a catastrophe on the outskirts of Houston, and the US Army Corps of Engineers anticipates that up to 500,000 people in Texas will be eligible for financial disaster assistance.

site_title: New Silkroute's Q4 loss widens to US$1m
summary: New Silkroutes Group reported a widened net loss of US$1 million for its fourth quarter, from a net loss of US$268,000 in the previous year. Revenue surged 227.2% to US$114.6 million, mainly due to its oil trading subsidiary. Loss per share narrowed to 1.382 US cents, and net asset value per share slipped to 27.081 US cents. No dividend was proposed, and shares ended unchanged at S$0.39.

site_title: S'pore well-positioned to reap gains in Belt & Road: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore is well-positioned to reap gains from China's One Belt, One Road initiative, said Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam. The country's competitive advantage lies in its good governance, educated population, and respected financial centre and port status. Singapore has actively supported the initiative, positioning itself for potential economic benefits.

site_title: Trump hints at Nafta withdrawal, says Mexico will pay for wall
summary: US President Donald Trump hinted at withdrawing from the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) and insisted Mexico will pay for a border wall. Trump criticized Mexico for being "difficult" in talks to rework the trade deal, suggesting that terminating Nafta could be necessary for a fair agreement. He also reiterated his claim that Mexico will ultimately pay for the wall, despite repeated denials from Mexico. Trump's comments come as he struggles to convince Congress to fund the wall.

site_title: Mark Zuckerberg welcomes second daughter in Facebook post
summary: Mark Zuckerberg and his wife Priscilla Chan welcomed their second daughter, August, on August 28, 2017. The couple shared a letter with their daughter, emphasizing the importance of enjoying childhood and not worrying too much about the future. This is similar to the letter they wrote after the birth of their first daughter, Maxima, in 2015.

site_title: Keppel Land prices S$150m, 2.843% notes due in 2023
summary: Keppel Land Limited priced S$150 million in 2.843% notes due 2023, with a fixed interest rate and semi-annual payments. The notes will be issued at 100% of principal, with denominations of S$250,000. The net proceeds will be used to refinance existing debts, finance acquisition opportunities, and cover general corporate and working capital needs. United Overseas Bank Limited has been appointed as the sole lead manager for the issue.

site_title: US judge blocks new movie about Lynyrd Skynyrd
summary: A US judge has blocked the production and distribution of a movie about Lynyrd Skynyrd's 1977 plane crash, citing a 1988 consent order governing the use of the band's name. The lawsuit, brought by surviving members, alleged that the film would cause irreparable harm by destroying their right to use the band's name and history. Judge Robert Sweet ruled that the movie's depiction of the crash and its use of the Lynyrd Skynyrd name violated the consent order. The decision prevents the movie, "Street Survivors: The True Story of the Lynyrd Skynyrd Plane Crash," from being released.

site_title: Singapore home sales surge even as foreign demand stays subdued
summary: Singapore's home sales surged 50% in the first seven months of the year, with 7,147 private homes sold, driven primarily by local Singaporeans. Foreign buyers accounted for just 6% of purchases, down from 9% in 2013, due to stringent stamp duties. The rebound in local demand is attributed to the government's efforts to dampen speculative foreign demand.

site_title: SPH launches two new education platforms, ZBSchools.sg and NewsEd
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) launches two new education platforms, ZBSchools.sg and NewsEd. ZBSchools.sg is an adaptive learning platform for students and teachers to track progress, while NewsEd provides bite-sized learning activities for young people to engage with the news and learn English values and 21st-century competencies. The platforms will be rolled out for primary and secondary students, and high-progressing primary schoolers, respectively. The platforms aim to make learning Chinese and English more interactive and engaging.

site_title: Merkel warns UK it'll have to pay EU obligations in Brexit
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel warned the UK that it must pay its outstanding EU obligations as part of Brexit talks, stating it's not about the cost of divorce but rather about fulfilling existing commitments. Merkel emphasized that the UK's obligations must remain on the EU's books, contradicting the UK's view that it should only pay a "divorce bill." The comments came as Brexit negotiations are still in their early stages.

site_title: US dollar hits 4-month low vs yen after North Korea ballistic missile launch
summary: The US dollar dropped to a four-month low against the yen after North Korea launched a ballistic missile that passed over northern Japan. The dollar was down 0.5% at 108.725 yen, its lowest since April 18. This move comes as the US dollar was already under pressure due to Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's silence on monetary policy at a recent central bankers' summit and European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's reluctance to talk down the euro.

site_title: US gasoline price jumps, crude falls as Harvey hits refiners
summary: US gasoline prices surged to two-year highs as Tropical Storm Harvey knocked out several refineries and disrupted fuel production, while crude oil futures fell due to reduced demand. Gasoline inventories could decline rapidly if refineries shut down, prompting a 7% surge in spot prices. The Motiva Port Arthur refinery in Texas, the country's largest, is considering a shutdown due to flooding. US crude futures fell 2.7% to $46.57 per barrel, while Brent crude futures fell 1% to $51.89 per barrel.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics Q4 profit up 61% on global semiconductor industry boom
summary: Micro-Mechanics, a Singapore-listed semiconductor industry maker, reported a 60.9% increase in net profit to S$4.6 million in its Q4 fiscal year 2017, driven by a 19.5% revenue growth to S$15.4 million. The company attributed the growth to the strong expansion of the global semiconductor industry.

site_title: ExxonMobil completes acquisition of Jurong Aromatics plant
summary: ExxonMobil has completed its acquisition of Jurong Aromatics Corporation's (JAC) Jurong Island plant in Singapore, one of the largest aromatics facilities worldwide. The deal was valued at approximately US$1.7 billion and will boost ExxonMobil's Singapore aromatics production to over 3.5 million tonnes per year. The acquisition will also add 65,000 barrels per day of transportation fuels capacity, enhancing ExxonMobil's ability to serve customers in key Asian growth markets and solidify Singapore's position as a global trade hub.

site_title: Harvey leaves Houston crippled by floods
summary: Hurricane Harvey has paralyzed Houston, Texas, with catastrophic flooding, killing at least two people. The storm, the most powerful to hit Texas in over 50 years, has dumped a year's worth of rain in a week, causing widespread destruction and evacuations. Over 50,000 people have been ordered to leave their homes, and the city's infrastructure, including schools, airports, and office buildings, has been shut down. Total precipitation is forecast to reach 50 inches in some coastal areas, and federal relief efforts have been triggered, with US President Donald Trump planning to survey damage on Tuesday.

site_title: Sinopec rides chemicals to best half-year profit since 2014
