site_title: Sterling bounces after Yellen speech though outlook bleak
summary: Sterling rose to its highest level in four days after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech, despite a bleak outlook. Yellen focused on US financial reforms, not monetary policy, sending sterling 0.7% higher to US$1.2875. Analysts warn the currency remains under pressure due to economic disparities between the UK and eurozone. The pound is down 2.5% in August and 5% against the euro since mid-July. Formal EU exit discussions are ongoing, with the government issuing position papers on potential compromises.

site_title: Netflix like a pro
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

As the Chinese Ghost Festival approaches, Netflix users may spend more time binge-watching due to the holiday's cultural significance. To enhance the viewing experience, Netflix users can utilize keyboard shortcuts, download extensions like Flix Assist and Netflix Party, and explore hyper-specific genres on a comprehensive list. Additionally, Netflix has introduced a unique feature called Netflix Socks, which can detect when a user falls asleep and pause the show, using actigraphy technology. These hacks aim to make binge-watching easier and more enjoyable for users. The features can be found on the Netflix platform.

site_title: S'pore shares await Fed's guiding light to escape Jackson Hole fog
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% higher on Friday, despite a decline in trading activity, as investors awaited guidance from the US Federal Reserve's Janet Yellen and European Central Bank's Mario Draghi at the Jackson Hole symposium. The market had previously consolidated ahead of the speeches, with tepid inflation expectations dampening expectations for a December rate hike. Analysts expect Draghi's speech to have significant impact on the forex, stocks, and bond markets, and cautious investors sold bank stocks, while property and investment group Rowsley gained 1.7%.

site_title: Thakral surges 14% after acceptance of bid for HK properties
summary: Thakral Corp's shares surged 14% after accepting a HK$420 million (S$73 million) bid for its Hong Kong warehouse properties. The counter closed at 58 Singapore cents, with the buyer paying a HK$20 million deposit and expected to complete the sale by late November. The sale is expected to lift the group's net tangible asset per share to S$1.02 and earnings per share to 26.04 Singapore cents, with a profit of some HK$192 million anticipated.

site_title: Singapore shares close week on down note; STI slips 0.38% to 3,259.57
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.38% to 3,259.57 on Friday, amidst light volumes. The Straits Times Index declined despite a slight majority of gainers over losers. Banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB slid due to anticipation of central banker speeches. The market remained steady ahead of GDP data.

site_title: ST Engineering picks up rig repair assets in the US for US$25 million
summary: ST Engineering has acquired rig repair assets in Pascagoula, Mississippi, for US$25 million. The assets, previously owned by World Marine of Mississippi LLC, include a 94-acre facility for heavy marine fabrication and offshore oil and gas repairs. The acquisition aims to enhance ST Engineering's capabilities and scale advantages in the marine repair segment. The purchase was funded internally and is expected to have minimal impact on the company's consolidated net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Metech International's Q4 profit rockets to S$391,000 from loss in previous year
summary: Metech International Ltd reported a significant turnaround in its Q4 financials, with a net profit of S$391,000, reversing a net loss of S$2.2 million in the previous year. Revenue surged 304.2% to S$41.6 million, and earnings per share improved to 0.0093 Singapore cents from a loss of 0.0533 cents. The company attributed the improvement to successful operational restructuring and diversification efforts started three financial years ago.

site_title: SPH divests stakes in Mediacorp entities
summary: SPH divests 20% stake in Mediacorp TV Holdings and 40% stake in Mediacorp Press for S$18 million, expected to be completed at the end of September. The transaction is part of a rationalisation plan, allowing SPH to focus on its core media business. The divestment follows Mediacorp's decision to turn Today into a fully digital product. SPH will record a writedown of S$31 million in its books.

site_title: Imperium Crown's FY results still bogged in red ink with S$6.7m loss
summary: Imperium Crown, a CATALIST-LISTED real estate developer, reported a net loss of S$6.7 million for the 12 months ended June 30, compared to S$12.4 million in the previous year. Revenue grew 2.6% to S$4.9 million, driven by increased revenue from Tokyo's Hatchobori Place office property. The company continues to undergo transformation, focusing on divesting Japanese properties and reallocating capital to new projects. Executive Chairman and CEO Wan Jinn Woei stated the company will look for strategic partnerships to unlock value for shareholders.

site_title: Repeat of 2008 rout not likely, says hedge fund veteran
summary: Hedge fund veteran Stephen Diggle says a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis is unlikely due to central banks' efforts to dampen price swings. Despite increased algorithmic trading, Diggle believes a "super spike" in volatility is unlikely, citing low volatility levels and complacency. His fund, Vulpes Investment Management, has avoided betting on volatility and is instead focusing on long-term investments in UK biotechnology firms, a New Zealand avocado orchard, and German real estate, which have returned 63% and 63% this year, respectively.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.330 points to 1,769.170. The market saw 2.005 billion lots traded worth RM1.934 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 323 to 546.

site_title: Sunseap, ST Kinetics ink solar energy agreement
summary: Sunseap Group, a solar energy system developer, has signed an agreement with ST Kinetics to provide solar power for 25 years. A 4.7 MWp solar photovoltaic system will be installed, generating up to 6.2 gigawatt-hours of energy annually and reducing ST Kinetics' carbon footprint by 2,633 tonnes. This deal is Sunseap's third largest and comes as Singapore aims to increase its solar power capacity, with the government setting a target of 1 gigawatt-peak beyond 2020.

images.alt_text: Solar panels on the rooftops of HDB blocks in Jurong, which are among the buildings Sunseap uses to supply clean energy to Apple's Singapore operations.

site_title: US:Wall St opens higher on tax reform talks, Yellen speech eyed
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech, with concerns on tax reforms fading after President Donald Trump plans to focus on the long-awaited campaign promise next week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 60.62 points, or 0.28%, to 21,844.02, while the S&P 500 gained 7.62 points, or 0.31%, to 2,446.59. Investors are awaiting Yellen's speech for clues on monetary policy, including the timing of the Fed's bond unwinding and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: ICP's FY earnings still mired in red ink with S$2.7m loss; revenue expands 6.8% to S$2.1m
summary: ICP Ltd reported a net loss of S$2.72 million for its FY, down from a net loss of S$3.92 million in the previous year. Revenue grew 6.8% to S$2.1 million, driven by higher sales in the hospitality division. Loss per share narrowed to 0.10 Singapore cent, and net asset value per share declined to 1.14 Singapore cents. The company's shares closed S$0.001 lower at S$0.008.

site_title: US sales of previously owned homes decline to 11-month low
summary: US sales of previously owned homes declined to an 11-month low in July, reaching 4.33 million, due to a limited inventory of properties for sale and rising prices. This slowdown is attributed to a shortage of homes, which is keeping home-price growth above wage gains, leaving prospective buyers with fewer choices. Despite this, the housing market is expected to continue its gradual progress, driven by solid hiring and low borrowing costs. The National Association of Realtors' chief economist, Lawrence Yun, attributes the issue to an inventory shortage, which is preventing prices from aligning with wage growth.

site_title: Malaysia's AMMB, RHB Bank to end merger talks
summary: RHB Bank Bhd and AMMB Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's fourth-largest lender, have ended merger talks due to difficulty in reaching agreement on terms. The proposed all-share deal was expected to be announced as early as Tuesday, but shares of both lenders were suspended from trading pending material announcements. This decision comes more than two years after a previous merger plan involving RHB and CIMB Group Holdings Bhd fell apart. The central bank has been encouraging consolidation among local lenders to create larger entities that can better compete regionally.

site_title: Classic love story
summary: David Chan, a 72-year-old Singaporean, has spent his life around classic cars, restoring and racing British makes like MG and Lotus. He still owns the car his grandfather gifted him at 18, an early-model Austin-Healey Sprite, and runs a small garage, David Works Garage, with his son Brian. The family business specializes in servicing and restoring classic cars, with a focus on bonding and preserving motoring heritage. Chan credits his grandfather, a motorsports hero, as the major influence on his life, and his son Brian has followed in his footsteps, inheriting a Mini Cooper and finding love through his cars.

site_title: Colour power
summary: Hillary Clinton, a long-time fan of fashion designer Nina McLemore, has credited colour with changing her attractiveness and how people see her in the boardroom. Clinton's wardrobe features bold and vibrant pieces, such as a turquoise jacket, fuschia blazer, and canary yellow pantsuit, which she has worn for high-profile events. According to McLemore, "colour can change your attractiveness entirely," and Clinton's use of colour is a key part of her personal and professional style.

site_title: Europe: Shares inched higher ahead of Jackson Hole meet
summary: European shares rose 0.2% ahead of the Jackson Hole meeting, driven by gains in financials and Fiat Chrysler. Ahold fell 5% after Amazon cut prices on Whole Foods, a US supermarket with a strong Dutch presence. The retail index fell 0.8%, with Casino and Carrefour also declining. Meanwhile, Provident Financial rose 8.2% after replacing its home credit business manager.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise for fourth-straight day
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for the fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 1.20% to 27,848.16. The rally was driven by energy firms following PetroChina's profit surge and its promise to distribute it to shareholders. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with gains of 1.83% and 1.04%, respectively. The market's momentum is seen as a positive sign, despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output surged 21% in July, exceeding market expectations. The government is seeking e-payment solutions for hawker centres and coffee shops, while studying the possibility of selling larger land parcels in Jurong Lake District. SPH divested its stakes in Mediacorp entities, and Malaysia's Sime Darby reported a Q4 profit decline due to weak industrial segments. Ex-PM Yingluck Shinawatra fled Thailand, and Samsung heir Jay Y Lee was sentenced to five years in prison on graft conviction.

site_title: Update: Ex-PM Yingluck has fled the country - sources
summary: Ousted former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra has fled the country, sources close to her confirmed on Friday. The move comes after the Supreme Court issued an arrest warrant for her failure to attend the court for a negligence case brought by the ruling junta. Yingluck had failed to appear for the verdict, which was set for Friday. The exact location of her current whereabouts is not disclosed. This development comes amid ongoing tensions between Yingluck's supporters and the Thai government.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise for 4th day despite jailing of Samsung boss, won flat
summary: South Korean shares rose for a fourth consecutive day, closing 0.1% higher at 2,378.51 points, despite the jailing of Samsung Group's billionaire head Jay Y Lee for five years. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) gained 0.9% for the week, driven by easing tensions between North Korea and the US. Samsung Electronics fell 1.1% but recovered from its lows. The South Korean won ended flat, awaiting speeches from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and European Central Bank President Mario Draghi.

site_title: US core capital goods orders rise, shipments surge
summary: US capital goods orders rose 0.4% in July, exceeding expectations, as shipments surged 1.0% after a 0.6% increase in June. This indicates business spending is accelerating early in the third quarter, despite uncertainty over tax cuts. Shipments of core capital goods added 0.44 percentage points to the economy's 2.6% annualized growth pace in the second quarter, buoyed by the energy sector. However, orders for machinery and durable goods fell, with the latter dropping 6.8% due to a decline in transportation equipment bookings.

site_title: Thailand's deputy PM says unclear if Yingluck has fled country
summary: Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister Prawit Wongsuwan expressed uncertainty about former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra's whereabouts after she failed to attend a Supreme Court hearing on a negligence case. The court set a new date for the verdict on September 27 and will seek an arrest warrant for Yingluck, who could face up to 10 years in jail if found guilty. Yingluck had claimed she was suffering from an ear problem, but it is unclear if she has fled the country or is at a hospital.

site_title: Some takeaways from the Global Financial Crisis of 2007
summary: The article discusses the 2007 Global Financial Crisis (GFC), which began with financial markets taking notice in August 2007, and eventually led to a 55% decline into March 2009. The article highlights key takeaways for investors, including the cyclical nature of financial crises, the importance of productivity gains, and the impact of de-dollarisation and shifting safe havens. While signs of the next recession may seem far off, the article notes that the bubble-and-crash cycle will likely repeat itself.

site_title: German business confidence dips slightly in August: Ifo
summary: German business confidence fell to 115.9 points in August, dipping slightly from a record high in July, according to the Ifo institute. This beat analyst expectations of a decline to 115.7 points. The slight decline is still a positive indicator of future performance in Europe's powerhouse, Germany.

site_title: Higher home prices risk closing door on US housing momentum
summary: US home sales unexpectedly fell to an 11-month low in July, with new home sales at their weakest this year. The median time on the market for existing properties remains at 30 days, indicating resilient demand, but the number of listings remains lean. Rising home prices are outpacing wage growth, making affordability a concern, with the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller nationwide home-price index at a record high. Experts warn that this trend may choke off buyers, but some see it as a pause in early-year momentum.

site_title: Sime Darby on track to list plantation, property businesses by year-end
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Bhd, the world's largest oil palm planter, is on track to list its plantations and property businesses by year-end. The conglomerate plans to restructure and transfer assets to create three standalone units, with Sime Darby Plantation and Sime Darby Property expected to seek admission into Bursa Malaysia. The restructuring includes issuing new shares and settling inter-company loans, with the company's net profit for the fourth quarter more than halving to 571 million ringgit.

site_title: WeWork wins US$4.4b SoftBank xpansion
summary: WeWork has secured a US$4.4 billion investment from SoftBank Group's Vision Fund, part of its aggressive global expansion plan. The investment includes US$3 billion to buy shares from WeWork and current shareholders, and US$1.4 billion for three Asia-focused subsidiaries. WeWork's valuation has increased to around US$20 billion, making it one of the world's five most-valuable tech startups. The deal aims to quickly gain a foothold in Asia before homegrown competitors can take over, similar to SoftBank's approach with Uber in China.

site_title: Silverlake Axis Q4 profit falls 58%; declares final and special dividends
summary: Silverlake Axis Ltd reported a 58% decline in Q4 FY2017 profit to RM32.7 million, due to customers deferring and reducing IT capital expenditures amid regional uncertainties. The company's group revenue fell 25% to RM124.9 million. Despite this, Silverlake declared final and special dividends of 0.3 and 1.0 Singapore cents per share, respectively, to return gains from the sale of shares in Global Infotech Co Ltd. The company expects to deploy proceeds towards payment of special dividends and acquisitions to expand its fintech and insuretech software products.

site_title: Second missing warship sailor identified from remains found by US divers
summary: US Navy and Marine Corps divers have identified the remains of a second missing sailor from an American warship that collided with a tanker earlier this week. This is the second sailor to be found and identified, following the discovery of the first missing sailor's remains. The incident occurred on a US warship, but no further information on the incident is provided in the article.

images.alt_text: United States Navy and Marine Corps divers have found and identified the remains of one of the missing sailors of an American warship which collided with a tanker earlier in the week.

site_title: Higher home prices risk closing door on US housing momentum
summary: Rising US home prices are threatening to temper the momentum in residential real estate, with purchases of previously owned houses falling to an 11-month low in July. Limited inventory remains a primary reason for home price growth outpacing wage growth, making affordability its weakest point in the expansion. The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller nationwide home-price index reached a record in May, while the cost of a previously owned home in June also reached an all-time high. Experts warn that if home-price growth continues to outpace income growth, it could choke off buyers and slow down the housing market.

site_title: Surge in air cargo demand adds heft to Asian airline earnings
summary: Asian airlines are experiencing a surge in air cargo demand, bolstering earnings and outperforming passenger operations. The region accounts for nearly 40% of the global air freight market, driven by Asia's manufacturing hub. Global air cargo volumes surged 10.4% in the first half, with Cathay Pacific and Korean Air seeing significant increases in cargo revenue. The boom in air freight is expected to continue, driven by e-commerce growth and pharmaceutical companies' shift to air transportation for safer cold storage.

site_title: Citi sees the sun rising in Japan even as inflation stays tepid
summary: Citigroup has upgraded its 2017 growth forecast for Japan's economy from 1.6% to 2%, citing robust second-quarter growth. However, the bank expects core inflation to remain below 1% in the years to come, preventing the Bank of Japan from raising short-term policy rates. Despite the economy showing traction after decades of stagnation, core inflation accelerated to a tepid 0.5% in July, short of the BOJ's two per cent target. This divergence puzzles economists, as faster growth typically leads to higher prices.

site_title: Who are the Shinawatras and why are they so polarising?
summary: Thailand's ousted Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra failed to appear for her verdict, sparking an arrest warrant and speculation about her whereabouts. The Shinawatra family, led by Yingluck's brother Thaksin, has been at the center of Thailand's current political divide. Thaksin, a former telecoms tycoon and prime minister, was ousted in 2006 and now lives overseas to avoid jail for corruption. The Shinawatras' popularity stems from their pro-poor policies, but they are also criticized for corruption, authoritarianism, and enriching themselves. The family's influence has been curbed through coups and courts, and they face significant legal challenges, potentially marking the end of the Shinawatra clan's leading role in Thai politics.

site_title: Shell joins solar push in coal country of world's top exporter
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is investigating a solar power project in Australia's Western Downs region, a coal country, to develop a 250-megawatt Delga Solar Farm project. The project is part of Shell's $1 billion annual investment in New Energies division and will partner with Sunseap Group to invest in solar in the Asia Pacific. This follows a record-breaking 12 months of investment in Australia's large-scale solar sector, driven by falling technology costs and surging electricity prices.

site_title: Singapore government seeks e-payment solutions at hawker centres, coffee shops
summary: The Singapore government is seeking electronic payment solutions for hawker centres, coffee shops, and heartland shops. Four government agencies, including the National Environment Agency and the Monetary Authority of Singapore, have issued a Request for Information (RFI) for e-payment solutions. The goal is to make payments easy, convenient, and affordable for merchants and customers. The solution must also be suitable for low-value transactions. The agencies are crowd-sourcing views and ideas from the private sector to co-create a solution that improves lives and supports Singapore's drive towards a cashless society.

site_title: Loyal supporters of ousted South Korean president root for Samsung leader
summary: Hundreds of loyal supporters of ousted South Korean President Park Geun-Hye rallied outside a court on Friday, demanding the acquittal of Samsung Group leader Jay Y Lee, who faces bribery charges that could lead to Park's conviction. The supporters, mostly older women and men, believe that Lee's conviction would be a miscarriage of justice and that the trials of Park and Lee are "hand in hand." A ruling on Lee's case is expected, with Park's trial set for October.

site_title: Price slump, tight cash wreak havoc in Canada's top housing market
summary: Canada's top housing market, Toronto, is experiencing chaos due to a sharp price slump and tight cash, with buyers desperate to get out of deals. Lenders have tightened credit, and property appraisers have lowered valuations, resulting in smaller loan amounts and increased financial strain for buyers. Up to 5% of deals are at risk, and real estate agents, lawyers, and mortgage brokers struggle to cope with the new reality. The market has cooled significantly, with Toronto home prices down 19% from the April peak, and resales 40% lower than a year earlier.

site_title: Australia shares end little changed despite weak banks, property; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares finished nearly flat on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index ending down 0.03% at 5,743.90. Energy stocks rose 1.3%, offsetting losses in banks and real estate. Westpac Banking fell 1.1%, while Scentre Group plummeted 3.1%. In contrast, shares of Santos Ltd and Qantas Airways Ltd rose 3.7% and 3.8%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.14%.

site_title: Samsung heir sentenced to five years prison on graft conviction
summary: Jay Y Lee, vice chairman of Samsung Electronics, was convicted of bribery, perjury, and embezzlement and sentenced to five years in prison by a Seoul Central District Court. The ruling casts doubt on Lee's return to the conglomerate he inherited from his grandfather. This case, known as the "Trial of the Century," highlighted the interaction between South Korea's chaebol and the political elite, with prosecutors linking backing for a merger to money paid to a confidante of President Park Geun Hye.

site_title: Unwanted statues of a defeated general? Taiwan has the answer
summary: Taiwan has created a park featuring over 200 unwanted statues of Chiang Kai-Shek, a former nationalist leader and dictator, by relocating them from schools and government buildings. The Cihu Memorial Statues Park has become a popular tourist spot, with visitors from both Taiwan and China, with some viewing Chiang as a hero who fought against Japanese imperialism, while others see him as a divisive figure. The relocated statues have lost their partisan edge, and the park offers a serene contrast to the controversy surrounding Confederate monuments in the US.

site_title: PBOC drains most funds since June even as money costs climb
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, drained 330 billion yuan (S$67.455 billion) from the financial system in open-market operations, the largest since June 30. This move, combined with a lack of reverse-repurchase agreements, has raised concerns over tight liquidity ahead of quarter-end demand. The one-week Shanghai Interbank Offered Rate reached 2.91%, the highest since June 23, and lending costs have increased for banks. The PBOC maintains liquidity is at a "moderate" level and plans to offset maturities with fiscal spending and reserve releases.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as automakers post gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday as Toyota and Honda posted gains, with the Nikkei 225 index increasing 0.51% to close at 19,452.61. The broader Topix index also rose 0.30%. Investors are awaiting a meeting of top central bankers later in the day, but the gains were largely driven by the automakers' performances.

site_title: Chinese government debt risks under control
summary: China's government debt risks are generally under control, according to a report by the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. The report found that overall liabilities rose 70% from 2010 to 2015, reaching 70 trillion yuan, but the government is able to effectively cope with debt risks. The report's estimate of liabilities is considered the upper limit, including all shortfalls and contingent debts. The assets of the Chinese government exceeded 125 trillion yuan in 2015, providing a cushion against potential debt issues.

site_title: Flash: SPH to divest stakes in Mediacorp entities
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) plans to divest its stakes in Mediacorp entities, a move that has not been explained by the company. The divestment comes as SPH focuses on its digital transformation and expansion into new areas. The decision marks a significant shift in the media landscape in Singapore. The divestment details are expected to be revealed in a full story.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges down, stocks rise as Samsung verdict looms
summary: The South Korean won decreased slightly, while stocks rose 0.2% on the Korea Composite Stock Price Index, as investors await the verdict in the bribery trial of Samsung Electronics vice chairman Jay Y. Lee. Samsung Electronics shares fell 0.7%, despite the company's strong performance, due to concerns about a possible conviction and leadership vacuum. Other Samsung group shares rose, including Samsung Biologic and Samsung Heavy, which won an order worth 309 billion won.

site_title: Asia: Stocks resilient, US dollar up before Yellen, Draghi speeches
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday, driven by a resilient market despite a sluggish US day, and the US dollar strengthened ahead of central bankers' speeches in Jackson Hole. The US dollar index rose 0.1% and the euro declined 0.3% as investors await comments from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and European Central Bank President Mario Draghi. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index was up 0.1% and the US dollar was supported by lower-than-expected jobless claims and rising oil prices.

site_title: Japan automaker Subaru cuts profit forecast on mounting Takata recall costs
summary: Subaru has cut its full-year profit forecast by a fifth due to mounting costs from the global Takata airbag recall. The company expects a special loss of 81.3 billion yen and now forecasts a net profit of 228.5 billion yen, down from a previous estimate of 285.0 billion yen. Recall-related costs are estimated to total 154.8 billion yen, affecting around 4.7 million inflators. Takata, the supplier, has filed for bankruptcy, and Subaru expects to incur a special loss as it cannot claim compensation from the company.

site_title: Smartphone maker HTC is said to explore strategic options
summary: HTC, a struggling smartphone manufacturer, is exploring strategic options including selling its virtual-reality business or spinning it off, according to people familiar with the matter. The company is working with an adviser to consider bringing in a strategic investor or selling its Vive headset business. Shares jumped 8.5% in Friday trading, marking the highest level in three weeks, as the company attempts to refocus on its high-end VR business and recover from a 75% decline in value over the past five years.

site_title: Singapore factory output surges 21% in July, exceeds market expectations
summary: Singapore's factory output surged 21% in July, exceeding market expectations, driven by strong growth in the electronics and precision engineering clusters. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output grew 24.9% year on year. The electronics cluster led the charge with a 49.1% growth, while precision engineering grew 21.8%. Biomedical manufacturing also saw a 5% increase, with medical technology segment rising 17.7%. The growth momentum was maintained with month-on-month manufacturing output expanding 1% seasonally-adjusted.

site_title: US dollar supported as spotlight falls on monetary policy, inflation puzzle
summary: The US dollar gained 0.5% against the yen overnight, driven by speculation of central bankers' discussions at the Jackson Hole meeting, where Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and European Central Bank President Mario Draghi are expected to provide insights into monetary policy. Investors are seeking clues on further US rate hikes and balance sheet tapering. Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.5% in July, but the gain was weak, and the yen showed little reaction. The euro was 0.05% lower, awaiting Draghi's speech, which is expected to provide few hints before the ECB's next policy review on September 7.

site_title: South Korea's S-Oil signs LNG contract with Malaysia's Petronas for 2018-2033
summary: South Korea's S-Oil Corp signed a 15-year LNG supply contract with Malaysia's Petronas starting from 2018, purchasing 700,000 tonnes of LNG per year. The deal aims to ensure stable supplies of LNG and is part of S-Oil's expansion project, which includes building a residual fuel oil upgrading system and an olefin production system. The company plans to use LNG as fuel and feedstock for petrochemical products, increasing profitability with its expanded facilities set to start operations in 2018.

site_title: NZD posts worst week in 4 months on election jitters; AUD muted
summary: The New Zealand dollar (NZD) is experiencing its worst week in four months due to election jitters ahead of a hotly-contested election between Labour leader Jacinda Ardern and Prime Minister Bill English. The NZD has fallen more than two percent this week, its fourth consecutive week of losses. The Australian dollar (AUD) has also had a lacklustre week, dipping 0.3 percent. Traders are awaiting monetary policy clues from the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium, where US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and European Central Bank President Mario Draghi are set to speak.

site_title: Gold steady ahead of central bank speeches at Jackson Hole
summary: Gold prices remained steady ahead of central bank speeches at Jackson Hole, with spot gold unchanged at US$1,286.48 an ounce. Investors will closely watch comments from Fed Chair Janet Yellen and ECB President Mario Draghi for clues on monetary policy and interest rates. Rising US interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, boosting the US dollar, which negatively impacts gold prices. Geopolitical concerns, including US-China tensions, also support gold prices, with net gold imports in China increasing 2.3% in July.

site_title: Go fetch! Drones help Swiss rescue dogs find the missing
summary: Swiss rescue teams are using drones to aid in search-and-rescue missions, particularly in areas inaccessible to dogs and handlers. The drones, equipped with high-definition and infrared cameras, can quickly survey flat areas while dogs search in wooded terrain. Since partnering with the Swiss Association for Search and Rescue Dogs, drone teams have assisted with 12 out of 22 missions, saving time and increasing efficiency. The goal is to deploy drones on all missions, with the potential to reduce costs by avoiding costly helicopter deployments.

site_title: Hot stock: Beauty specialist Mary Chia Holdings' shares get a lift
summary: Mary Chia Holdings' shares surged 73% to 11.6 Singapore cents after a mandatory takeover bid of 11.1 Singapore cents by Suki Sushi. Trading volume reached one million shares worth S$113,000.

site_title: Hong Kong pro-independence duo lose appeal over council seats
summary: Hong Kong's highest court dismissed an appeal by pro-independence lawmakers Baggio Leung and Yau Wai Ching, effectively ruling out their return to the legislature. The duo was disqualified for improper oath-taking after inserting digs at China. The ruling follows a similar decision for four other pro-democracy lawmakers. The move is seen as a blow to Hong Kong's autonomy, which is under increasing pressure from China's Communist Party leaders. The decision comes as Hong Kong authorities face criticism for jailing pro-democracy activists, including Joshua Wong, Alex Chow, and Nathan Law.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's highest court dismissed an appeal by two pro-independence lawmakers contesting their disqualification from the legislature last year on Friday, effectively ruling out their return to the political fold in the Chinese-ruled city.

site_title: China's yuan weakens as corporate demand for US dollars edges up
summary: China's yuan eased against the US dollar on Friday, weakening 0.08% to 6.6579 per US dollar, as corporate demand for the greenback increased. The yuan has gained 4.2% this year, supported by the US currency's weakness and Beijing's capital controls. Market participants await clues on US monetary tightening at a central bankers' conference. If the spot yuan finishes flat, it will be the second week in a row the currency trades flat against the US dollar.

site_title: Hot stock: Thakral shares soar on big sale of warehouse properties in Hong Kong
summary: Thakral Corp shares jumped 15% to 58.5 Singapore cents after accepting a HK$420 million bid for its Hong Kong warehouse properties. The bid, from Good Hour International, represented a significant premium of HK$205 million above the properties' net book value. The announcement halted trading on Thursday and resumed on Friday.

site_title: China's school dropouts a growing concern for economy in transition
summary: China is facing a growing concern of school dropouts in rural areas, where children have lower cognitive and social skills compared to urban counterparts. The issue affects the country's economy, as a higher-skilled labor force is needed to transition to a higher-value economy. According to the government, 76% of China's labor force did not attend high school, and the gap between rural and urban areas is significant. Early-childhood development centers, like the one in Huangchuan, may be the solution to address this issue, with estimates suggesting 300,000 centers are needed across China.

site_title: Iron ore in China headed for 9th weekly rise on steel strength
summary: China's iron ore futures rose 0.5% to 586.50 yuan (S$119.929) a tonne, poised for a ninth consecutive weekly gain, driven by strong steel demand from the country's infrastructure push. Steel consumption is expected to peak in September, supporting prices and margins at producers. Analysts predict that steel prices could reach 5,000 yuan a tonne if China curbs steel output in key areas, further supporting iron ore prices, which closed in on US$80 a tonne this week.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby Q4 profit slides on weak industrial, logistics segments
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby, the world's largest oil palm planter, reported a net profit of 571 million ringgit (S$181.902 million) for Q4 2017, more than halving from 1.2 billion ringgit in the same quarter last year. Weak performances in industrial, logistics, and property segments contributed to the decline. Revenue for the quarter stood at 8.2 billion ringgit, down from 7.7 billion ringgit last year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.680 points to 1,771.820 on Friday, with a trading volume of 53.924 million lots worth RM21.558 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 80.

site_title: Japan hits nuclear-armed North Korea with fresh sanctions
summary: Japan has imposed fresh sanctions on North Korea, freezing the assets of Chinese and Namibian firms doing business with the nuclear-armed state. The move aims to disrupt cash funding for North Korea's nuclear weapons programmes. Japan's top spokesman, Yoshihide Suga, urged North Korea to take denuclearization actions. The sanctions follow US punitive measures against Chinese and Russian firms, and come amid heightened tensions over North Korea's missile tests. The move is aimed at applying pressure on North Korea to stop violating UN resolutions.

site_title: Japan's richest village can't find workers for its factory
summary: Japan's richest village, Sarufutsu, struggles to find workers for its scallop factory due to low wages and limited job opportunities. The village, which boasts high average incomes, relies on older women for labor, and the current workforce is expected to retire in about 7 years. Efforts to attract new workers, including tourism initiatives, have been unsuccessful, and the factory's production is limited by labor shortages. Experts warn that the village's economy may be unsustainable as the population ages and shrinks, highlighting the challenges of balancing profitability with labor needs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip at open after three-day rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped marginally on Friday, edging down 9.17 points to 27,509.43, after a three-day rally. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw minor declines. The dip follows a strong three-day rally, with investors taking a breather ahead of the weekend.

site_title: Update: Thailand's Yingluck a no-show for negligence ruling, verdict postponed
summary: Thailand's former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra failed to appear in court for a negligence ruling, leading a judge to suspect she may have fled or gone into hiding. The case centers on a multi-billion dollar rice subsidy scheme for farmers, with Yingluck facing up to 10 years in prison if found guilty. A new verdict date of September 27 has been set, and an arrest warrant may be issued for Yingluck. The verdict's outcome could exacerbate tensions in the country, which has been divided by politics since a 2014 military coup.

images.alt_text: Former Thai prime minister Yingluck Shinawatra arrives at the Supreme Court in Bangkok on August 1, 2017.

site_title: Bruce Lee's toughest fight immortalised in film
summary: A new film, "Birth of the Dragon," immortalizes a legendary fight between 24-year-old Bruce Lee and Wong Jack Man, a skilled Shaolin monk, in 1960s California. The film's depiction of the encounter has been disputed, with witnesses disagreeing on the outcome and Lee's approach to kung fu. The fight is said to have transformed Lee's approach, setting him on the path to becoming a global martial arts superstar. The film takes inspiration from Lee's classic movies, such as "Fist of Fury," and stars Chinese-American actor Philip Ng as Lee.

images.alt_text: On a crisp December evening in 1960s California, two men near the peak of their powers locked horns in a battle that would go down in the annals of kung fu mythology.

site_title: Grab to invest US$100m in Myanmar as smartphone use surges
summary: Grab, Southeast Asia's largest ride-hailing app, plans to invest $100 million in Myanmar over three years to expand its services, including ride-hailing and digital payment. The investment aims to grow Grab's workforce fivefold to 200 drivers, as smartphone use surges in the country. Grab has already reached 25,000 bookings a day since its debut in Yangon in March. The investment will also enable drivers to access financial services through partnerships with local banks. Grab sees Myanmar as a key market in its battle with Uber.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.20% and the Topix index rising 0.12%. The yen declined modestly against the dollar as traders awaited a major central bankers' meeting later in the day.

site_title: Thailand deploys 4,000 police as Yingluck supporters gather ahead of court ruling
summary: Thousands of Yingluck supporters gathered outside Bangkok's Supreme Court ahead of a court ruling on a negligence case against her, which could inflame tension in Thailand. Around 4,000 police were deployed, and the court will also rule on a separate case against Yingluck's former commerce minister. The verdict could have far-reaching implications in the politically divided country, where the Shinawatra family has dominated politics for over 15 years. Yingluck faces up to 10 years in prison if found guilty, and her supporters have called for peaceful demonstrations.

site_title: Chinese national arrested in Los Angeles on US hacking charge
summary: A Chinese national, Yu Pingan, was arrested on August 21 at Los Angeles International Airport on charges of participating in a hacking conspiracy related to the theft of security clearance records from millions of American government employees. The alleged hacking group used malicious software known as Sakula, previously linked to breaches at the US Office of Personnel Management. Yu's arrest is part of a US investigation into the hacking incident.

site_title: Jump in employment costs threatens UK wage growth, BCC says
summary: The UK business community is facing increased pressure due to rising employment costs, which could negatively impact investment and wage growth. According to a survey of 1,400 businesses, nearly 80% have seen their costs increase this year, mainly due to government measures such as pension auto-enrollment and the minimum wage. This may lead to businesses raising prices, reducing pay growth, and impacting consumer confidence, which has already seen a decline for five consecutive months.

site_title: Government studying possibility of selling larger land parcels in Jurong Lake District
summary: The Singapore government is studying the possibility of selling larger land parcels in the Jurong Lake District (JLD) for development. The district, which will take 15-20 years to complete, aims to create 100,000 new jobs and 20,000 new homes. The development will feature a mixed-use business area, district-level infrastructure, and car-lite initiatives. The government plans to achieve over 80% public transport mode share in the district, and is also exploring logistics centre options to reduce freight traffic. A draft master plan is currently on public consultation.

site_title: "Big Four" banks, miners drag Australia shares down; NZ edges up
summary: Australia's benchmark stock index declined 0.3% on Friday, weighed down by losses from the "Big Four" banks, which pulled the S&P/ASX 200 index to 5,729.80. Investors are cautious ahead of speeches by US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and European Central Bank President Mario Draghi, looking for clues on monetary policy.

site_title: Hurricane Harvey targets Texas, Louisiana
summary: Hurricane Harvey, a category one hurricane, was upgraded to a category three storm, targeting Texas and Louisiana with "life-threatening" floods. The storm could make landfall as a category three with 209 km/h winds, potentially causing widespread flooding in Texas, including 30 inches of rain in some areas. New Orleans, still recovering from Hurricane Katrina, is also at risk of flooding. Governor Greg Abbott declared 30 counties a disaster zone, and officials in Houston do not anticipate evacuation orders but expect heavy rainfall lasting up to five days.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint in talks to acquire assets in UK but outcome not certain
summary: Frasers Centrepoint is in talks with "certain vendors" to acquire a business park portfolio in the UK for £900 million (S$1.6 billion). The assets have been on the block for two years, and a deal could be completed in the next two weeks due to pressure to undertake a transaction quickly. Frasers Centrepoint clarified that it is continually reviewing acquisition opportunities to enhance shareholder value, including potential overseas acquisitions. The outcome of the potential deal is not certain, and the company has not confirmed any further details.

site_title: Spotify reaches deal with Warner Music, paving way to go public
summary: Spotify has reached a global agreement with Warner Music Group, securing long-term deals with the three major record labels. This deal allows Spotify to go public directly on the New York Stock Exchange, bypassing a traditional share sale. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed. With over 60 million paying subscribers, Spotify is poised to list later this year or early next, marking a significant milestone for the music streaming pioneer.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% up on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 4.25 points to 3,276.41, despite US stocks dipping overnight due to political uncertainty in Washington. About 32.1 million shares changed hands, with Blumont being the most actively traded counter. Gainers outnumbered losers 64 to 30, while Japan's Topix and South Korea's Kospi index remained steady.

site_title: Fed's George, Kaplan stake out inflation debate at Jackson Hole
summary: US Federal Reserve officials, Kansas City Fed President Esther George and Dallas Fed chief Robert Kaplan, disagreed on how to respond to low inflation figures, with George favoring potential rate hikes in 2017 and Kaplan advocating for patience. Both officials support starting the gradual process of shrinking the Fed's $4.5 trillion balance sheet. The Fed rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee meets September 19-20, and investors expect an announcement on unwinding the balance sheet, with a roughly one-in-three chance of another rate hike by the end of the year.

site_title: Fed's inflation headache to intensify as Amazon cuts food prices
summary: The Federal Reserve is facing a challenge in hitting its 2% inflation target due to Amazon's price cuts at Whole Foods, which could lead to reduced margins and downward price pressure. According to Chicago Fed President Charles Evans, the use of technology and global developments have restrained pricing power, contributing to low inflation. This is despite a low unemployment rate, which is expected to boost inflation. The Fed's inflation headache is expected to intensify, raising concerns about its ability to meet its inflation target.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mary Chia, Frasers Centrepoint, Wing Tai, Creative Technology
summary: Mary Chia Holdings received a mandatory cash takeover bid from Suki Sushi at 11.1 Singapore cents apiece, representing a 68.2% premium. Frasers Centrepoint is in discussions with UK vendors for potential acquisition opportunities. Wing Tai Holdings posted a net profit of S$9.49 million for Q4 FY2017, with shareholders receiving a first and final dividend. Creative Technology swung into a net loss of US$5.54 million for Q4 FY2017 due to lower sales and rising expenses.

site_title: McGregor upset over Mayweather would put UFC model to the test
summary: Floyd Mayweather faces Conor McGregor in a highly anticipated boxing match, with Dana White, UFC president, under pressure to meet McGregor's financial demands. McGregor, who has held titles in two weight classes, is expected to earn up to $100 million from the fight, surpassing his UFC earnings in 4.5 years. A McGregor upset could give mixed martial arts newfound status and threaten the UFC's business model, with White acknowledging that McGregor's monetary needs may need to be addressed. The fight is expected to break records for ticket sales and pay-per-view buys, with the outcome potentially altering the dynamics between McGregor, the UFC, and the boxing world.

site_title: New high-tech 'yarn' could make electricity: study
summary: US and South Korean researchers have invented a new 'twistron' yarn that generates electricity when stretched or twisted. The yarn, made of carbon nanotubes, can power small devices like LEDs when submerged in or coated with an electrolyte. Lab experiments have shown that a single yarn can power a small LED, and the technology may be used for self-powered sensors and other IoT applications. The research, funded by various organizations, is still in its early stage and not suitable for large-scale electricity projects.

site_title: Japan inflation ticks up again, but chiefly on energy bills
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 0.5% in July, driven mainly by energy costs, for the seventh consecutive month. Excluding food and energy, prices increased 0.1%. The inflation rate still lags the Bank of Japan's 2.0% target, despite a strong labor market and business confidence. The recent price gains are largely due to higher energy costs, not a broader rise in consumer spending, and efforts to lift inflation have been unsuccessful despite years of monetary easing.

site_title: Macau death toll rises to 9 as city struggles with typhoon aftermath
summary: Macau's death toll from Typhoon Hato rose to nine, with another body found in an underground carpark, as the city struggled to recover from the storm's aftermath. The typhoon, a number 10 force, caused extensive damage, a near city-wide blackout, and serious flooding. Authorities faced public criticism for their handling of the storm, including a perceived failure to adequately warn residents. Macau's leader, Fernando Chui, apologized and the head of the weather observatory, Fong Soi-Kun, was set to step down. The city's infrastructure was severely damaged, with many residents relying on back-up generators.

site_title: SpaceX launches Taiwan's first home-built satellite
summary: SpaceX successfully launched Taiwan's first home-built satellite, Formosat-5, from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. The 450kg satellite, designed for disaster forecasts, mapping, and space research, is expected to last five years and orbit the Earth every 100 minutes. This marks a significant milestone for Taiwan's space program, following the decommissioning of its predecessor, FormosaT-2, which operated for 12 years.

site_title: Celebrating 50 years
summary: Rolex has unveiled an updated version of its 50-year-old Sea-Dweller watch, featuring a larger 43mm case, a new cyclops magnifying glass on the date window, and a more precise and efficient Rolex movement (Calibre 3235). The changes sparked controversy, with some hailing the updates as a nod to the watch's heritage and others criticizing the cyclops as a departure from the original design. Despite the debate, collectors are eagerly awaiting the watch's release, which is seen as a tribute to the Sea-Dweller's 50th anniversary.

site_title: After durians, what next for Serial System?
summary: Serial System, a Singapore-based electronics component distributor, has invested S$1.915 million in a Malaysian durian business, Musang Durians Frozen Food. The investment aims to scale up the company's operations and expand its business through Serial System's distribution network. The move follows the company's efforts to diversify and increase margins, as its revenue has been increasing but profit has been declining. Serial System's CEO, Derek Goh, expects the investment to bear fruit in two years, with a target of raising the group's revenue to US$5-10 billion within 10 years.

site_title: Could Australia's Deputy PM become New Zealander of the Year?
summary: Australia's Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce is facing a constitutional crisis after renouncing his New Zealand citizenship. Despite this, he has the second-most nominations for the 2018 New Zealander of the Year award, which could lead to him winning the award. However, his eligibility is yet to be determined, and his status as a dual national has raised doubts about his ability to sit in Australia's parliament. The High Court will start hearings on the matter in mid-October, which could impact the government's one-seat majority in the lower house.

images.alt_text: Australian Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce reacts in the House of Representatives at Parliament House in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, Australia, on August 14 2017.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges lower with Jackson Hole meeting in focus
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday as investors remained cautious ahead of the Jackson Hole meeting of central bankers. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.13%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite lost 0.21% and 0.11%, respectively. Despite mixed economic data, including a rise in unemployment benefits and a drop in home resales, investors are focused on central bankers' comments on monetary policy. President Trump's comments on the debt ceiling and tax reform also weighed on the market, with some analysts expressing concerns about the President's ability to advance his agenda.

site_title: Mother wins US$758.7m in record single US jackpot, quits job
summary: A 53-year-old Massachusetts mother, Mavis Wanczyk, won the largest single jackpot in US history, $758.7 million, in the Powerball lottery. She quit her 32-year hospital job immediately, saying it was a dream come true. Wanczyk, who had played the lottery as a "pipe dream," bought the winning ticket nine months after her husband's death in a hit-and-run accident. She now has the option to take the prize as an annuity or a cash lump sum.

site_title: Mary Chia receives mandatory takeover bid from Suki Sushi
summary: Mary Chia Holdings, a beauty specialist company, has received a mandatory takeover bid from Suki Sushi at 11.1 Singapore cents apiece, a 68.2% premium over its last traded price. The offeror, controlled by Lee Boon Leng, intends to maintain the company's listing status. Following the disposal of her interest, Mary Chia's CEO Ho Yow Ping's wife stepped down from executive positions, and the company will undergo a strategic review to strengthen its financial position and optimize its potential. The offeror aims to explore diversification into complementary sectors.

site_title: Unveiling 3 new models
summary: Jaeger-LeCoultre unveiled three new Master Control models to celebrate its 25th birthday. The watches, powered by in-house automatic movements, feature a common blue color theme and a two-tone sector design. The three models include the Master Control Date, Master Chronograph, and Master Geographic, with prices ranging from S$8,800 to S$14,600. The Master Control line has also achieved the brand's 1,000 Hours Control certification, demonstrating its durability and reliability.

site_title: US dollar inches up ahead of Jackson Hole policymakers' meeting
summary: The US dollar rose 0.4% to 109.49 yen and 0.1% to 93.272 against a major currency basket ahead of the Jackson Hole Economic Policy Summit, where Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and European Central Bank President Mario Draghi are set to speak. The dollar's gains were driven by a decline in euro and yen, despite no new policy messages from the officials. Investors are focused on inflationary pressures and the US economy, and analysts are skeptical that the dollar's gains will be sustained, citing ongoing government tension and the threat of a government shutdown.

site_title: Amazon says Whole Foods deal to close Monday, vows lower prices
summary: Amazon is set to close its $13.7 billion acquisition of Whole Foods Market on Monday, marking the end of the deal. The US retail giant has vowed to lower grocery prices and integrate Whole Foods into its Prime subscription program, offering customers free two-day shipping, original programming, and other perks. The acquisition, which received antitrust approval, will broaden Whole Foods' offerings and make its products available to Amazon Prime members.

site_title: Two Brazil boat wrecks in two days leave 39 dead
summary: Two Brazilian ferry wrecks in two days left at least 39 people dead, according to authorities. A boat sank on the Xingu river in Para state on Tuesday, resulting in 21 confirmed deaths. Rescuers are still searching for several missing people. President Michel Temer expressed regret for the loss of lives, stating "tens of lives" were lost in the accidents in Para and Bahia states.

site_title: The Substation and the politics of space
summary: The Substation, a 27-year-old independent arts center in Singapore, has undergone a major transformation to explore the relationship between architecture and behavior. The exhibition "Discipline The City" features artworks that challenge the city's architectural landscape and invite viewers to question control and access. The show includes installations and videos by artists such as Chen Sai Hua Kuan, Debbie Ding, and Kuang-Yu Tsui, which use humor and satire to interrogate the politics of space. The exhibition aims to spark a national conversation about the city's design and its impact on citizens.

site_title: Take a spin with BT Weekend
summary: The BT Weekend article discusses various topics, including the resurgence of vinyl in Singapore, a style guide for power wardrobes, and lifestyle destinations. A former insurance agent was awarded S$4 million after a bad reference cost him a job, and the article also covers travel hacks, the 50th anniversary of The Beatles' Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, and a review of the Mercedes-AMG GLC-43. Additionally, the article highlights various lifestyle and motoring topics, including a new restaurant and financial literacy initiatives.

site_title: Want to boost productivity? Engage your workforce
summary: Singapore aims to boost productivity through employee engagement, recognizing it as a key driver of performance and economic growth. A recent study found that Singaporeans value a meritocracy, involvement in decisions, and clear strategic intent, but business leaders struggle to deliver these. To improve engagement, policymakers recommend a multi-stakeholder approach, setting clear goals, structures, and accountabilities, and encouraging leaders to live the values they promote. By fostering a sense of empowerment and belonging, employers can enhance their employer brand and motivate employees to drive productivity gains.

site_title: Best-performing China equities fund bought just three stocks this year
summary: Cederberg Capital's Dawid Krige's China equities fund achieved a 46% return in 2017, the best-performing active mutual fund in Greater China. The fund, which has a 159% five-year return, focused on just three stocks: Tencent Holdings, Alibaba Group, and Beijing Tong Ren Tang Chinese Medicine Co. Krige's strategy of buying few, high-quality stocks has worked, with the two internet giants rising over 70%. The fund's performance outpaces the MSCI China Index, which gained 40% in 2017.

site_title: When tough meets elegance
summary: Casio's MRG-G2000HT, launched in 2017, is the brand's top release, featuring the world's first three-day time sync system, the Connected Engine 3-Way. This system automatically updates time data with radio wave and GPS signals and connects to time servers via a smartphone. The watch also boasts a solar charging system and a unique metal-hammered finish. Limited to 500 pieces, the MRG-G2000HT is part of Casio's G-Shock line, which includes the GPW-2000 and G-Steel series, featuring similar technological innovations and rugged designs.

site_title: Hedge funds' MiFID defection highlights limit of EU rule revamp
summary: Two major hedge funds, Tudor Investment Corp and Brevan Howard Asset Management, have dropped their MiFID licences, joining approximately 2,400 alternative investment fund managers operating under the 2011 Alternative Investment Fund Managers Directive (AIFMD). This move highlights the potential for regulatory arbitrage and the need for policymakers to review AIFMD to align with MiFID II regulations. A review of AIFMD, which could take years to complete, aims to close gaps between the two laws and make things easier for supervisors and market participants.

site_title: Don't forget to prune your portfolio
summary: Executives often avoid divesting non-core businesses due to concerns about revenue loss, market reaction, and stranded costs. However, strategically designed divestitures can generate significant shareholder value and improve remaining businesses. A study by Bain & Company found that companies engaging in focused divestments outperform inactive companies by 15% over 10 years. Successful divestitures require including strong talent, defining how to increase the value of the divested business and the remaining company, and minimizing stranded costs. Companies that regularly prune their portfolio and manage the separation process can deliver outsized value through divestitures.

site_title: Slaying adversity with Mindkiller
summary: Vandetta, a local musician, is set to release her new EP "Mindkiller" on Friday, inspired by Frank Herbert's novel "Dune". The five-track EP explores themes of struggle and overcoming adversity, with Fernandez collaborating with local producers. Despite her busy work schedule, making music remains important to her, providing catharsis and a connection to her creative side. The EP marks a departure from her previous work, with a more accessible sound and a focus on collaboration and seeking help.

site_title: Amazon, Whole Foods merger gets the okay from shareholders, US regulators
summary: Amazon's $13.7 billion acquisition of Whole Foods Market Inc has cleared major hurdles, with the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) not pursuing an investigation and Whole Foods shareholders voting in favor. The deal gives Amazon a foothold in the US grocery market and access to over 465 brick-and-mortar stores. The merger has sent shockwaves through the supermarket industry, with larger grocers like Kroger Co and Wal-Mart Stores Inc racing to add online shopping options. Amazon is expected to close the merger this year, with Whole Foods shares rising 0.7% in after-hours trading.

site_title: Blumont gets mandatory takeover bid from Malaysian businessman
summary: BLUMONT Group, a Singapore-based company, has received a mandatory takeover bid from Malaysian businessman Siaw Lu Howe at 0.0182 Singapore cent per share. Ultimate Horizon, owned by Mr. Siaw, acquired a 69.56% stake in Blumont for S$4 million. The offer price represents an 81.8% discount to the stock's last traded price, and the offeror plans to review the group's business and operations. Trading in Blumont shares resumed after a halt, finishing the day unchanged.

site_title: China speculators send price of aluminium to six-year high
summary: China's aluminium prices have surged to a six-year high due to government curbs on supply to eliminate industrial overcapacity and reduce pollution. Trading in August has already surpassed the previous monthly record, with prices rising 27% in Shanghai and 24% on the London Metal Exchange. The Shanghai Futures Exchange has stepped in to calm trading in steel and zinc, while China's central government aims to shutter as much as one million tonnes of unlicensed aluminium production capacity and one million tonnes of thermal power capacity. This shift is seen as a fundamental change in the market, with some speculators optimistic about the potential for higher prices.

site_title: Cyclicals boost European shares while Dixons Carphone plummets
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Thursday, driven by gains in cyclical sectors, while Dixons Carphone shares plummeted 29% after a profit warning. The mobile phone retailer downgraded full-year profit expectations due to customers holding onto handsets for longer. Despite this, pan-European Stoxx 600 and euro zone stocks remained in line with blue chips.

site_title: Pretty amazing
summary: Watch companies have finally catered to the growing number of female luxury watch connoisseurs with stylish and sophisticated timepieces. Brands such as Patek Philippe, Audemars Piguet, Jaeger-LeCoultre, Omega, Cartier, IWC, Hublot, and Chopard have released new collections that combine elegance and horological depth. These watches, featuring unique designs and complications, are designed to appeal to women who appreciate the art of fine watchmaking. With their exceptional craftsmanship and attention to detail, these timepieces are poised to give men's watches a run for their money.
