site_title: Good Hour International clinches Thakral's HK warehouse property with HK$420m bid
summary: Good Hour International Limited has clinched Thakral's Hong Kong warehouse property with a bid of HK$420 million (S$73 million). The properties, comprising four floors in Kowloon, will be sold subject to shareholders' approval. The sale is expected to generate a profit of approximately HK$192 million and free up capital resources to fund the group's core businesses. The buyer will also enter into a tenancy agreement for the first floor, and the expected completion date is before November 22.

site_title: Dollar steadies ahead of Jackson Hole meetings
summary: The US dollar steadied ahead of the Jackson Hole meetings, where Fed chairwoman Janet Yellen is expected to provide insight on interest rate hikes and the US central bank's balance sheet. The dollar has dropped 14% against the euro this year due to weakened expectations for tax cuts and rate hikes. A potential hawkish message from Yellen could boost the dollar, which rose 0.2% to trade at $1.1788 per euro.

site_title: HMI profit doubles in Q4 to RM10.7m amid higher patient load, larger bill sizes
summary: Health Management International Ltd (HMI) reported a 2.5-fold increase in net profit to RM10.7 million for the fourth quarter ended June 30, 2017, driven by a higher patient load and larger bill sizes. The group's healthcare business saw a 5.2% increase in turnover, while its education business reported a RM5.6 million increase in revenue. Despite rising costs, HMI expects to continue its growth trend, focusing on volume-driven growth and leveraging technology to attract more medical tourists.

images.alt_text: ''Typically, a procedure in our hospitals costs about one-third of the cost in Singapore,'' said group CEO Ms Chin Wei Jia, seen here with CFO Mr Chin Wei Yao.

site_title: Farid submits papers, has 'no regrets' no matter the outcome
summary: Farid Khan Kaim Khan, chairman of Bourbon Offshore Asia Pacific, has submitted his application to contest Singapore's reserved presidential election, which will be held for candidates from the Malay community. Despite not meeting the S$500 million equity criteria, Farid expressed confidence in being approved by the Presidential Elections Committee, stating he is ready for a contest. His application comes a day after Mohamed Salleh Marican, CEO of Second Chance Properties, also submitted his papers, also not meeting the criteria. The six-member PEC will now review their eligibility.

site_title: Fair value accounting deserves more scrutiny
summary: Fair value accounting in real estate investment trusts (Reits) has raised concerns about potential systemic risk, particularly in a low-interest-rate environment. Reits' values are determined by external valuers using capitalisation and discounted cash flow methods, which rely on estimates of discount rates and capitalisation rates. Small changes to these rates can result in significant differences in value, and the lack of transparency in these estimates has raised red flags. The Singapore Exchange and Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers are jointly reviewing valuation practices to address these concerns and ensure fair value accounting is scrutinized adequately.

site_title: The ones to watch out for
summary: The Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Geneve (GPHG) will include smartwatches in its 2017 competition, marking a change in the luxury watch industry's equivalent of the Oscars. Two smartwatches, from TAG Heuer and Montblanc, will compete in the Petite Aiguille category, while no smartwatches will compete in the Sports category. The event will feature 181 watches across 12 categories, with notable timepieces including the Audemars Piguet Royal Oak Frosted Gold and the AkriviA AK-06.

site_title: Iceland takes off as island of drone deliveries
summary: Icelandic autonomous drone delivery company Flytrex has started commercial operations in Reykjavik, delivering goods to 8,000 customers across the city via drones. The service aims to save 60% of delivery costs and plans to transport orders directly to customers' backyards with regulatory approval by the end of the year. Flytrex is one of the first companies to offer drone delivery on demand and is competing with other major players such as Amazon and Google.

site_title: Smart luxury
summary: TAG Heuer, Montblanc, and Louis Vuitton have launched high-end smartwatches. TAG Heuer's Connected Modular 45 features interchangeable modules, high-quality materials, and GPS tracking, while Montblanc's Summit boasts a curved sapphire glass and Android 2.0 operating system. Louis Vuitton's Tambour Horizon includes travel-related features such as flight and city guides, and a GMT function. These smartwatches mark a new era in luxury wearables, combining traditional watchmaking with cutting-edge technology.

site_title: Is the US stock market crazy - or just giddy?
summary: Economist William Cline disputes the notion that the US stock market is overvalued, citing statistical comparisons with the past as evidence. He argues that low inflation, low unemployment, and low interest rates justify the relatively high price-earnings ratios. Cline points to forecasts of rapid profit growth and a robust market advance since 2011, but notes that the current price-earnings ratio is not significantly higher than historical averages. However, rising interest rates and the Trump administration's policies pose potential vulnerabilities to the market.

site_title: Thai ex-PM Yingluck to hear verdict on negligence charge
summary: Thailand's Supreme Court will rule on Friday whether ousted Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra is guilty of criminal negligence, which could lead to up to 10 years in prison and a life ban from politics. The verdict could also reinvigorate the "Red Shirts" supporters and rile the Shinawatra family's significant support base. Yingluck, 50, faces charges related to a rice subsidy that was beset by graft and led to billions of dollars in losses. A guilty verdict would be a heavy blow to the Shinawatra dynasty, which has been involved in two coups and numerous law cases.

site_title: Note by note with Singapore's 'King of Swing'
summary: Jeremy Monteiro, known as Singapore's "King of Swing," has been promoting jazz for decades through concerts and lectures. He recently started the non-profit Jazz Association (Singapore) Ltd, which aims to encourage participation and excellence in the genre. Monteiro has performed with an ensemble and will give a talk on the history of jazz, ahead of his performance on Saturday. He believes the Singapore jazz scene was born in the 1950s and has seen a resurgence in interest from well-educated and talented young musicians, including pianists Chok Kerong and Tan Wei Xiang.

site_title: UK net migration falls to lowest level in 3 years in wake of Brexit vote
summary: UK net migration fell to 246,000 in the 12 months to March, its lowest level in three years, with 127,000 EU citizens leaving and fewer arriving. The drop is largely due to EU citizens departing, and the annual difference has fallen from 350,000 since the Brexit vote. This reduction has raised concerns about immigration, which contributed to the Brexit vote. The UK aims to guarantee the rights of EU citizens, but some are leaving due to the weakened pound.

site_title: Pulling off the East-West balancing act
summary: A modern Chinese restaurant, Blue Lotus Chinese Grill House, in Tanjong Pagar Centre, offers a unique blend of East and West in its cooking methods and ambiance. Despite its non-traditional approach, the restaurant serves serious food with a focus on taste over gimmicks. Key dishes include deconstructed chilli crab, braised beef shank noodles, and a fermented tofu barley risotto. The restaurant's lunch sets offer good value, and its unique offerings make it a standout in the culinary scene. With a strong background in Chinese food, Blue Lotus successfully balances its modern and traditional elements.

site_title: Mitsui Sumitomo paying US$1.6b for S'pore insurer
summary: Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance is acquiring First Capital Insurance, Singapore's largest property and casualty insurance company, for $1.6 billion from Fairfax Financial Holdings. The acquisition aims to cement MSI's leading position in Asean's non-life insurance market. First Capital Insurance has 160 employees and writes both personal and commercial lines of non-life insurance. The deal is expected to complete early next year, subject to regulatory approvals, and will enable MSI to become a top insurer in the Singapore non-life insurance market.

site_title: McDonald's to cut use of antibiotics in its chickens worldwide
summary: McDonald's plans to curb the use of high-value human antibiotics in its global chicken supply starting in 2018. The company will phase out the use of "highest priority critically important antimicrobials" (HPCIA) in chicken meat, affecting markets in Brazil, Canada, Japan, South Korea, the US, and Europe. By 2019, suppliers in Australia and Russia will stop using HPCIA, and European suppliers will remove Colistin. The move aims to reduce medically important antibiotics in the food supply, which contribute to the rise of antibiotic-resistant superbugs.

site_title: Microsoft, the old man of tech, looks like a growth stock again
summary: Microsoft shares have surged under CEO Satya Nadella's leadership, rising 160% since 2014. The company has become a major player in commercial cloud computing, with $133 billion in cash reserves. Its AAA-rated bond is considered a "gold standard" by Standard and Poor's, and major investors such as Vanguard and BlackRock own significant stakes. Meanwhile, Johnson & Johnson shares have also risen, doubling in price over the past five years, despite a recent verdict in a talc lawsuit.

site_title: Income tax, GST take taxman's haul to new peak of S$47b
summary: Singapore's Inland Revenue Authority (IRAS) collected a record S$47 billion in tax revenue for the 2017 financial year, a 5% increase from the previous year. Economists attribute the boost to the global and domestic economic recovery, which is expected to continue in the coming year. Individual income tax rose to S$10.5 billion, while corporate income taxes slipped slightly. GST and stamp duties also increased, despite a slight drop in corporate income taxes. The government's budget surplus may be better than anticipated, allowing for further fiscal support and potentially reducing the need for income tax and GST increases.

site_title: Australia's Cromwell gets SGX nod for billion-euro Reit IPO
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has received conditional approval for Australia-listed Cromwell Property Group's 1 billion euro (S$1.61 billion) initial public offering of Cromwell European Reit (CEREIT), set to list in September. This is a boost to SGX's goal of becoming a global real estate investment trust (Reit) hub. CEREIT will be the second largest IPO in Singapore this year and the only euro-denominated counter on the exchange, spanning retail, office, and industrial assets across European countries.

site_title: Apex gets MAS in-principle nod for third derivatives exchange: sources
summary: Apex, a Singapore-based exchange, has received an in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to launch a third derivatives exchange. The exchange, which will be focused on refined palm oil contracts, will be priced in dollars and physically delivered in Malaysia and Indonesia. Apex aims to rival existing exchanges Intercontinental Exchange Inc and Singapore Exchange Ltd. The company's board includes notable figures such as KKR Inc's Lim Hwee Hua and former MAS official Mimi Ho.

site_title: Uber Q2 losses go down as bookings go up
summary: Uber Technologies Inc reported a 16% increase in quarterly bookings and a 9% decrease in losses to $645 million in Q2, with gross ride bookings reaching $8.7 billion and 150% growth in global trips. The company's adjusted net revenue rose to $1.75 billion, despite facing allegations of misconduct and declining investor confidence, with some investors marking down the value of their shares by up to 15%. Uber's efforts to rein in spending and become profitable continue, but a new CEO and CFO are still being sought.

images.alt_text: Uber's shrinking losses reflect its efforts to rein in massive spending on subsidies for both drivers and customers even as it battles rivals in tough markets such as South Asia.

site_title: GSK opens high-tech consumer behaviour lab
summary: GSK Consumer Healthcare has opened a high-tech Shopper Science Lab in Singapore, utilizing eye-tracking, facial biometrics, and data visualization technology to analyze consumer behavior. The lab, comprising three integrated labs, replicates retail environments and evaluates shoppers' responses to online and in-store promotions. This data will drive business growth in emerging markets through unique shopper insights and collaborations with retailers. The facility aims to enhance consumers' shopping experience and inform business decisions, leveraging virtual reality and biometric technology for more efficient and effective market research.

site_title: Luxury watch market ticks up ahead of time, thanks to Chinese orders
summary: The luxury watch market has seen a significant jump in orders from China, putting it back on its feet sooner than expected after a two-year slump. This growth is expected to be beneficial for the Singapore market, which is among the world's top 10. The recovery is seen as a positive sign for the industry, with China's increased demand contributing to the turnaround.

site_title: Same brand, different shape
summary: FP Journe's Vagabondage III watch features a flat, tortoise-shaped case, a departure from the brand's usual round cases. The watch's name, meaning "vagrancy" or "wandering," reflects its unconventional design. The Vagabondage series, which includes Vagabondage I and II, features jumping hours and minutes. Vagabondage III boasts a digital jumping seconds display, a world's first mechanical watch to achieve this feat. The watch is powered by a hand-wound 18K rose gold movement and is available in limited platinum and red gold editions, priced at CHF 56,000 and CHF 54,000, respectively.

site_title: SoHo's soaring rents keep storefronts empty
summary: SoHo's iconic storefronts remain empty due to soaring rents, which have increased by 75% between 2010 and 2014, outpacing a 31.9% rise in retail sales. The area, once a hub for small boutiques and art galleries, now features vacant spaces as national chains and big commercial real estate firms push rents higher. Experts attribute the issue to unrealistic rent levels, with some landlords offering short-term leases or incentives to attract tenants, but the area's retail spine remains underutilized.

images.alt_text: Across the United States, retailers have been wounded by competition from Amazon and other Internet sales sites, prompting caution in opening new stores.

site_title: Promoting Singapore through the years
summary: Singapore has unveiled a new branding to promote its spirit and image. The country also set up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, and plans to visit the US for trade talks. Additionally, the government is providing a new grant of up to S$100,000 to businesses affected by tariffs. A study suggests Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The government is also offering support to workers who need training to future-proof their careers, citing better employment rates among graduates.

site_title: Trump invites Najib to White House visit
summary: US President Donald Trump has invited Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak to the White House on September 12, despite Najib being under investigation for corruption in the US. Najib is facing civil lawsuits to seize $1.7 billion in assets linked to the 1MDB scandal. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral ties and regional cooperation, but critics fear Najib may use the meeting to derail further investigations. The US sees Malaysia as a key partner in countering China's territorial claims in the South China Sea and backing the global fight against terrorism.

site_title: Taking the innovation war to the military
summary: The military is being explored as a testing ground for emerging disruptive technologies, with the potential to become an incubator for innovation. Historically, defence has driven the development of new technologies, such as radar and GPS, and has partnered with industry to identify and adopt new technologies. The Israeli Defence Force is cited as an example of a successful defence industry that has fostered innovation. The convergence of government, defence industry, and industry partners is seen as a perfect storm that presents opportunities for technological advancements and economic growth.

site_title: Jewel in the crown
summary: Tudor has launched several new versions of its popular Heritage Black Bay collection, including the Heritage Black Bay Chrono, Steel and Gold, Steel, and 41. The Chrono features a hybrid design combining racing and aquatic heritage, with a chronograph movement developed in collaboration with Breitling. The Steel and Gold model boasts 18k yellow gold details and is currently worn by David Beckham. The Heritage Black Bay 41 offers a more formal look with a redesigned middle section and flat sapphire crystal. These new models follow the success of the original Heritage Black Bay, which was named the best "revival" watch at the 2013 Grand Prix d' Horlogerie de Geneve.

images.alt_text: Heritage Black Bay Chrono.
Heritage Black Bay 41.
Left: Heritage Black Bay Steel and Gold. Right: Heritage Black Bay Steel with Khaki fabric.

site_title: Germany 'has vital interest in saving diesel engine industry'
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel's chief of staff, Peter Altmaier, defends the country's diesel engine industry, stating it has a "vital interest" in preserving the technology due to its lower CO2 emissions compared to other technologies. Despite criticism over cheating on emissions tests, Altmaier says the industry must follow rules and regulations. A compromise deal reached earlier this month includes software updates on millions of vehicles, but Environment Minister Barbara Hendricks says these measures are insufficient to meet air quality standards, and further hardware changes may be needed.

images.alt_text: Diesel, once the symbol of German auto-engineering prowess, has been blackened by Volkswagen's emissions scandal. While the technology offers more power and emits about 15 per cent less carbon dioxide than equivalent petrol engines, it produces more nitrogen oxide.

site_title: Steel pulling in the crowd
summary: Rolex unveiled stainless steel and steel-gold alternatives of its Sky-Dweller watch at the Baselworld watch fair, drawing attention and interest in the timepiece. The Sky-Dweller, launched five years ago, remains Rolex's most complicated modern watch, with the new models featuring the same features as earlier ones. The case size remains 42mm, with hour and minute hands being longer, and indexes now in rectangular format. The new models offer a more affordable option, with prices ranging from around S$19,000, making them more accessible to collectors.

site_title: Where US homebuyers are headed next: Chicago, Colorado Springs, Reno
summary: US homebuyers are shifting their focus to cities like Chicago, Colorado Springs, and Reno, where inventory is increasing and prices are relatively lower. The report, based on Attom Data Solutions' pre-mover index, shows these areas as the most active housing markets, while cities like San Francisco and Rochester, NY, remain less active due to high prices and limited supply. The suburbs surrounding these cities, such as Washington, Chicago, and Atlanta, are also seeing increased housing activity.

site_title: Only the men get it
summary: Cartier introduces new men's watch collections, including the Drive de Cartier Extra-Flat and Drive de Cartier Moon Phases, featuring innovative timepieces such as an extra-flat model and a moonphase complication. The brand also showcases its expertise in watchmaking with the Ronde de Cartier Minute Repeater Mysterious Double Tourbillon and Rotonde de Cartier Skeleton Mysterious Hour. The Drive de Cartier Extra-Flat is available in pink gold and white gold, while the Moon Phases model features a limited edition of 200 pieces in white gold.

site_title: India eyes remote air traffic control towers for regional airports
summary: India is considering setting up remote air traffic control towers to reduce costs and address labor shortages at regional airports. The technology, used in countries like Australia and Canada, allows for remote monitoring of flights from a central location, reducing the need for physical towers and air traffic controllers. The Airports Authority of India has initiated a study on remote monitoring, with a recommendation expected in September, and companies like Saab and Searidge Technologies are in talks to bring the technology to India, which is home to the world's fourth-largest air passenger market.

site_title: Breaking new ground
summary: Panerai has launched a 50-year warranty for a limited 50 pieces of its new model, the Lab-ID Luminor 1950 Carbotech, powered by a movement requiring no lubrication. The 49mm carbotech case is lighter and more resistant to external stresses than traditional materials. The 50-year warranty surpasses the longest offered by other brands like Rolex and Omega. The watch features a semi-skeletonised hand-wound movement made of carbon composites, and a dial coated with carbon nanotubes for a deep black appearance.

site_title: Building for the poor the Doshi way: plant a seed, grow a forest
summary: Architect Balkrishna Doshi advocates for a natural, organic approach to building, inspired by planting seeds and allowing them to grow into a forest. He believes that modern city planners and designers have misunderstood the concept of a building as a living organism. Doshi's approach, showcased in his 1988 project in Indore, India, involved providing residents with simple, locally-sourced materials and allowing them to build their own homes, resulting in a thriving community with 35,000 residents. This approach prioritizes adaptation and growth, rather than rigid, alienating structures.

site_title: Keeping watch of time
summary: A Lange & Sohne's Zeitwerk Decimal Strike is the world's first mechanical wristwatch with a jumping numerals display and a visible chiming mechanism, available in a limited edition of 100 in honey gold. The watch features a striking train that uses the energy reserves from the jumping numerals display to power the chiming mechanism, providing a low-pitched tone for each hour and a high-pitched tone for each 10-minute interval. The Zeitwerk Decimal Strike is the third model in six years from the brand, following the Zeitwerk Striking Time and the Zeitwerk Minute Repeater.

site_title: China's imports show how its humming factories are propping up other economies
summary: China's trade surplus with over 40 nations, including South Korea, Switzerland, and Australia, highlights the country's role in propping up other economies through its humming factories. The surplus is driven by imports of machines, electronics, and raw materials, with South Korea and Malaysia being key suppliers. China's economic influence is evident in its supply chains, which include components from Germany, Japan, and the US. The data also shows China's reliance on commodity exporters, such as Brazil and Chile, and its impact on regional economies, including the Australian dollar and Mongolian GDP.

site_title: Japan's biggest freight line to test remote-controlled container ship
summary: Japan's largest container line, Nippon Yusen KK, plans to test a remote-controlled container ship across the Pacific Ocean in 2019. The vessel will be operated remotely, with a crew on standby for safe operations. This technology aims to disrupt the global shipping industry by reducing costs and boosting safety. The move follows a series of incidents involving human error, including the US Navy's recent accident involving the USS John S McCain. Several companies, including Rolls-Royce and BHP Billiton, are also studying autonomous ship technology.

site_title: New law to boost S'pore debt revamp prowess
summary: Singapore is introducing an omnibus Insolvency Bill in 2018 to consolidate personal bankruptcy and corporate insolvency regimes, aiming to boost the country's status as a leading debt restructuring center. This comes amid the highest global corporate default rates since the 2008 crisis, with nearly US$1 billion in defaults in the Singapore bond market since 2015. The new law will streamline and update existing laws, provide consistency and clarity, and implement recommendations from the Insolvency Law Reform Committee.

site_title: Hublot's latest collection dazzles
summary: Hublot's latest collection, launched at Baselworld, showcases the brand's innovations and partnerships. Three timepieces stand out: the Hublot Techframe Ferrari 70 Years, a flying tourbillon chronograph designed like a supercar; the Hublot MP-09 Tourbillon Bi-Axis Titanium, featuring a bi-axial tourbillon with maximum view; and the Hublot Big Bang Unico Blue Sapphire, a watch with a blue sapphire case made using a sophisticated process. The collection includes limited-edition pieces, with prices ranging from S$120,400 to S$301,000.

site_title: For the younger crowd
summary: Patek Philippe celebrates the 20th anniversary of its iconic Aquanaut collection with two new timepieces. The Ref 5168G is an upsized model featuring a 42mm 18k white gold case, paying homage to the original Nautilus. The Ref 5650 Aquanaut Travel Time Advanced Research is a limited edition, incorporating innovative technologies such as the Spiromax balance spring and a compliant mechanism for improved time zone setting accuracy.

site_title: Misadventures and mayhem, but no surprises
summary: The comedy film Rough Night follows a group of college friends, including Jess (Scarlett Johansson), Alice (Jillian Bell), Frankie (Ilana Glazer), and Pippa (Kate McKinnon), as they reunite for a bachelorette weekend in Miami. The night descends into chaos after a male stripper is killed, leading to a series of misadventures. Despite a talented ensemble cast, the film is criticized for its lack of surprises and shallow character development, ultimately receiving a rating of C.

site_title: Tanker rates soar on strong global fuel demand
summary: Tanker rates for refined fuels such as petrol and diesel have surged globally due to strong fuel demand and supply crunch. Rates have risen to around 155 points on the Worldscale rate for medium-range tankers and 120 points for bigger tankers, with US rates also increasing. Strong demand in the Middle East, East Africa, and Asia, combined with rising Chinese fuel exports and jet fuel shipments, have driven up fuel demand and rates. However, US petrol demand has been lower than expected, resulting in a surge in US fuel exports to Europe and Latin America.

site_title: Trends in vogue
summary: The luxury watch industry is shifting towards affordable luxury, with brands like IWC, Panerai, and Montblanc offering entry-level timepieces. This trend is driven by the growing demand for women's watches and price moderation, with many brands revising their pricing strategies. High-tech watches and smartwatches are also gaining popularity, with innovations in materials and watchmaking. Despite caution due to declining exports, the industry is continuing to innovate, with brands like Richard Mille and Vacheron Constantin pushing the boundaries of watchmaking.

images.alt_text: Panerai Lab-ID Luminor 1950 Carbotech - A watch that needs no lubrication and comes with a 50-year warranty.

site_title: STI see-sawing ahead of bankers' meeting
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.37% to close at 3,272.16 on Thursday, despite concerns over a US government shutdown and uncertainty surrounding central bank policy. The market remained on a see-saw, with 218 stocks gaining and 207 losing, in the week's most active session. IG market strategist Pan Jingyi attributed the market's cautiousness to the lack of consensus on central bank policy, including the timing and pace of US Federal Reserve rate hikes.

site_title: China prosecutors charge Trafigura, staff member in oil probe
summary: Chinese prosecutors have charged Trafigura's Singapore division and a Beijing-based staff member, Tian Meng, for allegedly fabricating petrol deals with a Chinese oil trading company, resulting in the fraudulent obtaining of bank credit. Prosecutors also charged a second individual, Zhang Wei, for conspiring with Tian in the alleged fraud. The charges stem from a three-year probe that began after a complaint from Qingdao United Energy, alleging it lost US$32 million from trade financing deals arranged by Tian and Zhang. The Swiss firm declined to comment on the charges.

site_title: Same, yet different
summary: High-end watchmakers are shifting focus from extravagant complications to more practical and affordable timepieces, prioritizing value and reliability over innovative features. Brands like IWC, Zenith, and Ulysse Nardin offer competitive pricing, while maintaining high-quality movements and craftsmanship. Notable technical achievements include the FP Journe Vagabondage III and the Panerai LAB-ID Luminor 1950 Carbotech 3 Days, showcasing innovative materials and mechanics. Meanwhile, Rolex's Cellini Moonphase and Konstantin Chaykin's Joker demonstrate the appeal of classic designs and whimsical touches, highlighting the industry's adaptability to changing market trends.

images.alt_text: Tourbograph Perpetual Pour le Merite (above), the flagship complicated watch introduced by A Lange & Sohne this year.
Zenith Defy El Primero 21.
The IWC Da Vinci Perpetual Calendar Chronograph is priced at about S$40,000 - a hefty sum by any standard but reasonable for the combination of complications that are built on a proprietary movement.
The Rolex Cellini Moonphase has a date and phase of the moon display.
It can pay just to have fun, which is what Konstantin Chaykin is doing with his Joker.
Back of watch Panerai LAB-ID Luminor 1950 Carbotech 3 Days.

site_title: The art of watchmaking
summary: Patek Philippe unveiled nine limited-edition watches at The Art of Watches Grand-Exhibition New York 2017, showcasing the brand's expertise in watchmaking. The collection includes the World Time Minute Repeater Ref 5531, a unique timepiece that combines a minute repeater and world time function, and the Calatrava Pilot Ref 5522, a pilot watch with a GMT hand and date display. Only 10 of the World Time Minute Repeater are available, making it a highly sought-after piece. The exhibition also featured the Ladies' Minute Repeater Ref 7000/250, Patek's first chiming timepiece for women, and a special edition of the Men's World Time Ref 5230.

site_title: Keppel's US unit lands US$400m contract to build LNG vessels
summary: Keppel Corp's US unit, Keppel Offshore & Marine, has secured a contract worth over US$400 million to build two liquefied natural gas (LNG) vessels for Pasha Hawaii. The vessels, expected to be delivered in 2020, will be built to Keppel's proprietary design and customised to Pasha Hawaii's requirements. The LNG-fuelled containerships will be hydrodynamically efficient and able to run on LNG fuel, reducing environmental impact and increasing fuel efficiency.

site_title: A fresh branding emerges from deep dive into Singapore spirit
summary: Singapore's new branding campaign, "Passion Made Possible," aims to capture the nation's essence beyond tourism and businesses, showcasing its attitude and mindset through storytelling. The joint effort by the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) and Economic Development Board (EDB) uses local personalities to share their passions, with a focus on entrepreneurship, nature, and innovation. The campaign, which took a year to conceptualize, aims to appeal to sophisticated tourists seeking aspirational value propositions. The move comes after Singapore's tourism numbers grew in recent years, with a 7.7% increase in visitors last year.

site_title: Disney uses a new kind of Force to hype latest Star Wars movie
summary: Disney is launching a global campaign to promote its latest Star Wars movie, The Last Jedi, through an augmented-reality treasure hunt and social media promotions. Starting September 1, fans can use smartphones to participate in the "Find the Force" hunt, which will take place in over 20,000 stores in 30 countries. Fans who participate can win prizes, including tickets to the movie's premiere, and share their experiences on social media. The campaign aims to draw in a new generation of fans and coincide with the launch of new Star Wars merchandise, including action figures and drones.

site_title: China's JD.com partners Qihoo to win more customers
summary: JD.com, China's second-largest e-commerce firm, has partnered with Qihoo 360 Technology Co Ltd to sell goods through the popular browser, search engine, and app store. The deal aims to attract new users, as JD struggles with profitability due to heavy investment in storage and logistics. The partnership allows users to make purchases without leaving the Qihoo apps, mirroring previous deals with Tencent and Baidu. This move follows JD's 66% share price growth this year, with 25-35% of new users coming from its Tencent partnership.

site_title: Setting a milestone
summary: Franck Muller unveiled 10 new timepieces on its 25th birthday, including the Cintree Curvex 25th Anniversary, Vanguard Fullback, and Vanguard Skeleton Sapphire. The Cintree Curvex features a tonneau-shaped case with baroque-inspired numerals, while the Fullback is inspired by an aircraft cockpit. The Vanguard Skeleton Sapphire showcases a tourbillon movement in a virtually scratch-resistant sapphire case. The brand's 25th anniversary models range from $38,820 to $481,586, highlighting the company's commitment to innovative watchmaking.

images.alt_text: The Cintree Curvex 25th Anniversary, a special edition which pays homage to its iconic shape.
The Vanguard Skeleton Sapphire Tourbillon showcases the watch's tourbillon movement to the fullest.
A key feature of the Vanguard Fullback is the dial, which is inspired by the dashboard of an aircraft cockpit.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Corp secured two LNG-fuelled containership contracts worth over US$400 million from Pasha Hawaii, boosting its year-to-date wins to about S$850 million. Health Management International reported a 5.2% year-on-year revenue increase and a net profit of 10.7 million ringgit in Q4 FY17. However, IHH Healthcare's H1 FY17 adjusted core earnings fell 32% year-on-year, missing estimates, leading to a reduced 2017-19 earnings estimate and a "hold" target price of S$1.73.

site_title: The curious case of Becoming Graphic
summary: Singaporean comic artist Sonny Liew's stage debut "Becoming Graphic" at the Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) faced pacing problems, thematic ambiguity, and genre blending issues. Despite Liew's immense gifts as a writer and illustrator, the production struggled to bring a two-dimensional art form onto a three-dimensional stage. The show featured excerpts from Liew's graphic novel "The Green Bolt," exploring the issues of ageing through the eyes of a man with superhuman powers, but ultimately fell back on popular storytelling devices.

site_title: Pavilion Gas secures two-year access rights to LNG terminal
summary: Pavilion Gas, a subsidiary of Pavilion Energy, has secured a two-year access rights to the LNG terminal on Jurong Island, Singapore. The agreement supports higher LNG trading volumes, small-scale LNG opportunities, and vessel cool-down services. Pavilion Gas will have access to 160,000 cubic meters of tank capacity and aims to expand its LNG trading presence regionally and globally. The move strengthens Singapore's position as an Asian LNG hub, with the terminal's total storage capacity set to increase to 800,000 cubic meters by next year.

site_title: Lufthansa eyes Niki in tussle for bankrupt Air Berlin's assets
summary: Lufthansa has submitted a letter of interest in acquiring Air Berlin's Niki unit and other assets, as part of the insolvent carrier's restructuring process. The German airline aims to strengthen its position on German-Spain routes, where it would control around 95% of domestic routes if it acquired Niki. Lufthansa's interest is seen as a response to Ryanair's bid for Air Berlin as a whole, which has been criticized for favoring the German carrier. Other interested parties, including Condor and EasyJet, are also involved in the negotiations.

site_title: Cargill Inc, Bill Gates bet on 'clean' meat
summary: Cargill Inc and Bill Gates have invested $17 million in Memphis Meats, a startup that produces meat from animal cells without raising livestock. The investment, led by venture capital firm DFJ, aims to reduce the environmental, animal welfare, and health impacts of traditional meat production. Memphis Meats has raised a total of $22 million, signaling a commitment to the "clean-meat movement." The investment will allow Cargill to enter the cultured protein market and work with Memphis Meats to innovate and commercialize sustainable meat alternatives.

site_title: Samsung sounds right Note 8 in wary launch of latest wares
summary: Samsung launched its Galaxy Note 8 in Singapore on Wednesday, just weeks before the expected release of the next iPhone. The phone boasts a 6.3-inch touchscreen, improved dual rear cameras, and a stylus, but a smaller battery than its predecessor. Despite a tumultuous past, Samsung has taken a cautious approach to launch the Note 8, bundling it with two optional packages and offering a comprehensive after-sales support suite. Analysts believe the phone's success will gauge Samsung's brand recovery and longer-term appeal.

site_title: High five for the men
summary: Bulgari has introduced five new men's watch models, including the world's thinnest self-winding watch, a skeleton tourbillon, a see-through tourbillon complication, a dress watch, and a sleek Octo Finissimo Automatic. The new Octo Finissimo Automatic measures 5.15mm slim and features a new 2.23mm self-winding movement. Other new models include the Octo Tourbillon Skeleton and the Octo Roma dress watch, which showcases the brand's focus on elegance and modernity. Prices range from S$8,210 to S$25,900.

site_title: Japan steelmakers' shares fall after reports of surprise price cuts
summary: Japan's steelmakers see shares fall after Nippon Steel agrees to surprise price cuts for 6 months through September with Toyota Motor, weighing on margins. The price cuts are below expectations, with Toyota to drop wholesale steel prices for parts suppliers by around 5,000 yen per tonne. This comes as Chinese iron ore futures rise to their highest level in over five months, reflecting strong demand. Japanese steelmakers forecast solid profit growth in the business year, but the price cuts may impact this.

site_title: Suki Sushi to make general offer for Mary Chia Holdings
summary: Suki Sushi Pte Ltd, 95.45% owned by Lee Boon Leng and his wife, has agreed to acquire 60.98% of Mary Chia Holdings, a Singapore-based beauty chain, for S$11 million. The offeror, Suki Sushi, will maintain Catalist listing status and control 80.97% of Mary Chia Holdings after the acquisition. The offer price is S$0.111 per share, and the group incurred net losses of S$5.7 million in the latest financial year. Suki Sushi plans to undertake a strategic review to strengthen the group's financial position and explore diversification into other sectors.

site_title: Singing praises of seniors-only supergroup
summary: The documentary "Buena Vista Social Club: Adios" revisits the triumphs of a Cuban ensemble 20 years after their World Music breakthrough. The film, directed by Lucy Walker, explores the backstory of the group's main players, including Ibrahim Ferrer and Omara Portuondo, who rose from being backup singers to headliners. The documentary showcases their late-in-life success, performing despite advancing age and ailments, and highlights the significance of their music, which tells of life's torment and suffering. The film is a welcome addition to the music history, with the surviving members' dedication to their craft.

site_title: Raízen nears buying Shell's Argentina gas station chain: sources
summary: Brazil's Raízen Energia SA is close to buying Royal Dutch Shell's Argentina gas station network for over US$1 billion, surpassing rival offers from YPF SA, Quinenco SA, and Petrochina Co Ltd. Raízen's non-binding bid topped the competitive auction process overseen by Credit Suisse Group AG. The deal is part of Shell's US$30 billion divestiture program to cut debt, and Raízen's CEO has personally engaged in acquisition talks. The sale would give Raízen control of 630 Argentine gas stations.

site_title: At the races
summary: Chopard has launched a pair of chronograph watches, the Mille Miglia Classic Chronograph for men and women, marking the 30th anniversary of its partnership with the Mille Miglia vintage car race in Italy. The male watch features a 42mm stainless case with a tachymetric scale, while the female watch has a 39mm steel frame with a gem-set bezel. Both watches are powered by a COSC-certified automatic movement and are part of the Classic and GT XL lines, inspired by the oldest and most recent cars in the Mille Miglia collection, respectively.

site_title: China to use 'all necessary' means to defend itself against Trump 'protectionism'
summary: China has vowed to defend itself against US President Donald Trump's "protectionism" and use all necessary means to protect its trade interests. The statement came after the US initiated an investigation into Chinese companies accused of stealing US intellectual property. China's Commerce Ministry called the move "irresponsible" and a "violation" of international trade rules. Despite the tension, experts believe a trade war between the two countries is unlikely due to the potential damage it could cause to both economies.

site_title: When soft power calls, surrender
summary: Chambolle-Musigny wines are described as "delicacy and seeming weightlessness" that enchant and tease, defying benchmarking. The 1997 Chambolle-Musigny Premier Cru La Combe D'Orveaux from Domaine Anne Gros is noted for its subtle and light flavors that leave a lasting impression, but resist easy identification. The wine is its own reference point, evading attempts to pin down a familiar sensory experience. This unique characteristic makes Chambolle-Musigny wines stand out in the world of Burgundy.

site_title: Macau struggles to recover from Typhoon Hato's destruction
summary: Typhoon Hato hit Macau, killing at least 9 people, leaving over half the city without water and power, and causing widespread destruction. The storm's powerful winds of over 200 km/h ripped away building exteriors, including casino facades. Many residents and tourists criticized the government for being unprepared, with some saying the city looked like it was in a war. The typhoon also affected Hong Kong, with 34 people injured and hundreds of flights cancelled. Hato was downgraded to a tropical storm and was expected to weaken further as it moved inland.

site_title: The hills are alive ... with Austrian choirs
summary: Austrian choirs Chorus Sine Nomine and A-cappella-Chor Villach will perform in Singapore next week. Chorus Sine Nomine, founded in 1991, has won international competitions and will share the stage with pianist Churen Li in a concert on Sept 3. A-cappella-Chor Villach, founded in 1855, will perform folk songs and sacred music at the Enabling Village and Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music. The performances aim to share European musical culture with Singaporeans and the local music community.

site_title: Dancing in the city
summary: A dance performance titled MARK, choreographed by Daniel Kok, will be shown in public again at *SCAPE Playspace on Aug 27 and Marina Bay Sands Event Plaza on Aug 31 and Sept 2. The 85-minute dance explores the tension between individuality, collectivity, and uniformity, featuring nine dancers moving to music in a National Library Plaza setting. Admission is free, allowing the public to experience the hypnotic performance.

images.alt_text: Choreographed by Daniel Kok, the work titled MARK (above).

site_title: US Navy suspends sea search efforts for missing USS McCain sailors
summary: The US Navy suspended search and rescue operations for 10 missing USS John S McCain sailors after 80 hours of multinational efforts. A sailor was confirmed dead, and remains of others were found inside the damaged hull. The US Navy will continue to search-and-recover efforts inside flooded sailors. The pre-dawn collision on Monday, the fourth major accident for the US Pacific Fleet this year, prompted a review of its operations and led to the removal of the Seventh Fleet Commander.

site_title: Wing Tai Q4 earnings up despite impairment
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a net profit of S$9.49 million for the fourth quarter of 2017, up from S$1.88 million a year ago, driven by a higher contribution from its associated company in Hong Kong and a tax credit of S$5.3 million. Revenue fell 58% to S$58.64 million. The company also reported an impairment charge for its joint-venture condo development, The Crest, but still managed to increase earnings per share and net asset value per share. Wing Tai expects to book a profit from units sold in its Shanghai project and plans to rationalize its retail business.

site_title: Fly me to the moon
summary: Omega's Speedmaster series, certified by NASA for space exploration, has undergone numerous design and technological changes since its introduction in 1957. The first Speedmaster, Ref CK2915, was marketed to car enthusiasts and racing drivers, while the CK2998 model, introduced in 1959, featured a black aluminum tachymeter bezel. The Speedmaster ST 105.003, submitted to NASA in 1964, became the official watch for astronauts, including those on the Gemini mission. The series has continued to evolve with new models, including the Moonwatch, which debuted in 1968, and the Speedmaster 57, introduced in 2013, featuring Omega's Co-Axial movement.

images.alt_text: The Dark Side of the Moon
The first Speedmaster 1957 - Broad Arrow
Speedmaster 125 was created in 1973 to celebrate Omega's 125th anniversary, indicated by the polished "125" on the black dial.

When astronaut Edward White stepped outside his space capsule on the Gemini mission, Speedmaster 105.003 was strapped on his wrist.
The asymmetric case, one of the Speedmaster's trademark design-elements, made its debut in 1964 with ST 105.012.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ezion Holdings is arranging informal meetings with lenders and note holders amid anticipated cash flow challenges. The company halted trading in its shares on Aug 10. FJ Benjamin reported a narrowed net loss of S$17.42 million in its fiscal year ended June 30, with improved gross profit margin due to tighter inventory management. OUE Commercial Reit successfully priced S$150 million of fixed-rate notes with an interest rate of 3.03% under its S$1.5 billion multi-currency debt issuance programme.

site_title: Germany's 'diesel fear' sees 4.5b euros in used cars gather dust
summary: Germany's diesel car market is experiencing a significant downturn due to concerns over pollution, causing a backlog of 4.5 billion euros in used models on dealer lots. A deal between major carmakers to upgrade newer diesel cars and offer trade-in incentives has not alleviated concerns, with German Environment Minister Barbara Hendricks stating the planned software upgrades are insufficient. As a result, 300,000 used vehicles are piling up, and car dealers are cutting prices, potentially triggering writedowns in carmakers' lease portfolios.

site_title: S'pore startups get leg-up to enter Thai market
summary: Singapore tech companies can now enter the Thai market with ease, thanks to two memoranda of understanding (MOUs) signed with Thai partners C asean and Hubba. The agreements aim to foster collaboration in sectors like e-commerce, fintech, and healthtech. This move is seen as an attractive opportunity for Singapore tech companies to tap into the growing Thai market, following International Enterprise (IE) Singapore's vision.

images.alt_text: Skyline of Bangkok.

site_title: Lingering spell of Cigarettes After Sex
summary: Cigarettes After Sex, a Texas-based Brooklyn quartet, sold out its first-ever show in Singapore, despite being an internet sensation. The band's slow-burning ballads, inspired by frontman Greg Gonzalez's broken relationships, received critical acclaim for its self-titled debut album. The intimate performance featured stripped-down versions of their songs, including a haunting rendition of REO Speedwagon's "Keep On Loving You." The band's minimalist approach transformed sadness into a thing of beauty, leaving the audience spellbound.

site_title: Swedish govt promises welfare splurge in election year
summary: Sweden's centre-left coalition plans to spend billions more on teachers, nurses, and police ahead of next year's election, utilizing the country's strong economy and low debt. The government aims to boost job growth, reduce unemployment to 5.9%, and invest in healthcare, education, and police forces. The 40 billion crowns (S$6.74 billion) extra budget will also include tax cuts for pensioners. The move is seen as a response to declining social wellbeing and the challenges posed by a growing migrant population.

site_title: US: Wall St slips ahead of Jackson Hole meet
summary: US stocks slipped on Thursday ahead of the Jackson Hole meeting of central bankers, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.11% and the S&P 500 down 0.11%. Investors are awaiting speeches from Janet Yellen and Mario Draghi, but expect no fresh policy guidance. Geopolitical concerns and President Trump's comments on border funding weighed on markets, with the Nasdaq Composite down 0.13%.

site_title: Time for Asian businesses to ramp up their cyber security defences
summary: Asian businesses are under pressure to boost their cyber security defenses as technology continues to integrate into daily life. A survey of 500 industry professionals found that the biggest cyber security challenge is a lack of awareness among employees, with 47% citing this as a major issue. Many companies are taking a reactive approach to cyber security, relying on basic defenses such as antivirus solutions and firewalls, and are not investing enough in training employees or implementing preventative measures. To effectively combat cyber threats, companies need to adopt a proactive mindset and invest in dedicated employees, centralised security platforms, and smart tools to prevent cyber breaches.

site_title: China slams reported Indian road project on border
summary: China has condemned India's reported plan to build a road in the disputed Ladakh region, calling it a contradiction to India's words and actions on border issues. The road project, which would run through the region near Pangong Lake, follows a separate Chinese attempt to build a road in the Doklam area, sparking a standoff between hundreds of Indian and Chinese soldiers. China's foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying accused India of trespassing on Chinese soil and said the road construction is not conducive to peace and stability in the area.

site_title: Bid for a good cause
summary: The 2017 Only Watch charity auction, benefiting a cure for Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, may see Patek Philippe's Ref 5208T-010, a triple-complication watch valued at $932,000 to $1.14 million, break a record. Other notable timepieces include FP Journe's Chronographe Monopoussoir Rattrapante, valued at $208,000 to $425,000, and MB&F's HM8 model, valued at $83,000 to $103,000. The auction, hosted by Christie's, will feature 48 one-of-a-kind timepieces from luxury brands, with proceeds benefiting the cause.

site_title: India's crackdown on Chinese tech firms gathering pace
summary: India intensifies a crackdown on Chinese technology companies, with security testing of China's UC Browser underway to determine if it's leaking data. The government aims to secure Indian cyberspace and digital infrastructure, amid a tense stand-off with China over territory. Chinese phone companies, including Xiaomi and Lenovo, have improved market share, and India's imports of electronics are expected to rise to $300 billion by 2020. The government is seeking to ensure the safety and security of devices, and companies have been directed to provide written responses on their safety and security practices.

site_title: The spaceship has landed
summary: Swiss watch brand MB&F has created a spaceship-like timepiece called the Horological Machine Number 6 Alien Nation, featuring a crew of six individually modelled and hand-sculpted aliens. The watch, powered by the same movement as its predecessors, is made entirely of sapphire crystal and features a unique design inspired by 1970s and 1980s Japanese anime TV series Capitaine Flam. Only four unique pieces will be produced due to the watch's complexity, requiring up to 510 hours of work to achieve seamless sapphire crystal construction.

site_title: Creative Technology swings into the red in Q4 and FY17
summary: Creative Technology Ltd reported a net loss of US$5.54 million in Q4 FY17, down from a net profit of US$535,000 the previous year, due to a 15% decline in net sales to US$14.48 million. The company also saw a net loss of US$22.91 million for the full year, with 17% decline in net sales to US$69.9 million. The decline was attributed to uncertain and difficult market conditions affecting product sales.

site_title: Goldman, Pimco load up on mortgage bonds as junk grows riskier
summary: Big investors are shifting from junk debt to mortgage bonds as junk debt's risk increases. Pacific Investment Management Co, Goldman Sachs Asset Management, and others are buying mortgage-backed securities, while selling high-yield corporate bonds. These investors say mortgage bonds offer higher potential returns given the risk. The US mortgage market is showing signs of strength, and investors are betting on housing after years of tight mortgage credit. This shift may signal the end of a bull market in corporate credit, with investors seeking safer assets.

site_title: EU risks breakup without social dumping reform: Macron
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron warned that the EU risks breakup if it fails to reform the Posted Workers Directive, allowing firms to send temporary workers from low-wage countries to rich economies without paying local social charges. Macron wants to limit job duration to 12 months and increase efforts to fight abuse. Eastern European governments oppose the plan, citing concerns over competitiveness. Macron's proposals aim to address "social dumping" and ensure public opinion in developed countries accepts the current format. A European Union summit in Brussels on October 19-20 will discuss the reform.

summary:

Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: July US existing home sales lowest of 2017
summary: US existing home sales fell to the lowest of 2017 in July, marking the second consecutive month of decline, due to high prices and a tight supply. Most homes sold within a month, with prices rising faster than incomes in much of the US. This drop in sales coincided with a decline in new single-family home sales, also reported by the Commerce Department.

site_title: Brazil to crack down on ship sales that feed 'toxic' scrap trade
summary: Brazilian regulators plan to strengthen rules to prevent the sale of aging ships to South Asian coastal scrapyards, which have been criticized for using dirty and dangerous methods. Companies such as Petrobras and Vale could face fines of up to 10 million reais if they violate international standards. The move aims to prevent vessels from being sent to shipbreaking facilities in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh, where workers are exposed to hazardous chemicals and injury and death rates are high.

site_title: OUE C-Reit prices S$150m fixed-rate notes with 3.03% interest
summary: OUE Commercial Reit Management successfully priced S$150 million worth of fixed-rate notes with a 3.03% interest rate, set to mature on Sept 5, 2020. The notes were priced in excess of S$400 million, primarily backed by institutional investors. The net proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings and fund capital expenditure or working capital requirements, diversifying the Reit's funding sources and improving financial flexibility.

site_title: Tiffany rises as Lady Gaga helps fuel demand for new designs
summary: Tiffany & Co. shares rose 3% in early trading after the jeweler reported 92 US cents in earnings per share for the second quarter, beating analysts' projections. The company's strategy to revamp stores and offer new designs, such as the HardWear collection promoted by Lady Gaga, appears to be working, with same-store sales exceeding estimates in the US and Japan. Despite missing estimates in Europe and Asia, Tiffany maintained its forecast for the full year, citing growth in fashion and designer jewelry.

site_title: Kelvin Tang appointed as chief executive officer of KrisEnergy
summary: KrisEnergy Ltd has appointed Kelvin Tang as its new chief executive officer (CEO) effective September 1, following the resignation of Jeffrey MacDonald as interim CEO. Tang, who is currently the company's chief operating officer and president of Cambodian operations, has been with the company since 2009. His appointment comes as the company welcomes the Block A petroleum agreement, a significant deal for Cambodia and KrisEnergy. Tang expressed his commitment to executing development plans and creating value for all stakeholders.

site_title: Single ticket scoops US$758.7 million US jackpot
summary: A single ticket in Massachusetts won the US$758.7 million US jackpot, the second-largest in US history. The winning numbers were 6, 7, 16, 23, and 26, with Powerball number 4. The ticket was purchased in Chicopee, about 160 kilometers west of Boston. The winner has one year to claim their prize, choosing between a 30-year annuity or a one-off cash lump sum of US$480.5 million. This jackpot surpasses the 2016 record of nearly US$1.6 billion, which was split among three winners.

site_title: Good Hour International clinches Thakral's HK warehouse properties with HK$420m bid
summary: Good Hour International Limited has clinched Thakral Corporation Ltd's Hong Kong warehouse properties with a HK$420 million bid. The properties, comprising four floors of a warehouse in Kowloon, were put up for sale by Thakral. The deal is subject to shareholders' approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Denmark wants to attract more IPOs by cutting tax on equity investments
summary: Denmark aims to attract more initial public offerings (IPOs) by cutting tax on equity investments. The country's business minister, Brian Mikkelsen, plans to reduce tax on deposits up to 500,000 Danish crowns to 1.25% annually, making it more attractive for companies to list on the Copenhagen stock exchange. The move is expected to inject 500-1 billion crowns into small and medium-sized companies each year, aiming to boost the number of IPOs in Denmark, which fell to just five last year compared to 152 in Sweden and 79 in Norway.

site_title: IRAS collected S$47b in tax revenue in FY2017; up nearly 5% from a year ago
summary: IRAS collected S$47 billion in tax revenue in FY2017, a 5% increase from the previous year. This accounts for 68.2% of the Singaporean government's operating revenue and 11.3% of GDP. The main contributors were corporate and individual income taxes, with GST collection also rising to S$11.1 billion. The cost of collection remained low at 0.84 cents per dollar collected, and tax compliance remained high.

site_title: Cyber bank robbers stick up Ethereum owners for US$225m
summary: Cyber thieves have targeted Ethereum owners, stealing approximately US$225 million in phishing scams this year. Chainalysis estimates that over 30,000 people have lost an average of US$7,500 each. The scammers, often using fake websites and social media accounts, trick investors into sending money to internet addresses pretending to be funding sites for digital token offerings related to the Ethereum blockchain technology. The losses are approaching the US$390 million incurred by robberies in 2015, and the cryptocurrency phishers are considered a significant threat.

images.alt_text: Here's another reason to be leery of the initial coin offerings being done at a staggering pace in the cryptocurrency world: there's a one-in-10 chance you'll end up a victim of theft.

site_title: Oil slips as market focus shifts to Jackson Hole
summary: Oil prices slipped on Thursday as the US dollar strengthened ahead of the Jackson Hole meeting of central bankers, potentially signaling changes to monetary policy. Benchmark Brent crude fell 20 US cents to $52.37 a barrel, while US light, sweet crude declined 20 US cents to $48.21 a barrel. The meeting may provide volatility for the US dollar and hit oil prices. Recent gains were reversed as traders took profits after Tropical Depression Harvey strengthened into a Category I hurricane, potentially disrupting oil production in the Gulf of Mexico.

site_title: China prosecutors charge Trafigura, staff member in 3-year oil probe: document
summary: Chinese prosecutors have charged Trafigura's Singapore division and a Beijing-based staff member, Tian Meng, for allegedly fabricating gasoline deals with a Chinese oil trading company. The charges, filed on August 4, include fraudulently obtaining bank credit through fabricated oil deals. Zhang Wei, a Chinese fuel trader and shareholder in Qingdao United Energy, has also been charged for conspiring with Tian Meng. The charges follow a three-year probe into the alleged trade financing deals, which resulted in Qingdao United Energy losing $32 million.

site_title: SEA Games: Gold in 21 seconds for Filipino-Brit boxer
summary: Filipino-British boxer John Marvin won the Southeast Asian Games light heavyweight title in 21 seconds, stopping Malaysia's Adli Hafidz Mohamad Pauzi. Marvin, a lance corporal in the British Army, aimed to avoid a judges' decision, following a questionable loss by teammate Carlo Paalam. Marvin dedicated the win to Paalam and the Philippines, seeking revenge for Paalam's loss. The Philippines claimed its second gold medal through middleweight Eumir Felix Marcial, while Malaysia won its first gold in the light flyweight class with Muhamad Fuad Redzuan's victory.

site_title: Gold slips on firmer US dollar ahead of Jackson Hole meeting
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to $1,287.10 an ounce, pressured by a firmer US dollar ahead of the Jackson Hole meeting of central bankers. Investors await signals on interest rates, which gold is sensitive to. Despite US President Trump's threat to shut down the government unless he gets funding for a border wall with Mexico, gold prices are under pressure. Markets are expecting some kind of tightening from the Federal Reserve, contributing to gold's decline.

site_title: FJ Benjamin posts S$17.42m net loss for FY17
summary: FJ Benjamin, a Singapore retailer, posted a net loss of S$17.42 million for FY17, narrowing from S$22.96 million the previous year. Revenue declined 18% to S$207.49 million, mainly due to discontinued businesses and decreased sales to an Indonesian associate. Despite a 3% increase in gross profit margin to 42%, the group faces a challenging operating environment due to sluggish economic growth and a strengthening Singapore dollar. Management remains vigilant on costs and aims to identify new business opportunities to enhance the group's portfolio and return to profitability.

site_title: China Vanke H1 core profit up 33.5%, sees land market cooling
summary: China Vanke Co, the country's second-largest developer, reported a 33.5% rise in first-half core profit to 7.1 billion yuan, driven by a property boom and higher margins. The company expects the land market to cool down as the residential property market stabilizes. This follows a prolonged struggle for boardroom control, which ended when a state-owned stake was raised to 29.38%. Vanke's net profit rose 36.5% to 7.3 billion yuan, while revenue dropped 6.7% due to fewer completed projects. The company will work closely with Shenzhen Metro Group to implement a railway-plus-property strategy.

site_title: China Everbright secures 71m yuan contract for waste water treatment in Jiangsu
summary: China Everbright Water Limited has secured a 71 million yuan (S$14.5 million) contract for the Xinyi City Waste Water Treatment project in Jiangsu Province. The project, which will be invested, constructed, and operated under a build-operate-transfer model, aims to process municipal and industrial waste water from various areas. With a 24-year concession period, the project will increase Xinyi City's total daily treatment capacity to 100,000 cubic meters, meeting the national Grade 1A standard for treated water.

site_title: China's Baoshan H1 profit hits highest in 5 years
summary: China's Baoshan Iron and Steel Co Ltd reported a 65% surge in net profit for the first half of the year, reaching 6.2 billion yuan, the highest in 5 years. Revenue rose 106.6% to 169.93 billion yuan due to better-than-expected demand for steel products. The company's crude steel output increased 11.5% compared to the same period last year, with steel rebar prices reaching 4-1/2 year highs amid concerns about Beijing's efforts to cut outdated capacity and curb low-end steel output.

site_title: Abercrombie posts much smaller loss than expected, shares soar
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch Co reported a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss, with net sales falling slightly to $779.3 million. The company's Hollister surfwear brand drove results, with sales rising 5% at established stores. In contrast, the company's namesake brand saw same-store sales decline 7%. Abercrombie's shares surged 18% as the company reported a net loss of $15.5 million, beating analysts' expectations. The results come as the teen apparel market faces changing consumer tastes and pressure from fast-fashion retailers.

site_title: Denmark to seek murder charge against submarine inventor
summary: Denmark's prosecutors plan to seek a murder charge against Peter Madsen, the inventor of a self-built submarine, in connection with the disappearance and murder of Swedish journalist Kim Wall. Wall's headless torso was found floating off Denmark in September 2017. Madsen, 46, has denied the allegations, claiming Wall died in an accident on board the submarine. Prosecutors believe Wall's body was deliberately mutilated and weighted down. A court hearing to extend Madsen's custody is set for September 5.

site_title: Flash: IRAS collected S$47b in tax revenue in FY2017; up nearly 5% from a year ago
summary: IRAS collected S$47 billion in tax revenue in FY2017, a 5% increase from the previous year. This marks a significant achievement for the agency.

site_title: Suki Sushi to acquire 61% of Mary Chia Holdings
summary: SUKI Sushi Pte Ltd agreed to acquire 61% of Mary Chia Holdings for S$11 million, aiming to maintain the company's listing status. The acquisition, valued at about S$0.111 per share, translates to a 1.5% increase in Mary Chia's stock price. After the acquisition, SUKI Sushi and its associates will own approximately 80.97% of the total shares.

site_title: UK shop sales slide unexpectedly in August, retailers' mood downbeat: CBI
summary: UK retail sales growth slowed in August to -10, the lowest since July 2016, due to rising prices and consumer squeeze. The Confederation of British Industry's monthly retail sales balance fell short of forecasts, with retailers expecting a modest slowdown in growth. Retailers reduced staff at the fastest pace since 2009 and are downbeat about the current business situation, citing higher inflation. The Brexit vote has led to a decline in the value of sterling, pushing up inflation and reducing disposable income.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.56 points to 1,775.50, driven by gains in the market. The index closed higher on Thursday with 433 gainers outnumbering 414 losers. Total volume was 2.13 billion lots worth RM1.97 billion.

site_title: China Life Insurance H1 profit rises 18% on strong investment income
summary: China Life Insurance Co Ltd reported a 17.8% increase in first-half net profit to 12.242 billion yuan (S$2.5 billion), driven by strong investment income of 11.45% to 56.66 billion yuan. This follows a broader trend in China's insurance industry, where overall first-half earnings rose 10% to 116.1 billion yuan. The results underscore the industry's reliance on investment returns.

site_title: China's ZTE posts 30% rise in H1 profit on 4G, handsets
summary: Chinese telecommunications equipment maker ZTE Corp reported a 30% rise in first-half net profit to 2.29 billion yuan, matching its forecast, driven by increased investments in 4G infrastructure and mobile phone sales. Revenue rose 13% to 54 billion yuan. ZTE plans to invest more in wireless and 5G technology and international marketing in the second half of 2017. The company also reported a 24% growth in its consumer business, mainly due to increased handset sales overseas.

site_title: AirAsia X reports big jump in quarterly profit on forex gains
summary: AirAsia X, Malaysia's long-haul budget airline, reported a seventh consecutive quarterly profit of 47.4 million ringgit, driven by foreign exchange gains and deferred taxes. Revenue rose 17% to a record 1.04 billion ringgit, with aircraft leasing income growing 15% and ancillary revenue increasing 41%. The airline expects to maintain its full-year earnings estimate of 193 million ringgit, with plans to strengthen its position in Australia and focus on North Asia growth.

site_title: Chinese selfie app maker Meitu H1 loss narrows as revenue surges
summary: Meitu Inc, a Chinese selfie app maker, reported a 272% surge in first-half revenue to 2.18 billion yuan, driven by strong demand from female consumers. The company's adjusted net loss narrowed by 87% to 33 million yuan. Revenue growth was fueled by higher income from handset sales and a 762% surge in revenues from internet services and others.

site_title: Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance buying Singapore property, casualty insurance firm First Capital Insurance
summary: Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance (MSI) is acquiring Singapore's largest property and casualty insurance company First Capital Insurance from Fairfax Financial Holdings for $1.6 billion. MSI will acquire 97.7% of First Capital's stake, further solidifying its leading position in Asean's non-life insurance market. The deal is expected to complete by March 2018, subject to regulatory approvals. MSI will also partner with Fairfax in reinsurance relationships and digital technologies, aiming to expand its international business, particularly in Asia.

site_title: China's appetite for steak grows, Beijing ends its beef with imports
summary: China has lifted its 14-year ban on importing beef from the US, South Africa, and Ireland, amid a surge in demand from the country's growing middle class for steaks and ribs. The move aims to address domestic supplies and food safety concerns, with beef now the fastest-growing meat in China. The country's beef imports have surpassed 800,000 tonnes worth $2.6 billion, making it the world's second-largest importer after the US. However, the increased competition may unsettle current top suppliers, and domestic production is struggling to keep up with demand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down after Trump threats
summary: Tokyo stocks declined Thursday, closing 0.42% lower due to a strong yen and investor sentiment affected by President Donald Trump's remarks on a key trade agreement and border wall with Mexico. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 19,353.77, and the Topix index of all first-section issues fell 0.49% to 1,592.20.

site_title: Dubai's DP World reports flat half-year profit
summary: DP World, a leading port operator, reported a flat half-year net profit of $606 million for the six months to June 30, down from $608 million last year. Revenue increased 9.6% to $2.29 billion. The company's P&O Maritime subsidiary acquired Reyser in June, while Qatari vessels are banned from its UAE terminals due to a dispute.

site_title: Australia: Shares finish higher
summary: Australian shares finished higher on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 8.34 points, or 0.2%, to 5,745.50. The gains were driven by upbeat profit numbers from miner South32 Ltd and firm commodity prices, which lifted material stocks. Nickel prices surged to an eight-month high, while zinc and aluminium prices also rose. However, financial stocks lost ground, with Woolworths Ltd and Commonwealth Bank of Australia falling 3.4% and 0.8%, respectively.

site_title: Reports of Infosys co-founder Nilekani's board return trigger stock rebound
summary: Infosys co-founder Nandan Nilekani is set to return as non-executive chairman, resolving a dispute between the board and founders. The move comes after a series of governance lapses and a massive sell-off in shares following the resignation of CEO Vishal Sikka. Nilekani's return aims to achieve a series of goals, including hiring a new CEO. The news has led to a 2.4% increase in Infosys shares, which have gained 4.8% in the last three sessions. Nilekani's return is seen as a comfort to stakeholders, with a track record of running the company as CEO.

site_title: Driverless cars of the future confront rules written for drivers
summary: US regulators are poised to overhaul the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards to accommodate self-driving cars, which could be deployed in less than 10 years. The regulations, currently written for human drivers, must be adapted to address technical challenges and safety concerns. Automakers and industry groups are pressing for swift action, while safety advocates warn of a complicated and time-consuming process. The overhaul is expected to be one of the biggest updates to the safety standards in decades, with nearly 900 pages of rules to be revised.

images.alt_text: When the US government finally got around to regulating auto safety in 1967, it insisted that every car have seatbelts and that the steering column be engineered to absorb impact so it wouldn't spear the driver.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4 per cent up on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% on Thursday, advancing to 3,272.16, driven by a mix of gainers and losers. About 2.19 billion shares worth S$1.04 billion changed hands. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite ongoing US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Qatar to reinstate ambassador to Iran amid Gulf crisis
summary: Qatar plans to restore its ambassador to Iran, ending a 1-year hiatus due to diplomatic friction within the Gulf. The move aims to bolster relations between the two countries, which share the world's largest natural gas field. Qatar seeks to strengthen ties with Iran in all fields, despite being locked in a diplomatic impasse with Saudi Arabia. The decision comes as Qatar faces economic pressure from the boycott, and Iran's involvement may help alleviate food import issues.

site_title: NZ dollar near 2-month lows, Aussie rangebound with focus on Jackson Hole
summary: The New Zealand dollar is near two-month lows at US$0.7218, following the government's downgrade of its growth outlook. The Australian dollar remains rangebound at US$0.7896. Traders are focused on the Jackson Hole central bankers' meeting, where speeches from Janet Yellen and Mario Draghi are expected to influence markets. The upcoming New Zealand election and dual citizenship crisis in Australia are also contributing to the currency volatility.

site_title: Australia: Shares up, South32 and Santos jump on strong profits; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5747.70, boosted by South32 Ltd's 5% surge in earnings, a positive sign for the materials sector. Heavyweights BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto also benefited. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.2% on Wednesday.

site_title: PetroChina rewards investors with full profit payout on oil rise
summary: PetroChina, China's largest oil and gas producer, has announced a full profit payout to shareholders, rewarding investors with 12.7 billion yuan (S$2.6 billion) in profits. The payout is nearly triple the forecast, driven by higher global crude prices averaging 30% higher than last year. Despite this, China's oil output fell 5% in the first half, and the company's oil and gas output declined 3% to 725.7 million barrels of oil equivalent.

site_title: Crackdown risk has China's hottest stocks looking vulnerable
summary: China's commodity shares, the best performing part of the market, are experiencing increased volatility amid warnings of possible government intervention to cool surging raw material prices. The 30-day price swing on a gauge of commodity producers reached its highest since April 2016, with a 2.4% tumble on Wednesday. Analysts warn of increased selling pressure on commodity shares if policymakers intervene, potentially blighting the market's few bright spots. The materials index has surged 13% in the second half of the year, five times the pace of the CSI 300 Index.

site_title: Wing Tai posts Q4 profit of S$9.49m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a net profit of S$9.49 million for Q4 FY 2017, up from S$1.88 million in the same period last year, driven by higher share of profits from associated and joint venture companies and a tax credit of S$5.3 million. Revenue fell 58% to S$58.64 million. Earnings per share rose to 1.22 Singapore cents, and the net asset value per share increased to S$4.07. Shareholders will receive a first and final dividend of three Singapore cents and a special dividend of the same quantum.

site_title: Regulator issue directive for software fix for A350 on explosion risk
summary: European aviation safety authorities have issued an emergency directive for Airbus A350-900 operators to upload a software fix to prevent overheating of the hydraulic system and potential explosion risk. The issue was discovered after an overheat failure mode was found in the hydraulic engine driven pump, which could lead to uncontrolled fuel-air ignition. Airbus has informed operators and is investigating further action. Airlines including Lufthansa, Singapore Airlines, and Cathay Pacific have complied with the directive, with no expected impact on their A350 fleets. The software fix aims to mitigate the risk of explosion.

site_title: STB, EDB launch unified Passion Made Possible brand for Singapore
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) and Economic Development Board (EDB) have launched a unified brand, Passion Made Possible, to market Singapore internationally for tourism and business.
