summary: The Euro zone manufacturing sector experienced its best month of growth in six-and-a-half years in August, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 57.4. Services growth, however, dipped to 54.9, the weakest in seven months. Overall economic growth is projected at 0.5% for the July-September period, slightly down from the previous quarter. Despite a slight slowdown, the euro zone economy continues to expand, with price pressures accelerating slightly.

site_title: Reit Association of Singapore appoints Nupur Joshi as new CEO
summary: The Reit Association of Singapore has appointed Nupur Joshi as its new CEO, succeeding Sonny Tan. Joshi will lead the association with the executive committee, led by President Chua Tiow Chye. Chua thanked Tan for his contributions and hard work as the association's first CEO.

site_title: Oil prices fall on concerns of oversupply as Libyan output recovers
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday due to concerns of oversupply as Libyan output recovers. Brent crude futures dropped 23 US cents, or 0.4%, to $51.64 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 24 US cents, or 0.5%, to $47.59 per barrel. Libya's Sharara oil field, a key producer, has increased output to 280,000 barrels per day, exceeding OPEC's production target, and may lead to a volatile supply situation.

images.alt_text: Oil markets were roiled on Monday after Tropical Storm Harvey wreaked havoc along the US Gulf Coast over the weekend, crippling Houston and its port, and knocking out several refineries as well as some crude production.

site_title: Europeans are abandoning their utility companies in droves
summary: Europe's largest and most-established utilities are experiencing a significant exodus of customers, with an average annual rate of nearly 12% since 2010. The largest six utilities in the UK have lost over 2 million customers since 2010, as new companies offer lower prices, better customer service, and a commitment to renewables. The liberalization of Europe's utility markets in the 1990s and 2007 has enabled customers to shop around and switch providers, with independent power retailers becoming the fourth largest provider of household electricity in Britain.

site_title: Johnnie Walker launches limited edition Blenders' Batch whiskies
summary: Johnnie Walker is launching three limited edition Blenders' Batch whiskies in Mexico City, designed for both whisky aficionados and cocktail lovers. The new blends, including Wine Cask Blend, Rum Cask Finish, and Espresso Roast, were crafted by a team of skilled blenders under the guidance of two-time Master Blender Jim Beveridge. The whiskies will be available in selected countries starting September 2017 and globally at top bars starting October 2017, with prices ranging from US$29.99.

site_title: Sim Lian clinches Tampines Court enbloc for S$970m
summary: Sim Lian Development has clinched the enbloc sale of Tampines Court for S$970 million, surpassing the site's reserve price of S$952 million. The sale includes two payments to the state, a differential premium for enhancing the site's intensity and a lease-upgrading premium, which will top up the site's lease to 99 years. The sale works out to around S$676 per square foot of potential gross floor area.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Wednesday, closing at 1,772.94 after a 1.28-point drop. The index saw 2 billion lots traded, with 415 gainers and 454 losers.

site_title: UN racism committee issues 'warning' over US tensions
summary: The United Nations Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination has issued a formal "early warning" over US conditions, citing the proliferation of racist demonstrations, including the Charlottesville unrest in which a woman was killed. The committee invoked its "early warning and urgent action procedure" due to the increasing tensions. This rare move signals potential of a looming civil conflict in the US.

site_title: German economy set to break through 2% growth hurdle in 2017
summary: German economic growth is expected to exceed 2% this year, the first time since 2011, driven by increased momentum in manufacturing and services. The Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 55.7 in August, surpassing economists' predictions. The Bundesbank has hinted that its June forecast of 1.9% growth may be too pessimistic, and IHS Markit's current forecast of 2% growth is likely to be raised. This follows an unexpectedly strong improvement in French manufacturing and is a positive sign for the European economy.

site_title: Financials, healthcare pull Australia lower; NZ closes at record high
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,737 due to poor results from Insurance Australia Group and Healthscope Ltd, dragging down the healthcare and financial sectors. Commonwealth Bank of Australia slipped 0.6% on a lawsuit threat. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index reached a record high of 7,879.46, driven by a 0.2% gain in the consumer staples sector.

site_title: US Navy relieves Seventh Fleet commander in wake of collisions in Asia
summary: The US Navy relieved Seventh Fleet Commander Vice Admiral Joseph Aucoin following a series of collisions involving its warships in Asia. The decision comes days after a pre-dawn collision between a guided-missile destroyer and a merchant vessel east of Singapore and Malaysia, the fourth major incident in the US Pacific Fleet this year. Rear Admiral Phil Sawyer, deputy Pacific Fleet commander, has taken command of the Seventh Fleet, and Vice Admiral Aucoin's removal is attributed to a loss of confidence in his ability to command.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks erase gains on Trump comments, still end at 2-week highs
summary: South Korean won and stocks reached two-week highs on Wednesday, despite US President Donald Trump's comments on a government shutdown. The won closed at 1,131.8 to the US dollar, a 0.2% gain, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.1% to 2,366.40 points. Foreign investors purchased 105.7 billion won worth of Kospi shares, contributing to the gains. The currency and local stocks closed at their highest levels since August 9, but erased earlier gains due to Trump's comments.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore COE premiums fell across the board, with motorcycle and small car premiums declining the most. Singapore inflation edged up to 0.6% in July due to higher retail and water prices. CapitaLand partnered with Alibaba and Lazada to connect shoppers offline and online. Meanwhile, Ascendas-Singbridge and GIC acquired a 16-acre site in Pune, India, and Allianz partnered with Keppel to buy a Shanghai property for $525 million. The Court of Appeal dismissed Tan Cheng Bock's appeal on reserved presidential election.

images.alt_text: Orders for commercial vehicles have skyrocketed but certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums are not expected to rise because of the huge COE supply in the next three months.

site_title: Allianz partners Keppel to buy Shanghai's Hongkou SOHO for US$525m
summary: Allianz has partnered with Keppel Group to buy Shanghai's Hongkou SOHO for US$525 million. The 40% stake will be held by Keppel's Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund, while the remaining 60% will be split equally between Allianz and Keppel Land China. This investment is part of Allianz's strategy to allocate 5% of its global real estate portfolio to the Asia-Pacific region, with Shanghai seen as a key growth hub.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund is said to hire head of US$111b portfolio
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has hired Rashed Sharif as head of domestic investments, tasked with managing its $111 billion portfolio of Saudi assets. Sharif, previously CEO of Riyad Bank's investment-banking unit, will report to Yasir Alrumayyan, the fund's managing director. The move is part of PIF's transformation into a $2 trillion investment giant, aimed at reducing Saudi Arabia's dependence on oil and becoming the world's largest sovereign-wealth fund.

site_title: China's VIPKid raises US$200m led by Tencent, Sequoia
summary: VIPKid, an online education company, has raised US$200 million led by Sequoia Capital China and Tencent Holdings Ltd. The Beijing-based company, which matches Chinese students with North American teachers, now has a valuation of over US$1.5 billion. The investment round is aimed at expanding into new markets and broadening academic offerings.

site_title: India Cabinet approves plans to merge some state-run banks
summary: India's federal cabinet approved plans to merge some state-run banks, addressing concerns over sour assets and capital requirements. The move is part of broader banking sector reforms aimed at boosting credit growth and supporting economic expansion. The government owns majority stakes in 21 lenders, which account for over two-thirds of banking assets in Asia. The consolidation is expected to help meet global Basel III banking rules, requiring billions of dollars in new capital by March 2019. The decision was met with positive market reaction, with state-run banks rising in value.

site_title: Trump lashes out at media in Arizona rally
summary: US President Donald Trump lashed out at the media in a rally speech in Phoenix, Arizona, defending his response to the Charlottesville violence, despite facing bipartisan outrage over his remarks. Trump criticized "dishonest" media coverage, claiming they misrepresent his words, while omitting his initial equivocation. He also mocked fellow Republicans, including Senator Jeff Flake, and hinted at a potential pardon for former Sheriff Joe Arpaio. Trump's speech came as he sought to re-energize his base and build momentum for a border wall, with his approval rating at a historical low of 35%.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge and GIC acquire 16-acre site in Kharadi, Pune
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge and GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, have acquired a 16-acre land parcel in Pune, India. This is part of the AIGP, a growth programme established in 2013 with a target asset size of S$600 million. The acquisition is aimed at deepening the presence of Ascendas-Singbridge and GIC in India, as stated in a joint release.

site_title: Singapore COE premiums fall across the board
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums have fallen across the board, with the sharpest declines seen in motorcycles and small cars. Category A COE premiums dropped from S$3,878 to S$42,900, while Category B and Cat E premiums fell to S$51,000 and S$50,000, respectively. Category C and D COE premiums also decreased, with Category C dropping to S$42,004 and Category D falling to S$3,512. These declines are the latest in a series of price reductions for COE premiums in Singapore.

site_title: KrisEnergy's trading halt fuels speculation of Cambodian oil deal
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-listed oil company, has halted trading of its shares pending the release of announcements related to a petroleum agreement with the Cambodian government. The agreement is expected to be signed on August 23, 2017, for the Cambodia Block A offshore oil project. KrisEnergy's CEO, Jeffrey MacDonald, stated that the deal marks a major step forward in Cambodia's oil development and establishment as an oil-producing nation. The agreement will see the Cambodian government acquire a 5% working interest, reducing KrisEnergy's holdings to 95%.

site_title: Update: Hong Kong lowers storm signal as typhoon Hato makes landfall
summary: Severe Typhoon Hato made landfall in southern China, forcing Hong Kong to issue its highest storm warning and cancel full-day trading. The storm lashed Hong Kong with heavy winds and rain, causing widespread disruptions, including 450 flight cancellations, business closures, and public transport shutdowns. The city's stock exchange canceled trading, and schools were closed. The storm has weakened and is moving away from Hong Kong, with trading likely to resume on Thursday. At least 34 people sought medical treatment, and 182 reports of fallen trees were made, with some areas experiencing waist-deep flooding.

site_title: China July trade with North Korea slows from June as coal ban bites
summary: China's trade with North Korea slowed in July, with imports and exports totaling $456.16 million, down from $489 million in June. The decline is attributed to a ban on coal purchases due to growing pressure from the US to rein in North Korea's missile program. This marks a reversal from a month earlier, when trade increased. The data suggests China's economic ties with North Korea are tightening under US pressure.

site_title: Trump threatens government shutdown over border wall funding
summary: President Donald Trump threatened to bring the US government to a shutdown if Congress fails to fund the border wall along the US-Mexico border. Trump called Democratic lawmakers "obstructionists" and stated that the US needs to crack down on illegal immigration. He made the threat during a campaign-style rally in Phoenix, saying "If we have to close down our government, we're building that wall." The move is a significant escalation in the ongoing debate over border security funding.

site_title: Singapore inflation edges up in July on higher retail, water prices
summary: Singapore's inflation edged up in July, with headline inflation at 0.6% and core inflation at 1.6%, exceeding market expectations. Higher retail and water prices drove the increase, while private road transport and services inflation rose due to smaller declines in car prices and telecommunication fees. Food inflation remained stable at 1.4%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry reiterated their full-year inflation forecasts, predicting 0.5-1.5% for CPI-All Items inflation.

images.alt_text: In a joint statement, the MAS and the MTI said that retail and water prices rose by 1.2 per cent collectively, reversing the 0.2 per cent decline in June.

site_title: Court of Appeal dismisses Tan Cheng Bock's appeal on reserved presidential election
summary: The Court of Appeal in Singapore has dismissed former presidential candidate Tan Cheng Bock's appeal against a High Court decision on the timing and basis of the upcoming presidential election, which is reserved for Malay candidates. Tan argued it was unconstitutional to start counting terms from the term of President Wee Kim Wee, as he was not elected by the people. The decision upholds the High Court's ruling, allowing the election to proceed with the reserved position for a Malay candidate.

site_title: Hanergy to partner with Audi to put solar cells on car roofs
summary: Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd has partnered with Audi AG to outfit select car models with solar cells on their rooftops. The cells will harvest solar energy to power air conditioning and electrical functions, boosting mileage. The companies plan to present a vehicle prototype by the end of the year, with a long-term goal of using solar energy to provide primary power. This partnership aims to achieve Audi's goal of delivering one-third of its cars with fully electric drivetrains by 2025, and is part of a growing trend to use photovoltaics on car roofs.

site_title: Hong Kong halts share trading for full day due to typhoon
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange halted trading for the full day due to Typhoon Hato, which lashed the financial centre and other parts of southern China. Trading was suspended until the next business day, with hundreds of flights and transport services cancelled. Schools and most businesses were expected to be closed. The typhoon's highest level warning, No 10, was still in force at noon, prompting the exchange to follow its bad weather trading rules.

site_title: US warship collisions raise cyberattack fears
summary: A series of incidents involving US warships in Asia has raised concerns about cyberattacks, following a deadly collision off Singapore this week. The USS John S McCain collided with a tanker, leaving 10 sailors missing and five injured. The Navy is considering the possibility of a cyberattack, with some experts suggesting hackers could have tampered with GPS systems, causing the ships to miscalculate their positions. China and North Korea are being cited as potential culprits, given their past involvement in cyberattacks and the tensions between the US and these nations.

site_title: Wal-Mart to enter voice-shopping market via Google platform
summary: Wal-Mart is partnering with Google to enter the voice-shopping market, offering hundreds of thousands of items through Google Assistant from late September. This move aims to compete with Amazon, which dominates the US voice-controlled device industry. Wal-Mart's e-commerce head, Marc Lore, said the retailer will offer a wider selection than any other retailer on the platform. The partnership also includes integrating quick reordering tools into Google's same-day delivery service, with plans for further expansion in 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong raises highest warning for Severe Typhoon Hato
summary: Hong Kong raised its highest storm warning as Severe Typhoon Hato brought heavy rain and winds, shutting down the stock market and cancelling hundreds of flights. The Typhoon 10 signal, meaning hurricane force winds, was raised for the first time in five years, with gusts reaching up to 168 km/h. The storm caused flooding, power cuts, and damage to buildings, with two men injured and around 200 people seeking refuge in temporary shelters. The typhoon is expected to make landfall in the afternoon, with many flights and transportation services cancelled.

site_title: Mutual funds mark down investments in Uber by as much as 15%
summary: Four mutual fund companies have marked down their investments in Uber by as much as 15% due to the company's scandal-ridden year. Uber has faced a federal probe, a trade secrets lawsuit, and a corporate culture scandal led to CEO Travis Kalanick's resignation in June. These setbacks have led to a decline in investor confidence, resulting in significant markdowns to Uber's mutual fund holdings.

images.alt_text: Four mutual fund companies have marked down their investments in Uber Technologies Inc by as much as 15 per cent following a scandal-ridden year for the ride-hailing company.

site_title: Trump warns may terminate Nafta treaty
summary: US President Donald Trump warned that he may terminate the Nafta trade treaty with Mexico and Canada, citing a lack of progress in renegotiation talks. Trump stated that he personally doesn't think a deal can be made, and that termination is a possibility. The three-way talks failed to bridge deep differences, with Trump reopening negotiations due to concerns over US economic interests.

site_title: Judgment day looms for Thai ex-PM Yingluck and Shinawatra clan
summary: Thai ex-PM Yingluck Shinawatra's fate hangs in the balance as the Supreme Court decides whether to convict her of criminal negligence over a rice subsidy policy that was riddled with graft. A guilty verdict could result in up to 10 years in jail, a life ban from politics, and trigger the downfall of the Shinawatra dynasty. The ruling could also impact the country's politics, with the military's reform strategy cementing its power and limiting civilian government. The outcome is seen as a turning point in Thailand's decade-long power struggle between the establishment and the Shinawatra clan.

site_title: NZ dollar slumps after govt cuts growth outlook
summary: The New Zealand dollar fell to a one-week low against the US dollar and a 3-1/2-month low against the Australian dollar after the government reduced its economic growth forecast for the fiscal year and next. The New Zealand Treasury lowered its growth forecast to 2.6% for the year to June, from 3.2% previously. The Aussie dollar rose to a level not seen since May 2, while copper and nickel prices held near record highs.

site_title: Malaysia July inflation rate eases to 3.2% y-o-y, just below forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index in July rose 3.2% from a year earlier, slowing in pace for the fourth month in a row, just below the forecasted 3.3%. The 3.2% inflation rate is the lowest since February. Higher fuel and food prices, with a 7.7% increase in the transport index, drove the inflation. This rate is below Malaysia's central bank target of 3-4% for 2017, indicating a moderation in inflation.

site_title: Air New Zealand flags long-haul aircraft order as competition abates
summary: Air New Zealand is planning to order new long-haul aircraft, including Airbus A350 or Boeing 777X planes, to expand direct flights to the US and Brazil. The move comes as fierce competition in the market begins to abate, with rivals reducing capacity to New Zealand. The new aircraft will replace at least eight 777-200s, potentially allowing Air New Zealand to add flights to destinations like New York and Brazil. This expansion could provide a competitive edge for the airline, which has seen its core annual profit drop 21% but is now lifting its dividend.

site_title: Verdict for Samsung heir weighs on telecom giant
summary: Samsung heir Lee Jae-Yong faces a 12-year sentence for bribery and embezzlement charges in connection with the corruption scandal that brought down President Park Geun-Hye. The verdict could leave the world's largest smartphone maker rudderless for over a decade, as Lee's family controls a significant portion of the company. If convicted, Lee's absence could slow down Samsung's decision-making process, potentially impacting its future strategy and investments. Analysts predict that the company will continue to operate, but with a more cautious approach, as specialists make decisions without direct family control.

site_title: Australia shares drop, Insurance Australia slumps 10%; NZ gains
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dropping 23.43 points to 5726.70, due to disappointing full year results from Insurance Australia Group and Healthscope Ltd. Insurance Australia Group tumbled 10.1% and Healthscope Ltd fell 17.8% after reporting lower profits. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.25% as dairy firm a2 Milk Company reached a record high.

site_title: Record reserves turn costly cash pile for India central bank
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), is facing a costly conundrum as its foreign-exchange reserves near the $400 billion mark. The surge in liquidity is eroding the RBI's earnings, halving its annual dividend to the government. To manage this, the RBI is resuming open-market bond sales, auctions of longer duration repos, and imposing costs on the government. The RBI's earnings have been reduced by an estimated $70 billion due to consistent buildup in the forward dollar book and $100 billion in liquidity-absorption costs from demonetization.

site_title: Updated: KrisEnergy signs Cambodia's first oil field development project
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-listed company, has signed fiscal and technical agreements with the Royal Government of Cambodia for the development of Cambodia's first oil field in the Gulf of Thailand. The project, known as the Apsara area, is expected to take up to 24 months to produce first oil. Cambodia will own 5% of the participating interest, while KrisEnergy will hold 95%. The agreement marks a significant step in Cambodia's economic development and is aligned with the government's key development goals.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks at 2-week high as strong Wall Street boosts sentiment
summary: South Korea's won and shares hit two-week highs as investors became more risk-friendly following strong Wall Street gains. The won rose 0.4% to 1,129.2 against the US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) reached 2,365.89 points. Foreign investors returned to buy local shares, adding 43.9 billion won to their portfolios. LG Electronics' plans to establish an electric vehicle parts factory in Michigan boosted the tech firm's shares, while Samsung Electronics saw a 1% gain. The KOSPI's surge was attributed to easing concerns over North Korea's provocations.

site_title: Thai July exports up 10.5% y-o-y, below forecast
summary: Thailand's July exports rose 10.5% from last year, falling short of forecasts, after a 11.7% increase in June. The growth, driven by increased demand from major markets, follows a 8.2% growth in January-July. However, exports are under pressure from a strong baht, which has appreciated 7.7% against the US dollar. The Commerce Ministry now expects exports to rise 5-6% this year, down from its earlier 5% target. A trade deficit of $188 million was recorded in July, the first in over two years.

site_title: Bank Indonesia's rate cut shows its comfort with rupiah outlook
summary: Bank Indonesia cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter point to 4.5% in a surprise move, reflecting its comfort with the rupiah's stability and inflation outlook. The decision was made despite concerns about US monetary policy tightening. The central bank cited an improving inflation outlook and expectations of only one more US rate increase this year as motivations for the rate cut. The move aims to boost consumer spending and stimulate economic growth, which is currently around 5% and short of President Joko Widodo's 7% goal.

site_title: China's yuan slightly firmer on tight liquidity
summary: China's yuan edged up slightly against the US dollar early Wednesday, trading at 6.6620 per US dollar, due to tight liquidity. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.6633 per US dollar, 36 pips or 0.05% weaker than the previous fix. The offshore yuan traded weaker than its onshore counterpart due to ample liquidity in Hong Kong. China's short-term money rates jumped to their highest level in nearly five months, and traders are awaiting cues from the annual central banking conference in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, for further policy actions.

site_title: Hot stock: ComfortDelGro stock revs up on news of possible tie up with rival Uber
summary: ComfortDelGro's stock surged 10.6% to S$2.40 after the company announced it was in exclusive discussions for a "potential strategic alliance" with Uber. The land transport giant operates Comfort and CityCab taxis in Singapore. The news led to 16 million shares being traded worth S$38 million.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro stock revved up on news that it plans to car-pool with its competitor and ride-hailing stalwart Uber.

site_title: Salesforce.com profit beats estimates, shares dip after hours
summary: Salesforce.com reported a quarterly profit that beat analysts' estimates, driven by investments to fend off competition in the cloud-based software sector. The company's revenue grew, but shares slipped 1% after hours due to investor expectations of even greater performance. Despite this, Salesforce's profit beat estimates, indicating the company's efforts to invest in its growth are paying off.

site_title: Several firsts for Bukit Panjang integrated transport hub
summary: The Bukit Panjang Integrated Transport Hub (BPITH) set to open in September will be the first facility operated by SMRT Buses, featuring a traffic management system that uses sensors and blinking lights to alert bus drivers. The system improves workplace safety and assists with bus parking and timeliness. The hub is part of Hillion Mall with direct LRT and MRT connections, and is the ninth integrated transport hub in Singapore, with a 10th planned for Yishun in 2019.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, tracking global rebounds, as investors ignored concerns about political uncertainty. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.85% and the Topix index rose 0.90%, driven by a weakening yen.

site_title: Hyundai will launch pickup, more SUVs to reverse US sales slide
summary: Hyundai plans to launch a pickup truck in the US, following a decline in sales of sedans. The decision was made after top management gave the green light for development, similar to the Santa Cruz show vehicle unveiled in 2015. Hyundai currently does not offer a pickup truck in the US, but the move aims to reverse the sales slide. The company's US unit is also planning to launch more SUVs to regain market share.

site_title: New Zealand's a2 Milk logs record profit after making the right bets on China
summary: New Zealand's a2 Milk Co Ltd reported record profit of NZ$90.6 million, tripling annual earnings, driven by soaring demand for infant formula in China. The company's informal "daigou" shopping agents played a key role in its success, outpacing rivals who struggled with China's registration laws. The stronger dairy market, fueled by global supply shortages, also contributed to the record earnings. The company's shares rose 5.9% to a record high, valuing the company at NZ$3.6 billion, after announcing a NZ$40 million share buyback.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's a2 Milk Co Ltd said annual profit tripled to record levels on soaring demand for its infant formula products in China and also unveiled a share buyback that propelled its stock, already an investor favourite, higher.

site_title: CapitaLand inks pact with Alibaba, Lazada to connect shoppers offline and online
summary: CapitaLand has partnered with Alibaba and Lazada to create an "omni-channel" retail experience, connecting shoppers offline and online. The partnership will manage Alibaba's Shanghai Centre and launch an exclusive online mall on Lazada Singapore, allowing retailers to reach customers through both physical and digital channels. CapitaLand aims to leverage digital tools, data, and smart building technologies to enhance customer experience and drive long-term success.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 2.96 points to 1,777.18. The market saw a gain of 146 to 87 gainer-to-loser ratio, with a total trading volume of 113.4 million lots worth RM44.07 million.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for typhoon Hato, flights, ferries cancelled
summary: Hong Kong braces for severe typhoon Hato, with hundreds of flights and transport services cancelled. The weather observatory issued a signal 9 warning, its second-highest, as the storm skirts the territory. Winds of up to 155 kph and flash floods are expected, with the city's financial markets, schools, and businesses closed. Trading is delayed, and flights to and from Hong Kong are cancelled. The city's flagship carrier, Cathay Pacific, said the storm would severely impact flight operations.

site_title: Google touts Titan security chip to market cloud services
summary: Google is set to disclose technical details of its Titan security chip, a tiny stud earring-sized chip installed in its data centers to scan hardware for tampering, and prevent machines from booting if compromised. The feature aims to enhance cloud security and differentiate Google's services from competitors. Google holds just 7% of the worldwide cloud market, and analysts question the effectiveness of Titan, citing that security is a hallmark for AWS and Microsoft.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Oxley Holdings, ComfortDelGro
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include: CapitaLand partnering with Alibaba and Lazada to create an "omni-channel" retail landlord, Oxley Holdings increasing its stake in United Engineers, and ComfortDelGro in talks with Uber for a potential strategic alliance. These moves may impact trading of the companies' shares.

site_title: Tillerson says talks with North Korea may be close, notes 'restraint'
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said talks with North Korea may be possible in the near future after Pyongyang showed restraint following new UN sanctions. The US imposed new sanctions on Chinese and Russian firms suspected of doing business with North Korea. Tillerson acknowledged the regime's restraint but emphasized the US remains committed to halting North Korea's missile program and negotiating denuclearization. The US Treasury also imposed sanctions on 16 individuals and companies, accusing them of supporting North Korea's nuclear program.

site_title: Miners bolster European shares, Provident Financial plummets
summary: European shares rose 0.8% on Tuesday, ending a three-day losing streak, as mining stocks bolstered the market. The pan-European Stoxx 600 and euro zone blue chips gained, driven by a weaker euro and a rally in iron ore prices. In contrast, UK subprime lender Provident Financial plummeted 66% after issuing its second profit warning in two months. Despite this, UK housebuilder Persimmon rose 1.8% after posting a 30% rise in first-half profit.

site_title: South Korea's Q2 household debt growth slowest in almost 2 years
summary: South Korea's household credit grew 10.4% in Q2, the slowest pace in almost 2 years, due to tightened lending rules. This marks a decrease from the 11.1% increase in the previous quarter. Mortgages and loans at depository institutions rose 12.0 trillion won, while borrowings from non-depository institutions increased by 6.3 trillion won. The outstanding amount of purchases on credit jumped 13.6% year-on-year, driven by retail and automobile sales. The slower credit growth is attributed to the Bank of Korea's efforts to curb high household debt.

site_title: Trump arrives on Mexican border to rally supporters
summary: President Donald Trump arrived at the US-Mexican border on August 22, 2017, to rally supporters and build momentum for a border wall. Trump will tour a stretch of border fence in Yuma, Arizona, before heading to Phoenix for a campaign-style rally. The event aims to tout the benefits of a border fence, turn up heat on reluctant allies, and demonstrate the president's determination to realize a central campaign pledge. Trump may use the rally to formally endorse a challenger to moderate Republican Senator Jeff Flake, but is unlikely to issue a pardon for former Sheriff Joe Arpaio.

site_title: Clooneys donate US$1m to combat hate groups after Charlottesville
summary: George and Amal Clooney donate $1 million to the Southern Poverty Law Centre, a civil rights advocacy organization, to combat hate groups following the deadly violence in Charlottesville, Virginia. The donation was made via the Clooney Foundation for Justice and joins other recent donations from prominent individuals and corporations, including James Murdoch and J.P. Morgan, to address the surge in hate groups and anti-discrimination organizations. The move comes after US President Donald Trump faced criticism for his comments on the Charlottesville violence, highlighting racial tensions in the US.

site_title: Nam Cheong will not make coupon, principal payments on two notes in line with debt standstill
summary: Nam Cheong will not make coupon and principal payments due on Aug 28 on its S$90 million 5% notes (Series 2 notes) and Aug 26 on the S$200 million 5.05% notes (Series 3 notes), consistent with its debt standstill. The company is working with its advisers and has formed an informal steering committee to discuss the impact of its restructuring exercise on noteholders. Principal payments on the Series 4 notes were made on Aug 1.

site_title: Great Wall Motor pours cold water on possible deal with Fiat
summary: Great Wall Motor has expressed skepticism about a potential deal with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, stating there are no talks and uncertainties about pursuing a takeover of the Jeep division. The Chinese automaker cited "big uncertainties" and lack of concrete progress in studying Fiat Chrysler, despite previous interest. This move comes after Fiat Chrysler's CEO Sergio Marchionne mentioned the possibility of spinning off some businesses, including the Jeep marque.

site_title: NZ government raises 2016/17 budget surplus forecast, cuts GDP projections
summary: The New Zealand government has raised its forecast for a budget surplus in 2016/17 to NZ$3.706 billion, up from NZ$1.62 billion, due to strong corporate tax revenues. However, it has cut its economic growth projections for the current year and next to 2.6% and 3.5%, respectively. The move comes ahead of a September election that has become increasingly contested. The National Party government's budget surplus will be a welcome boost, but may not be enough to sway voters.

site_title: Brazil's ex-president Collor is charged in Petrobras graft case
summary: Brazil's ex-president Collor was formally charged with "passive corruption", money laundering, and racketeering in connection with the Petrobras graft case, allegedly taking $9 million. The federal Supreme Court allowed Collor to be tried despite his immunity as a lawmaker. He is the third senator to be formally charged in the investigation, following Gleisi Hoffmann and Valdir Raupp. The charges stem from transactions at BR Distribuidora, a Petrobras subsidiary, between 2010 and 2014.

site_title: Brazil eyes privatization of Eletrobras
summary: Brazil's government plans to privatize Eletrobras, the country's largest power utility, to balance its budget deficit. The move is expected to raise 20 billion reais ($8.6 billion) and add competitiveness to the business. The government will retain a golden share to exercise veto power and exclude nuclear power plants and the Itaipu hydroelectric station from the sale. The privatization comes as the government struggles to pay bills following two years of deep recession. Share prices surged on the announcement, closing 48.9% higher.

site_title: Kim orders more production of ICBMs: state media
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un has ordered more production of rocket engines and ICBM nosecones, according to state media. This comes after two ICBM tests last month that brought most of the US within range, sparking tensions. The US and South Korea have begun their annual military drills, which the North condemns as a rehearsal for invasion. The North has threatened to fire missiles at Guam but has since backed down, while US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson praised the North's restraint and expressed hope for peace talks with Washington.

site_title: Insurance Australia Group shares dive as disaster claims hit margins
summary: Insurance Australia Group Ltd shares dropped 7.1% to a four-month low after reporting underlying insurance margins fell due to higher costs in its motor businesses and natural disasters. The company's profit jumped 49% to A$929 million, but its guidance for 2018 margins missed market expectations. IAG attributed the decline to costs linked to natural hazards and rising claims in its motor business, with margins expected to fall to 12.5-14.5% in the 2018 financial year.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2% up on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 7.94 points to 3,271.73. The gains followed US stocks' best one-day percentage gains in over a week, driven by tax reform optimism. About 63.1 million shares changed hands, with Golden Agri-Resources being the most actively traded counter. The market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with gainers outnumbering losers 94 to 30.

site_title: Matt LeBlanc on saying goodbye to... Matt LeBlanc
summary: Matt LeBlanc, star of the Showtime sitcom "Episodes," reflects on his experience playing a fictionalized version of himself. LeBlanc was approached by "Friends" co-creator David Crane in 2010 to star in a comedy series satirizing the US television industry. Initially unsure, LeBlanc agreed, saying "I thought, 'That's a show I would watch.'" The show, which ran from 2011-2017, explored the behind-the-scenes of a fictional British version of "Friends." LeBlanc expressed gratitude for the experience, stating he would watch the show if he weren't in it.

site_title: US dollar advances as euro falters ahead of Jackson Hole meeting
summary: The US dollar advanced on Tuesday after the euro declined following weaker-than-expected euro zone data, and ahead of the Jackson Hole meeting of global central bankers. The dollar posted its largest daily percentage gain in over two weeks against the euro and its best one-day rise in a week versus the yen. This rally is attributed to heavy short positioning on the dollar and stabilizing foreign growth momentum.

site_title: US Treasury chief's wife apologises over Instagram post
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's wife, Louise Linton, apologized after posting an Instagram photo with comments deemed tone-deaf and elitist. The photo showed her and Mnuchin returning from a trip to Kentucky, where he addressed the Louisville Chamber of Commerce and visited Fort Knox. Linton's post was criticized for her seemingly dismissive response to a commenter who accused her of freeloading on taxpayer dollars. Linton eventually removed the post and issued an apology, stating it was "inappropriate and highly insensitive."

site_title: Australia's Woolworths cuts its way back to profit
summary: Woolworths Ltd, Australia's largest grocery chain, reported a net profit of A$1.53 billion for the year to June 25, reversing a net loss of A$1.2 billion the previous year. The company attributed the improvement to cost-cutting measures, excluding one-off charges. Comparable store food sales rose 3.6% and the company declared a final dividend of 50 Australian cents per share. Woolworths aims to refocus on groceries amid a price war with rival Coles and discount players. The company's efforts to cut non-core businesses have shown progress, with a record profit posted by its competitor Wesfarmers earlier this month.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies on optimism about tax reform
summary: US stocks surged on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite posting their best one-day percentage gains in over a week, driven by optimism over tax reform and a debt ceiling. Lawmakers' comments, including House Speaker Paul Ryan's assertion that tax reform would be easier to pass, boosted investor confidence. The tech sector led the advance, with technology shares up 1.5%, while metals prices also rose due to strong results for mining firms and talk of shortages.

site_title: Yellen risks exposing old vulnerabilities in emerging Asia
summary: The populist leaders of India, Indonesia, and the Philippines have promised massive infrastructure spending to boost economic growth, emulating China's success. However, with the US Federal Reserve set to shrink its balance sheet, old vulnerabilities are resurfacing. The trio lack industrial, export, and domestic savings bases to fund their plans, leading to widening current account deficits and increased external debt. Experts warn of potential fallout, including capital outflows, currency mismatch risks, and increased debt levels. The Asian Development Bank estimates emerging economies need $26 trillion in infrastructure investment by 2030, but growth rates remain uncertain.

site_title: Oil prices climb as traders eye another US crude drawdown
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday as traders expected a crude stockpile drawdown in the US, but gains were limited by industry data showing a decline in gasoline inventories. US crude inventories were expected to fall 3.5 million barrels, while gasoline inventories rose by over 600,000 barrels. Brent crude settled 21 cents higher at $51.87 a barrel, while US crude futures for September delivery closed 27 cents higher at $47.64. Libya's Sharara oil field reopened after a shutdown, and US crude production reached 9.5 million barrels per day, its highest since July 2015.

site_title: World's largest samosa record smashed in London
summary: A record-breaking 153.1 kg samosa was created in London, surpassing the previous Guinness World Record of 110.8 kg set in 2012. A team of 12 volunteers from Muslim Aid UK charity built the giant samosa, which was deep-fried in a custom-built vat, and then certified by Guinness World Records adjudicators. The massive snack was made with traditional ingredients and had to retain its shape and be edible, with no wastage. The successful attempt broke the record and provided hundreds of portions to local homeless individuals.

images.alt_text: The world record for the largest samosa was smashed in London on Tuesday by a whopping version of the popular Asian snack weighing in at 153.1 kilogrammes.

site_title: Intel's new Core chip will have 40% jump
summary: Intel's new eighth-generation Core processors will deliver a 40% performance boost over its predecessor, marking the biggest bump in years for personal computer users. The Santa Clara-based company announced the significant improvement in performance.

site_title: Alipay targeting Singapore consumers
summary: Alipay, a Chinese mobile payment provider, is expanding its operations in Singapore by targeting tourists and Chinese citizens with a China banking account. The company has partnered with CCPay to increase Alipay acceptance points in Singapore, with plans to roll out the service to Singapore banking users "soon". Alipay will support transactions in 18 currencies, including the Singapore dollar, and businesses won't need to register for an Alipay account to use the service. The partnership aims to encourage greater spending from Chinese tourists and provide a payment method familiar to them.

site_title: Growing beyond finance function
summary: CFOs are evolving to play a more strategic role in helping companies achieve long-term goals. They need to balance their time between financial management and strategic growth, building trusted relationships with key stakeholders. A framework, "four faces of the CFO," guides CFOs to focus on strategist and catalyst roles, while also maintaining traditional functions as stewards and operators. Experts emphasize the importance of non-finance experience, strong communications skills, and a broad view of the company to be successful in this new role.

site_title: McDonald's cuts ties with India franchisee after feud
summary: McDonald's has terminated its agreement with Connaught Plaza Restaurants Pvt, a joint venture operating 169 restaurants in northern and eastern India. The move comes after the local partner allegedly failed to pay royalties and breached essential obligations. This decision creates uncertainty for McDonald's operations in the country, where it has a relatively small presence. The company will need to rebuild its brand across half the country as it searches for another partner, disrupting its operations in one of the world's biggest emerging markets.

site_title: Competition headwinds hit Air New Zealand profit
summary: Air New Zealand posted a 17.5% fall in annual net profit to NZ$382 million, down from a record NZ$463 million in the previous year, due to increased competition from major airlines. Pre-tax earnings and operating revenue also declined. Despite this, the airline described the result as "strong" and cited commercial, customer, and cultural excellence. The company remains optimistic about market dynamics and aims to improve earnings in the current financial year.

site_title: Spain suspect says terror cell planned big attack on monuments
summary: A Spanish suspect, Mohamed Houli Chemlal, 21, has admitted to a judge that the terror cell behind last week's twin attacks in Barcelona planned a bigger attack targeting monuments using bombs. Chemlal and three other suspects, including Driss Oukabir, were remanded in custody and charged with terror-related offenses. The cell, believed to be a 12-man group, had prepared bombs for one or more attacks in Barcelona before an accidental explosion at their makeshift bomb factory forced them to alter their plans.

site_title: Investors wave red flags at Hong Kong's dual-class shares plan
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd's plan for dual-class shares has faced opposition from key investors, including the Council of Institutional Investors, Hong Kong Investment Funds Association, and activist investor David Webb. They argue the proposal would weaken corporate governance and set a lower standard for exchanges worldwide. The groups have written to HKEX in response to a June concept paper proposing a new exchange for dual-class stocks. The opposition has raised concerns about the impact on the city's reputation as a hub for high-quality corporate governance.

site_title: China's 'big four' banks raise billions for Belt and Road deals
summary: China's "big four" banks, including China Construction Bank and Bank of China, are raising billions of dollars to fund Belt and Road investment deals. The banks are raising cash onshore and offshore, with China Construction Bank aiming to raise at least $20.5 billion and Bank of China seeking around $2.1 billion. This move supports Beijing's ambitions as private capital pulls back, following a pledge by Chinese President Xi Jinping to boost funding for the Belt and Road initiative to $124 billion. The funds will be used to finance offshore investments, including Belt and Road deals.

site_title: Berkshire's flop on Oncor puts another dent in Buffett's dealmaking reputation
summary: Warren Buffett's bid to acquire Oncor Electric Delivery Co. for US$9 billion fell apart after Paul Singer's Elliott Management Corp. acquired a small parcel of unsecured debt, opening the door for Sempra Energy to swoop in and strike a deal. This marks the second multibillion-dollar Buffett pursuit to hit the skids this year, following a failed US$15 billion bid to help Kraft Heinz Co. acquire Unilever. The collapse highlights Buffett's reputation as a savvy dealmaker, which may be at risk unless he changes his approach.

site_title: American, Delta get pinched by the rise of cheap airfares to Europe
summary: Major US airlines American Airlines and Delta Air Lines are facing increased competition from low-cost European rivals, leading to a decline in trans-Atlantic fares. American Airlines saw a 9.1% drop in fares, the largest since the 2009 recession, while Delta's fares also plummeted. United Continental Holdings Inc eked out a small gain. The decline in fares is attributed to the expansion of European budget carriers such as Norwegian Air Shuttle ASA.

site_title: Research firm rolls out pay-as-you-go menu for European equity reports
summary: Autonomous Research, a London-based research firm, has introduced a pay-as-you-go menu for its European equity reports, priced starting at $1,000 for a single stock report and up to $5,000 for high-end industry research. The move comes ahead of the European Union's MiFID II rules, which require research to be charged for. This is a contrast to banking rivals, which tend to offer analysis for free or lump it in with execution costs. The new pricing structure is part of the firm's efforts to adapt to the changing regulatory landscape.

site_title: Russia's record grain crop will test storage, transport capacity
summary: Russia is poised to become the world's largest wheat exporter in the 2017/18 marketing year with a record 125-127 million tonnes of grain, but its infrastructure is expected to be severely tested due to unprecedented grain volumes. Storage and transport capacity will face constraints, potentially affecting exports to major buyers, including the EU and US. August and September grain exports are expected to reach record levels, with SovEcon forecasting 43.6 million tonnes of exports, a 3.3 million tonne increase from previous estimates.

site_title: Rise in financial crimes bodes well for regulatory tech
summary: A US$2.1 trillion problem, financial crime poses a significant threat to the global financial system, with money laundering, bribery, and corruption being the most prevalent forms. Regulatory technology (RegTech) is emerging as a key solution to combat financial crime, leveraging advancements in data mining, artificial intelligence, and automation to enhance regulatory compliance and risk management. RegTech solutions are being deployed in real-time transaction monitoring and customer risk assessment processes, offering improved efficiency and effectiveness. As the global spend on regulatory compliance technology is expected to rise, collaboration among stakeholders is crucial to advance the promise of RegTech and drive change in the financial crime response.

site_title: Banking on a new way forward for East Asia
summary: US and Japan may join China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), potentially helping to resolve the North Korea standoff. President Trump has suggested going easy on China's trade surplus if Beijing applies pressure on Pyongyang. Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has expressed readiness to join the AIIB, provided certain conditions are met, including a free and fair trans-Pacific economic zone. China would gain a top-rank position in the multilateral financial institution, while the US and Japan would gain influence in shaping global institutions and infrastructure projects.

site_title: OCBC inks 10-year collaboration pact with Ningbo associate
summary: OCBC Bank has signed a 10-year strategic cooperation agreement with 20% associate Bank of Ningbo, aiming to collaborate across business segments. The deal includes a $5 million training grant and knowledge sharing. OCBC will leverage Ningbo's local market expertise to expand its customer base, while Ningbo will benefit from OCBC's structured training and development programme. The partnership will focus on corporate banking, treasury, investment banking, and wealth management. This marks the latest expansion of OCBC's presence in China, following its 2006 acquisition of a 12.2% stake in Ningbo.

site_title: Businesses wise up to importance of digitalisation, says study
summary: Business leaders in Asia Pacific overwhelmingly believe that digital transformation is necessary for future growth, with 80% stating they need to transform into a digital business. However, only 29% have a comprehensive digital strategy in place, and the majority face barriers such as security concerns and limited digital literacy. Despite these challenges, cloud computing and decreasing device costs make digital transformation more accessible, with 81% of business leaders considering it essential for their digital transformation strategy.

site_title: This stock market magic can't last
summary: The stock market has been experiencing an unusually calm environment, with the S&P 500 index rising 267% since its start in 2009. However, this trend is unlikely to continue, with several statistical measurements indicating a high probability of a correction. The market's average daily trading range has been the lowest on record, and the VIX index has remained low despite recent spikes. Experts, including Ryan Detrick and Salil Mehta, believe that a 5% decline is imminent, which would be a buying opportunity for investors.

images.alt_text: The bull market's longevity has been fuelled largely by the Fed's ultra-low interest rates and voracious bond buying. The upward trend in stocks ranks as the second longest since 1900.

site_title: Fund managers keep dancing even as September jinx looms
summary: Despite September's reputation as a challenging month for US stocks, many fund managers remain optimistic, citing broad corporate performance and justified stock market valuations. Investors are monitoring North Korea and central banks' next moves, but giant tech stocks and defensive businesses continue to attract attention.

images.alt_text: September is approaching, with its reputation as the worst month in history for US stocks, which lead sentiment in Asia. Yet many money managers continue to dance.

site_title: A 90s superhero returns to Marvel Comics
summary: Marvel Comics is reviving its 1990s superhero Darkhawk as part of the "Marvel Legacy" event. The character, who gained popularity in the 1990s for his armored android suit, will return in a one-shot issue (issue #51) this autumn. Written by Chad Bowers and Christopher Sims, the story will explore Darkhawk's current status and his potential as a key player in the Marvel universe. The issue will be a standalone and may lead to future series if fans respond positively, with the creative team hinting at re-establishing Darkhawk's identity and story.

site_title: BHP quits US shale as annual profit surges
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest miner, reported a surge in underlying full-year profits of $6.7 billion, driven by a recovery in industrial commodities markets. The company announced its intention to exit its underperforming US shale oil and gas business, citing a need to boost shareholder returns and reduce debt. This move comes after pressure from US hedge fund Elliott Management and other investors, who had called for a sale. BHP's net debt decreased to $16.3 billion, and the company tripled its final dividend to $0.43 per share.

site_title: Google names latest Android operating system Oreo
summary: Google has named its latest Android operating system "Oreo," a nod to the popular cookie. The company has partnered with Mondelez, the maker of Oreos, for the name, which is a "pure co-branding partnership." The new operating system features a redesigned notification center and various tweaks to increase speed. It will be available on select devices starting Monday, with full rollout expected by the end of the year. The partnership will also include joint initiatives and experiences for Android and Oreo fans.

site_title: Euro falls against broadly resurgent dollar
summary: The euro fell 0.6% against the US dollar to $1.1750, reversing most of its overnight gains. The single currency's strength may be fading due to investors' speculative bullish bets, which are near their highest in five years. European Central Bank (ECB) president Mario Draghi will refrain from delivering a new policy message at the Jackson Hole symposium, potentially tempering expectations for the ECB to taper its quantitative easing stimulus program. The euro's losses were exacerbated by a broad bounce in the dollar against most of its rivals.

site_title: Cut the debt burden? Politics gets in the way
summary: China's debt burden is growing, with corporate debt reaching 166% of GDP, surpassing the US, Japan, and South Korea. The country's biggest firms, including state-owned enterprises, have accumulated debt at a rate and scale unprecedented in recent history. Despite efforts to slow debt growth, vested interests, including the powerful real-estate sector and state-owned firms, are resisting any measures that could threaten their interests. The Chinese government is hesitant to act due to the risk of a financial crisis and the potential impact on key political constituencies.

site_title: Is regulatory framework for valuation industry adequate?
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV) have conducted a joint review of real estate valuers' practices for listed companies, raising questions about the adequacy of the regulatory framework. The review aims to ensure quality valuations safeguard investor interest, but the current framework's effectiveness is uncertain, with few public disciplinary actions taken against errant valuers. The SISV has self-regulatory mechanisms, but the absence of overt public accountability raises concerns. The SGX and SISV are pushing for greater disclosures and clearer information on valuation methodologies to maintain investor trust.

site_title: Four types of asset managers that will survive the upheavals
summary: The active fund management industry is facing significant challenges due to technological advancements, declining workforce, and increasing competition from passive management. Since 1977, nominal equity returns and bond yields have fallen while management fees have remained relatively unchanged, making it harder for active managers to generate alpha. The rise of ETFs, smart beta, and automation has made it easier for computers to replicate investment strategies, further threatening the industry. Only four types of asset management firms - those that can adapt and leverage technology, and those that focus on high-value-added tasks - are likely to survive the upheavals.

site_title: Jeju Air flies high on home support despite curbs in China
summary: Jeju Air, South Korea's largest low-cost carrier, expects a record quarterly profit due to increased demand for travel despite China's rejection of its charter flight application. The airline has redirected flights to Japan and Southeast Asia, generating a 24-fold increase in operating profit from the previous year. Jeju plans to expand its fleet to 50 aircraft by 2020, with a focus on cost-competitiveness to ensure its survival in the competitive market.

site_title: Singapore firms ink deals to ride tech and consumer wave in Guangdong
summary: Singapore companies signed 16 agreements with 20 organisations in Guangdong, China, focusing on consumer, logistics, and technology sectors. Deals include joint ventures for e-commerce, education, and technology development. The agreements aim to set up 550 point-of-sale outlets, establish a pre-school, and build integrated logistics facilities. This marks Singapore's continued expansion in Guangdong, its top provincial trading partner since 1988, with total investments reaching S$15.1 billion in 2,620 projects.

site_title: Pros and cons of Cosco's proposed asset sale
summary: Cosco Shipping International, a Singapore-listed company, is considering selling its loss-making shipyards to its parent company, China Cosco Shipping, in a proposed asset sale. The move aims to generate cash and reduce debt, but shareholders must decide whether to accept the offer. The sale would represent about 80% of the company's value, and the parent company would pay 100% of the assets' value, totaling S$299.5 million. Shareholders must vote on the proposal, which will be held on August 30, and should consider the company's future plans and how they will maximize shareholder value.

site_title: Asia could benefit from some Trump policies
summary: US President Donald Trump's policies may benefit Asia, particularly in terms of trade and immigration. The Trump administration's decision to withdraw from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) has allowed China to fill the void with its own Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) agreements. These initiatives may expand China's economic influence in the region. On the immigration front, Trump's proposed changes to the Immigration Act of 1965 could lead to increased migration from Asia, particularly from South Asia, as the US seeks to prioritize English-speaking, skilled workers.

images.alt_text: President Trump making an announcement on immigration with Senator Cotton (left) and Senator Perdue on Aug 2.

site_title: UK outlines approach to cross-border legal disputes post-Brexit
summary: The UK government will outline its approach to resolving cross-border civil disputes with the European Union post-Brexit, focusing on civil judicial cooperation. The proposal aims to tackle disputes ranging from marital cases to business challenges, with the goal of ensuring fair and sensible application of laws to citizens living across borders. The plan builds on existing cooperation and aims to develop judicial ties as societies and laws evolve, with Justice Minister David Lidington emphasizing the need for swift resolution of disputes without bureaucracy.

site_title: Industrial stocks on ST Index just a shade ahead of benchmark's year-to-date returns
summary: Industrial stocks on the Straits Times Index (STI) have outperformed the benchmark, with an average 12.3% price return compared to 12.1% for the non-weighted average of 30 STI stocks. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has been the best performer, with a 95.7% increase in its share price, driven by a recovery in demand for new bulk carriers. The STI, in its weighted form, has lower historical volatility than other Asian financial centers, with an 8.5% 180-day annualized volatility.

site_title: RHB and AmBank Group call off merger talks
summary: RHB Bank Bhd and AmBank Group have ended merger talks due to inability to reach mutually acceptable terms and conditions. The proposed merger, initially valued at US$9 billion, would have created Malaysia's fourth-largest banking group. Analysts had questioned revenue synergies, citing operational and revenue duplication. A general election is expected to be called in the coming months, potentially weighing on the deal. The last banking merger in Malaysia occurred in 2011.

site_title: Talk of plan for outbound China investors revived
summary: China is reviving a plan to allow individuals to invest abroad, with the foreign-exchange regulator seeking State Council approval for a pilot program in cities like Shanghai and Tianjin. The plan, known as QDII2, would start with a US$50,000 annual limit and aim to signal a departure from strict controls on outbound investment. The proposal is an extension of the 2006 QDII program, which allowed individuals to invest in overseas markets through asset managers. The plan's timing has not been announced, but it reflects the authorities' confidence in stable capital movements and their desire to refocus on economic reforms.

site_title: Wanda calls off £470m London land buy amid govt pressure
summary: Wanda Group Co, a Chinese conglomerate, has called off its £470m plan to buy a four-hectare land plot in London's Nine Elms Square amid government pressure. This move is part of the company's downsizing efforts, following last month's sale of most hotels and theme-park assets. The Chinese government has stepped up its scrutiny of overseas investments to protect the yuan, leading to a clampdown on "irrational" acquisitions. Wanda still owns the £700m One Nine Elms complex in London and plans to invest in domestic markets, shifting its focus away from overseas investments.

site_title: Swiss meat: expensive in dollars, cheap in minutes
summary: Switzerland has the highest meat prices, with a kilogram of beef leg round costing $49.68, but locals can afford it in just 3.1 hours. In contrast, Ukraine has the lowest meat prices, with the same amount costing just $9.01. The study found that in some countries, such as Indonesia and Egypt, people have to work excessively long hours to afford meat, while in others, like Sweden, the cost is high but the labor required is relatively short. This has led to meat smuggling and innovative alternatives like beetle larvae burgers.

site_title: US destroyer collision: Remains found amid search for 10 missing sailors
summary: US destroyer USS John S McCain collided with an oil tanker in Singapore waters, resulting in 10 missing sailors. Two days of search-and-rescue efforts led to the discovery of the bodies of some of the missing sailors, with three confirmed remains found. The US Pacific Fleet Commander, Admiral Scott Swift, stated that search efforts will continue until no survivors are found. Investigations into the cause of the collision are ongoing, with no indication of a cyberbreach or overworked personnel.

site_title: Civmec's Q4 profit drops 35.4% to S$956,000
summary: Civmec, an Australia-headquartered construction and engineering services company, reported a 35.4% drop in Q4 profit to S$956,000 due to a joint-venture loss and higher administrative costs. Revenue rose 10.5% to S$97.7 million, while earnings per share fell to 0.19 Singapore cents. The company recommended maintaining a 0.7 cent per share cash dividend, subject to shareholder approval. Full-year net profit dropped 51.7% to S$8.4 million, with revenue declining 12.8% to S$346 million, mainly due to a 40.4% drop in the oil-and-gas sector revenue.

site_title: Rosewood Hotels & Resorts to expand into South-east Asia
summary: Rosewood Hotels & Resorts is expanding into South-east Asia, with three hotels set to open in Phnom Penh, Phuket, and Luang Prabang in the fourth quarter of 2017. The luxury hotel chain plans to add more properties in Asia, including Hong Kong, Guangzhou, Siem Reap, Hoi An, and Bangkok, beyond 2017. The company believes the region's natural beauty and culture make it an attractive market for expansion, with a focus on curated experiences and ultra-luxury offerings.

site_title: Philip Morris cheers FDA's lower-nicotine proposal
summary: Philip Morris International's CEO, Andre Calantzopoulos, expressed enthusiasm over the FDA's proposal to lower nicotine levels in cigarettes, encouraging the shift towards less harmful alternatives like e-cigarettes. The announcement was seen as a "best articulated position in many years". Calantzopoulos stated he was "extremely encouraged" by the move, suggesting a potential boon for the company's e-cigarette business.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson ordered to pay US$417m in lawsuit tying its baby powder to cancer
summary: A Los Angeles jury ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $417 million in damages to a medical receptionist who developed ovarian cancer after using the company's baby powder on her perineum for decades. This is the largest award in a lawsuit tying ovarian cancer to talcum powder. The verdict comes after several other lawsuits have gone against the company, with some awarding millions of dollars in damages. Johnson & Johnson plans to appeal the verdict, citing the safety of its baby powder, which has been linked to cancer studies dating back to 1971.

site_title: Lenovo seen falling another 27% after posting surprise Q1 loss
summary: Lenovo reported a surprise net loss of $72 million in Q1, with its smartphone and data centre businesses struggling. The company's shares fell 3.5% in Hong Kong trading. Analysts cut price targets, citing Lenovo's lack of innovation in the smartphone and server markets. The company faces stiff competition from rivals, and its PC sales have declined. Lenovo's best prospects for growth are in the Indian smartphone market and contract manufacturing, but its traditional business model may not be sustainable.

site_title: Singapore property's next 'Sail' moment not on the horizon
summary: Singapore property developer City Developments Ltd's chairman, Kwek Leng Beng, launched the ambitious Sail @ Marina Bay project in 2004, despite a 45% decline in the market. The project's predicted 5-10% annual price rise was achieved, with home prices rising over the next seven years. However, the article does not suggest that a similar "Sail" moment is imminent for Singapore property, contradicting previous predictions.

site_title: Former CEO of Brazil's Petrobras charged with corruption
summary: Brazilian prosecutors have charged the former CEO of state-controlled oil company Petrobras, Aldemir Bendine, with corruption, alleging he took bribes from construction firm Odebrecht during his tenure from 2015 to 2016. Bendine, who previously led Banco do Brasil SA, was arrested last month and remains in jail. The charges come as part of efforts to clean up Petrobras after its central role in Brazil's massive political graft scandal. Bendine's legal team has not commented on the charges.

site_title: China loses arbitration but wins control of S China Sea
summary: China has emerged victorious in real terms despite losing an arbitration case brought by the Philippines over their dispute in the South China Sea. The Philippines, under President Rodrigo Duterte, has adopted a policy of cooperation with Beijing, while Vietnam has ceased oil exploration activities in its exclusive economic zone following threats from China. China's military power and flouting of international law have allowed it to effectively control the South China Sea, with the US, Japan, and Australia issuing joint statements urging China and the Philippines to abide by the arbitration's ruling, but China dismissing their advice.

site_title: Blackstone's bid for Croesus 'fair and reasonable': CIMB
summary: Blackstone's S$1.17 per unit cash offer to privatize Croesus Retail Trust has been deemed "fair and reasonable" by CIMB, an independent financial adviser. The offer price represents a 24.5-37.7% premium to the trust's market price and a 19.9% premium to net asset value. Unitholders will vote on the proposed scheme of arrangement on Sept 13, with a majority vote of 75% required for approval.

site_title: India races to regulate cryptocurrencies as cyberattacks soar
summary: India is racing to regulate cryptocurrencies amid a surge in cyberattacks, including a recent attack that crippled the country's largest container port. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley called an urgent meeting with top officials to address the issue. The country aims to digitize its $2 trillion economy, but the cyberattacks have highlighted the need for better regulation. A meeting was held to discuss the issue, with representatives from the home, technology, finance, and central bank ministries in attendance.

site_title: Sichuan's isolated Zhaba move with the times
summary: In the isolated Zhaba ethnic group of Sichuan province, China, traditional "walking marriages" are waning due to changing societal values. The introduction of the internet, smartphones, and other modern influences have led to an increase in desire for commitment and financial security. The upcoming construction of a massive dam will further disrupt the community, threatening the preservation of their unique cultural traditions. According to a 2004 survey, only 49% of Zhaba households still practice the traditional walking marriage, which involves men climbing to meet their lovers in secret.

site_title: Chinese developer Country Garden posts record 6-month net profit
summary: Country Garden Holdings Co Ltd, China's top property developer, reported a record 6-month net profit of 7.5 billion yuan (S$1.5 billion), a 39.2% increase from the previous year. The company's core profit rose 35% to 7.2 billion yuan, driven by robust business in smaller cities despite government curbs on property prices in larger cities. Country Garden's revenue rose 35.5% to 77.7 billion yuan and it expects further growth, with pre-sold but unrecognised projects. The company has climbed to the top developer spot with 288.9 billion yuan in sales for the first six months.

site_title: 'Stop blaming trade and protecting obsolete jobs'
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan urged the US and China to avoid a trade war, citing the need to focus on the digital revolution and interdependence. The US and China are intertwined in trade and investment, making a trade war comparable to the Cold War. Balakrishnan warned that rising trade protectionism poses a risk to Singapore's economy, which relies heavily on trade. He called for "cool heads" and cooperation to reap the benefits of the technological revolution, rather than blaming trade for job losses.

site_title: Breather for market after five-day slide
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a brief respite from a five-session decline, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.52% to close at 3,263.79 on Tuesday. Gainers outnumbered losers 253-165, driven by positive overnight markets in the US and reduced tensions in Korea. However, volumes remained thin at 1.9 billion shares, and the rally may be seen as a technical rebound. Investors will continue to watch for guidance from the US Federal Reserve ahead of key speeches this week.

site_title: Digitally savvy leaders to lead future growth
summary: Asian economies face significant changes due to the Fourth Industrial Revolution, with companies needing to become digitally fluent to stay relevant. Despite 75% of business leaders agreeing that new data insights can lead to new revenue streams, only one-third have a digital strategy in place. To overcome barriers such as lack of organisational leadership skills and cyber threats, companies must re-envision business models and integrate digital thinking into everyday management. Leadership is key, with CEOs needing to take a more strategic and active role in driving digital transformation.

site_title: Lum Chang unveils plan for One Tree Hill; FY17 profit falls
summary: Lum Chang Holdings, a Singaporean property and construction group, reported a 37% drop in FY17 net profit to S$18.7 million. The company plans to redevelop the One Tree Hill Garden site into 12 freehold conventional semi-detached houses and two bungalows, with construction expected to start in the second half of 2023.

images.alt_text: Plan for former The Verge: Other than the plan for the One Tree Hill site, the property in Little India formerly known as The Verge will be redeveloped into a project (left) with 320 serviced apartments and 114,000 sq ft GFA of retail space.

site_title: Airbus spreads its wings - making same plane on 3 continents
summary: Airbus is marking a milestone by simultaneously producing the same A320 aircraft on three continents: Mobile, Alabama; Europe; and Asia. The first US-built A320 will be handed over to Spirit Airlines on August 25, following the opening of Airbus's first assembly plant outside Europe in Tianjin, China, in 2008. This move aims to bring the company closer to its customers and expand its global industrial footprint. Airbus aims to reach a production rate of four aircraft per month at the Mobile facility by year's end, with a total of 8,421 A320 orders, including a backlog of over 3,800.

site_title: Rare total solar eclipse leaves millions in the US awed
summary: Millions of Americans witnessed the first coast-to-coast total solar eclipse in a century on August 21, 2017. The eclipse, visible from Oregon to South Carolina, left onlookers in awe as the moon blocked out the sun for two minutes at a time, plunging a narrow band of the US into near darkness and colder temperatures. Thousands of people traveled to remote national parks to witness the rare event, which generated widespread excitement and anticipation.

images.alt_text: Enthusiasts Josh Blink (left) and Tanner Person watching a total solar eclipse from atop Carroll Rim Trail at Painted Hills in Oregon.

site_title: China has more room to tackle debt - if it wants to
summary: China has more room to address its growing debt issues without harming its economy, according to rising corporate profits. Despite tightening financial conditions, including higher lending rates and stricter regulations, the economy is on track to meet its 6.5% GDP growth target. Analysts expect policymakers to move to curb debt further, but a recent surge in corporate profits and reduced bankruptcies suggest a more cautious approach. Total social financing has fallen, but still grew 13.2% from last year, indicating authorities are not eager to hit the brakes too hard.

site_title: Declaration of war on diabetes timely, key battle will be fighting obesity
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister urges citizens to tackle obesity and diabetes, citing the country's high rate of the disease, with one in nine Singaporeans suffering from diabetes. The government aims to combat the issue through education, healthy eating, and increased physical activity, while also encouraging food and soft drink manufacturers to reduce sugar content in their products. A sugar tax is also being considered. The global trend of increasing diabetes cases is expected to double in the next 20 years, with genes playing a role in the disease but also emphasizing the importance of diet, physical activity, and medication in prevention and management.

site_title: Brokers' take
