summary: Singtel reported a 5.6% drop in net profit to S$891.6 million in Q1 due to lower associate and joint venture results. Excluding Airtel, net profit rose 3.4%. Core and digital businesses drove revenue and Ebitda growth, with 8.3% operating revenue growth. Turn's first-time contribution and higher equipment sales contributed to the growth. Singtel CEO Chua Sock Koong attributed the results to the resilience of the core consumer business and digital investments.

site_title: MAS and CAD sound warning over digital tokens and related investment schemes
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) have sounded a warning over digital tokens and related investment schemes, citing over 100 police reports filed since 2015. The authorities urge caution, as the industry's growth attracts believers but also increases the risk of losing money. The warning comes as the digital token market continues to expand, despite the risks involved.

site_title: Tennis: Federer into Montreal quarters as Ferrer downed again
summary: Roger Federer advanced to the quarter-finals of the ATP Montreal Masters after defeating David Ferrer in a three-set match, 4-6, 6-4, 6-2. Federer, 36, maintained his career-long winning streak over Ferrer, 35, in their 16th meeting. Despite an early error-prone performance, Federer raised his game to win and will face Roberto Bautista Agut in the quarter-finals.

site_title: North Korea tensions send US dollar to eight-week low vs yen
summary: The US dollar fell to an eight-week low against the Japanese yen, 0.77% down, due to escalating tensions between the US and North Korea, driving investors to safer assets. The yen rallied against major currencies as risk aversion remained a concern.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on North Korea worries
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.9% and the S&P 500 dropping 1.5%, amid concerns over North Korea's nuclear program. President Trump's comments, which included a statement that might not have been "tough enough," contributed to the losses. High-tech companies, retailers, and biotechs were particularly affected, with Apple, Amazon, and Facebook falling. Analysts noted that the market seemed skeptical about the North Korea situation growing into a major crisis, but the losses were still significant.

site_title: Doctors at heart of US opioid crisis
summary: Doctors in the US are facing scrutiny for their role in the country's opioid crisis, with many prescribing excessive amounts of painkillers that can lead to addiction. An estimated two million Americans are addicted to opioids, resulting in 90 daily deaths and over 180,000 fatalities since 1999. Specialists argue that doctors are not solely to blame, but rather the entire healthcare system must be held accountable. Pharmaceutical companies are also being targeted, with attorneys-general suing them over their marketing tactics.

site_title: MAS keeps monetary policy stance after Singapore's Q2 GDP growth beats forecast
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 2.9% in Q2, beating market expectations, prompting the government to narrow its growth forecast to 2-3% for this year. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) kept its monetary policy stance unchanged, citing an appropriate "neutral" stance. The better outlook was attributed to a strong manufacturing sector, with a 8.1% growth rate, and stable global growth. However, downside risks such as protectionism and monetary policy normalisation remain, but their impact on global growth is considered to have eased.

site_title: Japan core machinery orders drop in June
summary: Japan's core machinery orders unexpectedly fell for a third consecutive month in June, with a 1.9% decline, contradicting recent signs of economic recovery. This decline, coupled with a 4.7% drop in the April-June period, casts doubt on policymakers' optimism that business spending will drive up capital expenditure. The data contradicts forecasts of a 3.7% increase in core orders, and analysts warn against reading too much into the highly volatile series.

site_title: Trump to North Korea: 'Be very, very nervous'
summary: US President Donald Trump warned North Korea that it should be "very, very nervous" of the consequences if it attacks US soil, after Pyongyang announced plans to send four missiles over Japan and towards Guam, home to 6,000 US soldiers. Trump dismissed criticism of his "fire and fury" warning, saying it may not have been tough enough, and urged China to pressure North Korea to end its nuclear programs. The North's military said it would finalize its plan by mid-August and submit it to leader Kim Jong-Un for consideration.

site_title: Car COE premiums higher
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars have risen, with Category A and B seeing increases of S$2,776 and S$3,710 respectively, to S$46,778 and S$53,711. Commercial vehicles and motorcycles remain flat. The increase is attributed to the long booking period and reduced quota, with Category C and D seeing decreases. Dealers attribute the rise in Cat B premium to the launch of the new Toyota Harrier Turbo SUV.

site_title: CityDev promotes Sherman Kwek to CEO-designate; Q2 net profit slips 17.9%
summary: CityDev Ltd has promoted Sherman Kwek, the deputy CEO, to CEO-designate with immediate effect, succeeding Grant Kelley who resigned on December 31, 2017. Kwek will take over full responsibilities on January 1, 2018. The company posted a 17.9% decline in Q2 net profit to S$109.9 million, despite a 21.8% drop in revenue. The board declared a special interim dividend of 4.0 cents per share. Kwek has experience in investments, mergers, and acquisitions, and will focus on replenishing the land bank while maintaining core fundamentals.

site_title: GP Industries to make cash offer for GP Batteries at S$1.30 per share
summary: GP Industries plans to launch a voluntary conditional cash offer for GP Batteries International at S$1.30 per share, aiming to privatize and delist the company. The offer, if successful, will be final as the price is not expected to be revised. The offeror, GP Industries, holds 85.47% of the shares and needs shareholder approval from Hong Kong-listed Gold Peak Industries (Holdings).

site_title: Germany needs coal for power supply security
summary: Germany's coal industry remains a crucial component of its power supply, despite Chancellor Angela Merkel's efforts to reduce the country's reliance on fossil fuels. Coal accounts for 40% of energy generation, down from 50% in 2000, but still generates 40% of Germany's electricity. Merkel is avoiding discussing a phase-out of coal due to concerns over job losses and industrial disruptions, with industry lobbies emphasizing its role in energy security and steel manufacturing.

site_title: Cyclicals and ex-divs send European shares to four-month low
summary: European shares dropped to a four-month low, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index falling 1% to 376.05. Cyclicals and some big stocks, including Anglo American and Rio Tinto, fell after going ex-dividend. Euro zone blue chips slipped 1.1% and London's FTSE 100 lost 1.4% as large caps fell. The decline was driven by a decline in basic resources and banks, overshadowing upbeat earnings reports.

site_title: National Australia Bank Q3 cash profit climbs 5%
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) reported a 5% increase in third-quarter cash profit to A$1.7 billion, driven by credit growth and a 12% decline in bad debt expenses. Revenue rose 2% and net interest margins improved due to lower funding costs. The bank's unaudited cash profit surpasses the previous year's A$1.6 billion.

site_title: Facebook launches dedicated home for videos
summary: Facebook has launched Watch, a dedicated home for videos, as part of its effort to become a major player in online video consumption. The platform, which is currently available to a limited group of US users, features a redesigned video tab with a focus on longer-form content and social interaction. Facebook aims to differentiate itself from YouTube and Netflix by incorporating social features, such as the ability to chat with friends while watching videos. The company is also expanding its video advertisement monetization program to encourage more creators to produce content for Watch.

site_title: Several firsts for Art Stage Jakarta
summary: The second edition of Art Stage Jakarta is set to take place this weekend, featuring 60 galleries, including Singapore and Malaysian participants. The fair aims to learn more about Indonesian collectors and their tastes, with regional gallerists seeking to establish a foothold in the local market. Notable galleries, such as Gajah Gallery and Richard Koh Fine Art, will showcase works by Indonesian and international artists, including Damien Hirst and Yusra Martunus. The fair also includes an Indonesian Award and interactive art projects, with the goal of positioning Jakarta as an internationally competitive art capital.

site_title: London property slump drags UK home-price growth to a standstill
summary: The UK's housing market stagnated in July, with London property prices showing no growth and England's south-east experiencing its worst performance since 2011. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reported a slump in London values, which spread to neighbouring areas. Despite this, UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, according to an index. This mixed result highlights the ongoing challenges facing the UK housing market, with London's decline particularly concerning for the sector.

images.alt_text: The most worrying aspect of the latest survey is the suggestion that the recent slowdown in sales activity in the housing market is expected to continue for some time to come.

site_title: Chinese private equity firm GSR to pay US$1b to buy Nissan's battery business
summary: Nissan Motor Co is selling its battery business to Chinese private equity firm GSR Capital for about $1 billion, marking the end of the Japanese carmaker's search for a buyer. The deal includes Automotive Energy Supply Corp and manufacturing operations in Japan, the US, and the UK. GSR will become the exclusive supplier for Nissan's Leaf electric vehicles, handling cell module development and Nissan will produce battery packs. The sale aims to improve Nissan's competitiveness and reduce costs.

site_title: Investors run for cover as reliable UK dividends in jeopardy
summary: UK investors face concerns over reliable dividend payouts as sectors such as oil and gas, pharmaceuticals, and consumer stocks show signs of strain. A weaker sterling, which has flattered income for UK investors, is expected to end next quarter, raising doubts about the sustainability of high dividend yields. Investors are seeking diversification into sectors with growing dividends, such as mining and banking, but these are vulnerable to currency fluctuations. Experts warn that high dividend yields above 6% may be a red flag, and companies' ability to maintain payouts is under scrutiny.

site_title: A truly modern Singapore in BT Weekend
summary: A modern Singapore cuisine movement is emerging among young local chefs, aiming to develop a unique and innovative culinary identity. Meanwhile, a feature explores the luxury penthouse market in Singapore, while another piece delves into the issue of corporate diversity and Google's response to a disgruntled employee's memo. The weekend edition also covers various lifestyle topics, including food, music, and fashion, as well as sports and technology.

site_title: New era dawns as Disney moves to streaming
summary: Disney is launching two new streaming services, one focused on sports programming and the other on entertainment content, marking a significant shift towards a streaming business model. The move is expected to intensify competition in the streaming market, with Netflix shares declining 1.5% following the announcement. Disney plans to spend heavily on original programming and will pull future Disney and Pixar movies from Netflix. The company's decision is seen as a rare and impressive pivot, with many analysts applauding the move despite concerns about the enormous spending required to build two new services.

site_title: Snapchat results failed to click with Wall Street
summary: Snapchat's parent company, Snap, reported a quarterly loss of $443 million, despite revenue more than doubling to $182 million. The company's user growth missed Wall Street expectations, with 173 million daily users, 21% higher than the previous year. Shares plummeted 16.8% to new lows before recovering, and analysts say the company is struggling against Facebook-owned Instagram's growing competition. Despite expressing confidence in the company's long-term success, analysts believe Snap needs to show strong growth to keep pace in the rapidly evolving social media sector.

site_title: The danger of having an incurious president
summary: US President Harry Truman's decision to use the atomic bomb on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945 was influenced by his lack of curiosity about nuclear matters, according to historian Alex Wellerstein. Truman rarely questioned his advisers and never analyzed issues independently, leading to a misunderstanding of the bomb's effects. In contrast, President John F. Kennedy's thoughtful approach to the Cuban missile crisis in 1962 was informed by his reading of books and independent judgment. The article warns that a similarly incurious president, such as the current one, could lead to disastrous decisions, citing a recent statement from President Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner that "we've read enough books."

site_title: Beware, Annabelle's back to haunt
summary: The prequel to Annabelle, Annabelle: Creation, reveals the origin of the demonically possessed doll. The story follows Samuel Mullins, a dollmaker, and his wife, who lose their daughter due to a tragic accident involving Annabelle, a doll created by Mullins. Twelve years later, the couple takes in six orphaned girls, including Janice, who reawakens Annabelle and unleashes a series of terrifying events. The film connects back to the Conjuring franchise, setting the stage for future installments.

site_title: Technology a secular investment trend but caution still warranted
summary: The US stock market has reached new highs, driven largely by the technology sector, which has seen a 400% appreciation since its 2009 low. While some investors are concerned about a potential bubble, Goldman Sachs notes that today's tech stocks have distinct advantages, including higher cash flow, valuations, and cash balances. The sector's secular mega trend is expected to last decades, but investors should exercise caution due to a "valuation air pocket" and low volatility. A diversified portfolio may be affected if tech stocks correct steeply, making it a good time to trim exposure.

site_title: US equities roiled by geopolitical uncertainties, but China is set to lead Asian equities
summary: US equities continue to face geopolitical uncertainties, with employment growth and strong earnings outlooks contributing to market volatility. In contrast, China's inclusion in the MSCI and steady growth are expected to drive Asian equities forward, with the MSCI's Asian countries returning over 27% year-to-date. Despite US Fed expected to start shrinking its balance sheet and raise interest rates, China's robust economy and curbs on property investments are attracting investor interest in equities.

site_title: No longer YouTube's best kept secret
summary: Greg Gonzalez, frontman of indie dream pop band Cigarettes After Sex, has finally achieved mainstream success five years after releasing his first EP, I. in 2012. The band's track "Nothing's Gonna Hurt You Baby" gained 50 million views on YouTube, leading to a near-sold-out show in Singapore. Gonzalez credits the band's unique sound, which draws comparisons to Mazzy Star and Cocteau Twins, and his personal experiences, including heartbreak and a long-distance relationship, as key factors in their success.

site_title: Qatar Airways targets other US investments after American rebuff
summary: Qatar Airways' CEO, Akbar Al Baker, stated that the airline will consider other US investments despite scrapping plans to buy a stake in American Airlines Group Inc. due to opposition. Al Baker expressed confidence in the US market, citing other opportunities in America and North America. The airline's decision comes after a rebuff from American Airlines.

site_title: Interra renews oil production contracts in Myanmar
summary: Interra Resources, an oil exploration and production firm, has renewed its oil production contracts in Myanmar, providing a boost to its future production. With the extension, the company can now invest in new capital expenditure, bolstering oil production in existing fields. CEO Marcel Tjia stated that the renewal offers greater certainty for the firm's future growth.

site_title: Wilmar swings into black in Q2 with US$60.2m profit
summary: Wilmar International reported a net profit of US$60.2 million for the second quarter, swinging to a profit after a loss of US$220.1 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the improvement to a recovery in the oilseeds and grains business and gains from investment securities. Non-operating gains, fueled by stronger equity markets, were a key contributor to the turnaround.

site_title: Disappointing bottles that raise provenance concerns
summary: A recent article discusses the quality of Gevrey-Chambertin wines, a type of Burgundy wine. The village is known for producing full-bodied, tannic wines with a higher quality standard than in the past. Gevrey-Chambertin wines are comparable to Pauillac wines in Bordeaux, both being at the northern end of their respective regions and sharing similar characteristics. The article suggests that the best Gevrey-Chambertin wines can develop into long-lived Burgundies, offering a high level of quality and complexity.

site_title: Boustead Singapore's Q1 profit falls 58% on FX loss, weak markets
summary: Boustead Singapore's Q1 profit fell 58% to S$2.9 million due to FX losses and weak markets, particularly in oil & gas and industrial real estate. Revenue declined 21% to S$90.3 million, with energy-related engineering revenue dropping 29% and real estate solutions revenue falling 25%. Despite this, the company remains on the lookout for acquisition opportunities and expects to be profitable in FY18.

site_title: UK trade, manufacturing disappoint in second quarter
summary: The UK economy ended the second quarter on a disappointing note, with manufacturing stagnating and the trade deficit unexpectedly widening. Industrial production rose 0.5% in June, but manufacturing production remained unchanged due to a 6.7% decline in vehicle production. The economy grew 0.3% in the second quarter, half the pace of the euro region, and economists predict a similar expansion in the second half. The trade deficit widened to a nine-month high of £4.6 billion, and the Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates at a record-low for now.

site_title: All eyes on Ezion's moves to quell market jitters
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine company, has seen its stock tumble to a 52-week low amid market jitters before its second-quarter results. The company has taken on significant impairment losses and has set aside capital expenditure to high-grade its existing fleet. Ezion has also entered into a deal to divest 50% shareholding in two subsidiaries to Labuan-incorporated Sea Explorer for $10 million. Analysts question the company's ability to cope with dwindling cash flows and mounting impairments, raising concerns about its long-term viability.

site_title: At US$350m, Beverly Hillbillies mansion is priciest in the US
summary: A Beverly Hills mansion, Chartwell, has sold for $350 million, making it the priciest property in the US. The estate features a ballroom, formal salon, wine cellar, tennis court, pool, and 40-car parking. The sale price is a significant increase from the original estimate of $25 million to $100 million, reflecting the luxury and exclusivity of the property.

site_title: DBS launches largest direct seller-to-buyer car marketplace
summary: DBS has launched Singapore's largest direct seller-to-buyer car marketplace, partnering with sgCarMart and Carro to offer over 3,500 direct-owner listings. The platform provides a one-stop solution for buying and selling cars, offering exclusive benefits and streamlined processes. DBS's car loan interest rate is also available to buyers who purchase a car through the marketplace by August 31. The platform aims to capitalize on the trend of direct buying and selling of vehicles, with sgCarMart and Carro reporting a significant increase in listings and transactions.

site_title: mm2 Asia says it's still in talks to buy stake in Golden Village cinema business
summary: mm2 Asia Ltd is still in talks to buy a 50% stake in Golden Village cinema business in Singapore after a failed bid to acquire the stake lapsed. The company received a full refund of its S$8 million deposit and is pursuing other opportunities. Despite earlier selling pressures, mm2 Asia's shares rose 1.1% following the update. The group remains committed to its cinema growth strategy, which is not dependent on this one acquisition.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q2 profit jumps 75.3% to S$12.71m
summary: SBS Transit's Q2 profit surged 75.3% to S$12.71 million, driven by a 7% increase in revenue to S$287.8 million, largely due to higher bus and rail ridership. Operating costs rose 4.7% to S$271.63 million, but were offset by lower fuel and electricity costs. The company declared a tax-exempt one-tier interim dividend of 3.65 cents per share. Revenue from public transport services is expected to grow, driven by the Bus Contracting Model, while rail service revenue will increase with continued ridership growth.

site_title: Hertz's 101-year-old business model nears twilight in Uber age
summary: Hertz Global Holdings Inc, a 101-year-old car-rental company, is struggling due to the rise of ride-sharing services like Uber and Lyft. The company reported its third straight quarter of loss, with a 63 US cents-per-share adjusted loss. Hertz's bloated fleet and inability to unload cars at decent prices are major issues. The industry's tough times may be attributed to mismanagement rather than the threat posed by new mobility companies. Despite this, some analysts believe rental companies can adapt and benefit from the shift, particularly with their existing infrastructure and staff.

site_title: Boeing, Nasa look to flying geese in chase for jet-fuel savings
summary: Boeing and NASA are exploring a cost-effective method to reduce airline fuel bills by mimicking the aerodynamic efficiency of migratory geese. By arranging aircraft in a V-formation, known as "wake surfing," airlines can harness energy from the lead plane, potentially saving 10-15% on fuel costs. This technique requires precise scheduling and coordination, but studies suggest it could be feasible without extensive cockpit upgrades. The concept is part of Boeing's research into various fuel-saving methods, including glider-like wings and autonomous flight capabilities.

site_title: Another milestone in great landmarks
summary: DP Architects, a Singaporean firm, is celebrating its 50-year journey in designing iconic landmarks such as Suntec City, Marina Square, and Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay. Founded in 1967 with 15 staff, the firm has grown to 1,300 staff in 17 countries, ranking as the 10th largest firm in the world.

images.alt_text: DP Architects is behind buildings such as Suntec City, Marina Square, Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay, Wisma Atria, Paragon Shopping Centre and Singapore Sports Hub (above).
DP Architects is behind buildings such as Suntec City, Marina Square, Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay, Wisma Atria, Paragon Shopping Centre (above) and Singapore Sports Hub.
DP Architects is behind buildings such as Suntec City, Marina Square, Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay, Wisma Atria (above), Paragon Shopping Centre and Singapore Sports Hub.

site_title: Private condo rents in July up 0.2% as rental volume rises: SRX Property
summary: Singapore's private condo rents rose 0.2% in July from June, following a 0.6% increase in June, according to SRX Property. Rental volume also increased by 11.8% in July. The Core Central Region (CCR) and Outside Central Region (OCR) saw upticks, while the Rest of Central Region (RCR) saw a dip. However, the overall rental market remains subdued, with property consultants expecting continued weakness until next year.

site_title: Belgium, the Netherlands hatch plan to curb spread of bad eggs
summary: Dutch and Belgian investigators raided premises linked to a fipronil contamination probe, curbing the spread of bad eggs. Britain revealed it had imported more contaminated eggs than initially reported, while Luxembourg also found eggs containing the insecticide. This scandal, already affecting eight countries, raises concerns about human health. Authorities are working to address the issue, with some countries imposing measures to curb the spread of contaminated eggs.

images.alt_text: Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel receiving eggs from Philippe Duvivier of Fugea ahead of a meeting between the Prime Minister and delegates from the egg and chicken industry in Houffalize on Aug 10.

site_title: Glencore slashes debt as it gears up for acquisitions
summary: Glencore, the world's largest commodities trading house, has cut its debt to US$13.9 billion by June, with a strong first-half financial performance. The company is preparing for acquisitions, with a war chest built to take advantage of rising commodity prices. Despite keeping its dividend unchanged, Glencore is prioritizing its balance sheet, with a preferred leverage ratio of 1.07, below its target of 2. The company has already inked deals, including a US$1.1 billion coal mine stake, and is benefiting from metal price recoveries, particularly copper and aluminium.

site_title: Some US coding boot camps close as field gets crowded
summary: Coding boot camps in the US are facing a crowded market, leading to closures and shifts in focus towards corporate training. At least eight schools have shut down or announced plans to close in 2017, with many more expected to follow. Despite the challenges, some successful boot camps, such as Flatiron School, have reported high job placement rates and average starting salaries of over $70,000. Larger, venture-backed boot camps are now focusing on corporate training, with companies like Galvanize expanding their services to help businesses hire and retrain engineers.

site_title: Centurion to buy another student housing asset in the US
summary: Centurion Corporation plans to acquire College & Crown, a 160-unit student accommodation asset near Yale University in the US, for US$70 million. This follows its previous acquisition of a US student accommodation portfolio for US$136 million. The deal is expected to be completed in end-September and will be earnings accretive from the fourth quarter of 2017. Centurion will own up to 30% of the combined portfolio, which will total six accommodations with 2,140 beds.

site_title: Economists expect Q2 growth to be revised upwards
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow at a revised 2.5% in 2017, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's latest forecast. Economists predict modest second-half growth, with Q2 growth likely to come in at 2.5-2.8%. Manufacturing growth is expected to moderate, but services growth is expected to pick up, driven by improving regional trade and domestic consumer confidence. However, household consumption growth is expected to remain subdued due to elevated job market uncertainty and low income growth.

site_title: Brexit offers UK chance to reinvent its global role
summary: The UK's exit from the EU, known as Brexit, presents a chance for the country to reinvent its global role. Prime Minister Theresa May aims to rediscover the UK as a great global trading nation, with a focus on emerging markets like China and India. UK Secretary of State for International Trade Liam Fox is negotiating new trade deals with at least a dozen countries, while also discussing post-Brexit terms with the WTO. However, the UK's future trading arrangements will be severely disrupted if it fails to achieve new WTO commitments, and negotiations will be challenging due to the need for agreements to be secured after the UK leaves the EU.

site_title: Reinventing himself with disco and cats
summary: Singer Sezairi Sezali has undergone a musical transformation, embracing his love for disco and funk after finding inspiration in his cats. The 29-year-old, formerly known as Sezairi, has released a new single "70s" with a Swedish collaboration team, which he describes as a culmination of his personal quirks and joy in making music. He aims to leave his Idol days behind and set dance floors ablaze with his new dance-pop sound, encouraging listeners to relax and be true to themselves.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives posts lower Q2 profit
summary: Kingsmen Creatives, a Singapore-based communication design and production group, reported a 26% decline in Q2 net profit to S$2.37 million, driven by a 10% drop in revenue. The decline was largely due to a 24.5% drop in revenue from its exhibitions division. However, the company's retail and corporate interiors segments saw revenue rise 6.3% and 9.2%, respectively. The group's gross profit margin increased to 25.1%, despite a 5.4% decline in gross profit.

site_title: Thai billionaire leads four firms with top-20 return potential
summary: Thai billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont's four companies - Charoen Pokphand Foods, CP All, Siam Makro, and True Corp - are among the top 20 in terms of return potential in South-east Asia's emerging economies over the next 12 months. CP Foods is forecast to rally 28% and CP All to gain 17.3%, while Siam Makro is expected to provide a 13% return. The Thai economy is forecast to expand 3.4% this year, and investors are looking to these companies as a way to capitalize on emerging economic growth in the region.

site_title: Prudential Singapore reports strong growth in first half of 2017
summary: Prudential Singapore reported strong growth in the first half of 2017, with IFRS operating profit increasing 6% year-over-year to £133 million. The company's annual premium equivalent grew 23% to £195 million, and single-premium new sales in Singapore jumped 66% to £323 million. The merger of M&G and Prudential UK and Europe to create M&G Prudential was also announced, raising speculation about potential future changes.

images.alt_text: Mr Wells says combining M&G and Prudential UK and Europe "will allow us to better leverage our . . . scale and capabilities"

site_title: Japan Post Q1 profit up 26% at 104.5b yen
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co Ltd reported a 25.7% increase in quarterly profit to 104.5 billion yen, driven by gains from foreign exchange trading at its banking unit. The banking unit's net profit rose 31.6% to 89.4 billion yen, offsetting declining interest on Japanese government bond holdings. Japan Post's insurance unit also saw a 24.3% increase in annual profit to 24.1 billion yen. The company's reliance on foreign exchange trading and insurance premiums helped boost its performance despite declining interest from its government bond holdings.

site_title: Rambunctious slapstick machine
summary: Army Daze 2, a slapstick comedy sequel to the 1987 play, has been staged with over-the-top visuals and musical numbers. The new production follows 30 years after the original, with Malcolm Png, now a respected colonel, reuniting with his army buddies, including his son Justin, who is conscripted into the military. The sequel's reliance on visual gags and musical numbers has been praised, but also criticized for being too much for some viewers, with some performances being cheesy or lacking comedic timing.

images.alt_text: Army Daze 2 looks at a new batch of enlistees as they undergo Basic Military Training.

site_title: Unethical leaders thrive on support from followers
summary: A study reveals that employees often justify unethical behaviors by leaders, enabling them to continue their actions. This phenomenon is seen in cases such as Enron, Worldcom, and Tyco, where leaders were able to carry out large-scale shady ventures with the daily support of their employees. The study highlights that leaders' trustworthiness is negatively impacted by unethical behavior, leading to strained future interactions. This phenomenon underscores the complex relationship between leaders and their followers.

site_title: Fed up with paying the price for Teva's woes, workers dig in
summary: Workers at Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd in Israel are protesting proposed job cuts and demanding that managers share the financial burden of the company's debt, which totals US$43 billion. The workers, who earn an average of S$3,033 a month, feel that executives, including interim CEO Yitzhak Peterburg, should take personal responsibility for the company's financial woes. The demands come as Teva faces a 53% decline in market value and has been forced to slash dividend payments, exit markets, and deepen job cuts.

site_title: Invitation Homes, Starwood Waypoint deal sends shares soaring
summary: Invitation Homes and Starwood Waypoint Homes have agreed to merge, creating the largest single-family rental firm in the US. The all-stock deal values the combined company at over $11 billion and will own around 82,000 homes. The merger is driven by demand for rental homes and a growing US economy, despite low homeownership rates. Starwood Waypoint's CEO, Fred Tuomi, will lead the combined company, which will trade on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: In Aug 21 eclipse, gas will see its future as solar's back-up in US
summary: Natural gas is expected to regain its role as a backup power source in the US during the Aug 21 eclipse, as solar fields cede market share to fast-start natural gas generators, hydroelectric plants, and other sources. This shift is due to solar energy's increased capacity to generate power during the day, reducing the need for natural gas to fill gaps when the sun sets.

site_title: Cityneon shareholders advised to reject offer
summary: Cityneon Holdings Limited, a specialist in neon lighting and interactive exhibits, has been advised by independent directors to reject a mandatory unconditional cash offer from Lucrum 1 Investment, citing "unfair and unreasonable" financial terms. The offer price of 90 Singapore cents per share represents a 5.4% discount to the stock's volume-weighted average price and a 28.6% discount to estimated mean target prices. The company's shares have closed above the offer price on 150 out of 253 market days in the past year.

site_title: Euro falls against US$ as risk appetite drops
summary: The euro slipped 0.3% to $1.1723 against the US dollar, reaching a two-week low, due to decreased risk appetite amid tensions between the US and North Korea. Despite this, the euro remains the best-performing G10 currency this year, with gains of over 11% against the dollar. The dollar index was trading 0.2% up at 93.73. Geopolitical concerns and market uncertainty are expected to dominate investor mindsets in the coming days.

site_title: Cuban-born sugar barons amass over US$8b fortune by mastering US politics
summary: Cuban-born sugar barons, the Fanjul family, have amassed an estimated $8.2 billion fortune by mastering US politics. Their sons, Alfonso and Jose, have the Trump administration's ear as it aims to rewrite the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) with protections for US sugar growers and millers. The family's lobbying efforts have been successful, with a recent deal closing a loophole exploited by Mexican producers and securing a new definition of raw sugar that benefits US processors like the Fanjuls. The brothers' donations to both parties have made them influential political donors in America.

site_title: The nomads of summer in New York
summary: New Yorkers, particularly recent graduates, are delaying apartment hunting due to high summer rental prices, with some opting to move in with relatives or rent short-term Airbnb properties. The summer rental season is the most expensive, with prices increasing as graduates flock to the city for jobs or college. To avoid the high costs, some are taking a "nomadic" approach, moving out of the city for a few months to find more affordable options in the fall. This trend is driven by factors such as school turnover, job cycles, and the desire to avoid harsh winter weather.

site_title: China's bond issuers lacking in accountability
summary: Chinese bond issuers lack transparency, making it difficult for investors to assess their accountability. A Shandong Ruyi Science and Technology Group Co bond sale raised questions about its ownership, with a state-owned enterprise listed as a major shareholder. The bond's price plummeted after the sale but quickly recovered. This lack of transparency is a concern for investors in developed markets, where transparent accounting is a key factor in bond issuances.

site_title: Indian family drug firm turns world-beater
summary: Cadila Healthcare Ltd, an Indian family-owned generic drug manufacturer, has become one of the top generic drug manufacturers in the world under the leadership of managing director Sharvil Patel. Despite increased regulatory scrutiny and competition in the US, the company has achieved significant success, with a 50% return on stock in the first half of 2017 and a market value of over $1 billion. Patel attributes the company's success to its ability to launch new, exclusive products and its cultural changes that prioritize quality and efficiency.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: UOB Kay Hian's second-quarter net profit rose 3.2% to S$16.5 million due to higher trading volumes. Temasek invested US$110 million in PCCW Media, while Banyan Tree's loss narrowed to S$12.26 million. CSE Global suffered a S$13.8 million loss due to a US settlement, and Hiap Hoe reported a net profit of S$1.44 million. Dragon Group International received a US$20 million investment from Zhuhai Yinlong Energy Co, which will subscribe for 40% of its subsidiary EoCell's shares.

site_title: SIA to set up pilot training centre in Singapore with CAE
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is teaming up with CAE to establish a pilot training centre in Singapore, providing simulator training for Boeing aircraft types to SIA and other regional airlines. The 50/50 joint venture will begin operations by year-end, offering initial type rating and recurrent training programs for Boeing 737 MAX, 747, 777, and 787 aircraft. This move aims to meet growing pilot-training needs in the Asia-Pacific region, with SIA CEO Goh Choon Phong citing the need to drive revenue from new adjacent businesses.

site_title: Microsoft's Surface computers lose Consumer Reports backing
summary: Consumer Reports is withdrawing its recommendation for four Microsoft laptops and tablets, citing a quarter of the devices posing problems after two years. Despite laboratory testing, subscriber surveys revealed issues with start-up, freezing, and unresponsive touch screens. Microsoft disputes the findings, stating its devices accurately reflect owners' experiences. The decision affects the Surface Laptop and Surface Book, with Consumer Reports citing 90,741 devices from 2014-2017 in its study.

site_title: Next-generation battery seen powering space projects, cars
summary: Researchers in Japan's Hitachi Zosen Corp are developing a safer generation of solid-state lithium-ion batteries that can withstand extreme temperatures, potentially powering space projects and cars. The company has already shipped samples to potential customers in the aerospace and automobile industries, with plans to commercialize small-size batteries by 2020. While solid-state batteries hold promise for better safety and performance, challenges remain, including low power characteristics and high electrical resistance.

site_title: Banks hold up STI amid N Korea tensions
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 5.16 points to 3,323.24, driven by a strong performance from banks, particularly DBS, which gained S$0.24 to S$21.26. The index's rise was largely overshadowed by concerns over North Korea's plan to fire missiles towards the US territory of Guam, causing a decline in Asian markets and global stocks. Trading turnover soared to S$1.8 billion, with elevated trading in banks accounting for nearly 20% of the market's dollar volume.

site_title: Australia shares end lower as banks pull back; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 5,760.9, driven by financial stocks retreating after a brief buying surge and ex-dividend trading of Rio Tinto. Top lenders Westpac and ANZ Bank fell 0.3%, while National Australia Bank recovered slightly.

site_title: US$1.2b one-off charges deepen Noble Group's Q2 loss to US$1.75b
summary: Noble Group reported a Q2 loss of US$1.75 billion, with US$1.2 billion in one-off charges. Revenue declined 19% to US$10.12 billion, largely due to lower trading volumes in its oil liquids business. The company is working to reduce its debt and has partnered with Mercuria Energy America to access trade finance lines. Noble also plans to sell its North American gas and power operations and reduce its headcount to 400. The company aims to raise US$800 million to US$1 billion through asset disposal over the next two years.

images.alt_text: Hit by trading losses in its oil liquids business and US$1.2 billion in one-off charges, Noble Group fell deeper into the red in the second quarter, recording a loss of US$1.75 billion.

site_title: US:Dow slips 100 points as tensions with N Korea escalate
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 100 points, or 0.39%, on Thursday due to escalating tensions between the US and North Korea. The US President's warning of "fire and fury" if North Korea threatened the US sparked investor fears of an escalation. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with safe-haven assets like gold rising amid the nervousness. Retail results were also a concern, with Kohl's and Macy's shares down due to declining sales.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Analysts from DBS Group Research and CIMB Research have provided updates on Global Logistic Properties (GLP) and Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Reit (SSREIT). GLP's core earnings declined 2.6% year-over-year, while SSREIT's price surged 10% after reports of a potential takeover by e-Shang Redwood. Analysts at Phillip Securities Research believe the acquisition of SSREIT's assets is more likely than a consolidation. Meanwhile, GLP's core EPS was in line with expectations, and the company is exploring options to grow in new and existing markets.

site_title: Temasek to invest in PCCW Media's streaming venture
summary: Temasek, a Chinese private equity firm, Hony Capital, and Foxconn Ventures will invest US$110 million in PCCW Media's streaming venture, PCCW International OTT Holdings. The three investors will own approximately 18% of the company, supporting the introduction of more local content and innovative products. PCCW Media will remain the controlling shareholder, aiming to strengthen its market position and ecosystem through the partnership.

site_title: Toshiba Corp wins auditor sign-off, likely to have avoided delisting for now
summary: Toshiba Corp has likely avoided immediate delisting after its auditor, PriceWaterhouseCoopers, signed off on its financial results despite criticism of its governance. The auditor expressed concerns over Westinghouse's delayed booking of losses, which could have triggered delisting. Toshiba's chip unit, accounting for 94% of its operating profit, is being auctioned off to raise cash, but talks have stalled due to opposition from Western Digital Corp. Analysts say Toshiba's long-term prospects are bleak, and the company needs to reach a deal within weeks to avoid negative shareholder equity.

site_title: Henkel counts on new products to tackle weak sales growth
summary: Henkel plans to launch new beauty products in France and Italy to boost sales after its second quarter organic sales growth was the weakest in eight years. The company reported robust sales of professional beauty care products in April to June, but retail sales fell short of expectations. Henkel aims to capitalize on this growth with new product releases.

site_title: All about the booze and boys
summary: The comedy film Girls Trip follows four college friends, now in their 40s, who reunite in New Orleans for a wild weekend. The movie explores their personal and professional issues, including infidelity, motherhood, and career struggles, as they let loose and rediscover their younger selves. Led by Queen Latifah, Tiffany Haddish, Jada Pinkett Smith, and Regina Hall, the film delivers raunchy humor and a star-studded cast, despite some predictable plot points and gross-out humor. The movie's success will likely lead to a sequel, and it will appeal to fans of female empowerment and comedy.

site_title: Nam Cheong hit with writ of summons from AmBank
summary: Nam Cheong Ltd received a writ of summons and statement of claim from AmBank in the High Court of Malaysia, alleging RM70.4 million owed as of July 31. This comes amid restructuring discussions with AmBank and other lenders to address significant debt maturities. The company has defaulted on a S$365 million bond in July and its stock is suspended. Nam Cheong is reviewing the writ and seeking legal advice, while remaining committed to restructuring efforts.

site_title: Retailers on the rebound with the help of enhanced IT
summary: The South-east Asian region is experiencing rapid economic growth, with Asean GDP projected to reach 5% from 2010 to 2020. The region's digital economy is also booming, with 230 million individuals relying on digital means to purchase products and services, contributing to the region's internet economy exceeding $50 billion. Retailers are leveraging mobile devices to enhance the customer experience, incorporating tools like QR codes, online coupons, and augmented-reality product overlays. To succeed, retailers must overcome legacy technology barriers and invest in omnichannel experiences, customer loyalty, and real-time data analysis to create a seamless, comfortable experience across all channels.

site_title: Caribbean's forbidden fruit turns to Europe, China for a market
summary: Dominican Republic cigar maker Radhames Rodriguez is launching a premium cigar, Pulita, only in Europe due to US FDA regulations. The new product would have cost tens of thousands of dollars to obtain approval, pricing it out of the US market. The US tobacco regulations, introduced in August 2016, have led to a decline in business for cigar makers, with some producers temporarily cutting production or choosing to sell in Europe and Asia instead. The US market is expected to see less than 2% annual growth through 2021, while the Chinese market is projected to grow to $11 billion by 2021.

site_title: D'Silva hits the sweet spot in latest venture
summary: Chef Damian D'Silva's new restaurant, Folklore, has opened on Beach Road in Singapore. The restaurant embodies the chef's cooking comfort, showcasing his culinary expertise in fine dining, gastrobar, and hawker stall styles. With a focus on mod-Indian cuisine, Folklore offers a unique dining experience. The restaurant is open daily from 12pm to 2.30pm and 6pm to 9.30pm.

images.alt_text: Hati babi bungkus, minced pork and liver shaped into perfect, bouncy and juicy globes of goodness.

(Left) Kuih bengka baked to wobbly resilience and jelly-textured kuih kosui in a blanket of snowy grated coconut. (Middle) Peranakan chap chye is another heavy hitter where the chef doesn't skimp on ingredients. (Right) Chef D'Silva's trademark singgang is as good as ever - a Eurasian dish of meticulously deboned Spanish mackerel mixed in an almost creamy sauce of candlenut, galangal, shallots and turmeric.

site_title: A currency safe haven is feeling less safe
summary: The US dollar has lost nearly 8% against a basket of major currencies since the beginning of the year, sparking concerns about its status as a safe-haven currency. The decline is attributed to the unconventional actions of US President Donald Trump, including his threat to North Korea and expulsion of Russian diplomats, which have created uncertainty and scepticism among investors. The US dollar's value is seen as a reflection of contrasting economic prospects in the US and other countries, with Europe and Asia showing signs of growth and the US economy struggling due to the Trump administration's policies and recent interest rate hikes.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian's Q2 profit rises 3.2% to S$16.5m
summary: UOB Kay Hian's Q2 profit rose 3.2% to S$16.5 million, driven by higher trading volumes in regional markets. Total income increased 0.8% to S$90.5 million, with a 30.7% rise in commission income and a 31.7% fall in interest income. The group remains cautiously optimistic on regional market prospects, citing a firmer note in the first half of 2017 and early signs of recovery in the Singapore property market.

site_title: IReit Global to pay out Q2 DPU of 1.45 Singapore cents
summary: IReit Global, a Europe-focused real estate investment trust, announced a Q2 DPU of 1.45 Singapore cents, down from 1.6 Singapore cents previously. Income distribution fell 9.5% to 5.8 million euros due to retention of part of the distributable income. Gross revenue rose 4% year-over-year to 8.82 million euros, while net property income increased 2.7% to 7.85 million euros. A DPU of 2.89 Singapore cents for the six-month period will be paid out on Sept 15.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end Thursday lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended Thursday lower, closing at 1,777.77 after a 0.17-point drop. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 1.35 billion lots valued at RM1.5 billion traded, with 259 gains and 624 losses.

site_title: Banyan Tree narrows Q2 loss to S$12.26m
summary: Banyan Tree's loss for the second quarter narrowed to S$12.26 million, a 14% decrease from the previous year, due to a 6% year-on-year increase in revenue to S$69.84 million. The company reported an operating profit of S$350,000, up from an operating loss of S$3.36 million. Banyan Tree plans to open three new resorts in the next year.

site_title: Pan-United Corp Q2 net profit edges up
summary: Pan-United Corp reported a 2% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$5.35 million for the second quarter ended June 30, despite a 24% decline in profit from continuing operations. Revenue fell 6% to S$164.76 million, while earnings per share decreased to one Singapore cent. The company has disposed of a business that resulted in a loss in the corresponding quarter last year.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives Q2 profit falls 26%
summary: Kingsmen Creatives' Q2 net profit fell 26% to S$2.37 million due to lower revenue from its exhibitions & thematic division. Revenue declined 10% to S$78.77 million. Earnings per share decreased from 1.61 Singapore cents to 1.19 Singapore cents. Despite this, the company declared a dividend of one Singapore cent per share. Kingsmen plans to invest in talent, expand capabilities, and pursue new businesses to enhance service offerings.

site_title: Veggie bank notes? BoE sticks with animal-fat cash
summary: Britain's Bank of England has decided to stick with animal-fat cash for its new plastic banknotes, despite thousands of complaints from vegetarians and religious groups. The decision was made due to environmental risks and high costs associated with using alternative palm oil-derived materials. The bank notes, launched last year, contain less than 0.05% of animal products and are expected to cost an additional £16.5 million over the next decade. The Bank of England cited environmental concerns and cost considerations as the reasons for their decision.

site_title: Chinese firm to invest US$20m into Dragon Group unit
summary: Dragon Group International (DGI) announced a strategic investment of US$20 million from Chinese firm Zhuhai Yinlong Energy Co (YLE) into its subsidiary EoCell. YLE will subscribe for 940,000 new shares, representing about 40% of EoCell's enlarged share capital. DGI currently holds a 93% stake in EoCell, which will be reduced to 40% after the investment, similar to YLE's stake. The remaining 20% stake will be held by EoCell's key management.

site_title: SoftBank bolsters Flipkart's firepower to challenge Amazon in India
summary: SoftBank has invested nearly $2.5 billion in Flipkart, giving the Indian e-commerce company more firepower to compete with Amazon. The investment, part of the same funding round that raised $1.4 billion in April, will make SoftBank one of Flipkart's top shareholders. The deal comes as global investors grow confident in the Indian e-commerce sector, where dominant players are focusing on customer experience and technology investments. SoftBank's Vision Fund will own around one-fifth of Flipkart, displacing US hedge fund Tiger Global as the company's largest investor.

site_title: Moon to spoil meteor show: astronomers
summary: A bright Moon will outshine the annual Perseids meteor shower, reducing the number of visible shooting stars to about 20 per hour. The Moon's gibbous phase will spoil stargazers' view, similar to urban light pollution. Experts predict an enhanced rate of 150 meteors per hour, but the Moon's light will cancel out the fainter Perseids, making it a less-than-ideal viewing year. The best viewing opportunity is expected before the Moon rises around 11pm local time on Friday, when the meteors tend to be longer and more visible.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS and CAD issued warnings about potential risks of digital tokens and related investment schemes, advising consumers to exercise caution. COE premiums rose in Singapore, while Interra Resources secured an 11-year deal with Myanma Oil & Gas Enterprise. MM2 Asia is still in talks to buy Golden Village, and Centurion acquired a US$70 million student housing project in the US. Stocks finished weaker in Singapore, despite bank support, due to North Korea tensions. International news includes Vietnam's surprise over US tariffs, Malaysia's asset seizure, China's slowing GDP, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Canada June new home prices up less than expected as Toronto pauses
summary: Canada's new home prices rose 0.2% in June, below analyst forecasts of a 0.4% gain. The Toronto housing market, Canada's largest city, paused for the first time in six months due to provincial measures to rein in the market. This pause was also seen in nearby areas such as Oshawa and Hamilton, where high costs in Toronto drove buyers to other areas.

site_title: VW Group, Tata cooperation talks have ended -source
summary: Volkswagen Group's cooperation talks with Tata Motors on a joint car development for emerging markets have ended. The talks, which began in March, aimed to create a cheap vehicle platform for Asian markets. However, Volkswagen's Skoda division dropped the idea due to concerns over significant investment needed for future crash-test and emissions requirements. Volkswagen will instead explore its own MQB platform for potential synergies. The partnership's collapse is a blow to Volkswagen's efforts to develop an affordable vehicle platform for Asian markets.

site_title: US producer prices post biggest drop in 11 months
summary: US producer prices dropped 0.1% in July, the largest decline in nearly a year, due to a 0.2% decrease in services and a 0.3% decline in energy prices. This marks a reversal of June's 0.1% gain and a 1.9% increase in the 12 months through July. The drop may lead to concerns about the moderation in inflation, potentially delaying the next Federal Reserve interest rate increase, which was previously expected in December.

images.alt_text: The Labor Department said on Thursday its producer price index for final demand slipped 0.1 percent last month, reversing June's 0.1 percent gain. July's drop was the largest since August 2016. SOURCE:AFP

site_title: Bombardier C Series eyes Europe-US after London City boost
summary: Bombardier's C Series jetliner is targeting Europe-US routes following the start of flights from London City airport, where its unique features, including double range, 25% more capacity, and quieter noise footprint, have been demonstrated. The aircraft has previously completed a test flight from London City to New York's JFK International hub. This move aims to establish the C Series' long-haul credentials and attract potential buyers, particularly for trans-Atlantic operations.

site_title: Criticism of regulators over Noble is misplaced
summary: Regulators of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) were criticized for not acting on Noble Group's financial issues over 30 months, resulting in a 90% share price crash. Critics argue that SGX should have intervened earlier, but experts argue that the exchange follows an evidence-based approach and that regulators must be cautious not to cause unintended harm to the market. The role of research analysts also raises questions, with some arguing they should be held accountable for elevating Noble's stock price.

images.alt_text: Frontline stockmarket regulator SGX (Singapore Exchange) and its supervisor MAS (Monetary Authority of Singapore) were criticised by research firm Iceberg Research last month for not acting over the past 30 months during which the shares of commodities firm Noble Group crashed by more than 90 per cent following publication of Iceberg's first attack on Noble's financials in early 2015.

site_title: Toshiba reports long-delayed earnings, posts US$8.8b loss
summary: Toshiba reported a net loss of $8.8 billion for its fiscal year ended March 31, largely due to losses at its US nuclear unit Westinghouse Electric. The company dodged a delisting from Japan's stock exchange, but still faces a court battle over the sale of its prized memory chip business. Toshiba expects to return to profitability in the current fiscal year, driven by a strong performance in the chip division. The company needs to get out of negative net worth by March 2018 to avoid delisting.

site_title: Car COE premiums rise in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose in the first round of bidding in August, with Category A increasing to S$46,778 and Cat B to S$53,711. Cat E, the open category, rose S$2,650 to S$52,751. Commercial vehicles and motorcycles saw no change. The increases are attributed to rising demand and supply constraints.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker despite banks' support for STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 5.16 points to 3,323.24, despite a broad market of 314 falls and 168 rises, driven by banks' support. Trading volume reached S$1.8 billion, with banks accounting for almost 20% of the market's dollar volume. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally, with investors staying positive despite US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Provisions to settle Iran issue drag CSE Global to S$13.8m Q2 loss
summary: CSE Global reported a Q2 loss of S$13.8 million, down from a S$5.5 million profit a year ago, due to a S$16.8 million provision for a US settlement on alleged Iran sanctions violations. Revenue rose 15% to S$85.5 million, but operating profit fell 45% to S$3.8 million. The company declared an unchanged interim dividend of 1.25 Singapore cents a share.

site_title: SIA, CAE sign MOU to start pilot training JV
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and CAE have signed a 50:50 joint venture (JV) for pilot training in Singapore. The JV will provide simulator training for Boeing aircraft types, initially focusing on SIA's airlines and other operators in the region. The training facility, located at the Singapore Airlines Training Centre, will offer initial and recurrent training programs for Boeing 737 MAX, 747, 777, and 787 aircraft types. Operations are expected to begin by year-end, with SIA transferring four of its full-flight simulators to the venture.

site_title: Noble falls deeper into the red with US$1.75b Q2 loss
summary: Noble Group reported a Q2 net loss of US$1.75 billion, down from a net loss of US$54.9 million in the previous year, due to trading losses in its oil liquids business and impairment charges. Revenue declined 19% to US$10.1 billion, resulting in an operating loss of US$1.5 billion. The company attributed the challenges to the commodities sector and its own issues, stating that steps taken are setting it on a path to recovery.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q2 profit jumps 75% to S$12.71m
summary: SBS Transit reported a 75.3% increase in Q2 net profit to S$12.71 million, driven by 7% growth in revenue to S$287.8 million. Earnings per share rose to 4.09 Singapore cents, higher than the same period last year. A tax-exempt one-tier interim dividend of 3.65 Singapore cents per share was declared, up from 2.35 cents a year ago.

site_title: Boustead Singapore Q1 profit falls 58% on currency loss, weakness in key segments
summary: Boustead Singapore's Q1 net profit fell 58% to S$2.9 million due to currency losses and weakness in key segments, including oil & gas and industrial real estate. Revenue declined 21% to S$90.3 million. Energy-related engineering revenue dropped 29% and real estate solutions revenue fell 25%. The company expects to be profitable in FY18, but with similar performance to FY17. Its order book backlog stands at S$209 million, with S$137 million under real estate solutions.

site_title: Europe: Political tensions continue to weigh on stocks
summary: European stock markets declined on Thursday due to ongoing geopolitical tensions between the US and North Korea. London's FTSE 100 fell 0.7% and the Paris CAC 40 lost 0.2%. Despite this, some sectors such as mining and healthcare saw gains. The US stock market also reached fresh records, despite uncertainty over tariffs. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China urges US to act 'prudently' in aluminium foil dispute
summary: China urged the US to act "prudently" in its decision to impose anti-dumping duties on Chinese aluminium foil, warning that damaging economic relations could ensue. The Ministry of Commerce stated that the US ignored Chinese offers of cooperation, and the statement was more strongly worded than typical responses. The move is part of a larger trade dispute between the two countries.

site_title: Hiap Hoe back in the black with S$1.44m Q2 profit
summary: Hiap Hoe, a Singapore property group, reported a net profit of S$1.44 million for the second quarter, reversing a loss of S$3.1 million in the same period last year. Revenue decreased 3.1% to S$23.2 million, mainly due to lower property sales. The company declared an interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share and plans to grow its recurring income base and evaluate property development opportunities locally and overseas. The hotel sector is expected to remain competitive despite increased supply.

site_title: Kaspersky Lab to withdraw Microsoft antitrust complaints
summary: Kaspersky Lab has withdrawn antitrust complaints against Microsoft in Europe after the US tech giant agreed to change how it delivers security updates to Windows users. The company had alleged that Microsoft was unfairly harming third-party antivirus providers by removing their software when customers installed Windows 10. Microsoft agreed to work more closely with antivirus vendors and allow them to issue alerts and notifications to customers. The resolution comes after nearly a year of disputes between the two companies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 7-week low, won slides on anxiety over North Korea
summary: South Korean stocks hit a seven-week low, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing down 0.4% at 2,359.47 points, amid anxiety over escalating tensions between the US and North Korea. Foreign selling and investor concerns contributed to the market's decline. The won currency slid to its weakest level in a month.

site_title: Vietnam's sole refinery plans 1.9t-dong IPO on November 7
summary: Vietnam's Binh Son Refinery & Petrochemical Co plans to raise approximately 1.9 trillion dong (S$110 million) from its initial public offering (IPO) on November 7. The company, which operates Vietnam's only refinery, Dung Quat Oil Refinery, aims to sell 49% of the refinery to strategic investors next year. The refinery expects government approval for its IPO plan within three weeks and will conduct roadshows in Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, and Danang prior to the IPO.

site_title: Former HK commodities exchange chief charged with conspiracy to defraud regulator: court
summary: Former Hong Kong commodities exchange chief Barry Cheung, 59, has been charged with conspiracy to defraud the securities regulator and fraud. He is accused of concealing the true financial position of the Hong Kong Mercantile Exchange and causing false information to be supplied to the Securities and Futures Commission. Cheung, a former board member of AIA Group and RUSAL Plc, is also charged with intent to defraud a company out of HK$30 million. He was released on bail and will return to court on August 24.

site_title: Prudential's H1 results up on strong business growth in Asia
summary: British insurer Prudential reported a 5% rise in IFRS operating profit to £2.4 billion in the first half of 2017, driven by strong growth in Asia. Asia new business profit increased 18% to £1.1 billion, while UK life retail annual premium equivalent sales rose 22% to £721 million. The company declared its first interim dividend of 14.50p per share, up 12%. Group Solvency II surplus was estimated at £12.9 billion, representing earnings per share of 58.7p, more than double the previous year.

site_title: China offers rocket launchers, radar system to Malaysia: reports
summary: China is offering Malaysia advanced rocket launchers and a radar system to be based on the southern tip of the country, potentially raising security concerns for Singapore. The offer, made by a Chinese delegation, includes up to 12 units of the AR3 multiple-launch artillery rocket system, to be purchased with a 50-year loan period. The move comes as part of a US$13-billion rail project being built by China in Malaysia.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall marginally, eyes on North Korea tensions
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally lower, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.05% due to US-North Korea tensions. Despite this, Japanese cosmetics giant Shiseido surged on upbeat earnings. The benchmark index closed at 19,729.74, while the Topix index edged down 0.04%. Markets remain on edge, with investors closely watching the situation.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks close down
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks fell on August 10, 2017, with the Hang Seng Index down 1.13% and the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.42%. The decline was attributed to ongoing tensions over North Korea. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 0.69%. These losses followed a second day of spiraling tensions.

site_title: VW, Mercedes diesel rebates set to lure 1.3 million drivers
summary: Germany's auto manufacturers, including Volkswagen, Mercedes, and BMW, are offering rebates of up to 10,000 euros per car to encourage the trade-in of older, more polluting diesel models. The program aims to clean up diesel's image and reduce emissions, but it's unlikely to significantly reduce the number of diesel cars on German roads. An estimated 1.3 million drivers will accept the rebates, but over 5 million diesel autos with outdated emissions systems will remain on the road.

site_title: Australia vitamin 'breakthrough' to cut miscarriages, birth defects
summary: Australian scientists discovered a vitamin B3 supplement can prevent miscarriages and birth defects by treating a deficiency in the NAD molecule. A 12-year study found that taking vitamin B3 cured miscarriages and birth defects in mice embryos with similar NAD deficiencies. Researchers plan to develop a test to identify women at risk and ensure they have sufficient vitamin B3. The breakthrough has the potential to significantly reduce miscarriages and birth defects worldwide, with the Australian health minister calling it a "historic medical breakthrough".

site_title: UK industrial output beats expectations, but outlook murky
summary: UK industrial output unexpectedly rose 0.5% in June due to delayed oilfield maintenance, but overall growth remains sluggish at 0.3% in the second quarter. Car production dropped 3.6% and construction fell 0.1%, while the trade deficit widened to £12.7 billion. Despite mixed signals, economists expect Britain to maintain a quarterly pace of growth of 0.3% for the coming year, similar to the euro zone. The Bank of England expects stronger exports and business investment to lift growth in the second half of 2017.

site_title: Glencore slashes debt as it positions for M&A in commodities
summary: Glencore, the world's largest commodities trading house, has cut its debt to $13.9 billion by June, positioning itself for mergers and acquisitions. The company has a strong balance sheet, with a preferred leverage ratio of 1.07, and is looking to reward shareholders with higher dividends after a difficult period in 2015 and 2016. Glencore has already inked deals, including a $1.1 billion purchase of a stake in an Australian coal mine, and is expected to pursue acquisitions as metal prices recover.

site_title: Malaysia palm oil stocks hit highest in over a year
summary: Malaysia's palm oil inventories surged 16.8% to 1.78 million tonnes in July, the highest level in over a year, driven by stronger-than-forecast production of 1.83 million tonnes. This marked the first rise in three months and could drag on benchmark prices, which have risen over 7% this quarter. Production levels were the highest in almost two years, with exports edging up 1.3% to 1.40 million tonnes, despite softer demand.

site_title: Derwent raises rents forecast as central London property proves resilient
summary: Derwent London, a central London office developer, has raised its full-year rent forecast, citing a record level of new lettings in the first half. The company expects rental values to be between down 3% and up 2%, up from its previous estimate of flat to down 5%. Strong demand from technology, media, and telecoms tenants, and limited exposure to financial clients, has contributed to the increased confidence. The London office market has seen a slight decline in rents and rise in vacancy levels post-Brexit, but Derwent's results suggest resilience in the commercial real estate market.

site_title: Wanda Hotel shares soar on 7.05b yuan acquisition deal
summary: Wanda Hotel, a Hong Kong-listed arm of Dalian Wanda, announced a major restructuring plan, acquiring assets from firms controlled by chairman Wang Jianlin for 7.05 billion yuan. This includes Wanda Travel and Wanda Hotel Management, and comes as the group faces difficulty paying debts. The move is part of a wider shake-up of Wang's Dalian Wanda Group, now under scrutiny by Chinese authorities, and follows a series of high-profile foreign acquisitions. Wanda Hotel's stock rose over 20% following the announcement.

site_title: Amazon joins major Asian backers of Android creator's new phone
summary: Amazon has joined a $300 million funding round for Essential Products, a startup co-founded by Android creator Andy Rubin. The company, backed by Tencent Holdings and Foxconn Technology Group, aims to sell a new smartphone and a home device. Essential's first products include a high-end smartphone and an Amazon Echo-like gadget, featuring modern smartphone technologies and a customized user interface. The startup is valued at $900-1 billion and plans to deliver the Essential Phone next week.

site_title: Asia: Markets stabilise as Tillerson seeks to ease tensions
summary: Asian markets stabilised on Thursday as US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson sought to ease tensions with North Korea, calming traders' nerves after a dramatic sell-off sparked by escalating bellicosity. Tokyo, Shanghai, and Hong Kong markets largely halted their decline, while Seoul shares continued to slump. Analysts credited Tillerson's words with easing concerns over potential armed conflict. Meanwhile, US markets edged higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong walking tour aims to show gritty side of city
summary: A Hong Kong walking tour led by Alla Lau aims to show the city's gritty side, contrasting its luxurious image. Lau, 26, wants visitors to see the city's less affluent areas and understand the "other side" of the story. The tour took nearly a dozen tourists to explore the city's underbelly, highlighting its complexities.

site_title: Steel recovery lifts Thyssenkrupp as market awaits Tata tie-up
summary: Thyssenkrupp posted higher-than-expected third-quarter group orders and profits at its steel business in Europe, driven by a steel price recovery. The company reported a 14% rise in order intake to 10.7 billion euros and adjusted earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) of 620 million. CEO Heinrich Hiesinger expressed relief, stating that the company had achieved the minimum level necessary to cover the cost of capital. This positive performance comes ahead of a potential merger with Tata Steel, which is expected to boost the company's market position.

site_title: Facebook's Sandberg says sexual harassers should lose their jobs
summary: Facebook's COO Sheryl Sandberg advocates for a zero-tolerance policy for sexual harassment in the workplace, stating that those who engage in such behavior should lose their jobs. She believes this will deter others from committing similar acts. Sandberg, a prominent female executive, spoke out amid the growing number of harassment scandals in Silicon Valley, including Uber's recent ousting of co-founder Travis Kalanick.

site_title: Interra Resources secures 11-year deal from Myanma Oil & Gas Enterprise
summary: Interra Resources secured an 11-year deal with Myanma Oil & Gas Enterprise to expand oil production activities in Myanmar's Chauk and Yenangyaung fields. The deal allows Interra Resources to increase its petroleum production and reserves base, with plans to explore new reservoirs and accelerate development drilling. The contract covers 1,800 sq km and includes a 60% interest in the fields. This agreement paves the way for Interra Resources to implement advanced oil and gas techniques and technologies, supporting Myanmar's economic development.

site_title: Malaysia June factory output up 4% y-o-y, above forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production in June rose 4% year-over-year, beating the forecasted 3% annual rise. The growth was driven by the manufacturing, mining, and electricity sectors. However, exports grew only 10% year-over-year, below expectations, due to a decline in manufactured goods shipments. This slower-than-expected export growth may impact the country's economic growth.

site_title: Wilmar swings into the black in Q2 with US$60.2m profit
summary: Wilmar International reported a net profit of US$60.2 million for the second quarter, reversing a net loss of US$220.1 million from the previous year. Revenue rose 13.2% to US$10.6 billion, driven by higher sales volume and stronger commodity prices. The company's core net profit was US$37.3 million. Wilmar's first-half net profit jumped to US$422 million, with a 15% increase in revenue to US$21.2 billion. The board has proposed an interim tax-exempt dividend of S$0.03 per share, a 20% increase from the previous year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won extend losses on North Korea jitters
summary: South Korean stocks fell to a seven-week low on Thursday, extending losses due to North Korea tensions. The won dropped 0.5% and the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 1.2% to 2,339.97 points. Foreign investors reduced their positions, selling 176.7 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while domestic institutions purchased 241 billion won worth of stocks. The won hovered at a four-week low, 1,141.5 against the US dollar.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.47 points to 1776.94. The market saw 71.26 million lots traded worth RM31.89 million, with 108 gainers outnumbering 74 losers.

site_title: Magnitude 4.9 quake hits Tokyo area, no tsunami warning
summary: A magnitude 4.9 earthquake hit the Tokyo area on August 10, 2017, with its center located in northwestern Chiba prefecture. No tsunami warning was issued by Japan's Meteorological Agency. Japan is a seismically active area, accounting for 20% of the world's earthquakes of magnitude six or greater.

images.alt_text: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.9 hit the Tokyo area on Thursday but no tsunami warning was issued, Japan's Meteorological Agency said.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on August 10, 2017, as US-North Korea tensions eased, causing the yen's appreciation against the US dollar to peak out. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.18%, and the Topix index increased 0.07%.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.65% to 3,339.69 on Thursday, driven by a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The benchmark index was largely unaffected by rising tensions between North Korea and the US, with Singtel and other stocks also showing resilience. About 290 million shares worth S$345 million changed hands, with 128 gainers to 101 losers, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Hong Kong's crowded currency trade enters perilous territory
summary: The Hong Kong dollar's carry trade, which has generated steady returns for seven months, suffered a setback as the currency strengthened against the US dollar, its largest gain since February 2016. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) triggered the spike by announcing plans to sell additional debt instruments, sparking speculation that the move aimed to drain cash and guide local interest rates higher. The move may have further volatility in the market, with some analysts predicting faster increases in Hong Kong dollar rates in the coming weeks.

site_title: China examines official spending on luxury alcohol amid rebound
summary: China's anti-corruption campaign is examining official spending on luxury alcohol, with a focus on identifying illicit spending from January to August. The move comes as premium liquor sales are experiencing a resurgence, driven by strong demand from family and business gatherings. Despite a crackdown in 2012, luxury liquor sales have seen a significant increase, with Kweichow Moutai Co reporting a 28% profit climb.
