The government's campaign may not significantly impact the industry, as most luxury brands are seeing growth in the mass market, and the economy is showing signs of strength.

site_title: Rents of private home in Singapore up 0.2% in July: SRX Property
summary: Rentals of private homes in Singapore rose 0.2% in July, with rental volumes increasing 11.8% to 4,834 units. This follows a 0.6% increase in June. However, islandwide rents are still down 2.7% from last year, with all regions experiencing declines. HDB rents slipped 0.1% in July, with an estimated 1,835 flats rented, a 6.7% increase from June.

images.alt_text: Rents of private non-landed homes in Singapore rose 0.2 per cent in July compared to June, while rental volumes rose by 11.8 per cent from a month ago to 4,834 units, going by the flash estimates of SRX Property.

site_title: Facebook makes new bid for TV viewers with expanded video
summary: Facebook expands its video offerings with a redesigned product called "Watch", initially available to a limited group in the US on its mobile app, website, and TV apps. The platform features original and well-produced videos from creators such as Vox Media, BuzzFeed, and National Geographic, including sports, parenting, and safari shows. The move aims to compete with traditional TV networks and newer producers like Netflix and YouTube, with the goal of becoming a dedicated video destination for users.

site_title: Toshiba secures auditor sign-off, likely avoiding immediate delisting
summary: Toshiba Corp secured its auditor's sign-off on its financial results, avoiding immediate delisting. PriceWaterhouseCoopers Aarata LLC gave a "qualified opinion" on Toshiba's results, vouching for book-keeping despite minor problems. However, PwC will give an "adverse opinion" on Toshiba's internal controls in an annual report. Toshiba's chips business sale talks have stalled, leaving its future uncertain. The company has struggled to regain shareholder trust since a 2015 accounting scandal.

site_title: Japan PM should focus on regulatory reforms, say economists
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe should prioritize regulatory reforms to boost the economy, according to economists. The country's economy is forecast to expand 1.4% this fiscal year and 1.1% next, with core inflation expected to average 0.6% this year and 0.8% next. A majority of analysts polled said Abe should proceed swiftly with deregulation to encourage liquidity in the labor market and raise wages. However, only a few predicted Abe would focus on regulatory reforms, and the Bank of Japan is likely to unwind its ultra-easy monetary policy in late 2018.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe ought to prioritise regulatory reforms, according to economists in a monthly Reuters poll whose forecasts show they remain pessimistic on prospects for the pace of inflation to pick up in coming years.

site_title: Smugglers push migrants into sea off Yemen, killing 29
summary: Smugglers off Yemen's coast killed 29 Somali and Ethiopian migrants, pushing over 120 into rough seas, the International Organization for Migration reported. The migrants were deliberately pushed into the water to avoid authorities, with 22 still missing. Survivors found shallow graves of the victims on a beach in Shabwa province.

images.alt_text: Smugglers forced more than 120 Somali and Ethiopian migrants into rough seas off Yemen on Wednesday, leaving 29 dead and 22 missing, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) said.

site_title: US Q2 earnings boom may not last much longer
summary: US corporate profits surged in Q2, with S&P 500 companies averaging a 10% rise, driven by technology, banking, and energy sectors. However, analysts warn that future gains may be challenged by sluggish economic growth and insufficient reforms in Washington. This boom may not last, with more difficult year-on-year comparisons expected in the coming quarters, particularly for energy earnings.

site_title: Next generation battery seen powering space projects, cars
summary: Researchers at Hitachi Zosen Corp in Japan are developing a safer generation of solid-state lithium-ion batteries that can withstand extreme temperatures, including those found in outer space. The company has shipped samples to potential customers in the aerospace and automobile industries and plans to commercialize small-size batteries by 2020. While solid-state batteries hold promise for better safety and performance, they currently have low power characteristics and require further development. Hitachi Zosen aims to reduce costs while maintaining its lead in quality, with the goal of making solid-state batteries a viable option for industries such as electric vehicles and renewable energy.

site_title: Gold hovers near two-month highs on North Korea tensions
summary: Gold prices held steady near two-month highs due to safe-haven demand triggered by rising tensions on the Korean peninsula. North Korea dismissed US President Donald Trump's warning of "fire and fury" as "nonsense", and outlined plans for a missile strike near Guam. Geopolitical risk boosted demand for gold, with spot gold easing 0.1% to $1,276.40 per ounce and US gold futures rising 0.2% to $1,281.90 per ounce. Analysts expect gold prices to continue moving higher, potentially crossing the $1,300 per ounce mark in the short term.

site_title: MAS, CAD warn public of potential risks of digital tokens and related investment schemes
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) have warned the public of potential risks associated with digital tokens and related investment schemes. These schemes often involve initial coin offerings (ICOs) and may be operated by unregulated entities, exposing consumers to heightened risks of fraud, money laundering, and terrorist financing. Consumers are advised to verify the authenticity of projects and business before investing, as recovery of invested monies may be subject to foreign laws and regulations.

site_title: Sega embraces rogue fan programmers with retro Sonic game sequel
summary: Sega is embracing fan programmers by giving them jobs to create a retro Sonic game sequel, Sonic Mania, set for release on August 15. Unlike Nintendo, Sega is collaborating with enthusiasts to revitalize the Sonic franchise, which could attract new fans and breathe life into classic franchises. This move is seen as a risk, but Sega is betting it will pay off and set the company apart from Nintendo, which has taken legal action against fan games. The partnership could lead to increased fan engagement and a boost in Sega's popularity.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Centurion, mm2 Asia, Manulife US Reit
summary: Centurion Corporation plans to acquire a 160-unit US student accommodation asset for $70 million. mm2 Asia Ltd is still in discussions with Village Cinemas Australia to acquire a 50% stake in Golden Village cinema business in Singapore. Manulife US Reit posted better-than-expected Q2 results, exceeding forecasts with a 7.5% increase in DPU.

site_title: Australia shares edge up as materials gain; NZ flat
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index edged up 11.54 points, or 0.2%, to 5,777.2, driven by robust commodity prices and gains in material stocks like Newcrest Mining and BHP Billiton. Financial stocks, including the "Big Four" banks, rose 0.6-0.9% after a soft start. Shares of Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd jumped 5.7% after reporting a smaller-than-expected annual loss. In contrast, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index remained flat, despite a record high for dairy firm a2 Milk Company.

site_title: NZ dollar off 3-week lows as RBNZ wrong-foots doves, Aussie muted
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) surprised markets by not lowering interest rates, instead keeping them at a record low 1.75%, contrary to expectations from doves. The New Zealand dollar briefly rose to a high of US$0.7373, while the Australian dollar ticked higher to US$0.7896. The RBNZ projected steady course on rates until 2020 and expects headline inflation to struggle back into the midpoint of its 1-3% target band. The decision was seen as a green light for further currency appreciation.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened lower on Thursday, following a sell-off in the US and Europe due to escalating geopolitical tensions. The Hang Seng Index declined 0.08%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also eased. Despite this, Asia's stocks have been on a 5-day rally, with Singapore's STI up 0.4% on Thursday. The rally is attributed to investors' positive outlook, despite uncertainty over US trade policies and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Swiss franc, yen rise as North Korea tensions brew
summary: The Swiss franc and yen rose against the euro and US dollar on Wednesday, August 9, 2017, due to increased tensions between the US and North Korea. The Swiss franc jumped 1.1% against the euro, its largest single-day gain since 2015, while the yen fell 0.26% against the US dollar. Weaker US Treasury yields and investors seeking safe-haven assets contributed to the currency fluctuations.

site_title: IFA and independent directors advise Cityneon shareholders to reject offer
summary: Independent directors of Cityneon Holdings Limited advised shareholders to reject the mandatory unconditional cash offer from Lucrum 1 Investment, citing "unfair and unreasonable" financial terms. The offer price of 90 Singapore cents per share is lower than the current market price of 94 cents. The directors recommended shareholders sell their shares in the open market for a higher price, if desired. Lucrum 1 Investment, a special purpose vehicle, initiated the mandatory takeover after acquiring a 52.51% stake in Cityneon.

site_title: Virgin Australia says business uptick brightens outlook
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd reported a smaller annual net loss of A$185.8 million, compared to a net loss of A$224.7 million last year, due to cost-cutting measures. The airline's CEO, John Borghetti, attributed the improvement to a surge in business confidence and corporate traffic, which drove a return in business travel. Virgin shares rose 5.7% to an eight-week high, while the broader market gained 0.2%. The airline is ahead of schedule on its cost-cutting program and has increased its targeted savings by A$50 million to A$350 million per year.

site_title: Singapore's oldest businesses
summary: Singapore's oldest businesses remain relevant despite the changing market landscape. A recent article highlights the strategies employed by these firms to stay afloat. Companies such as Creative Technology and NTT DC Reit are adapting to the market by focusing on their core strengths. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank has announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing outgoing CEO Thian Tong. The bank aims to leverage Long's experience as a former DBS veteran to drive growth and stability.

site_title: Intel set to roll out 100 self-driving cars
summary: Intel announces plans to roll out a fleet of 100 self-driving cars for testing in Europe, Israel, and the US, following its purchase of Israeli autonomous technology firm Mobileye for $15 billion. The vehicles, expected to be deployed later this year, will feature various types and makes of vehicles and capitalize on Mobileye's expertise in computer vision, mapping, and sensing. Intel aims to accelerate the development of autonomous vehicle technology, enabling automakers to deliver driverless cars faster while reducing costs, with the goal of deploying autonomous vehicle technology anywhere.

site_title: AsiaPhos says no casualty at its mines and facilities from Sichuan quake
summary: AsiaPhos Limited reported no casualties or disruptions to its operations at its mines and facilities in Sichuan, China, following the 7.0 magnitude earthquake in Jiuzhaigou County on Tuesday. The epicentre was 300 km away, and the company will continue to monitor the situation, providing updates as necessary.

site_title: SEC research finds no merit in claim rules imperil trading
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has released a report dismissing claims that post-crisis regulations have made markets more susceptible to shocks. The report, which analyzed market dynamics, found no decline in total issuance of securities following the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act. The study suggests that market fluctuations were not caused by stricter rules, but rather by other factors.

site_title: Virgin Australia posts narrower FY net loss
summary: Virgin Australia reported a smaller full-year net loss of A$185.8 million, down from A$224.7 million in the previous year, as it completed the first year of a three-year cost-cutting programme. The airline attributed the improvement to its cost-cutting efforts and increased targeted savings to A$350 million per year. CEO John Borghetti stated the airline is ahead of schedule and aims to continue its cost-cutting programme.

images.alt_text: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd on Thursday reported a smaller full-year net loss as the airline completed the first year of a three-year cost-cutting programme.

site_title: Manulife eyes US$2b more of Asian office assets
summary: Manulife Real Estate aims to invest over US$2 billion in office assets in Asia, doubling its direct real estate holdings in the region to US$4.4 billion. The Canadian insurer's global head of asset management, Ted Willcocks, said the investment will focus on prime CBD offices in key cities such as Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Singapore. The move comes as Asia's insurance sales and wealth management grow, while US rental growth slows. Manulife will deploy its capital in Asia within the next 24 months, with a focus on alternative assets to back its long-term liabilities.

site_title: UK house price growth weakest in over 4 years: RICS
summary: UK house prices rose at their slowest rate in over four years in July, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reporting a 'plus one' balance, down from 'plus seven' in June. Sales slowed due to a limited supply of property and continued political uncertainty, with over two-thirds of homes valued over £1 million failing to reach their asking price. The outlook for prices over the next 12 months is also the weakest since the EU vote, with RICS chief economist Simon Rubinsohn stating that the market is unlikely to become more affordable anytime soon.

images.alt_text: British house prices rose at their slowest rate in over four years last month, while the number of sales slowed due to a limited supply of property and continued political uncertainty, a property industry body said on Thursday.

site_title: mm2 Asia still in talks to buy Golden Village
summary: mm2 Asia Ltd is still in talks to buy a 50% stake in Golden Village cinema business in Singapore after the initial agreement lapsed due to Golden Screen's disapproval. The company received a full refund of S$8 million deposit from Village Cinemas Australia. Despite the setback, mm2 Asia remains committed to its cinema expansion plans and is pursuing other opportunities. Executive chairman Melvin Ang stated that the company's cinema growth strategy is not dependent on this one acquisition. The discussions are ongoing, but no further updates have been provided.

images.alt_text: mm2 Asia Ltd said it is still in discussions with Village Cinemas Australia on possible options to proceed with the purchase of a 50 per cent interest in Golden Village cinema business in Singapore.

site_title: France passes law to clean up politics after fake job scandals
summary: France's parliament has passed a law to clean up politics, with 412 lawmakers backing the bill, which includes measures to ban lawmakers and ministers from employing family members and scrapping cash handouts for lawmakers to spend on areas and NGOs. The law comes after a series of scandals, including allegations of misuse of public funds by President Emmanuel Macron's opponents and his own government. The move aims to restore public trust in politicians and follows a string of controversies since Macron took office in May, including plummeting approval ratings and public spats with the head of the French armed forces.

site_title: US, North Korea have few channels by which to resolve crises
summary: US and North Korea lack formal channels to resolve crises, unlike Washington and Moscow, which have established hotlines, satellites, and over-flights to prevent conflicts. Experts warn that an accident or miscommunication could escalate into full-scale war, despite neither side seeking conflict. The US and North Korea maintain limited communication through the United Nations, embassies in Beijing, and military meetings, but these channels are not reliable or secure. The US President Donald Trump's use of Twitter to deliver policy announcements has raised concerns, highlighting the need for more formal communication mechanisms.

site_title: Impossible Burger's 'secret sauce' highlights challenges of food tech
summary: The Impossible Burger's secret sauce, soy leghemoglobin, has raised regulatory questions due to its genetically engineered production. This ingredient, found in soybean roots, is a key selling point of the plant-based burger patty, which has attracted $250 million in investment. The US FDA has not approved soy leghemoglobin for human consumption, sparking concerns over its safety. Impossible Foods faces challenges in meeting FDA regulations, which may impact the company's growth and the burger's widespread adoption.

site_title: US: S&P closes barely lower despite North Korea tensions
summary: US stocks closed slightly lower on Wednesday despite North Korea tensions, with investors focusing on the global economy and earnings. Despite President Trump's "fire and fury" warning, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.17% to 22,048.7, while the S&P 500 lost 0.04% to 2,474.02. Defensive stocks like Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman rose, and the CBOE Volatility Index ended at a session low. Investors appeared to be brushing off geopolitical concerns, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite both reaching fresh records.

site_title: North Korea will develop Guam strike plan by mid-August: KCNA
summary: North Korea plans to develop a strike plan by mid-August to launch four intermediate-range missiles at US territory Guam, according to state media KCNA. The plan aims to interdict enemy forces on Guam and signal a warning to the US. The move comes after US President Donald Trump warned North Korea of "fire and fury" if it threatened the US. North Korea's KCNA described Trump's threat as "nonsense," saying sound dialogue is not possible with him, and that only force can work on him.

images.alt_text: North Korea will develop a plan by mid-August to launch four intermediate range missiles at the US territory of Guam before presenting it to leader Kim Jong Un who will make a decision on whether to proceed, the North's state media said on Thursday.

site_title: Nearly 60,000 evacuated after China quake kills 19
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck Sichuan province in China, killing at least 19 people and injuring 263. Nearly 60,000 people were evacuated, mostly tourists stranded at a national park, with over 1,000 aftershocks detected. Local homes suffered varying degrees of damage, and rescue efforts are ongoing. The quake, which occurred at a shallow depth, evoked memories of a 2008 massive earthquake in the same region, leaving 87,000 dead or missing.

site_title: US housing market's new dominant force: Baby boomers who won't sell
summary: The US housing market is experiencing a shortage of affordable homes due to baby boomers holding onto their properties, contributing to a 53% share of owner-occupied houses among those 55 and older. Millennials like Jake Yanoviak are struggling to find homes, with 11% of 18- to 34-year-olds owning a home. Public policy, including property-tax exemptions and zoning rules, limits the supply of affordable housing. To address the issue, real estate agents and brokers are using unconventional tactics, such as offering incentives and personal connections, to persuade seniors to sell their homes.

site_title: Evans sees Sept Fed balance-sheet move, tech sapping prices
summary: Chicago Fed President Charles Evans suggests it's "reasonable" to announce the start of a US$4.5 trillion balance sheet reduction in September, despite concerns about inflation. He notes that technological disruptions, such as lower wireless services prices, have dampened price pressures. Evans also warns that disappointing inflation data may delay interest-rate increases, citing a one-in-three chance of another rate hike this year. The economy is doing well, but inflation may struggle to reach 2%, leading Evans to caution that policy moves may be "accommodative" for now.

site_title: Centurion to buy 160-unit student housing in the US for US$70m
summary: Centurion Corporation announced plans to acquire College & Crown, a 160-unit student accommodation asset near Yale University in the US, for US$70 million. This follows its previous acquisition of a US portfolio of 1,936 beds for US$136 million. The acquisition is expected to be completed by end-September and will be earnings accretive to the group's results. Centurion will own up to 30% of the combined portfolio, with the balance held by third-party investors, and will manage the operations through a joint venture with a local partner.

site_title: Twenty-First Century Fox revenue misses, profit tops estimates
summary: Twenty-First Century Fox Inc reported quarterly profit of 26 cents per share, beating estimates, but revenue fell 11.5% to $1.80 billion due to weak movie studio performance. The company's cable division saw a 10.4% revenue increase, while executives expressed optimism about growth from streaming services and a potential direct-to-consumer online streaming service. Fox is seeking regulatory approval for its $14.5 billion bid to buy Sky Plc, which faces roadblocks, including concerns over media influence.

site_title: Swiss franc up the most against euro since 2015
summary: The Swiss franc experienced its largest single-day rise against the euro since 2015, jumping 1.4% to 1.1272 francs per euro. This surge followed heightened geopolitical risks, including North Korea's threat to the US Pacific territory of Guam, prompting a risk-off sentiment in markets. The franc's strength may have room to run, but some analysts warned that further gains could trigger renewed risk of currency intervention by the Swiss central bank. The franc also rose against the dollar, reversing a two-week losing streak.

site_title: Taylor Swift shaken and humiliated by groping, mom tells trial
summary: Taylor Swift's mother, Andrea Swift, testified in a US jury trial that her 27-year-old daughter was "shattered" after a radio host, David Mueller, groped her by the buttocks during a 2013 concert in Denver. Andrea Swift recalled the moment they returned to the dressing room, where Taylor expressed her distress. Swift countersued Mueller, alleging the incident cost her a job. Mueller claims the accusations are false and cost him his job. The trial aims to determine the validity of Swift's allegations and the extent of Mueller's wrongdoing.

site_title: Oil inches higher after data points to declining US inventories
summary: US oil prices rose 1% on Wednesday after a report showed a 6.5 million barrel decline in crude inventories, the largest drop since 1982. Refineries processed a record 17.6 million barrels, surpassing previous records. Brent crude gained 1.1% to $52.70, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.8% to $49.56. The data suggests a decline in global supply, potentially helping to wipe out a three-year glut, although Opec's output cuts have been complicated by Libya and Nigeria's increased production.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were about one per cent higher on Wednesday after a report showed US refineries processed record amounts of crude in the latest week, eating into inventories, although a surprise jump in gasoline stockpiles limited price gains.

site_title: Damore went from intern to pariah in Google tenure ended by memo
summary: Google engineer James Damore was fired for his 3,300-word memo arguing that conservative viewpoints are suppressed at Google and that biological differences explain why more men work in software engineering. The memo was met with widespread criticism from Google employees and right-wing groups, but Damore has gained support from some, including WikiLeaks and a far-right social network. Damore has filed a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board and is exploring legal remedies. Google CEO Sundar Pichai has vowed to address the issue in a company-wide meeting on Thursday.

site_title: Small Japan hedge funds beat the Topix in returns
summary: Japanese small-cap hedge funds have outperformed the Topix Index, with Simplex Asset Management's Japan Lower Market Strategy Fund returning 29% in the first six months of the year. Eschewing big-name companies has helped funds like Sparx Group Co's Value Impact Fund and Strategic Capital Inc's activist fund gain 19% and 15%, respectively. The gains are attributed to smaller companies' immunity to macro and geopolitical risks, and their faster earnings growth. Japanese small-cap stocks have surged 22%, 23%, and 19% this year, outperforming the broader Topix Index.

site_title: Tennis: Williams battles into Toronto last 16, Muguruza through
summary: Venus Williams, the 37-year-old American tennis player, overcame 21-year-old Czech Katerina Siniakova to reach the last 16 of the WTA Toronto tournament with a 7-5, 7-5 victory. Williams, a ninth seed, converted only four of 13 break points, while Siniakova saved eight consecutive break points. Williams will face Elina Svitolina in the next round. Meanwhile, Garbine Muguruza advanced with a 7-5, 6-2 win over Kirsten Flipkens, while Karolína Pliskova also eased past Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova.

images.alt_text: Venus Williams was forced to draw on all of her vast experience before overcoming Czech youngster Katerina Siniakova to reach the last 16 of the WTA Toronto hardcourt tournament on Wednesday.

site_title: Fractures in Silicon Valley's political culture widen
summary: Google fires engineer James Damore for writing memo challenging the company's diversity efforts, sparking debate over the tech industry's handling of dissenting opinions. The move has widened fractures in Silicon Valley's political culture, with some accusing the company of silencing free speech and others praising Google's stance on diversity. The incident has echoes of past episodes, including the pressure on Facebook board member Peter Thiel for supporting Donald Trump and the departure of Oculus founder Palmer Luckey due to his pro-Trump views. The tech industry's politics have long been left-leaning, but recent events have raised concerns about intolerance of ideological diversity.

site_title: GIC increases stake in Rothesay Life
summary: GIC has increased its stake in Rothesay Life, a UK pensions provider, after Goldman Sachs sold its 32.7% stake to other shareholders, including GIC and private equity giant Blackstone. The deal valued Rothesay Life at £2 billion (S$3.54 billion) and is expected to close in the final quarter of the year. GIC and Blackstone will hold equal largest stakes, while Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company will increase its stake substantially. Rothesay Life has strong growth prospects, driven by increasing demand for annuity risk transfer solutions, according to GIC's chief investment officer.

site_title: Skills matter, whether it's sports or the workforce
summary: Singapore is shifting its focus from solely academic qualifications to lifelong learning and skill development. The SkillsFuture initiative encourages people to continue learning and relearning after school, pursue their passions, and develop their full potential. This approach recognizes that degrees can become obsolete and that the need to continue learning and honing skills applies to everyone. Employers are also encouraged to adopt technology and invest in staff training, with new "skills frameworks" launched to help businesses and job-seekers navigate career pathways and training needs.

site_title: Americans are dying younger, saving corporations billions
summary: The US life expectancy has stalled, with Americans dying younger, potentially saving companies billions in pension obligations. A slowdown in mortality improvements, observed since 2010, has led to revised estimates for companies like Verizon and General Motors, reducing their retirement obligations by up to $9.7 billion. The shift affects not only corporate pensions but also Social Security, with the program's financial outlook improving slightly. Experts attribute the decline to factors such as deaths of despair, rising obesity and smoking rates, and a lack of medical breakthroughs.

images.alt_text: There's no simple answer for why longevity gains are slowing. For years, economists and public health experts have been trying to ascertain what's behind America's troubling death trends.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall on Paris incident, North Korea worries
summary: European shares fell 0.7% on Wednesday due to geopolitical tensions, with North Korea's threat to attack Guam sparking global market volatility. France's CAC 40 dropped 1.4% after a car attack on soldiers in Paris, while Germany's DAX fell 1.1%. Gold miners Randgold Resources and Fresnillo rose, while banks suffered losses. Results season has been strong, with 76% of Euro zone companies beating earnings forecasts, but volatility is expected to increase in the future.

images.alt_text: European shares fell back on Wednesday as geopolitical tensions sent all major benchmarks into negative territory, accompanied by a slight uptick in volatility in what is typically a quiet period of summer trading for the market.

site_title: China's 'Silk Road' initiative lends urgency to India's regional ambitions
summary: India is investing heavily in road and rail links on its north-east borders to access markets in Thailand and beyond, as part of its "Act East" policy. The country aims to build a 1,360km highway connecting north-eastern India with markets in Thailand and beyond, with the help of the Asian Development Bank. This move comes as China pushes ahead with its own "One Belt, One Road" infrastructure initiative, raising concerns among strategic rivals India, Russia, the US, and Japan. India's investment in border infrastructure is seen as a bid to counter China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: Indonesia's retailers seek govt help to kickstart lacklustre sales
summary: Indonesian retailers are urging the government to speed up infrastructure projects to boost purchasing power and kickstart sluggish sales. Despite a 5.01% Q2 growth rate, private consumption remained weak, and government spending contracted. Retail sales rose 6.3% in June but are expected to decline 3% in July, according to a Bank Indonesia survey. Retailers are calling for the government to accelerate infrastructure projects or attract investment in labor-intensive industries to create jobs and increase purchasing power.

site_title: Westchester County in US bustling with developments
summary: Westchester County cities, including Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, and Yonkers, are experiencing a surge in development amid a housing crunch in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Local leaders have implemented aggressive growth policies, streamlining building permits and rezoning areas to encourage taller construction. New projects include residential rentals, breweries, and restaurants, with rents in Mount Vernon being about half of those in lower Manhattan. The area's proximity to Grand Central Terminal and Metro-North commuter railroad is seen as a major draw.

site_title: Marriott poised for relief in NYC with construction surge easing
summary: Marriott International Inc is expected to see relief in the New York hotel market as the supply surge that has kept room rates from rising for two and a half years begins to ease. The construction boom has led to a 1.8% decline in room rates in the first half of the year, according to STR. With supply growth forecast at 3.7% this year and 3.3% next year, Marriott expects positive performance in the next 18 months. The company's second-quarter revenue after costs fell to $102 million, partly due to lower results in New York, but adjusted earnings per diluted share rose 35%.

site_title: Aspial jewellery business weak, overseas property on track
summary: Aspial Corporation reported a first-half loss of S$205,000, despite narrowing from a S$3.3 million loss last year. Revenue declined 10% to S$245.5 million, primarily due to a 10% drop in jewellery sales. However, the company's real estate arm made progress in overseas property sales and construction, and its pawnbroking arm, Maxi-Cash, posted a flat pre-tax profit. Aspial expects substantial profits from its development projects in Singapore and Australia, with estimated revenue of over S$1.9 billion.

site_title: Normanton Park to be put up for en bloc sale at a minimum S$800m
summary: Normanton Park condominium, with 488 units, is set to be launched for collective sale on August 22 at a minimum price of S$800 million after over 80% of owners approved the collective sales agreement. The estimated premium for intensification and lease top-up is S$225.3 million and S$220.64 million, respectively. Owners can expect a gross profit of between S$1.62 million and S$1.8 million. This is considered a major feat, with the requisite approval obtained in just 11 days, and is seen as a record for a project of this scale.

site_title: With Mobileye deal, Intel enters the driverless car race
summary: Intel has acquired Mobileye, an Israeli tech firm, for $15.3 billion, gaining credibility in the autonomous vehicle market. The deal allows Intel to reshape the competitive landscape with its combined capabilities in cameras, sensors, software, and mapping. Mobileye will remain based in Israel, and its co-founder Amnon Shashua will lead Intel's autonomous-vehicle efforts. The acquisition puts Intel in the conversation and guarantees its participation in the development of self-driving cars. Intel aims to demonstrate its capabilities by building a fleet of 100 self-driving test vehicles and working on a new self-driving system combining Intel chips and Mobileye's technology.

site_title: China pledges to take on the 'original sin' of its financial system
summary: China's central government has pledged to tackle the country's "original sin" of financial leverage, which has grown over the past decade due to rapid expansion in household and corporate wealth seeking higher returns. The leverage problem is characterized by unprecedented stimulus since 2008, with implicit backing from the central government allowing borrowers to take on debt freely. To address the issue, regulators have implemented measures such as stricter guidelines on financial products, higher interest rates, and stricter regulations on shadow banking. Despite efforts, deleveraging has yet to begin, and the country's economy remains vulnerable to financial bubbles and instability.

site_title: SNC targets Canadian projects as Trudeau's plan edges out Trump's
summary: Canada's largest builder, SNC-Lavalin, is focusing on domestic projects, including light-rail lines and rapid transit systems, as US President Donald Trump's infrastructure spending plan is still to be confirmed. SNC chief executive officer Neil Bruce says the Canadian infrastructure market is more attractive, with a C$120 billion investment plan over 12 years. The company is also expanding its international footprint through its purchase of UK's WS Atkins Plc, with cost savings expected to reach C$120 million by the end of next year.

site_title: Toshiba shares jump as delisting fears ease
summary: Toshiba shares jumped over 9% on Wednesday after expectations that the company will meet a deadline to submit long-delayed earnings to financial regulators. The shares rose 3.2% to close at 290 yen, easing fears that the conglomerate's stock would be delisted from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. A qualified approval from auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers Aarata has boosted investor confidence, but analysts warn that the relief is temporary and Toshiba still faces major challenges, including massive losses at its US nuclear unit and a planned sale of its memory chip business.

site_title: Rallying to #OneNationTogether
summary: The NDP 2017 Show in Singapore showcased unity and determination among citizens, highlighting the importance of coming together as a nation. The event featured six acts addressing various issues, celebrating the country's diversity and looking ahead to the future. This event aligns with the NDP theme, #OneNationTogether, emphasizing the strength of Singaporean families and friends.

site_title: Singapore celebrates unity in diversity
summary: Singapore celebrates its National Day Parade, uniting citizens of various ethnic groups on the Marina Bay Floating Platform. The event featured performances showcasing the country's past, present, and future. The celebration highlights Singapore's unity in diversity, bringing together the young and old, Chinese, Malays, and Indians. The parade is a display of solidarity and national pride, emphasizing the country's commitment to its multicultural identity.

site_title: How S'pore's oldest firms stay relevant
summary: Singapore's oldest firms, such as Greatearth, Boustead, and Eu Yan Sang, have survived for over a century by adapting to changing market conditions and prioritizing merit-based succession planning. Family-run businesses, in particular, face the challenge of balancing lineage with meritocracy, with some opting to welcome outsiders into management roles. These firms recognize the importance of retaining talent and staying relevant, with some reinventing themselves to focus on specialized areas and modernizing their products to appeal to changing consumer trends.

site_title: Fox News declines to settle lawsuits for US$60m
summary: Fox News parent company, 21st Century Fox, has declined to settle lawsuits worth over $60 million filed by a lawyer on behalf of more than 20 current and former employees alleging gender and racial-discrimination. The case includes a defamation lawsuit against Fox News and 21st Century Fox over an article about Seth Rich, and a letter to the UK authority reviewing the company's $15 billion bid for Sky, alleging lack of transparency and dissemination of fake news. The company has denied the claims and the mediation failed to reach a resolution.

site_title: Catalans think twice about risks of rupture as jobs return
summary: Catalan separatists, led by Joan Boix, are reconsidering their push for independence from Spain as jobs return to the region. Hardliners are planning a final push, including a rogue tax agency or general strike, but Boix is hesitant due to business concerns. The Catalan government is preparing for a possible vote on independence, but the region's economic situation and potential consequences are weighing on the decision.

site_title: An extreme bike race across Russia struggles to keep women in the pack
summary: The Red Bull Trans-Siberian Extreme, the world's longest bicycle road race, saw only two women participate in its third year, with both dropping out of the 14-stage, 5,700-mile competition from Moscow to Vladivostok. The two female riders, Shangrila G Rendon and Gervais Dubina, struggled with the grueling terrain, lack of sleep, and limited recovery time, ultimately failing to complete half the stages. Organizers are now considering ways to attract more women to the event, including teaming up with women in two-person teams, to keep them in the pack longer.

site_title: Wealth tax under attack as richest Scandinavians prepare to vote
summary: Norway's richest individuals are preparing to vote on a wealth tax, which could be raised by five billion kroner (S$830 million) over four years. The country's largest business group has expressed concerns that the tax could harm job creation, citing a survey showing nearly 60% of business owners would increase employment if the tax were removed. The outcome of the vote could impact the Labor Party's election campaign and the country's economic policies.

site_title: Top oil buyers go on light crude diet to satisfy diesel craving
summary: Top oil buyers in Asia, including South Korea's SK Innovation, are shifting their focus to light crude due to high profits from making diesel, with demand surging in emerging economies like India and China. The shift is driven by cleaner diesel imports and increased construction and industrial consumption in China, leading to a 57% increase in profits from turning Dubai crude into diesel. As a result, South Korean refiners are scouring countries for light crude, with the US and Mexico set to supply more.

site_title: Novo Nordisk raises 2017 forecasts despite continued US price pressure
summary: Novo Nordisk, a leading diabetes drug manufacturer, reported a better-than-expected profit in 2017 despite US price pressure. The company attributed its improved forecast to new diabetes and obesity drugs. However, it warned that US sale prices would remain under pressure. This marks a reversal of Novo Nordisk's previous forecast cuts in 2016, which led to a 40% decline in its shares last year.

site_title: Investors parking their money in ETFs while waiting for more attractive deals
summary: Institutional investors, including pension plans and foundations, are increasingly turning to exchange-traded funds (ETFs) to park money earmarked for private funds due to the record amount of cash held by private equity firms. BlackRock and State Street report a surge in ETF usage as investors seek to generate extra returns on cash. The amount of dry powder, or money raised but not yet invested, in private equity is expected to hit $1 trillion by year-end, pushing out the average investment time to three years. ETFs offer instant and diversified exposure, allowing for quick liquidation to meet obligations.

site_title: A tweak, not a teardown, for that just-right house
summary: A couple, Daniela and Chris Sicuranza, opted to renovate and expand their 1955 brick ranch house in Arlington, Virginia, rather than demolishing it and building a new super home. The couple added a 745-square-foot rear addition, which includes a dining room, master bedroom, and screened porch, blending seamlessly into the existing home. The renovation aimed to maximize outdoor space and preserve the landscape, while also incorporating modern design elements and smart features, such as an audio system and modular furniture. The project, led by architect Jon Hensley and contractor AllenBuilt, took three years to complete and was completed at an undisclosed cost.

site_title: Iceberg's criticism does not take note of improvements by Noble
summary: SIAS criticizes Iceberg's report on Noble Group Limited, citing lack of improvements despite Noble's efforts to engage with retail investors and increase transparency in its financial statements. SIAS notes that Noble received clean audit opinions and adopted the "Key Audit Matters" standard early, but still faces criticisms on the same issues. SIAS advises investors to be cautious of unregulated research companies and to consider reports from regulated analysts for informed investment decisions. The organization invites Iceberg to meet to discuss concerns in the interests of Noble's shareholders.

site_title: UK says EU offers restricted post-Brexit residency rights to Britons
summary: The European Union has proposed limited post-Brexit residency rights for Britons living in the bloc, allowing them to stay only in the country where they are currently resident. This offer, made in the first stage of Brexit negotiations, does not guarantee the right to move freely within the EU. The EU Commission has not commented on the proposal, which has been met with skepticism by Britain, with questions raised about consistency with the principle of reciprocity and protection of existing rights.

site_title: Maersk family foundation launches Africa infrastructure fund
summary: The A P Moller Holding, parent company of Maersk, has launched a new Africa infrastructure fund with commitments of $550 million, aiming to raise $1 billion. The fund will be managed by experienced former Maersk executives and will focus on investing in infrastructure in emerging markets, particularly in sub-Saharan countries. The fund's launch is seen as a promising move by the company, which already has approximately $20 billion under management.

site_title: China gas sellers sidestep state giants to ride demand surge
summary: China's independent energy firms are capitalizing on the country's booming natural gas demand by importing liquefied natural gas (LNG) directly, bypassing state-backed giants. The number of LNG terminals is expected to expand by 5-6 million tonnes annually, with private investors accounting for 20% of the growth. This shift is driven by the government's efforts to encourage private competition and increase efficiencies in the energy sector. As a result, gas distributors are benefiting from lower downstream sales prices and boosted consumption, with some companies experiencing significant gains in recent months.

images.alt_text: China, which is forecast to more than double LNG purchases by 2022, has more than a dozen import terminals owned by its three state energy giants.

site_title: Singapore is world leader in e-government penetration: survey
summary: Singapore has retained its top spot in the world for e-government penetration, according to a joint survey by Waseda University and the International Academy of Chief Information Officers. The country has high internet penetration, with 82% of citizens using the internet daily, and has implemented various digital government strategies, including the development of a Smart Nation Platform and a National Portal. This allows citizens to easily access government services and information, facilitating a culture of "deliberative democracy" through ICT utilisation.

site_title: Reits actually do better when rates rise, but not in Canada
summary: Real estate investment trusts (REITs) tend to outperform in a rising-rate environment, according to Corrado Russo, global head of securities at Timbercreek Asset Management Inc. However, in Canada, REITs become riskier bets due to lower cash-flow growth and higher leverage. This contradicts the general trend of REITs performing well with rising interest rates globally. Russo stated that empirical evidence shows REITs outperform in a rising-rate environment, both relatively and absolutely.

site_title: Is 'Deep State' out to oust President Trump?
summary: A conspiracy theory suggesting the "Deep State" is working to oust President Trump from power is circulating among conservative talk-show hosts. However, the article concludes there is no evidence of a coup in Washington, despite claims of a coordinated effort by the Deep State, Republican Establishment, and liberal opinion makers to reverse Trump's 2016 election victory. Instead, it appears to be a series of individual acts of sabotage and leaks that are not coordinated.

site_title: Mizuho seeks growth of US$100b from overseas transaction banking
summary: Mizuho Financial Group Inc aims to grow its overseas transaction banking business by 20% to $100 billion this fiscal year, driven by Japan's negative interest rates. The bank seeks to capture low-cost deposits in local currencies and boost earnings. Mizuho has expanded its global transaction banking headquarters in Singapore and hired senior salespeople from foreign competitors to lead the business in each region. The move aims to help the bank shore up earnings and compete with global peers in the transaction banking market.

site_title: Prevention cheaper than cure - especially in cybersecurity
summary: Singapore is facing a significant cybersecurity threat, with 35% of organizations focusing on protecting customer information, despite 91% seeking specialist guidance. The country has been hit by multiple attacks, including WannaCry, affecting digital screens and sensitive government data. Cybercrime is becoming a major risk in the Asia-Pacific, with 43% of companies in Singapore affected in 2016, compared to 15% in 2014. Experts warn that a lack of investment in cybersecurity can lead to devastating losses, including financial costs and damage to reputation.

site_title: US productivity increases in second quarter; labour costs soft
summary: US worker productivity increased at a 0.9% annualised rate in the second quarter, driven by a rise in hours worked. This trend, however, remains weak, suggesting that robust economic growth could be elusive. The revision of first-quarter productivity to a 0.1% pace instead of unchanged also indicates a lack of momentum.

site_title: Amazon's Singapore play a precursor to S-E Asia e-commerce battle
summary: Amazon has entered the Singapore e-commerce market with its Prime Now service, offering free two-hour delivery for orders over S$40. The move is seen as a precursor to its larger goal of expanding into the South-east Asian market. The service was initially overwhelmed by demand, disrupting Amazon's delivery network. This marks a new strategy for Amazon in Singapore, where other players such as Lazada and Qoo10 already have a presence. The introduction of Prime Now is a niche product within Amazon's Prime subscription service.

site_title: Anti-globalisation: the new socialism of fools
summary: Globalization, often misunderstood as solely benefiting wealthy elites, can actually lead to a more evenly distributed income. According to Harvard economist Dani Rodrik, removing tariffs and non-tariff barriers can produce net gains, but also redistributes wealth. In the US, a shift from manufacturing to services and construction may have increased employment opportunities for lower-skilled workers. However, strong anti-globalization sentiment persists, driven by scapegoating foreigners and immigrants, inequitable economic growth, and policymakers' failure to address full employment and social policies.

site_title: Malaysia launches China-backed East Coast rail project amid concerns
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has launched the RM55 billion East Coast Rail Link (ECRL) project, a China-backed infrastructure project, amid concerns over its high price tag and impact on Kuala Lumpur's debt burden. The 688-km rail line aims to reduce travel time to four hours and boost economic growth, but critics question its viability and worry it will add to Malaysia's already staggering debt of RM676 billion. The project's financing is largely from China's Exim Bank, with a 20-year repayment period, raising concerns about Malaysia's ability to meet its obligations.

site_title: Country star Glen Campbell dies at 81
summary: Glen Campbell, a renowned country star and guitar prodigy, died on August 8, 2017, at 81. He announced his Alzheimer's diagnosis in 2011 and performed his farewell tour shortly after. Campbell won his sixth and final Grammy Award in 2015 for best country song "I'm Not Gonna Miss You." Throughout his six-decade career, he sold over 40 million records and was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame, known for his polished, countrypolitan sound and iconic hits like "Gentle on My Mind" and "Rhinestone Cowboy."

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as tensions with North Korea escalate
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on August 9, 2017, due to rising tensions between North Korea and the US. President Donald Trump's warning of "fire and fury" if North Korea threatened the US prompted investors to turn risk-averse, leading to a decline in stocks. Safe-haven assets like gold rose, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 49.62 points, or 0.22%, to 22,035.72.

site_title: Minimarts 2.0: Updating a traditional business
summary: Minimart operators in Singapore are facing disruption from supermarkets and e-grocers, and must adapt to stay relevant. To overcome this, they can automate manual processes using digital solutions, such as barcode scanning and automated inventory management, to boost efficiency and gain business intelligence. The government is providing support, including training programs and grants, to help minimarts adopt digital solutions and overcome challenges. However, policy changes, such as raising the minimum age for smokers, may also pose concerns for the industry, and dialogue with authorities is needed to address these issues.

site_title: Pokemon Go fans join giant Pikachus at Yokohama festival
summary: Thousands of Pokémon Go players gathered in Yokohama, Japan to catch rare virtual creatures while watching giant Pikachu dance shows. The festival, featuring 15,000 Pikachus, was jointly organized by Yokohama city and The Pokémon Company. The event was part of a series of Pokémon Go events leading up to the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. The festival's main venue, Pokémon Go Park, was busy, with servers often down due to congestion, similar to a previous event in Chicago that drew nearly 20,000 players.

site_title: US mortgage activity rises as rates fall
summary: US mortgage applications increased 3% last week, driven by a 5.3% rise in refinancing requests, as home borrowing costs fell, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. The seasonally adjusted index of overall mortgage activity rose to 418.7, while the refinancing barometer increased to 1,433.2. This growth is attributed to the decline in mortgage rates, which has made borrowing more affordable for homeowners.

site_title: HNA eyes airport deals amid China's outbound crackdown
summary: HNA Group is moving forward with a bid to operate Belgrade's Nikola Tesla airport, despite China's tightened scrutiny of overseas acquisitions. The company, part of Chinese conglomerate HNA, is leading a consortium that includes AVIC International Holding and China-Central and Eastern Europe Investment Cooperation Fund. HNA has also closed its acquisition of Hahn airport in Germany and is investing in an expansion project at the Rio de Janeiro international airport. The company's airport deals are part of its efforts to participate in China's Belt and Road initiative.

site_title: N Korea considers missile strike on Guam after Trump's 'fire and fury' warning
summary: North Korea considers a missile strike on Guam, a US Pacific territory, following President Donald Trump's warning of "fire and fury" against any threat to the US. The North Korean government says it is "carefully examining" a plan to strike Guam, which is home to about 163,000 people and a US military base. Guam Governor Eddie Calvo dismissed the threat and said the island is prepared for any eventuality. The US has warned it is ready to use force to stop North Korea's ballistic missile and nuclear programs, but prefers diplomatic action.

site_title: Two months into Saudi-led boycott, Qatar goes on the offensive
summary: Qatar, facing a two-month boycott by Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt, has launched a counterattack amid allegations of backing terrorism. The quartet severed ties in early June, citing Qatar's supposed ties to extremist groups. Qatar has denied the claims, and instead, has sought to strengthen its relationships with other nations, including Turkey and Iran. The crisis has significant implications for regional stability and US interests, but a resolution remains uncertain.

site_title: Deliver the six gold medals in KL, Joe
summary: Singaporean swimmer Joseph Schooling is predicted to deliver six gold medals in the upcoming 29th South-east Asian Games in Kuala Lumpur, aiming to boost his personal Sea Games tally to 23 main podium finishes. However, a recent World Swimming Championships experience serves as a reminder that complacency can be a dangerous ally, as Schooling had over-confidence before his bronze medal finish. A lesson from his teammate Caeleb Dressel, who achieved revenge with a strong mentality and physical presence, is that focus and determination are key to success.

images.alt_text: Schooling competing in a heat of the men's 100m butterfly during the 2017 FINA World Championships in Budapest on July 28.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.710 points to 1,777.940. Losers outnumbered gainers 452 to 317, and volume was 1.423 billion lots worth RM1.734 billion.

site_title: 53-year-old man arrested for flying drone at Marina Barrage on National Day
summary: A 53-year-old man was arrested in Singapore on National Day for flying a drone at Marina Barrage, an area where unmanned aerial vehicles are prohibited for 24 hours. The incident occurred at 3:01pm on August 9. The man's drone was seized by the police, but no further details on charges or bail have been released.

images.alt_text: A 53-year-old man was arrested on National Day for flying a drone at Marina Barrage.

site_title: Hard-pedalling soft power, China helps launch US$13b Belt and Road rail project in Malaysia
summary: China and Malaysia broke ground on the US$13 billion East Coast Rail Link project, a major part of Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative. The 688-km rail project will connect the South China Sea with the Straits of Malacca, and is seen as a significant expansion of China's soft power in Malaysia. The project is being financed with an 85% loan from China Exim Bank and is part of a series of infrastructure projects in Malaysia aimed at boosting foreign investment and cutting travel time.

site_title: France says to target Airbnb 'unacceptable' tax regime
summary: France is teaming up with Germany to address an "unacceptable" tax situation for homesharing website Airbnb and other digital platforms like Google and Amazon. Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire stated that France and Germany will submit a tax proposal at the next EU ministerial council on September 15, aiming to make digital platforms pay a fair contribution to the French treasury. This comes after Airbnb paid less than 100,000 euros in French taxes last year, despite generating tens of millions of sales.

site_title: Morgan Stanley pips Goldman Sachs profit-wise in Japan
summary: Morgan Stanley surpassed Goldman Sachs in profitability in Japan, with net income rising 32% to 29 billion yen in the fiscal year ending March 31. The US firm boosted structured product sales and managed the two largest initial public offerings in Japan. Morgan Stanley's fees for fixed income-related sales and trading increased 22% to 43.7 billion yen, while Goldman Sachs generated the second-highest revenue and profit, totaling 22.1 billion yen. The results highlight Japan's growing demand for assets with better returns than government bonds.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover sees higher incentive costs amid competition
summary: Jaguar Land Rover faces increased competition, leading to higher incentive costs to win customers. Despite a 49% profit before tax gain to £595 million, the company's slower growth in deliveries is a concern. The profit includes a one-time credit related to pension plans, with Tata Motors' net income rising 42% to 31.8 billion rupees. The company's luxury unit must continue to offer higher incentives to compete in a intensifying market.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks close down
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks closed down on August 9, 2017, due to escalating tensions over North Korea and lower-than-expected China factory gate inflation. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.35%, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.19%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.34%. The sell-off was part of a regional trend.

site_title: Opec says Iraq, UAE, Kazakhstan affirm commitment to cuts
summary: Opec has confirmed that Iraq, the UAE, and Kazakhstan have reaffirmed their commitment to production cuts, despite lagging behind in implementing the deal. The meeting, co-chaired by Kuwait and Russia, saw the countries express their support for monitoring production levels to achieve full conformity. Iraq and the UAE attributed their apparent non-compliance to inaccurate estimates by Opec, while Kazakhstan has increased its output despite promising cuts. The agreement aims to reduce oil production by 1.8 million barrels a day, but compliance is likely to falter, according to CME Group Senior Economist Erik Norland.

site_title: Tillerson calms North Korea tensions after Trump rattles markets
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson calmed North Korea tensions after President Donald Trump warned of "fire and fury" against Kim Jong Un's regime. Tillerson stated that Americans should have no concerns about the rhetoric, while emphasizing the US is engaged in a diplomatic effort to halt North Korea's nuclear pursuits. Trump's comments sparked global market sell-offs and criticism, with some lawmakers questioning his readiness to act. China urged all sides to avoid escalating tensions, and Japan and South Korea largely dismissed the threat.

site_title: Volkswagen workers want new car model for Germany to boost flagging output
summary: Volkswagen's powerful labour unions are urging the company to invest in new car models for German production to boost flagging output. The unions are concerned about a 3.8% drop in vehicle production in Germany due to waning demand for current models. Following a 2016 agreement to cut thousands of jobs at the core VW brand, the unions are seeking to avoid further cuts in production capacity at home. The unions want Volkswagen to create a new model for local production to increase work for German plants.

site_title: China quake scars treasured scenic tourist site
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck southwestern China's Jiuzhaigou on Tuesday, killing at least 19 people and leaving deep physical scars on the area. The quake triggered massive landslides, raking green forest from the mountainsides and scarred them with huge earth-coloured gashes. Jiuzhaigou, a network of mountain valleys with over 140 lakes, is prized for its pristine natural beauty, but the damage threatens to compromise its unique ecosystem.

images.alt_text: The strong earthquake that jolted southwestern China appears to have left deep physical scars on Jiuzhaigou, a network of mountain valleys prized as one of the country's few remaining areas of pristine natural beauty.

site_title: China's smog crackdown roils niche commodities markets
summary: China's government is cracking down on smog, forcing factories to close or suspend operations in key commodity markets. Soymeal and gasoline prices have surged, with soymeal rising 3% this week to a three-week high of 2,840 yuan per tonne. The crackdown, part of the government's efforts to clean up 28 cities by September, has also affected ferroalloys, zinc, and lead prices, with some markets experiencing sudden supply jolts and price swings. The move is expected to continue until air quality improves, with analysts predicting a long-term impact on prices of aluminum and steel.

site_title: Qatar Airways says will get delivery of Airbus A350-1000s this year
summary: Qatar Airways' CEO Akbar al-Baker announced that the airline will receive its first Airbus A350-1000 aircraft this year, despite previous delays. This is the launch customer of the A350-1000, and Qatar Airways had previously cancelled four A350-900 aircraft due to the delays. Airbus has assured Qatar Airways that the A350-1000 will be delivered before the end of the year.

site_title: Japan Display considers new capital to adapt to Apple's Oled shift
summary: Japan Display is considering new investors to raise capital and adapt to the shift to organic light-emitting diode (Oled) screens, as its late entry into the technology costs it orders from largest client Apple Inc. The display maker will streamline production lines and slash 30% of its workforce, resulting in a special loss of $2.096 billion. Japan Display plans to start mass-producing Oled panels for smartphones in 2019, while Apple is expected to adopt Oled for its iPhones later this year.

images.alt_text: Japan Display said it is considering tapping new investors for capital to catch up in organic light-emitting diode (Oled) screens as its late entry into the technology is costing the display maker orders from its largest client, Apple Inc.

site_title: Japan gives world-beating fidget spinner a whirl
summary: Japan's NSK Micro Precision has developed a fidget spinner that can whirl for 12 minutes and counting, beating its competitors. The "Saturn Spinner" uses ball bearings from space satellites and computer disks, increasing centrifugal force. Priced at 17,280 yen ($213) each, the gadget is designed for stress relief but is banned in some schools as a distraction. The company hopes the pricey product will stimulate interest in ball bearings, which are often overlooked.

images.alt_text: One company in perfectionism-obsessed Japan is claiming it has developed a fidget spinner that whirls longer than any rival on the market - 12 minutes and counting.

site_title: Brexit inflation pushing British shoppers to cheaper goods, BoE survey shows
summary: British businesses are keeping pay low and automating production amid rising inflation and uncertainty following the Brexit vote. The Bank of England's survey found that consumers are switching to cheaper products, with sales at consumer services businesses growing at their slowest pace in over four years. Businesses serving British consumers are suffering, while export-focused manufacturers are thriving due to the weaker pound. The BoE forecasts economic growth to slow to 1.7% this year and 1.6% in 2018, with wages rising by 2% and then 3%.

site_title: Yancoal shareholder lodges complaint over raising for US$2.69b Rio coal deal
summary: A shareholder, Senrigan Capital Management, is requesting Australian regulators to intervene in Yancoal's US$2.69 billion purchase of Rio Tinto's Coal & Allied division, citing unfair treatment of minority shareholders. Senrigan argues the proposed renounceable entitlement offer undervalues Yancoal shares and would concentrate voting power in the hands of Yanzhou Coal Mining. The Takeovers Panel has not made a decision on the matter, but another minority shareholder, Noble Group, is considering taking the issue to the panel.

images.alt_text: YancoalHedge fund Senrigan Capital Management has asked Australian regulators to intervene in Yancoal Australia's efforts to fund its US$2.69 billion purchase of the Coal & Allied division of Rio Tinto, saying it is unfair to minority shareholders.

site_title: UNEP chief urges China to do more on climate
summary: The UN's environment chief, Erik Solheim, urged China to do more on climate change, given its position as the world's biggest polluter and largest investor in renewable energy. China has pledged to reduce its reliance on coal, but still relies on it for 62% of its primary energy mix. Solheim warned that China's continued use of coal is "very dangerous" and urged the country to transform to renewable energy sources. Analysts see China's opportunity to establish credibility ahead of future climate negotiations.

site_title: Disney CEO sees a future without Netflix, Comcast or DirecTV
summary: Disney CEO Bob Iger plans to sell Disney content directly to consumers online, bypassing partners like Netflix, Comcast, and DirecTV. The company will launch a new online ESPN service next year and a Disney video service in 2019, featuring live-action films and Disney Channel TV shows. Disney will end its deal with Netflix to offer its newest films online, starting in 2019. The move is seen as a response to the decline of its cable TV division, with sales and profit falling due to weakness in the ESPN channel.

site_title: Car rams into soldiers in Paris suburb in suspected terrorist attack
summary: A car rammed into a group of soldiers in a Parisian suburb, injuring six before speeding off in a suspected terrorist attack. The incident occurred in Levallois-Perret, a suburb about 5 km from the city center, and is believed to be a "cowardly act" with premeditation. The driver, described as a BMW with dark-colored paint, was on the run and being sought by authorities. This attack follows a string of Islamist-inspired attacks on soldiers and police in France, resulting in over 230 deaths since 2015.

images.alt_text: A car rammed into a group of soldiers in a Parisian suburb on Wednesday, injuring six before speeding off in what officials identified as a suspected terrorist attack.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets descend at open
summary: European stock markets declined in opening trade on August 9, 2017, due to investor fears over US-North Korea tensions. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.5%, while the Paris CAC 40 fell 0.7% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 declined 0.8%. The declines were attributed to mounting concerns over escalating tensions between the US and North Korea.

site_title: Bank of England creates post to identify conflicts of interest
summary: The Bank of England has created a new post to identify potential conflicts of interest among its staff, following a review prompted by the resignation of Deputy Governor Charlotte Hogg, who failed to disclose her brother's role at Barclays. The review, conducted by non-executive directors, recommended updating requirements for notification of personal relationships and conflicts. BoE Governor Mark Carney welcomed the review's recommendations, which will be implemented in full. This move aims to increase transparency and prevent similar conflicts of interest in the future.

site_title: Tiger Woods set for arraignment on DUI charge in Florida
summary: Tiger Woods, 41, is set to be arraigned in a DUI case in Florida, stemming from an arrest in May after police found him asleep at the wheel of his Mercedes-Benz. Woods' lawyer waived his appearance in court, citing his focus on managing pain from a recent back surgery and taking prescription medication. Woods claims the incident was due to his medication use, not excessive drinking. He faces up to six months in prison if convicted, but may plead guilty to a lesser charge and enroll in a 12-month program to avoid a DUI conviction.

site_title: Australian consumers fret over finances in August: survey
summary: Australian consumer sentiment fell to its lowest in over a year in August, with a 1.2% decline, according to a survey by the Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank. The index reading of 95.5 was 5.5% lower than in August last year, citing pressure on family finances and concerns over rising interest rates. Despite this, the outlook for the next 12 months and five years improved, with 2.1% and 2.3% gains, respectively.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks tumble as US-North Korea tensions mount
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 1.29% on Wednesday amid escalating tensions between the US and North Korea. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 257.30 points to 19,738.71, while the Topix index fell 1.07% to 1,617.90. Investors pressed the sell button in response to rising tensions, with US President Trump making new threats against North Korea.

site_title: Gold up on rising US-North Korea tensions
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,264.50 per ounce amid rising tensions between the US and North Korea, with Pyongyang considering a missile strike on Guam. US President Donald Trump warned North Korea of "fire and fury" if it threatens the US. The increase in gold prices was attributed to geopolitical risks and safe-haven demand, despite previous weakness due to stronger-than-expected US jobs data.

site_title: ABN Amro bolsters capital as Dutch growth drives profit rise
summary: ABN Amro's quarterly profit more than doubled to 960 million euros, driven by a 200 million-euro gain from selling Asian private-banking assets and an expanding Dutch economy. The bank's common equity Tier one capital ratio rose to 17.6% as it refocuses on its home market. CEO Kees van Dijkhuizen plans to update investors on the capital position in 2018, and aims to lower the cost-to-income ratio to 56-58% by 2020. The Dutch economy expanded 0.4% in the first quarter, with growth expected to accelerate in the second quarter.

site_title: Blackstone, GIC lead buyout of Goldman's Rothesay Life stake
summary: Goldman Sachs has sold its remaining 32.7% stake in British pensions insurance business Rothesay Life to a trio of investors, including Blackstone Group, Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, and Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC. The deal, worth an undisclosed sum, comes a decade after Goldman initially set up the company. Rothesay's clients include major companies such as British Airways and InterContinental Hotels Group, with assets under management of £23.7 billion as of 2016. The deal will see GIC and Blackstone become Rothesay's largest shareholders.

site_title: Morgan Stanley tops Goldman Sachs with biggest profit in Japan
summary: Morgan Stanley has topped Goldman Sachs as the most profitable foreign securities firm in Japan, with a net income of 29 billion yen (S$356.61 million) in the year ended March 31, a 32% increase. This was driven by boosted structured-product sales and managed initial public offerings, including those of Kyushu Railway Co and Line Corp. Morgan Stanley's fees for fixed income-related sales and trading rose 22% to 43.7 billion yen, surpassing Goldman Sachs' 22.1 billion yen.

site_title: Banks, materials prop Australia shares; NZ score 3rd straight record closing high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to a record high, driven by gains in financials and materials. Commonwealth Bank of Australia's profit beat expectations, boosting its stock despite a money laundering scandal. Newcrest Mining and BHP Billiton also surged. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index closed at a record high for a third consecutive session, despite a 3.7% drop in SkyCity Entertainment Group's shares.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars lose to yen in safety bid
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell against the Japanese yen due to rising tensions over North Korea, with the Aussie dollar dropping 0.9% to 86.48 yen, its lowest in a month. The yen benefits during times of geopolitical or financial stress as investors assume Japan's creditor nation will repatriate funds in a crisis. This shift in investor sentiment pushed the Aussie and NZ dollars down, while the yen strengthened against both currencies.

site_title: Hong Kong cleans up 93 tonnes of palm oil, shuts 13 beaches after huge spill
summary: Hong Kong has collected over 90 tonnes of palm oil from 13 beaches affected by a ship spill, six days after two vessels collided in the Pearl River estuary. The spill, which also included dead fish, shells, and plastic, has sparked outrage among residents and environmentalists. The incident comes a year after massive amounts of rubbish, including packaging from mainland China, washed up on Hong Kong's beaches. The cleanup efforts are ongoing, with authorities urging residents to avoid the affected areas.

site_title: Asia: Shares, US stock futures, US dollar slip on rising Korean tensions
summary: Asian shares and US stock futures fell on Wednesday amid rising tensions on the Korean peninsula, with Pyongyang warning it is "carefully examining" plans for a missile strike on Guam. US President Donald Trump warned North Korea of "fire and fury" in response, leading to a 0.2% drop in MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares and a 0.2% decline in US S&P 500 e-mini futures. The US dollar also slipped, while the yen rose as investors sought safe-haven assets.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won slide to multi-week lows on US-North Korea tensions
summary: South Korean stocks slid to multi-week lows on Wednesday due to heightened US-North Korea tensions. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed down 1.1% at 2,368.39 points, its lowest level since June 21. Foreign investors, who had been net buyers earlier, unloaded 259.7 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The South Korean won also plummeted 0.9% to its lowest close since July 13, amid escalating rhetoric between the US and North Korea.

site_title: Guam stays calm, dismisses North Korea threat
summary: Guam Governor Eddie Calvo downplayed North Korea's threat to attack his island state, stating the territory is "prepared for any eventuality." Following US President Donald Trump's threat of "fire and fury," North Korea considered missile strikes near US military installations on Guam. Calvo assured the public that Guam is working with Washington to ensure safety, despite the escalating tensions in the region.

site_title: Ten years of firefighting leaves ECB poised to unwind stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is poised to unwind its stimulus package after a decade of emergency measures to combat the 2007 financial crisis. The ECB, which has expanded its balance sheet by trillions of euros, is expected to signal a gradual exit from its 2.3 trillion euro bond-buying plan, with ECB President Mario Draghi set to outline a timeline in the fall. The ECB's unconventional monetary policies, including quantitative easing, have been in place since 2008, but experts warn that the normalization process will take years and may not be completed until interest rates rise.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday due to concerns over US-North Korea tensions and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.27% and the Topix index dropped 0.20%. These declines followed similar market movements on Wall Street.

site_title: French start-up takes off with flight-sharing app
summary: A French start-up, Wingly, is connecting passengers with private pilots for low-cost, short flights in Europe. The platform, which has over 80,000 members, allows passengers to book flights directly with pilots, often at a lower cost than commercial airlines. Wingly's co-founder, Emeric de Waziers, aims to make private aviation accessible to a wider audience, rather than restricting it to the elite. The company has seen rapid growth, with a 20% monthly increase in community members, and plans to expand globally in the next decade.

images.alt_text: A French start-up is reaching for the skies with a flight-sharing app, matching pilots with passengers looking for a low-cost way to take off in a private aircraft.

site_title: China's Didi teams up with Careem in Middle East, North Africa
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's largest ride-hailing company, has formed a strategic partnership with Careem, a Saudi Arabia-based ride-hailing platform operating in the Middle East and North Africa. The two companies will share operations, product development, and knowledge, but users will not be able to hail both services from the same app. This move comes as Didi expands its international presence and competes with Uber in Pakistan, where Uber has invested $500 million by 2020. The partnership is backed by SoftBank Group Corp, with Saudi Arabia's main sovereign wealth fund also involved.

site_title: China's yuan set for 3rd straight winning session
summary: China's yuan strengthened for the third consecutive day against the US dollar, reaching a 10-month high.
