The People's Bank of China set the yuan midpoint at 6.7075 per US dollar, the strongest level since October 2016. The spot yuan rose to 6.6929 per US dollar, 151 pips firmer than the previous close. images.alt_text: China's yuan firmed against the US dollar on Wednesday, setting it up for a third straight day of gains on the back of a stronger fixing and continued corporate US dollar selling.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares tumble to over 1-month lows as US-North Korea tensions heat up
summary: South Korea's won tumbled to a one-month low, down 0.8% to 1,134.4 to the US dollar, amid escalating tensions between the US and North Korea. Shares of tech companies like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell 1.8% and 2.4%, respectively, while defence-related companies rose. The US has warned it is ready to use force against North Korea, but prefers diplomatic action.

site_title: Australia shares rise on upbeat CBA; NZ down
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 30.95 points, or 0.5%, to 5,774.7 on Wednesday, driven by a rally in financial stocks, particularly Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which climbed 1.4% after beating profit expectations. site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 4.35 points to 1,777.30. Volume reached 27.47 million lots worth RM12.08 million, with 81 gainers and 60 losers.

site_title: Investors lovin' it as McDonald's Japan moves past food scandals
summary: McDonald's Japan has made a significant turnaround, with its stock surging to a three-year high and posting 20 consecutive months of same-store sales gains. The company's focus on closing unprofitable stores and revamping existing ones has drawn in more customers with popular items and advertising tie-ins. Analysts expect continued momentum in its earnings report Wednesday, with a forecasted 67% increase in annual operating income. The company's turnaround has been led by CEO Sarah Casanova and efforts to engage with consumers through social media and other initiatives.

site_title: Update: Quake in China's Sichuan kills 13, including tourists, injures 175
summary: A 7.0 magnitude earthquake struck a remote area in China's Sichuan province, killing 13 people, including six tourists, and injuring 175. The quake, which hit at a depth of 10 km, was followed by aftershocks. The area is a popular tourist destination, with over 38,000 tourists currently visiting Jiuzhaigou nature reserve. The epicentre was in Ngawa prefecture, home to ethnic Tibetans, and was also close to a nature reserve. A separate 6.6 magnitude quake struck Xinjiang region, over 2,000 km away, with no immediate reports of casualties.

site_title: Vantiv agrees to purchase Worldpay Group for £8b
summary: Vantiv, the largest US merchant acquirer, agreed to purchase Worldpay Group for approximately £8 billion, valuing each Worldpay share at 397 pence. The combined company, called Worldpay, will have a pro forma enterprise value of £22.2 billion and process about $1.5 trillion in payment volume annually. The deal is expected to result in annual recurring pretax cost synergies of $200 million and incur $330 million in one-off integration costs. The companies will seek a secondary listing on the London Stock Exchange, with Worldpay CEO Philip Jansen set to co-lead the combined firm.

site_title: Kenya opposition rejects poll results showing president in lead
summary: Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta led with 55% of the vote in early results, but opposition leader Raila Odinga disputed the numbers, calling them "fake" and alleging vote rigging. Odinga's supporters fear a repeat of 2007's post-election violence, which killed 1,200 people. Kenyatta called for a peaceful transfer of power, but Odinga vowed not to accept the outcome unless it's "credible." The opposition is planning protests, and the outcome remains uncertain, with the winner needing a majority of votes and a quarter of the vote in 24 counties.

site_title: US envoys told to be coy on re-engaging in Paris climate deal: cable
summary: US diplomats are advised to be coy about re-engaging in the Paris climate deal, according to a diplomatic cable. The cable, sent by Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, instructs diplomats to sidestep questions about the US' climate change policy and the use of fossil fuels. If asked about re-engagement, diplomats should respond vaguely, stating they are "considering a number of factors" without providing any information on the process or timing. This approach aims to avoid giving foreign governments a clear understanding of the US' intentions on the Paris Agreement.

site_title: Initial coin offerings continue unabated
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has warned about the risks of initial coin offerings (ICOs), but many startups continue to raise money by selling virtual currencies, defying the commission's rules. Since the guidance was released, 46 new coin offerings have been announced, and 204 are moving towards fundraising. Only three projects have cancelled or postponed their sales due to the warning. The SEC is focusing on coins that should be categorized as securities, but many projects claim they are not securities, despite being sold to investors.

site_title: Hertz CEO touting turnaround plan after third straight loss
summary: Hertz Global Holdings Inc reported a second-quarter adjusted loss of 63 US cents per share, worse than analyst projections. Despite this, CEO Kathryn Marinello touted the company's progress in executing its operating turnaround plan, focusing on slimming its fleet of fast-depreciating cars. Hertz's shares rebounded in after-hours trading, increasing 2.9% to $14.70. The company aims to shrink its compact car fleet and purchase more SUVs, which are drawing greater demand from American consumers.

site_title: Australia's CBA vows reputational rebuild as scandal taints record profit
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia posted its eighth consecutive record profit, but its reputation is under scrutiny due to allegations of money laundering and terror financing. The bank's chairman, Catherine Livingstone, acknowledged the significance of the allegations and vowed to rebuild public trust. The bank has cut short-term bonuses for top executives and established a board sub-committee to address management accountability. CBA shares rose 1.07% after the profit release, but the bank faces potential billions of dollars in penalties and regulatory pressure to boost capital and slow lending to speculative property investors.

site_title: Vietnam seeks windfall selling US$7b brewery in slices
summary: Vietnam plans to sell its 90% stake in state-owned brewery Sabeco in tranches, aiming to maximize valuation after the company's market value surged to $7 billion. The phased sale will begin in the fourth quarter, with foreign companies such as Heineken, Anheuser-Busch InBev, and Asahi Group showing interest. The government expects to approve the plan by mid-next month, with additional sales possible through 2018. The sale may help Vietnam reduce its budget deficit, with the country planning to privatize 137 state-owned companies by 2020.

site_title: US: Dow streak of records ends amid US-North Korea tensions
summary: US stocks fell Tuesday, ending the Dow's nine-day record streak amid rising tensions between the US and North Korea. President Trump warned Pyongyang it will face "fire and fury" if it continues to threaten the US, following reports of a nuclear warhead small enough to fit inside North Korean missiles. The Dow closed down, with stocks dropping in the last hour of trading. The comments came as investors brushed off new Trump threats, which have yet to impact the extended rally in stocks.

site_title: US finds China aluminium foil subsidised, imposes duties
summary: The US Commerce Department found that imports of aluminium foil from China are subsidised, imposing countervailing duties ranging from 16.56% to 80.97%. The decision was made after US aluminium producers accused Chinese producers of receiving subsidies and dumping the product in the US market. The move aims to restore a level playing field for US aluminium foil production, supporting over 20,000 jobs and $6.8 billion in economic activity. A preliminary anti-dumping determination is expected on October 5, with the case separate from a broader investigation into China's aluminium overcapacity and dumping.

site_title: BlackBerry shares slide after Goldman 'sell' recommendation
summary: BlackBerry shares fell 3.6% on the Toronto Stock Exchange after Goldman Sachs issued a "sell" recommendation due to concerns about rising competition in its mobile software business. The recommendation comes after a disappointing quarterly earnings report and amid concerns about the company's ability to meet expectations for sales of new products, including automotive software. Analysts believe it will be difficult for BlackBerry to become a dominant player in the autonomous-vehicle software market, with expansion unlikely in the next 18 months.

site_title: HBO hackers demand millions in ransom note
summary: HBO hackers have demanded millions in ransom payments after breaching the network and releasing 10 files, including a script from "Game of Thrones." The hackers claim to have obtained 1.5 terabytes of data, including highly confidential documents and scripts. They are demanding half of HBO's annual budget, estimated at $12-15 million, to stop further leaks. HBO has confirmed the breach and is working with cybersecurity firms and law enforcement to resolve the incident, but has not confirmed the authenticity of the ransom demands.

site_title: Dutch egg probe widens to chicken meat tests
summary: Dutch authorities have expanded their probe into the tainted egg scandal by testing chicken meat coming from affected poultry farms for the presence of the insecticide fipronil. The probe, led by the food security agency NVWA, aims to determine if the insecticide was also contaminated in chicken meat. The investigation focuses on "a few dozen" farms that produce both eggs and chicken meat, and the Dutch Safety Board is also opening a separate probe into the incident.

site_title: Penny crash trials: Court rejects Soh's bid for documents
summary: John Soh Chee Wen, accused of masterminding the 2013 penny stock crash, failed to persuade the court to hand over documents that could support his bail application. Justice See Kee Oon rejected Soh's request, citing it as a "fishing expedition" and stating the burden of proof lies with the accused, not the prosecution. Soh faces 188 charges related to the crash and a hearing date for his latest bail application has not been set.

site_title: North Korea says seriously considering plan to strike Guam: KCNA
summary: North Korea stated it is "carefully examining" a plan to strike Guam with missiles, following US President Donald Trump's warning of "fire and fury" if North Korea threatens the US. A KCNA news agency spokesman said the plan will be implemented "in a multi-current and consecutive way" once leader Kim Jong Un makes a decision. North Korea also threatened to carry out a pre-emptive operation if the US shows signs of provocation.

site_title: Toshiba shares jump as delisting fears ease
summary: Toshiba shares rose 4.27% after reports that the company will meet a deadline to submit long-delayed earnings to financial regulators, easing fears of delisting from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The news came after auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers Aarata granted a qualified approval of Toshiba's earnings report, alleviating concerns over multi-billion dollar losses at its US nuclear unit Westinghouse Electric. Toshiba's shares jumped 9% in early trading before settling at 293 yen, bringing relief to investors, but analysts noted that the recovery is uncertain.

site_title: Country music legend Glen Campbell dead at 81
summary: Country music legend Glen Campbell has died at 81 after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Campbell sold over 50 million albums, earning six Grammy Awards and a Lifetime Achievement Award. His final album, Adios, was released in June. Born in Arkansas in 1936, Campbell began performing at age 4 and went on to have a successful music, TV, and movie career, including hosting his own show and starring in the classic Western True Grit.

site_title: Disney to pull movies from Netflix, plans own streaming service
summary: Disney plans to stop providing new movies to Netflix starting in 2019 and launch its own streaming service, aiming to capture digital viewers. The move comes as Netflix and rivals spend billions on content to stream directly to consumers. Disney's new service will feature a mix of live sports and original content, with the help of technology firm BAMTech. The company will pay $1.58 billion to acquire a 42% stake in BAMTech. Disney's defection is seen as a calculated gamble to generate more profit from its own subscription service, but may weigh on earnings in the short term.

site_title: Quants clamour for data, causing soul-searching at large banks
summary: Quantitative investors are pressuring banks to grant them access to proprietary information, as the demand for unique market data grows. Banks are struggling to balance offering useful tidbits without giving away sensitive information. To address this, some banks are exploring ways to anonymize data, such as aggregating figures or publishing it with a lag. Credit Suisse's new head of quantitative equity research, Matthew Rothman, is exploring the possibility of monetizing useful data, but is cautious about what information to share due to client concerns.

site_title: Yen gains broadly on latest bout of Korean tensions
summary: The yen strengthened against the US dollar and other currencies on Wednesday amid heightened tensions on the Korean Peninsula. North Korea threatened a missile strike on Guam, prompting US President Donald Trump to warn of "fire and fury." site_title: Europe's journeymen keep the past alive
summary: Young men and women from German-speaking countries, known as "wanderjungen," embark on a traditional journey to gather experience in various trades, adhering to strict rules and customs. site_title: Europe: Utilities, autos help European shares turn around, results weigh on Pandora
summary: European shares turned positive on Tuesday, driven by strong gains in utilities, auto, and energy stocks, which outweighed losses from Pandora after disappointing results. site_title: China developers sink as the world's biggest stock rally loses steam
summary: China's top-performing developers, including Evergrande and Country Garden, have seen significant declines after a record-breaking rally this year, with investors betting that the government's efforts to cool home prices will hurt sales in the second half. site_title: China July exports, imports weaker than expected
summary: China's exports and imports grew weaker than expected in July, with exports up 7.2% and imports up 11%, missing forecasts of 10.9% and 16.6% growth respectively. site_title: GLP's Q1 profit down 29% at US$144.2m on lower revaluations

site_title: Wisconsin won't break even on Foxconn plant incentives for 25 years: analysis
summary: Wisconsin is not projected to break even on a $3 billion incentive package for a proposed LCD screen plant by Foxconn for at least 25 years, according to a legislative analysis. State leaders, including Governor Scott Walker, have touted the incentives as a boon for the state. The analysis highlights concerns about the long-term financial burden of the incentives on Wisconsin.

site_title: Takata seeks to suspend air bag victims' lawsuits against carmakers
summary: Takata Corp's US business, facing tens of billions of dollars in liabilities, is seeking to suspend lawsuits against automakers for injuries caused by its faulty air bag inflators. Automakers including BMW, Ford, Honda, and Toyota support the request, arguing it would advance their interests and protect customer safety. Opponents say it's an abuse of bankruptcy laws and would delay compensation for injured drivers.

site_title: Australia's biggest bank scraps CEO's bonus

site_title: Latest from China: fabricated papers, fake peer reviews
summary: China has been rocked by a major academic fraud scandal, with 107 research papers retracted after discovering fabricated papers and fake peer reviews. site_title: VW offers discounts against dirty old diesels

site_title: Oil declines as supply concerns loom with summer season ending
summary: Oil prices declined as concerns about rising global supplies loomed, despite a recent decline in US stockpiles. Oil prices retreated below $50 a barrel amid concerns that OPEC's output cuts aren't rebalancing the market as expected. US crude output is forecast to rise to 9.91 million barrels per day in 2018, and the Energy Information Administration cut its WTI price forecast to $48.88 a barrel.

site_title: ARM bulks up staff and compensation after SoftBank acquisition
summary: ARM Holdings Plc posted a quarterly loss of $84.9 million due to increased headcount and compensation, as well as a one-time acquisition charge. ARM's customers signed 41 new processor licenses, up from 23 the previous year.

site_title: Stocks weaken ahead of National Day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 2.59 points to 3,318.08, its second consecutive decline, ahead of the National Day public holiday. DBS was the main driver of the decline, with its shares ending S$0.13 weaker at S$21.02. Traders attributed the bank's weakness to concerns over earnings and provisioning, with some analysts revising their estimates downwards. In contrast, UOL's shares rose 0.03 to S$8.13 after reporting a 59% increase in net attributable profit for the second quarter.

site_title: Understanding meaning of pragmatic leadership
summary: A pragmatic leader is one who takes actions to achieve desired outcomes without blindly adhering to past practices or ideologies. They prioritize results over consensus and are willing to make tough decisions. Examples of pragmatic leadership include Singapore's implementation of national service, revising population control policies, and allowing foreign workers. China's economic transformation under Deng Xiaoping is also attributed to pragmatic leadership, as he opened the country to foreign investments, encouraged private entrepreneurship, and lifted 700 million people out of poverty. In the corporate world, pragmatic decision-making was demonstrated by CapitaLand's venture into the Chinese real estate market, where they targeted an underserved market and took calculated risks to achieve success.

site_title: Bank of England sets out Brexit contingency planning issues
summary: The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority has reported that 147 banks and investment firms have submitted plans for a potential UK exit from the EU without an exit agreement by March 2019. The authority identified four main risks, including fragmentation of market-based finance, issues with existing contracts, and increased complexity for firms. The PRA expects to reach conclusions in autumn and is calling for a potential implementation period to allow UK and EU firms to adapt to the new relationship. The authority may face a significant burden on resources, which could impact its ability to supervise and resolve firms.

images.alt_text: The chief executive of the Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority said 147 banks and investment firms have given details on their plans for the eventuality the UK could leave the European Union in March 2019 without an exit agreement.

site_title: Surge in Class 8 truck orders a sign that US economy is picking up: analysts
summary: US economy shows signs of growth with surge in Class 8 truck orders, a 81% increase in July, the largest monthly jump in almost three years. Analysts attribute the rebound to increased residential construction and consumer purchases. Companies like Meritor and Cummins report higher revenue and full-year forecasts, driven by rising demand for trucks and construction equipment in North America and China.

site_title: Red and white show of cars

The event marks the start of Autobahn's National Day celebrations, which will continue with a parade of classic cars today.

site_title: Q2 fair-value gain lifts Perennial; group upbeat on China healthcare
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a surge in Q2 net profit to S$17.1 million, driven by a fair-value gain of S$16.6 million from the revaluation of Xi'an North High Speed Railway Integrated Development Plot 4. The company remains bullish on China's healthcare prospects and is capitalizing on its competitive advantage. Despite a 25.9% decline in revenue, Perennial's H1 2017 net profit rose to S$55.8 million, largely due to the divestment of a 20.2% equity stake in TripleOne Somerset.

site_title: Walmart heirs snap up British bikewear brand Rapha
summary: Walmart heirs Steuart and Tom Walton have acquired a majority stake in British bikewear brand Rapha, valuing the company at close to $255 million. Founded in 2004, Rapha has grown sales by 30% annually for 11 years, driven by the booming cycling market. The Walton brothers, avid cyclists, will continue to support Rapha's expansion, with a key focus on the US market, where cycling is the largest sports category.

site_title: Brexit is good news for shipping industry
summary: The UK's departure from the EU will give the shipping industry a significant advantage, as the UK will be able to act as a brake on unilateral EU action at the International Maritime Organization (IMO). This shift signals the end of the EU's high-handed and ill-judged involvement in shipping, which has led to consolidation and reduced competition. The UK's influence at IMO will increase, allowing it to speak authoritatively without EU constraints, and potentially curb EU excesses in global shipping policy debates.

site_title: China policies help drive gains in iron ore, steel
summary: China's steel and iron ore prices surged due to government-ordered capacity curbs and anti-pollution measures. Steel futures rose 6.3% and iron ore jumped 7.3% in Shanghai, with investors betting on tighter supply and sustained demand from massive infrastructure projects. The curbs, including a 50% output cut in Hebei province, are expected to reduce pollution and boost profit margins for steelmakers, driving up prices globally.

site_title: Bitcoin jumps by record 21% after miners' split
summary: Bitcoin surged by a record 21% to $3,423.37, surpassing its previous high, despite the recent split of its underlying technology. The increase came after the scaling debate between SegWit2x and Bitcoin Cash was put behind it. The cryptocurrency's value rose even after the division, showing its resilience. The gains are attributed to the market's optimism about the future of the digital currency.

site_title: Global confidence in the US is shaken
summary: Global confidence in the US has declined sharply under President Donald Trump, with a median of 22% of respondents expressing confidence in his ability to do the right thing in international affairs. The steepest decline is seen in advanced economies, with a median of 18% in Europe and 22% in Canada. In contrast, Russians and Israelis show greater support for Trump, with 53% and 56% confidence, respectively. Trump's policies, such as building a wall along the Mexican border, have also been unpopular globally, with a median of 83% of Latin Americans disapproving of the plan.

images.alt_text: President Trump and many of his key policies are broadly unpopular around the world.

site_title: Tokyo warns that North Korea may have nuclear-strike capability
summary: Tokyo's Ministry of Defence has warned that North Korea may have achieved nuclear-strike capability, citing the miniaturisation of nuclear weapons and acquired nuclear warheads. The warning comes amid a growing threat from North Korea's development of nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles. The Japanese government has pledged to step up pressure on North Korea through sanctions, and has asked Beijing to pressure Pyongyang. The US has also warned that North Korea's ICBM tests show the projectile weapons may now be able to reach most of the continental United States.

site_title: Drop in German trade activity feeds into global stimulus debate
summary: Germany's trade activity slowed in June with exports falling 2.8% and imports dropping 4.5%, the largest declines since 2015 and 2009, respectively. This signals a potential slowdown in demand for the leading economy, coinciding with central banks' consideration of scaling back stimulus. The drop in trade activity adds to global concerns about economic growth and the potential impact on stimulus policies.

site_title: China holds war games as N Korea tensions spike
summary: China's navy and air force conducted large-scale live-fire drills in the Yellow Sea and Bohai Gulf, amid heightened tensions with North Korea. The exercises included firing dozens of missiles, with naval and air force assets participating. The drills aim to test weapons and hone military abilities in coastal assaults and intercepting air targets. China's actions come days after backing a US-drafted UN Security Council resolution imposing stricter sanctions on North Korea.

site_title: China's leverage crackdown gets shrug from markets
summary: China's crackdown on financial leverage has not significantly concerned global investors, with the country's near 7% growth rate and stabilizing yuan helping to alleviate concerns. Fund managers have increased their allocation to Chinese stocks, citing an upgrade cycle in earnings. Capital controls and the dollar's decline have also contributed to the diminished worries about China. However, some experts warn that vulnerabilities remain, particularly if policymakers fail to implement an orderly deleveraging process, and the country's economic issues may become more apparent once the dollar stabilizes.

site_title: Tillerson in Thailand presses for more action on N Korea
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson visited Thailand, urging leaders to take action against North Korean front companies operating in Bangkok. He also pressed for support in handling North Korean refugees and a stronger democracy that respects human rights. Thailand's junta chief, Prayuth Chan-ocha, expressed support for a UN resolution on new sanctions, but made no specific action. Human rights groups are concerned about the re-establishment of normal relations, given Thailand's military crackdown on critics.

site_title: Venture Corp and Hi-P International sizzle
summary: Shares of Venture Corp and Hi-P International surged on Tuesday, driven by expectations of a better outlook for the tech sector, following the global technology boom. Venture Corp's shares rose 81 cents to close at S$15.70, while Hi-P International's shares jumped 7.5 cents to S$1.30. The companies' strong Q2 results, with Venture's net profit nearly doubling and Hi-P's net profit nearly doubling, contributed to the gains. Analysts predict continued growth in the tech sector, citing major product launches and strong demand for semiconductor-related services.

site_title: We are Singaporean, before anything else
summary: A Singaporean author reminisces about their primary school experience, where they wondered whether to sit with friends of the same ethnicity or language. However, the canteen was never segregated by race, and everyone sat together. The author notes this experience as a positive aspect of Singapore's multicultural society.

site_title: CBS's Q2 advertising sales up 4.3%, bucking trend
summary: CBS Corp reported a 4.3% increase in Q2 advertising sales, bucking the trend of declines or underwhelming forecasts from competitors. The network's broadcast of college basketball's national finals is believed to have contributed to this success. This follows drops from Time Warner Inc, Sinclair Broadcasting, and Viacom Inc, highlighting CBS's resilience in the challenging advertising climate.

site_title: Alibaba, Marriott team up to tap Chinese tourism boom
summary: Marriott International has partnered with Alibaba's Fliggy site to tap into China's booming tourism market. The partnership will feature Marriott's entire hotel line-up and link loyalty programs, promoting Chinese travelers. China is now the world's largest source of outbound travelers, with over $100 billion spent in 2016. The deal strengthens an existing partnership between Alibaba and Marriott, which aims to service the growing number of global travelers, particularly Chinese ones, and compete with alternative providers like Airbnb.

site_title: China's Sex And The City confronts awkward truths
summary: China's popular drama "Ode to Joy" has sparked controversy with its portrayal of sex, sexism, and status in socially conservative China. The show, which follows the lives of five young women, has been viewed 24 billion times online and has gained non-Chinese followers. The program reflects the changing mindset of China's urban middle class, where women are increasingly seeking equality and independence. The show's success has also led to increased discussions about topics such as virginity, class, and love, with some praising its realistic portrayal of challenges faced by women in China.

site_title: H-1B work visa programme benefits US, India: study
summary: A study by the Centre for Global Development and the University of Michigan found that the H-1B work visa programme provides economic benefits to both the US and India, despite criticism of its impact on American workers. The programme's combined incomes for the two countries rose by $17.3 billion in 2010, with US-born employees benefiting by $431 million. Total IT output also increased by 0.45% in 2010. The study acknowledges negative repercussions but concludes that the programme has overall economic benefits.

site_title: Sony designs digital 'fragrance Walkman'
summary: Sony is unveiling new digital products, including the Aromastic, a digital smell dispenser, and AeroSense self-flying drones, as part of its Seed Accelerator Program. The program aims to encourage innovation and risk-taking among employees, with over 1,600 employees participating since its launch in 2014. The company has seen a resurgence in innovation, with 12 new products developed, including the Aromastic, which was dubbed the "Walkman of fragrances." Analysts praise Sony's efforts to spur invention again, but note that the products are not yet making a significant contribution to the company's bottom line.

site_title: YZJ shares up again on strong Q2 results
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings posted a 73% surge in Q2 net profit to 719.9 million yuan due to higher revenue and lower finance costs. Revenue rose 27% to 3.79 billion yuan, driven by shipbuilding activities and a trading business boost. The company's gross margin slipped to 21% due to lower contract prices. Yangzijiang's outstanding order book stands at US$4 billion, with 85 vessels ordered. The stock rose 4.7% to S$1.55, making it the best-performing stock in 2017.

site_title: Centurion aims for HK presence with listing there
summary: Centurion Corporation Limited plans to establish a presence in the Hong Kong market through a secondary listing on the Hong Kong stock exchange, aiming to increase its investor base and brand presence. The company, which owns worker and student accommodation assets, also seeks to expand into the Middle East and China. Following a 72% year-on-year growth in net profit, Centurion plans to diversify its resources into student accommodation, with a goal of striking a balance between worker and student assets.

site_title: The importance of doing what you love
summary: A university student in Singapore expresses concern about the declining media industry, citing the budget cuts and staff reductions at major publications such as Fairfax Media and The New York Times. The student reflects on their own passion for journalism and the importance of doing what they love despite the challenges. This sentiment is echoed in a separate article about CEO salaries, highlighting the need for individuals to prioritize their passions and well-being.

site_title: Siemens to update medical scanner software to deal with security bugs
summary: Siemens plans to update software in its medical scanners by the end of the month to address vulnerabilities that could allow hackers to exploit the equipment. The US Department of Homeland Security had previously warned of the risks, and Siemens has assigned a security severity rating of 9.8 out of 10. Although no evidence of an attack has been found, the company initially advised hospital customers to disconnect the scanners until the update was released. The update aims to prevent cyber attacks on medical equipment, which has become a growing concern in recent years.

site_title: US$1,600 smartphone comes with concierge service
summary: A US$1,600 smartphone, the Appassionato, comes with a high-end concierge service overseen by a digital assistant named Sir Alan. Designed in Finland and manufactured in China, the phone features a 5.5-inch OLED screen and liquid metal construction. The concierge service, available to buyers willing to pay US$1,000 for a two-year subscription, offers services such as booking travel, making dinner reservations, and procuring concert tickets. Turing Robotic Industries, the company behind the phone, aims to differentiate itself in the competitive smartphone market with its luxury offering.

site_title: Flurry of activity in shares of obscure China stock draws authorities' attention
summary: China's Shanghai stock exchange has issued warnings to investors over unusual trading activity in Fangda Carbon New Material Co, a lesser-known Chinese stock that saw a 200% rally in shares since late June. The company's shares traded at a pace comparable to major global stocks like JPMorgan Chase, despite a relatively low market capitalization. This unusual activity has caught the attention of Chinese regulators, who have vowed to crack down on suspicious trading behavior, following a $5 trillion equity crash two years ago.

site_title: As the future beckons, fears mingle with hope
summary: Singaporean fresh graduates face uncertainty in securing internships and jobs, unlike their local counterparts who seem to find work with relative ease. Internships, once seen as a stepping stone to employment, have become increasingly competitive, with many students in the UK and US struggling to secure spots. The burden of student debt and collective global debt weighs heavily on young generations, with some nations struggling with aging populations and fewer able-bodied workers. However, Singapore's focus on job creation and fiscal responsibility may offer a silver lining for its young citizens.

images.alt_text: From left: Tan Jia Hui, Kimberly Chan, Syarafana Muhammad Shafeeq, Adeline Tan and Chin Yong Chang.
We were promised a secure economic future, but are instead saddled with debt, says Chin Yong Chang.

site_title: Gundlach, wary of pricey market, sets cap on DoubleLine's growth
summary: Jeffrey Gundlach, co-founder and CEO of DoubleLine Capital, is reducing his firm's exposure to overvalued assets like junk bonds and emerging-market debt. Gundlach is shifting towards higher-quality credits with less sensitivity to rising interest rates, aiming to maintain DoubleLine's outperformance while avoiding potential losses. Gundlach also plans to limit DoubleLine's growth, possibly stopping marketing once assets reach $150 billion, and prefers a diversified business with multiple funds rather than a single large one. Gundlach's cautious approach is out of step with the industry's focus on asset growth and scale.

site_title: State insurance officials seek backup plan faced with possibility of Trump's subsidy cuts
summary: State insurance officials are concerned about the potential loss of subsidies for millions of low-income people if President Trump cuts off payments to insurance companies. The subsidies, which reimburse insurers for reducing deductibles and out-of-pocket costs, are seen as crucial to maintaining coverage and insurer solvency. Without the subsidies, insurers may face large financial losses, leading to higher premiums and potentially fewer insurers participating in the individual market. State officials are debating how to mitigate the impact on consumers and are considering surcharges or alternative pricing strategies.

site_title: Taylor Swift in court as trial begins
summary: Taylor Swift's trial began against DJ David Mueller, who was accused of groping her at an event in 2013. Mueller, 54, is suing Swift for $3 million, claiming she caused him to lose his job. Swift countersued for sexual assault, alleging Mueller intentionally touched her. The trial, expected to last nine days, will determine whether Swift was indeed groped. The case aims to set a precedent for other women who may fear coming forward with similar allegations.

images.alt_text: Swift says radio DJ David Mueller grabbed her buttock during a visit backstage at the Pepsi Center in Denver in June 2013 before a concert.

site_title: Making the arts a national asset
summary: Singapore is embracing the arts as a national asset, with growing popularity and relevance among the public. Despite past skepticism, the country's arts scene is gaining traction, with notable successes such as Yayoi Kusama's exhibition and Sonny Liew's graphic novel "The Art of Charlie Chan Hock Chye" winning awards. The National Arts Council's decision to support the graphic novel has sparked important discussions about art and culture in Singapore, marking a shift towards a more progressive and inclusive approach.

site_title: US natural gas emerging as rival to Russia in Europe
summary: US natural gas production is surging, positioning the country to become a net exporter of energy next year, potentially challenging Russia's hold on the European market. US exports to Europe have grown to 13% of total shipments since 2016, with many projects underway to increase exports to the continent. Analysts predict US gas will first replace supplies from Britain and Holland, eventually replacing Norway, giving European countries a credible alternative to Russian gas.

site_title: Hotelier IHG posts slower Q2 RevPAR growth
summary: IHG reported slower Q2 RevPAR growth of 1.5% due to a later Easter weighing on its US performance, down from 2.7% in the first quarter and 2.5% in the same period last year. The company's shares dropped 4% in response. The decline was attributed to the Easter holiday falling in the second quarter, reducing business travel.

site_title: ThaiBev to buy KFC outlets in Thailand for 11.3b baht
summary: ThaiBev has agreed to buy over 240 existing KFC outlets in Thailand for 11.3 billion baht (S$463 million). An additional amount will be paid for outlets under development. The deal aims to scale up ThaiBev's presence in the food business, particularly in the fast food segment. The acquisition is expected to be completed by end-December, subject to regulatory approvals. This move will give ThaiBev direct access to multiple customer touch points across the country, enabling it to understand trends and stay at the forefront of the industry.

site_title: Architects, designers and refugees team up to build tiny houses in Berlin project
summary: Architect Van Bo Le-Mentzel and a team of architects, designers, and refugees in Berlin built 20 tiny houses, each measuring 10 square meters, to provide shelter and community space for asylum seekers and low-income locals. The tiny houses, built on wheels, will form a temporary village until March 2018 and serve as lodging, a library, cafe, workshop, and community center. The project aims to create affordable housing forms that allow people to live without land or money, with plans to expand into a larger building with compact apartments.

site_title: Jumbo profit down 1.1% at S$3.37m in Q3
summary: Jumbo Group reported a 1.1% decrease in net profit to S$3.37 million in Q3, despite a 6.4% year-on-year increase in revenue to S$34.81 million, driven by contributions from Singapore and China operations. Earnings per share remained flat at 0.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Cosco Shipping International narrowed its H1 17 net losses, thanks to a parent company buyout that eliminated insolvency risk. The company secured more orders at attractive prices, and productivity improvements could lead to a re-rated share price. Delfi Ltd reported Q2 17 revenue down 5.8% YoY, but PATMI increased 14.4% due to a one-off pre-tax divestment gain. China Everbright Water's revenue grew 30% YoY due to large projects, and its gross margin was held up despite higher construction revenue.

site_title: WannaCry-linked Bitcoin wallets emptied: analysts
summary: Three Bitcoin wallets linked to the WannaCry malware have been emptied, with the total value of 52 BTC (around $140,000) being divided into smaller amounts and sent to other addresses. The wallets were emptied between August 3-3:30 am GMT, and the money may have been moved to obscure its origins, similar to money laundering. Researchers have traced the bounty to its next destination, using a cryptocurrency conversion service called ShapeShift.io, which could potentially reveal the identities of the WannaCry attackers.

site_title: Airline workers warn of dangerous fumes in passenger cabins
summary: Airline workers are warning of a potential safety risk due to "toxic fume events" caused by engine oil vapors seeping into passenger cabins. These incidents, which have occurred 2.6 times a day, can cause breathing difficulties and force pilots to divert to the nearest airport. The US Senate has proposed the Cabin Air Safety Act, which would require airlines to install carbon monoxide sensors and train flight crews to identify fume events. The proposed law aims to improve safety and reporting of these incidents, which have been linked to engine seals deteriorating and synthetic engine oil fumes mixing with bleed air.

site_title: China to spend US$1.5t on outbound M&A in next decade
summary: China plans to spend approximately US$1.5 trillion on outbound mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in the next decade, a 70% increase from the previous 10 years. Despite regulatory blocks and concerns over national security, Chinese buyers will continue to pursue overseas investments due to government policies encouraging manufacturing capabilities and international trade. However, success will depend on overcoming foreign country concerns and liberalizing Chinese markets to international pressure.

site_title: US$ pulls back but fall cushioned by jobs data
summary: The US dollar weakened against its broad index, but maintained most of its gains from last week's strong US jobs data. The jobs data bolstered the view that the Federal Reserve may stay put on interest rate hikes in 2017. Despite concerns, the dollar clung to its gains, ending the week with a significant recovery. The strong jobs data was a positive indicator for the US economy, but the Federal Reserve's future rate hikes remain uncertain.

site_title: Singapore's economy to grow by 'around 2.5%' this year: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economy is forecasted to grow by around 2.5% this year, higher than last year's 2% growth. This announcement was made by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in his National Day Rally speech. The government will focus on improving the pre-school sector, addressing the diabetes problem, and advancing the Smart Nation drive.

site_title: How do you protect yourself from ransomware?
summary: A large-scale ransomware attack, WannaCrypt, has targeted Windows XP systems worldwide, encrypting files and demanding payment in exchange for restoration. To protect against such threats, a defence-in-depth approach is crucial, including strong endpoint protection, network isolation, and employee education on avoiding malware. Implementing fundamental security measures, such as patching vulnerable systems and upgrading end-of-life systems, can also help prevent initial infection. Taking a data-centric approach, backing up systems, and using cloud services with version history can limit exposure and undo damage in case of an attack.

site_title: Big Oil's dream of US$65b of crude fades away as Norway opts to defend natural wonder
summary: Norway is unlikely to lift a ban on drilling off the Arctic Lofoten islands, a natural wonder with significant cold-water coral reefs and seabird colonies, due to opposition from environmental groups and some politicians. The ban has been in place since a deadlock between the two main parties, Labour and Conservatives, over the issue. Industry groups argue that gaining access to the area is crucial for maintaining Norway's oil production, but opponents say it would harm the environment and breach the Paris climate accord. The deadlock has led to a stalemate, with the government estimating that Lofoten could hold 1.3 billion barrels of oil equivalent.

site_title: Mazda unveils plans to commercialise compression ignition petrol engine
summary: Mazda Motor Corp has announced plans to commercialize the world's first compression ignition petrol engine, called SKYACTIV-X, which it claims will be 20-30% more efficient than its current SKYACTIV-G engine. The engine will be introduced in Mazda's cars starting from 2019, as the company prioritizes internal combustion engines despite growing environmental regulations. Mazda also plans to start selling electric vehicles and autonomous driving technology in 2019, with a focus on markets that restrict the sale of other cars. The engine technology will not be supplied to other carmakers.

site_title: As Asean turns 50, the bloc must stay relevant or risk being left behind
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is celebrating its 50th anniversary, marking a milestone in the bloc's history. Asean's relevance is crucial as it faces growing opportunities and challenges, including the Rohingya issue in Myanmar, extremist terrorism, and the Marawi crisis in the Philippines. The bloc has made progress in creating an integrated market through the Asean Economic Community (AEC), but more work is needed to engage businesses and realize its full potential. Asean aims to strengthen its influence through regional initiatives, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, and pave the way for a code of conduct on maritime disputes with China.

site_title: For the love of sports, dive deep
summary: A Singaporean diver shares the challenges and triumphs of representing her country in international competitions. Born into a family of national athletes, she finds courage in balancing her passion for sports with her academic commitments. The country has made significant progress in sports since the 2010 Youth Olympic Games, with Singapore diving winning its first medal in 28 years. The author hopes for continued support and exposure for her sport, with the 29th SEA Games in Kuala Lumpur being a key opportunity.

images.alt_text: As Singapore grows a year older, my wish for Singapore is to keep that fighting spirit as my fellow athletes compete later this month this at the 29th SEA Games in Kuala Lumpur, says Kimberly Chan.
Ms Chan executing a dive at the 2015 SEA Games.

site_title: German financial watchdog investigating carmakers 'cartel'
summary: Germany's financial regulator, BaFin, is investigating whether Volkswagen and Daimler failed to notify investors about secret talks with other carmakers, potentially amounting to collusion. The talks allegedly occurred since the 1990s and involved technical, purchasing, and marketing details, as well as emissions levels. If found guilty, VW and Daimler could face fines of up to 5% of their annual revenue, potentially reaching billions of dollars. The investigation follows a report from German business daily Handelsblatt and the European Commission's own probe into the discussions.

site_title: In search of a Japanese Macron-like saviour
summary: Japan's politics has returned to a "single-party democracy" with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Liberal Democratic Party firmly in control. The main opposition Democratic Party has collapsed, giving the electorate little chance of changing the ruling party. A search for a "Japanese Macron" to save the country from totalitarianism has begun, but it's unclear where such a saviour will come from. Japan's stagnant politics and declining voter ratings have raised concerns about the country's future.

site_title: 1MDB gets 2nd payment reprieve but must cough up US$310m in 5 days
summary: 1MDB has been given a second extension until Aug 31 to pay US$629 million to IPIC, but must hand over at least US$310 million by Aug 12. Default interest has been added due to the missed payment deadline. The chairman stated that redemption of funds would "take time, which we didn't foresee."

site_title: Funds target 'unknown' stocks as Wall St cuts analyst jobs
summary: Wall Street analysts are cutting coverage of small-cap companies, leaving them untracked by major research firms. This shift has created opportunities for fund managers to buy into companies with no analyst coverage, hoping they will be undervalued. Since 2017, the number of small-cap companies with no formal attention from Wall Street research firms has jumped 30%, including household names like Tootsie Roll Industries and Revlon. The decline in research coverage has led to a greater chance of mispriced stocks, giving firms with in-house research an advantage.

images.alt_text: With a nearly 30 per cent gain in 2017, shares of industrial products maker Handy & Harman Ltd are outpacing hot stocks like Google's parent Alphabet Inc and Visa Inc.

site_title: Pressure on fees spreads to wealth management sector
summary: Wealth management firms' revenue stagnated last year despite a 4% increase in assets, highlighting the pressure on fees. Companies responded by cutting expenses to achieve a cost-income ratio below 80% for the first time since 2012. Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse, under turnaround plans, fell behind competitors, while UBS Group, Bank of America, and Morgan Stanley retained their top spots. The industry expects to consolidate, with most predicting a decline in profit margins and an increase in passive investing due to a new US rule requiring financial advisers to act in clients' best interests.

site_title: Facilitate, don't dictate
summary: As IT departments adapt to a changing work environment, they're shifting from a dictatorial approach to a facilitative one, enabling employees to use the tools they love while maintaining data security. By understanding users' needs and preferences, IT managers can set guidelines for cloud use and empower teams to adopt secure collaboration tools. This approach not only secures data but also fosters creativity, productivity, and business growth, positioning IT as a partner at the table with business leaders.

site_title: Libyan oil field 'back to normal' after protests
summary: Libya's largest oil field, Sharara, has resumed normal operations after a disruption caused by protests, according to the National Oil Corp. Pumping was halted for hours after armed protesters shut some facilities, but no explanation was given. The field, which produces 275,000 barrels a day, has experienced several brief shutdowns due to protests. Libya's crude output has reached a three-year high, making it harder for Opec to curb global supply, which is contributing to depressed oil prices. The country's oil production was boosted to 865,000 barrels a day in July.

site_title: Private condo resale prices fall 0.5% in July
summary: Resale prices of private condominiums in Singapore fell 0.5% in July, despite a year-on-year increase of 2%. The Core Central Region and Rest of Central Region saw a 0.6% and 0.4% price increase, respectively, while the Outside Central Region saw a 1.9% decrease. This decline is attributed to a correction after resale prices rose 2.7% from January to June. Year-to-date, prices have increased 2.2%, with consultants predicting a possible increase in prices next year due to new projects coming to the market.

site_title: BOJ urged to dial back stimulus before inflation hits
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is urged to dial back its massive stimulus before inflation hits its 2% target, according to former deputy governor Kazumasa Iwata. Iwata criticizes the central bank's price forecasts as too optimistic and warns that even hitting 1% inflation could be challenging. He recommends slowing bond buying to 40 trillion yen, citing the need for a more sustainable policy. The BOJ's prolonged ultra-easy policy is putting strain on banks and financial markets, with inflation currently at 0.4%. Iwata's views are closely watched as he is considered a contender to replace governor Haruhiko Kuroda.

site_title: Berkshire close to holding record US$100b in cash
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, holds nearly $100 billion in cash at the end of the second quarter, a record high. The conglomerate's cash pile is a burden, as it doesn't pay dividends and rarely buys back its own stock, prompting Buffett to find ways to invest. Despite the challenge of finding attractive deals in a years-long bull market, Buffett remains optimistic, citing history on his side. Recent investments include a stake in Apple and a deal to buy Texas's largest electric utility, with more deals expected in the future.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:

Shares of UOL Group, Neo Group, QAF Ltd, Boustead Projects, Bonvests Holdings, Fraser and Neave, and Hong Leong Finance were reported on August 8, 2017. Fraser and Neave's third-quarter net profit jumped to S$1.26 billion, driven by an exceptional gain from its Vietnam Dairy Products Joint Stock Co acquisition.

site_title: AEM on lookout for innovative firms
summary: AEM Holdings, a Singapore-based company, plans to acquire smaller firms with innovative technology or processes within the next 18-24 months to broaden its capabilities and increase global presence. The company's chairman, Loke Wai San, stated that target firms must have unique manufacturing processes or technology that allows for efficient production. This move comes after the company's stronger-than-expected Q2 results, with revenue increasing 264.4% and net profit more than six times the previous year. AEM aims to achieve revenue and operating profit targets of at least S$200 million and S$24 million, respectively, for FY2017.

site_title: China's hotpot billionaire ready to take on the world
summary: China's hotpot billionaire Zhang Yong, co-founder and chairman of Haidilao, is expanding the chain's stores to 80 more this year, with 10 overseas. The company, which has 196 outlets in 60 Chinese cities, aims to increase revenue by 30% to $2.03 billion. Zhang, who started with a monthly salary of $93, credits his success to customer service, treating employees well, and promoting from within. Haidilao's unique service, including nail and shoulder massages, and generous perks, has led to low employee turnover in China's high-churn service industry.

site_title: Thanks to Brexit, the Irish countryside is more popular than ever
summary: Ireland's countryside is experiencing a surge in popularity since Brexit, with nearly a dozen heritage properties being refurbished and targeted for renovations. Investors are seizing on great deals, with the potential to save on construction costs, and are benefiting from skilled British construction and restoration work. Tourism from outside Europe is surging, with non-European, non-British travelers increasing travel spending by over 20% year-to-date. Ireland is expected to achieve 3.5% gross domestic product growth this year and 3.2% in 2018, making it the fastest-growing economy in the European Union for the fourth consecutive year.

site_title: David Letterman returns to television with 2018 Netflix series
summary: David Letterman is returning to television with a six-episode talk show on Netflix, set to premiere next year. The show will feature interviews with "extraordinary people" and segments from the field, showcasing Letterman's curiosity and humor. This marks Letterman's first television appearance since leaving "The Late Show" in 2015, and follows Netflix's growing original content slate, which includes shows like "Chelsea" with Chelsea Handler. Letterman, 70, expressed excitement and gratitude for the opportunity, stating he feels lucky to be working on the project.

site_title: Michael Kors profit falls 15%
summary: Michael Kors reported a 15% drop in quarterly profit to $125.5 million, or 80 cents per share, due to decreased sales to department stores. Total revenue fell 3.6% to $952.4 million. Despite the decline, the company raised its annual revenue forecast.

site_title: Cashless future? S'pore needs bolder, overarching plan
summary: Singapore's push towards a cashless society is hindered by a lack of a comprehensive plan, despite recent developments such as the launch of PayNow, a bank-agnostic fund transfer service. The country is behind China, which has successfully implemented WeChat and Alipay for mobile payments, and has a booming e-commerce scene that drives payments away from cash. Singapore's banks have made progress in cashless and mobile technologies, but their efforts are fragmented, and the focus on being the "first and only" bank to achieve something is not contributing to a unified plan. A bolder, overarching plan is needed to transform Singapore into a cashless society and forget the use of cash and cheques.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as investors seek fresh catalysts
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on Tuesday as investors awaited new catalysts, despite a largely positive earnings season. The Dow Jones fell 30.99 points, the S&P 500 lost 4.12 points, and the Nasdaq dropped 9.09 points. The recent record rally is nearing its end, with investors seeking fresh drivers for the market.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank scraps CEO bonus over money-laundering allegations
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia has scrapped its CEO's bonus due to damaging the bank's reputation amid allegations of 53,700 money-laundering and counter-terrorism financing breaches. The bank's shares slid for their biggest one-day decline in 18 months following the allegations. The case is Australia's largest corporate history, with the financial intelligence agency launching a civil court action that could result in a multi-billion dollar fine. Despite this, the bank's board maintains confidence in its CEO.

site_title: China's Sichuan hit by 6.5 magnitude quake
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck a remote region of Sichuan province in southwest China late Tuesday, with no immediate information on damage or casualties. The epicentre was 284km north of Chengdu, China's provincial capital. This quake occurred near the site of a 2008 8.0-magnitude earthquake that killed 87,000 people. China frequently experiences earthquakes, particularly in its mountainous western and south-western regions.

site_title: CFA pass rate for June Level 3 exam holds at highest since 2006
summary: The CFA Institute announced that the pass rate for the June Level 3 exam is 54%, matching the success rate in June 2016, the highest since 2006. A record 31,631 people took the third test, with almost 152,000 taking all three parts, a 10% increase over last year. Successful candidates study an average of 1,000 hours for the exams. The fastest growth in test takers was in China, surpassing the US for the second consecutive year.

site_title: China Everbright Water secures phase 3 of Jiangyin Chengxi wastewater treatment project
summary: China Everbright Water has signed a supplemental agreement for Phase 3 of the Jiangyin Chengxi wastewater treatment project in Jiangsu province, with an investment of approximately 161 million yuan (S$32.7 million). The 30-year concession period project will increase the company's total daily treatment capacity to 220,000 cubic meters, serving areas including Shengang, Ligang, and Xiagang in the Lingang Development Zone.

site_title: EU approves Banco Popular rescue by Santander
summary: The European Commission has approved the acquisition of Spanish bank Banco Popular by Santander, marking the first major test of Europe's new banking rescue system. The sale, which was initially allowed by the European Central Bank for a symbolic fee, was deemed to not raise competition concerns. The combined market share of the two banks will be less than 25%, with strong competitors remaining in affected markets. The Spanish government praised the move, stating it preserved people's savings and avoided public funds expenditure.

site_title: Indian state to give property rights to slum dwellers in 'historic' step
summary: Odisha, a state in eastern India, has approved ordinances to grant land and property rights to approximately 200,000 slum dwellers, benefiting tens of thousands of residents. The decision, considered "historic," aims to improve living conditions by providing heritable, mortgageable, and non-transferable rights to residential land. This move addresses the concerns of slum dwellers, who often face eviction and harassment, and will enable redevelopment of slum settlements.

site_title: Putin's aide seeks US$100m to rival China in bitcoin mining
summary: Russian Miner Coin, co-owned by President Vladimir Putin's internet adviser, plans to raise US$100 million through an initial coin offering (ICO) to support Russian bitcoin mining. The company aims to challenge China's dominance in the sector. Investors will buy RMC tokens, which will give them 18% of the revenue earned by the company's mining equipment. This move could help Russian entrepreneurs compete with Chinese miners, who currently hold a significant market share.

site_title: US jobs openings surge to record high in June
summary: US job openings reached a record high in June, increasing 461,000 to 6.2 million, the highest level since 2000. The hiring rate remained unchanged at 3.7%, but the gap between openings and hiring suggests a skills mismatch. This marks the largest monthly increase in job openings since July 2015, pushing the job openings rate to a near one-year high of 4%.

site_title: Ralph Lauren's quarterly results beat on lower discounting
summary: Ralph Lauren reported a quarterly profit and sales beat, with shares rising 5% in premarket trading. The luxury apparel maker maintained a tight inventory and reduced discounting, a strategy to turn its business around. Despite weak sales due to sluggish spending and competition from Amazon and fast-fashion retailers, the company is pulling back inventory and shuttering underperforming brands. This move is part of its efforts to revamp its business and regain market share.

site_title: Time misses revenue estimates as advertising sales slip
summary: Time, publisher of Fortune and Time magazines, reported a lower-than-expected quarterly revenue due to declines in magazine sales and advertising revenue. Circulation revenue fell 12.3% to $207 million, and advertising revenue declined 12% to $374 million, driven by print and digital advertising drops. The decline was attributed to a shift in consumer behavior and increased competition in the media industry.

site_title: UOL's whitewash resolution for share swap is 'fair and reasonable': IFA
summary: UOL Group's independent financial adviser has advised shareholders to vote in favor of waiving their rights to a mandatory general offer from Haw Par Corporation. The proposed share swap, which involves issuing 27.3 million new shares in UOL in exchange for 60 million shares in United Industrial Corporation, is deemed "fair and reasonable" by the IFA. The transaction is seen as normal commercial terms, not prejudicial to UOL's interests or minority shareholders. An extraordinary general meeting will be held on August 24 to finalize the proposal.

site_title: South Korean court orders Japan's Mitsubishi to pay for war labour
summary: A South Korean court ordered Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to pay 120 million won (S$145,060) in compensation to a former wartime slave worker and his relative. The ruling comes after a district court in Gwangju found Mitsubishi liable for the workers' treatment during Japan's colonial rule. Mitsubishi has announced it will appeal the decision, but the ruling marks a significant step in South Korea's efforts to hold Japanese companies accountable for wartime labor abuses.

site_title: Fragrance Group's Q2 profit rises 3.1%
summary: Fragrance Group reported a 3.1% increase in net profit to S$3.8 million for the second quarter ended June 30, driven by a 14% rise in turnover to S$35 million. The company's six-month net profit rose 2.3% to S$9.2 million, with the City Gate project contributing substantially to the revenue increase. Shares in Fragrance closed 0.1 cent higher at S$0.168.

site_title: Manulife US Reit beats Q2 forecasts; DPU of 1.58 US cents
summary: Manulife US Reit posted better-than-expected Q2 results, with a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.58 US cents, surpassing projections by 7.5%. Net property income rose to US$12.79 million, driven by rental escalations and higher car park income. The Reit's gearing was reduced to 30.4% and it has further debt headroom for future acquisitions. A mortgage facility of up to US$51.6 million was secured for its new office property in New Jersey. Despite signs of weakness in occupancies and easing rental growth, analysts remain positive on the Reit's outlook.

site_title: American Airlines dodges unwelcome embrace as Qatar Airways moves on
summary: Qatar Airways dropped plans to invest in American Airlines following a chilly reception from the US carrier, citing the "latest public disclosure" by American without elaborating. This decision marks a victory for American Airlines CEO Doug Parker, who had expressed concerns about the proposed stake purchase. American Airlines has been fighting a battle against Qatar Airways and other Persian Gulf carriers, accusing them of getting unfair advantages from US$50 billion in alleged government subsidies. The decision does not change American's course, with the company saying it will continue to pursue its objectives through alternative investment opportunities.

site_title: Singapore economy to grow by 'around 2.5 per cent' in 2017: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow by around 2.5% in 2017, higher than last year's 2% growth, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The Ministry of Trade and Industry has maintained its GDP growth forecast at 1-3%. Lee emphasized the need to transform industries and prepare for the future economy, citing the risk of protectionism from international trade. He also highlighted the importance of using information technology to create opportunities and jobs, and becoming a "Smart Nation."

site_title: Singapore Reits chalk up average total return of 17.6% year-to-date
summary: Singapore Reits have achieved an average total return of 17.6% for the year to Aug 4, with some Reits like CDL Hospitality Trusts showing a 30% return. Institutions have been net buyers of Reits for four consecutive months, with cumulative inflows of S$133.6 million. The Reit industry's volatility has decreased compared to the same period last year, with the SGX Reit 20 Index generating an 18.8% total return.

site_title: Google fires engineer whose memo advances gender bias
summary: Google has fired an engineer, James Damore, for writing an internal memo that argued women are biologically unsuited for tech and leadership positions. The memo sparked a firestorm and Damore confirmed his dismissal, stating he was fired for "perpetuating gender stereotypes". This incident is the latest in a string of gender bias and diversity issues in the tech industry, following scandals at Uber and a 2015 lawsuit against Kleiner Perkins. Damore plans to explore legal remedies, while the incident highlights the need for greater diversity and inclusion in the tech sector.

site_title: BHG Retail Reit's Q2 DPU flat at 1.35 cents
summary: BHG Retail Reit's Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) remained flat at 1.35 Singapore cents, despite a 4.4% increase in income available for distribution to S$4.92 million. Gross revenue grew 3.2% to S$15.86 million, and net property income rose 5.7% to S$10.9 million. The company attributed the results to higher rental reversion and occupancy rates, offsetting the impact of a nationwide VAT reform in China.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1, while London's Heathrow considers higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are expanding cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance's Q2 profit rises 89%
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 89% year-over-year increase in Q2 profit to S$20.87 million, driven by a 25.3% rise in net interest income and fee/commission income growth of 30.8%. Interest expenses fell 30.2% due to lower deposits and interest rates. Staff costs decreased 6.4% due to lower bonus provisions. An interim dividend of four cents per share will be paid out on September 12, up from three cents last year.

images.alt_text: Hong Leong Finance's profit for the second quarter ended June 30 jumped around 89 per cent year on year to S$20.87 million from the corresponding quarter last year.

site_title: Food company QAF's Q2 profit plunges 72%
summary: Food company QAF reported a 72% plunge in net profit for its fiscal second quarter ended June 30, 2017, to S$8.1 million, down from S$28.8 million the year before. The decline was partly due to selling 20% of Gardenia Bakeries, which no longer consolidated into the group's operating profits. Revenue improved slightly to S$209.8 million. QAF shares closed at S$1.30, half a cent lower.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks close up
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.59% to 27,854.91, while Shanghai's benchmark index edged up 0.07% to 3,281.87. China's trade growth in July missed forecasts. Despite this, Hong Kong maintained its recent rally, while Shanghai closed slightly higher.

site_title: Tillerson in Thailand presses for more action on North Korea
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson visited Thailand, pressing leaders for more action against North Korea, particularly shutting down front companies active in the country. Thailand supports a UN resolution on new sanctions, but Tillerson emphasized the need for more concrete action. The US also urged Thailand to take in North Korean refugees and to improve its human rights record, amid concerns about the junta's crackdown on critics. Thailand's trade surplus with the US was also a point of discussion, with the US seeking to reduce the imbalance.

site_title: Shell begins restart of Europe's largest oil refinery
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has restarted a number of units at the 404,000 barrels per day Pernis oil refinery in the Netherlands, six weeks after shutting down most of the site due to a power outage. The restart will take place in a controlled manner, with no details provided on which units are resuming operations. The power outage occurred on July 29, and the complete restart is expected to occur in the coming days.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell said on Tuesday it was restarting a number of units at the 404,000 barrels per day Pernis oil refinery in the Netherlands after shutting down most of the site on July 30.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge down despite foreign buying, won up
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.2% on Tuesday, despite foreign investors adding 89.6 billion won to their portfolios, as local institutions sold a net 153.9 billion won worth of shares. Weaker-than-expected Chinese import and export data contributed to the cautious mood, with Hyundai Motor Co and Kia Motors Corp also experiencing losses. The South Korean won rose 0.2% to 1,125.1 to the US dollar.

site_title: Merkel rival wants to stay SPD leader if loses election
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's rival Martin Schulz stated he wants to remain as leader of the Social Democrats (SPD) even if his party loses the federal election on September 24. This comes as polls show the SPD trailing Merkel's conservatives by 12-18 points. Schulz, a former European Parliament president, aims to stay in the position despite the party's potential defeat, citing the possibility of longer terms for its leaders. Merkel is expected to win a fourth term, and the outcome of the election remains uncertain, with possible alliances with other parties.

site_title: Volkswagen offers rebates in Germany to trade in dirty diesel cars
summary: Volkswagen is offering up to 10,000 euros to German drivers to trade in older diesel cars for newer models, intensifying efforts to reduce emissions amid crackdowns. The incentives apply to trade-ins of models from any manufacturer, with Audi and Porsche also offering similar rebates. The move aims to update pollution-control software on 5.3 million diesel cars and take trade-ins of older models that can't be upgraded, estimated to cost 500 million euros.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG is offering as much as 10,000 euros (S$16,068.3) to drivers in Germany willing to trade in older diesel cars for a newer auto, intensifying a push to get aging vehicles off the road amid intensifying crackdowns on emissions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.740 points to 1,781.650 on Tuesday, driven by higher volumes of 2.093 billion lots worth RM2.256 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 602 to 269.

site_title: Fund outflows pressure Standard Life shares ahead of Aberdeen merger
summary: Standard Life shares fell 1.4% to 437 pence ahead of an £11 billion merger with Aberdeen Asset Management, creating Britain's largest active manager. The merger aims to save at least £200 million annually and follow industry consolidation due to competition from lower-cost index funds. Despite a 6% increase in first-half operating profit, Standard Life's flagship multi-asset strategy saw £5.6 billion in net outflows. Analysts are cautious about the merger, citing concerns over joint CEO roles.

site_title: Hotelier IHG revenue per room growth hit by timing of Easter holiday
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG) reported slower global revenue per room growth in the second quarter, with a 1.5% increase, down from 2.7% in the first quarter. The decline was attributed to a later Easter holiday, which typically attracts more business travelers. Despite this, IHG's operating profit for the first six months rose 8% to US$370 million. The company plans to focus on business customers and increase efficiency to drive growth, with a focus on strengthening its brand portfolio and investing in high-opportunity markets.

site_title: Jumbo's Q3 profit edges down 1.1%
summary: Jumbo Group posted a 1.1% dip in its net profit for the third quarter ended June 30, reaching S$3.37 million. Revenue rose 6.4% year-over-year to S$34.81 million, driven by contributions from Singapore and China operations. Earnings per share remained flat at 0.5 Singapore cents. The company expects the food and beverage industry to remain challenging, but plans to leverage its brands and talents to stay competitive.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Resale prices of private condominiums and apartments fell 0.5% in July, according to SRX data. The Singapore government ranked first globally for its use of ICT to improve services for the third consecutive year. The Sultan of Johor expressed concerns over the proposed design of the Singapore-Johor Rapid Transit System. SMRT Buses will start bus services at the Bukit Panjang Integrated Transport Hub on September 4. A court rejected Soh's bid to obtain prosecution documents related to the 2013 penny stock crash. UOB Kay Hian issued a 'buy' call on Kimly Limited with a target price of S$0.46.

site_title: Singapore government tops global list for use of ICT to improve services: Waseda-IAC survey
summary: Singapore's government has topped a global list for the third consecutive year in 2017 for its use of information and communication technology (ICT) to improve services, according to a Waseda University Institute of e-Government survey. The city-state beat 64 other economies, with high mobile penetration and over 300 mobile services, exceeding Apec average scores. Singapore scored well in network infrastructure, online services, and cybersecurity, but has potential to grow its use of emerging technologies.

site_title: F&N's Q3 profit jumps to S$1.3b on recognition of Vinamilk fair-value reserves
summary: F&N's third-quarter net profit surged to S$1.26 billion, or 87 Singapore cents per share, driven by an exceptional gain of S$1.20 billion from recognizing Vinamilk's fair-value reserves. Excluding exceptional items, net profit would have risen 59.9% to S$60.7 million. Revenue slipped 8.6% to S$483.1 million, but profit before tax and interest rose 33.2% to S$78.2 million. F&N expects a subdued market for food and beverages but sees opportunities in Vietnam and Myanmar.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 2.59 points to 3,318.08, marking the second consecutive day of losses. Brokers attributed the decline to cautious sentiment ahead of the National Day public holiday. The index, which had reached an all-time high earlier in the week, ended the day with 238 rises and 210 falls, resulting in 1.9 billion units worth S$1.3 billion in turnover.

site_title: This obscure China stock is suddenly trading more than JPMorgan
summary: Fangda Carbon New Material, a Chinese graphite electrode maker, has seen its shares trade at a pace similar to top-tier stocks like JPMorgan, despite a market capitalization of $8.4 billion. The company's shares jumped to the 11th most-traded stock globally, sparking questions about the sudden surge. The reasons behind this unexpected move are unclear, leaving investors and analysts puzzled.

site_title: Boustead Projects' Q1 profit falls 5%
summary: Boustead Projects reported a 5% drop in net profit to S$5.8 million in Q1, mainly due to lower other income and higher overhead expenses. Revenue fell 25% to S$45.7 million, driven by lower contributions from design-and-build and leasing businesses. Earnings per share decreased to 1.8 cents, and no dividend was recommended. Despite this, shares rose 0.5 cents to finish at 90.5 cents.

site_title: China July trade surplus with US slips to US$25.2b
summary: China's trade surplus with the US in July decreased to $25.2 billion, down from $25.4 billion in June. For the first seven months of the year, China's trade surplus with the US reached $142.75 billion.
