Experts estimate that California's forests hold 41 times more solid fertilizers and 80 times more liquid pesticides than previously reported. Exposure to these chemicals has hospitalized law enforcement officials and suspects, and cleanup efforts are costly, with some sites costing up to $100,000 to clean up. The state is still developing a licensing system for growers, despite the environmental risks.

site_title: Luxury sales outpace overall car market
summary: Luxury car sales outpaced the overall car market in Singapore, with 10,399 new mass luxury cars registered in the first six months of 2017, a 11.4% increase from the same period last year. German luxury brands, particularly Mercedes-Benz, Audi, and BMW, led the segment, with Mercedes-Benz experiencing the largest year-to-date growth. The introduction of premium entry-level cars has changed consumer behavior, with 59% of the premium market now comprised of entry-level vehicles. Luxury brands such as Land Rover and Jaguar also saw significant gains, with Land Rover experiencing a 35% increase in sales.

images.alt_text: The mass luxury car segment is outpacing the overall market as premium brands expand into the volume segment by offering a wider range of models with more accessible pricing.

site_title: Inflation, earnings and Mueller probe may crimp US stock gains
summary: US stocks hit new records after a strong jobs report, but gains may be short-lived due to potential inflation concerns and disappointing earnings reports from retailers and media companies. The unemployment rate fell to a 16-year low, but wage inflation remained stuck at 2.5%. The Federal Reserve may delay interest rate hikes if inflation remains low. Meanwhile, President Trump's legal worries and a weakening economy could crimp stock gains.

site_title: China set to overtake US as world's biggest oil importer this year
summary: China is poised to overtake the US as the world's biggest oil importer this year, driven by a surge in refining capacity and exports. China imported 8.55 million barrels per day in the first half of the year, surpassing the US's 8.12 million barrels per day. This shift highlights the growing influence of Asia in global oil markets, with Chinese state-run oil trader Unipec becoming the world's biggest physical oil trader. China's export-oriented refiners, particularly in Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan, will be most affected by the competition.

site_title: Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob to run in EP
summary: Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob has announced her candidacy for the upcoming presidential election in Singapore, making her the first woman to run for the highest office in the land. She will resign from her post and the People's Action Party, and has begun extensive consultations with her family and colleagues. Halimah, 62, has met with various groups and residents, and has expressed her passion to serve all Singaporeans, despite the heavy responsibility of the role.

site_title: Bank of Singapore revs up businesses of next-gen clients
summary: Bank of Singapore organized a three-day business management course for the next generation of its clients, resulting in one fledgling business quadrupling its revenue from three years ago. Private banks in Singapore are now offering wealth management training programs for their clients' children to prepare them for managing wealth and businesses. This initiative aims to equip the next generation with relevant skills and knowledge to succeed in managing family businesses or their own ventures.

site_title: Iron's in a sweet spot with good profits, little new supply
summary: Vale, the world's largest iron ore producer, says the industry is in a "sweet spot" with prices between US$60 and US$70, generating a tidy profit but not enough to lure new supply. Prices have rallied to almost US$95 in February before falling to US$53, but are now above US$70 due to increased demand from Chinese steel mills. However, Barclays predicts prices will average US$50 in the final three months due to falling steel prices hurting mills' margins.

site_title: Stretched valuations for every major asset class
summary: US stocks have reached record levels, with the Dow Jones Index crossing 22,000, amid heightened partisan conflict in the US government. The Partisan Conflict Index is at an all-time high, suggesting greater tension among politicians and Congress. President Trump's recent firing of his communications director demonstrates the chaos in US politics. This increase in political antagonism is seen as beneficial for US stocks, and by extension, other equity markets. Singapore stocks have also seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Female gamers out in force for Tencent's Honour of Kings
summary: Tencent's Honour of Kings has achieved the highest proportion of female players for a hard-core or battle-arena title, with 54.1% of users as of May, surpassing the 35% average for similar games on computers or consoles. The game's success can be attributed to its bite-sized match-ups, broader playable characters, and social media integration via WeChat. This shift marks a significant departure from the traditionally male-dominated gaming industry, with experts predicting Honour of Kings' revenue could reach $3 billion this year.

site_title: Strong jobs data set to spur Fed to trim bond portfolio
summary: The US economy added 209,000 jobs in July, beating expectations, with average hourly earnings rising 0.3% and wages increasing 2.5% year-over-year. This data suggests the Federal Reserve may delay raising interest rates until December, despite near full employment. The Fed is expected to announce a plan to start shrinking its massive bond portfolio in September, with economists citing a strong labor market and benign inflation as reasons for this decision.

site_title: UAW accuses Nissan of 'scare tactics' as workers reject union bid
summary: Workers at a Nissan plant in Mississippi overwhelmingly rejected a union bid, with 60% of the 3,500 employees voting against it. The United Automobile Workers (UAW) criticized the "scare tactics" used by Nissan. This is the latest setback in the UAW's efforts to organize car plants in the region, which has been a long-standing challenge. The union has been repeatedly frustrated in its organizing efforts, with this election marking another significant defeat.

site_title: Innovation needs to involve all employees
summary: Family businesses must nurture a workplace culture that supports innovation, empowering all employees to think creatively and contribute to idea generation, according to KPMG Singapore. Current research shows that innovation is mostly limited to founders and senior staff, and many family businesses lack existing plans to build a culture of innovation. Experts emphasize the need for a decentralized decision-making model, tone from the top, and a mindset shift towards proactive innovation and disruption.

site_title: Gold: The beginning of a secular bull market to US$1,920
summary: Gold prices are expected to continue their secular uptrend, with a potential target of US$1,920, following the December 2016 low of US$1,153. The current bull run is part of an eight-year cyclical pattern, with the previous cycle lasting from 2008 to 2016. The cyclical bottom is expected to hold, and the bull market is expected to last three to four years, with near-term levels to watch including US$1,300 resistance and US$1,200 support areas.

site_title: NZ's immigration debate hots up ahead of Sept election
summary: New Zealand's immigration debate intensifies ahead of the September election, with the government facing opposition from parties who argue that mass immigration is exacerbating a housing crisis and stretching social services. The country has seen a record 131,000 migrants in the past year, with permanent arrivals outnumbering departures for five consecutive years. Labour proposes cutting the inflow by up to 30,000 a year, while New Zealand First calls for steeper cuts. The debate may influence the election, which polls show is too close to call.

site_title: Canadian $ falls as US jobs data boosts greenback
summary: The Canadian dollar fell 0.5% to its weakest close in over two weeks against the US dollar, trading at 79.05 US cents, following a strong US jobs report and a jump in Canada's trade deficit. The US jobs report showed a surge in employment and wage growth, boosting the greenback. Canada's trade deficit swelled to $3.60 billion in June, with energy shipments weighing on exports. Despite this, the Canadian dollar has rallied 9% since May, driven by the Bank of Canada's interest rate hike.

site_title: M'sia retrenchment fund needs fine-tuning: bosses
summary: Malaysia's proposed Employment Insurance System (EIS) fund is facing criticism from employers and stakeholders, who claim it raises more questions than answers and may disincentivize retrenched employees from seeking re-employment quickly. The fund, which aims to provide three months of wages to retrenched workers, has concerns over its management, contributions, and potential impact on employers. Experts suggest the fund should be kept simple and proportionate to needs, with alternatives such as modifying contributions to the Employees Pension Fund (EPF) being explored.

site_title: Starburst - has the turnaround been factored in?
summary: Starburst Holdings' warrant has almost doubled in value since the start of the year, selling for S$0.155, which is in-the-money due to its exercise price of S$0.25. The company reported a turnaround in its first quarter, with a net profit of S$400,000 compared to a net loss in the previous period. The warrant's decent gearing and sufficient time until expiry in June 2021 make it worth considering. However, it remains to be seen whether the company's recent performance has already been factored into the current share price.

site_title: Huang Jing quits Keppel Land board
summary: Huang Jing, an independent director of Keppel Land, has resigned following the cancellation of his Singapore Permanent Residence status and an order to leave the country. The move comes after the Singapore Ministry of Home Affairs stated that Huang used his position to advance a foreign country's agenda at Singapore's expense. Huang had been accused of working with foreign intelligence agents to influence Singaporeans' opinions in favor of the country. His resignation takes immediate effect, citing the cancellation of his PR status for working with a foreign government to influence Singapore's foreign policy and public opinion.

site_title: Manulife S'pore rides high on 2016 breakthrough year
summary: Manulife Singapore, a Canadian insurer, has achieved significant growth in the past three years, becoming the group's third largest market in Asia, after Hong Kong and Japan. The company's fortunes were turned around due to its bank distribution channel, which contributed more than half of its new sales. Under the leadership of CEO Naveed Irshad, Manulife Singapore has grown 10-fold, with annualized premium equivalent rising from $71 million to $374 million in 2016. The company is now focusing on maximizing its bank partnership and leveraging data to simplify the underwriting process.

site_title: New Singapore record in the bag
summary: Yu Neng Primary School in Bedok North has set a new Singapore record for the "Most Number of People Decorating Tote Bags Together" with 1,324 participants.

site_title: ST Index maintains 3,300 level; director buys vs sells at 5:1
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) maintained its 18.7% dividend-inclusive return for the 2017 year to date, surpassing the benchmarks of Japan, Hong Kong, and Australia. Over five trading sessions, 50 stocks reported changes in director interests and/or substantial shareholders, with a 5:1 ratio of acquisitions to disposals. Six stocks conducted share buybacks, with OCBC buying back 160,000 shares at S$11.27 per share. Notable transactions included Aspen Group's listing on Catalist and Tung Lok Restaurants' increased stake by non-independent director Sam Goi.

site_title: Magnitude 5.8 quake hits Philippines says USGS
summary: A magnitude 5.8 earthquake struck south Mindanao island in the Philippines, 21 miles east of General Santos city, on August 5, 2017. The quake's epicentre was initially reported as 6.0, but the USGS later confirmed it was 5.8. The quake was 46.2 miles deep, but a European agency reported it at 6.2 miles deep. The moderate quake is capable of causing considerable damage.

images.alt_text: A magnitude 5.8 earthquake struck south Mindanao island in the Philippines on Saturday, the US Geological Survey said.

site_title: Many US cities unnerved by protectionist stance
summary: US cities are experiencing economic growth from foreign firms moving operations overseas, contrary to President Trump's protectionist stance. Chattanooga, Tennessee, has seen over 20 countries set up shop, generating billions of dollars in investment and employing thousands. The region's jobless rate has dropped to a record low, and foreign companies have established apprenticeship and training programs with local schools. However, leaders are worried that Trump's attacks on trade partners could lead to tariffs and import restrictions, hurting consumers and workers. Foreign companies, particularly from Japan, employ thousands in the area, and some have invested heavily in the region.

site_title: In the long run, we won't all be dead: Motley Fool
summary: Global markets have trended upwards for many years, with major economies such as the US, EU, China, and Japan still performing well despite individual risks. According to Tematica Research's chief investment officer, Christopher Versace, a major recession is unlikely in the long run. However, recent market fluctuations and company announcements, including NTT DC Reit's oversubscribed public offer and Creative Technology's revenue warning, suggest economic uncertainty. Meanwhile, Singapore's stock market has rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data, and MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

images.alt_text: Even though global markets have been trending upwards for very many years, a major recession does not appear to be likely, said Tematica Research chief investment officer Christopher Versace at InvestFair 2017 on Saturday.

site_title: UK fights rearguard action on EU financial laws
summary: The UK is engaged in a rearguard action to influence EU financial laws as it prepares to leave the EU. Negotiations on banking legislation and new rules on pensions, covered bonds, and derivatives clearing are set to resume, with the UK seeking to ensure equivalent rules in place after Brexit. Despite a diminished capacity to influence EU policies, UK lawmakers and officials continue to engage in debates and discussions, with the Bank of England seeking to avoid becoming a taker of EU rules. The UK aims to maintain its dominance in euro-denominated derivatives clearing and has taken aim at EU proposals on bank-failure rules and liquidity regulations.

site_title: Billionaire fuels revival in weary Wisconsin town
summary: Billionaire Diane Hendricks is revitalizing the Wisconsin town of Beloit, investing $47 million to transform its downtown area. She has renovated the town's library, built a performing arts center, and converted a former foundry into a commercial space called Ironworks. The project, which includes a sushi restaurant, high-end apartments, and a startup incubator, aims to create a thriving economy. Despite initial skepticism, the town has seen a surge in job creation, with around 1,000 people working out of Ironworks. However, unemployment remains high, and some worry about the town's long-term sustainability.

site_title: Glamour? There's an app for that
summary: A new app, Surkus, connects influencers and social media personalities with clients seeking attractive human "garnishes" for events, such as shopping parties and nightclub openings. Members, who can earn up to $100 per event, are matched with clients based on demographic details and are paid to attend. The app, which has 150,000 members, has also been used for film and modeling work. Surkus takes 50% of the earnings, and its CEO, Stephen George, has invested $250,000 in the company, which has generated $4,000 per year for power users.

site_title: World's biggest pension fund boosts assets to record high
summary: The Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF), the world's largest pension fund, reported a 3.5% quarterly gain, boosting its assets to a record 149.2 trillion yen. Global stocks rose, and a decline in the yen against the dollar and euro helped increase the value of its overseas investments. Domestic equities added 2.3 trillion yen, while foreign stocks increased by 1.9 trillion yen, with Japanese shares returning 6.6% and overseas stocks adding 5.5%. The fund's assets now surpass the previous record, driven by a positive market environment and a weakening yen.

site_title: Huang Jing resigns as independent director of Keppel Land
summary: Huang Jing, an independent director of Keppel Land, has resigned with immediate effect. This comes after the Singapore Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) cancelled his Singapore permanent residence status due to allegations that he worked with a foreign government to influence Singapore's foreign policy and public opinion. MHA described Huang as "an agent of influence of a foreign country" and permanently banned him from Singapore, along with his wife, in a rare case of its kind in nearly 20 years.

site_title: When just a scented candle won't do
summary: Air Esscentials, a 10-year-old company in Miami, is expanding its business beyond hotels and resorts to the home market, offering high-end scent-diffusing systems that can perfume living rooms and bedrooms. The company's devices, such as the Aera diffuser, can fill rooms with fragrance for hours or days at a time, and are priced between $50 and $849. The home fragrance market is a $6.4 billion industry, and companies like Air Esscentials and Prolitec are targeting a growing market of consumers who value the benefits of scent, including increased energy and relaxation.

site_title: SIA - not quite a great way to write?
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has been criticized for its use of jargon-laden and demeaning language when announcing voluntary no-pay leave to its cabin crew. The airline's description of its staff as "surpluses" and "deficits" is seen as dehumanizing, and the phrase "going forward" is deemed clichéd and meaningless. The airline's communications team is advised to do better, focusing on creativity and originality to convey the message in a respectful and professional manner.

site_title: No let-up in sight of Trump trade war chatter: analysts
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade war chatter with China and Germany appears unlikely to subside, with analysts expecting data to show a widening goods trade surplus in both countries. China's July surplus is expected to top $46 billion, while Germany's surplus in June is forecast to be 21 billion euros. Despite some optimism that international cooperation will prevail, concerns over protectionism persist, leaving financial markets wary. Analysts caution that while a full-blown trade war seems unlikely, rhetoric from both sides remains a risk.

site_title: Japan's Sapporo Holdings buys over US brewer
summary: Japan's Sapporo Holdings Ltd acquired US brewer Anchor Brewing Co for approximately $85 million, reflecting mounting pressure from craft brewers to find deep-pocketed partners in an increasingly crowded market. The deal will allow Sapporo to expand its presence in the US and increase sales of its premium beer. The acquisition also provides Sapporo with a bigger foothold in a key market and cachet, despite criticism from some analysts who question the value of the deal.

site_title: Berkshire profit falls on lower gains, underwriting loss
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway reported a 15% decline in second-quarter profit to $4.26 billion, or $2,592 per share, due to lower investment gains and an underwriting loss. Operating profit fell 11% to $4.12 billion, or $2,505 per share, beating analyst expectations. Buffett prefers operating income as a gauge of the company's performance, citing its volatility.

site_title: World Class Global H1 bottomline still mired in red ink with S$2.9m loss
summary: World Class Global (WCG) reported a net loss of S$2.9 million for the first half of the year, a 39% decrease from the previous year's net loss of S$4.7 million. The group did not generate revenue from property sales due to unfinished development projects. The loss was mainly attributed to a net foreign exchange gain of S$3.3 million and increased employee benefits and listing expenses. This was the company's first financial reporting since its initial public offering (IPO).

site_title: Toyota plans truck, possibly SUV production in Mexico after Trump threat
summary: Toyota plans to build pickup trucks and possibly SUVs at a new plant in Mexico, reversing its initial plan to produce Corolla sedans due to US President Donald Trump's threat to penalize the company. The move comes as the global automaker shifts production to the US to avoid tariffs. Toyota will study producing SUVs in Guanajuato, in addition to the Tacoma truck model, and expects the investment to remain similar despite the shift in plans. The decision aims to reduce political pressure from Trump.

site_title: When Frank Ocean's T-shirt raises questions of copyright
summary: Frank Ocean's T-shirt, which read "Why be racist, sexist, homophobic or transphobic when you could just be quiet?" and was produced by Green Box Shop, raised questions about copyright in an era of viral sharing. The T-shirt, originally created by 18-year-old Kayla Robinson, gained significant attention after Ocean wore it at the Panorama Music Festival, leading to 5,500 orders. However, the shirt's originator, Brandon Male, claimed he had not been properly credited for the quote, which he had posted on Twitter in 2015. Robinson has since apologized and offered Male $100.

site_title: Can Dukang offer the cigar butt's last puff?
summary: Dukang Distillers, a Chinese baijiu company, has seen its stock plummet from 36 Singapore cents in 2008 to 24 Singapore cents, a 10-to-1 share consolidation. The company's sales volumes have declined, and its premium line of baijiu is also losing ground. The Chinese baijiu industry is highly fragmented, with intense competition at the lower end. Dukang's failure to expand beyond its home province and overseas markets, as well as its inability to attract younger drinkers, has contributed to its decline. Despite its low valuations, Dukang's history and investments made in the past may indicate a potential turnaround if the company can develop a viable strategy to defend its turf.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese singer-songwriter Emil Chau (left), with then-Trump Dragon executive chairman Gao Feng, launching the Chinese liquor maker's IPO at the SGX Centre in 2008. Chau, who was the company's products spokesman, sang his hit song Friends at the listing ceremony.

site_title: Toshiba to cut off Western Digital's future supply of chips
summary: Toshiba has announced it will build a new chip factory, Fab 6, without Western Digital's participation, effectively cutting off its US partner's access to chips made with the new technology. This move escalates a fight between the two companies over a joint venture and Toshiba's plan to sell its share to cover multibillion-dollar losses. Western Digital claims it has rights to participate in the investment and may delay the sale, putting Toshiba at risk of being delisted. The dispute could further delay the sale and impact Western Digital's access to crucial chip production.

site_title: Keeping a step ahead
summary: Singapore is turning 52 and needs to build a unique identity to maintain its distinctive edge globally. Founder John Bittleston suggests the country needs to create an exceptional tourist attraction, aiming for a 35% annual increase in tourism. Geographically and geopolitically, Singapore is poised to achieve this goal. Bittleston envisions an air-conditioned, tsunami-protected city with internal-combustion engine-free infrastructure to showcase its capabilities. This move would help maintain Singapore's "Wow" factor and demonstrate its continued independence.

site_title: New 'Game of Thrones' episode leaks online through HBO partner
summary: A leaked episode of HBO's 'Game of Thrones' titled 'The Spoils of War' has been posted online through a partner of the premium channel, Star India. The leak occurred separately from a hack that stole 1.5 terrabytes of data, including two unaired episodes. Star India has initiated forensic investigations and is taking legal action. This incident comes as HBO is in the process of being sold to AT&T in a $85.4 billion deal. The leak is considered a grave issue and a breach of confidentiality.

site_title: US: Dow boasts eighth record close in a row, banks lead
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached its eighth consecutive record high, closing at 22,092.81, driven by gains in JPMorgan Chase and other banks following stronger-than-expected US job data in July. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the Nasdaq Composite reaching a fresh record.

site_title: Li Shengwu responds to AGC, says earlier post when taken in context is not in contempt of court
summary: Singapore's eldest son, Li Shengwu, 32, has responded to the Attorney-General's Chambers, saying his earlier post, when taken in context, is not in contempt of court. The AGC had filed an application to begin contempt of court proceedings against him on Friday. Li's post was made in response to a previous statement by his uncle, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The High Court will now decide on the AGC's application.

site_title: Paysafe backs £3b offer from Blackstone/CVC group
summary: Paysafe Group has accepted a £3 billion takeover offer from Blackstone and CVC Capital Partners. The consortium's 590 pence per share proposal was deemed "fair and reasonable" by Paysafe's board. The deal comes as Paysafe shares rose 0.3% to 598 pence, signaling investor hope for a higher offer. The acquisition would mark a significant deal in the payments processing sector.

images.alt_text: Payments processing company Paysafe Group has backed a £3 billion (S$5.39 billion) takeover offer from a consortium of funds managed by Blackstone and CVC Capital Partners, the latest in a string of deals in the sector.

site_title: Shanghai Stock Exchange to increase scrutiny of M&A risk
summary: Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) plans to increase scrutiny of mergers, acquisitions, and other corporate actions to prevent financial risk in the market. The exchange aims to ensure a stable market and prevent "financial chaos" by closely monitoring companies. This move follows concerns that a small number of companies are being used as platforms for financial risk, posing a threat to the overall market. SSE's focus on risk prevention and market stability is expected to enhance investor confidence and promote a more stable market environment.

site_title: South China Sea, North Korea tensions at security forum
summary: Vietnam urged Southeast Asian nations to take a stronger stance against Chinese expansionism in the South China Sea at the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) security forum. The move came ahead of talks with top diplomats from China, the US, Russia, and North Korea. Vietnam proposed changes to a joint communique, setting the stage for a fiery few days of diplomacy in the Philippines. The forum aims to address regional security concerns, including North Korea's nuclear program, which also drew criticism. The talks are expected to be tense, with China's expansionism and North Korea's nuclear threat on the agenda.

site_title: Tesla lowers price of Model X, saying margins improved
summary: Tesla lowered the base price of its Model X SUV to $79,500, citing improved margins. The move came as the company ramps up production of its lower-priced Model 3, which starts at $35,000. Despite concerns that Model 3 sales might cannibalize Model X, CEO Elon Musk said demand for the luxury electric vehicle has actually increased. The most expensive Model X variant costs $145,000. The price cut follows Tesla's overall gross margins falling to 25% in the second quarter due to the Model 3 build.

site_title: UK lawyers, accountants fund most of cost of police with taxes
summary: Britain's legal and accounting services industry funded almost the entire UK police budget of £16.6 billion with £15.5 billion in tax contributions last year, according to a PwC report. The sector's 693,000 employees paid an average tax rate of 54% and a tax contribution per employee of £22,463. This is close to covering 2.5% of all tax collected, with the industry contributing £15.5 billion. The report highlights the sector's significant impact on the UK economy, particularly during Brexit negotiations.

site_title: US makes deal to buy 747s once set for Russia as Air Force One
summary: The US Air Force has reached a deal with Boeing to purchase two 747 jets, previously set for Russia, to serve as Air Force One at a discounted price. The deal comes after President Donald Trump criticized the program's cost and threatened to cancel the order. The planes, which were stored since 2015, will require extensive modifications to meet the Air Force's requirements. The agreement sets the stage for a modernized Air Force One program and is seen as a cost-saving measure, with the estimated cost of the program now expected to be around $3.51 billion.

site_title: US unveils tougher new UN sanctions on North Korea
summary: The US has unveiled a draft UN resolution imposing tougher sanctions on North Korea, targeting coal, iron, lead, seafood, and joint ventures, aiming to deprive the country of $1 billion in annual revenue. The proposed ban would strip Pyongyang of a third of its export earnings. China and Russia are expected to support the sanctions, which would be the seventh set of UN sanctions on North Korea since 2006. The measures are aimed at pressuring North Korea to halt its missile and nuclear tests, with the US willing to engage in talks with Pyongyang.

site_title: US to join climate talks despite Paris accord exit
summary: The US will participate in international climate change negotiations despite its planned withdrawal from the Paris accord, the State Department confirmed. The US will continue to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and engage with the international community on combating climate change. The withdrawal process will take at least until 2020, but the US will not be able to formally pull out until then. President Trump remains open to re-engaging in the pact if terms can be made more favorable to the US.

site_title: Trump begins 17-day vacation as troubles brew in Washington
summary: US President Donald Trump has embarked on a 17-day vacation at his Bedminster golf resort in New Jersey, leaving behind a capital grappling with a Russia scandal and legislative failures. Trump's decision to take time off has been criticized, particularly given his past comments about the importance of working during vacations. Despite his claims of not taking vacations, Trump has spent more time off than his predecessor Barack Obama in their first seven months in office.

site_title: Football: PSG sell 10,000 Neymar shirts on first day
summary: Paris Saint-Germain sold over 10,000 Neymar shirts on his first day as the club's marquee summer signing, generating 1 million euros. The shirts, bearing Neymar's name and No 10 on the back, sold at an average price of 100 euros, paying off part of the world record 222 million euros transfer fee. The revenue is shared with Nike, meaning it would take twice as long to recoup the transfer fee.

site_title: Ascott fund investing S$170.3m in Funan project's serviced residence
summary: Ascott Limited is investing S$170.3 million in the Funan project's serviced residence component, with S$90.5 million for land acquisition from CapitaLand Mall Trust and S$80 million for development. This investment is through Ascott's serviced residence global fund with Qatar Investment Authority.

site_title: Wells Fargo clients want credit repair for insurance debacle
summary: Wells Fargo clients are suing the bank for forcing them to pay for unnecessary auto insurance, resulting in damaged credit scores and repossessed cars. The bank's internal review found over 500,000 clients may have paid for protection while already having their own policies. Wells Fargo has offered up to $80 million in refunds, but clients claim this is insufficient. The consumers are asking the court to order the bank to immediately correct inaccurate information on their credit reports.

site_title: Apple to launch watches that can make calls
summary: Apple plans to release a version of its smartwatch that can connect directly to cellular networks, allowing it to make calls and perform tasks without an iPhone. The new Apple Watch models will feature LTE chips, supplied by Intel, and are set to be released later this year. The company is in talks with carriers in the US and Europe to offer the cellular version, marking a significant upgrade to the current model that requires an iPhone connection.

site_title: Love in the ruins
summary: The Man Booker Prize longlist has been released, featuring Mohsin Hamid's novel "Exit West", a fantastical tale of a couple's journey through magical wormholes amidst war and refugee crises. The novel tackles issues like theological politics, immigration, and happiness, making it a timely and ambitious work. It joins other notable authors on the list, marking a significant moment for literary recognition.

site_title: Best day in 3 weeks for European shares as euro falls, all sectors rise
summary: European shares ended the week with a 1% gain, boosted by a drop in the euro and a strong US jobs report. The STOXX 600 index rose, with all sectors in positive territory, despite Swiss Re's weaker-than-expected earnings report and a decline in Andritz's shares. Petrofac and GEA were top gainers, driven by refinery contracts and a stake acquisition, respectively. The US dollar's rise also supported the euro's decline, potentially paving the way for further Federal Reserve monetary policy tightening.

site_title: MAS proposes raising deposit insurance coverage to S$75,000
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed raising the Deposit Insurance (DI) Scheme's coverage limit from S$50,000 to S$75,000 to restore the percentage of fully insured depositors to above 90%. This move aims to align with international norms. The current coverage limit was last raised in 2011 and has since seen a decline in fully covered insured depositors due to the growth in the deposit base.

site_title: US sees strong job creation in July as unemployment falls
summary: The US economy added 209,000 net new jobs in July, bringing unemployment to a 16-year low of 4.3%, according to the Labor Department. Average monthly job creation in 2017 is 185,000, slightly below 2016 and 2014, but above 2015. Hourly wages rose 0.3% and the stock market surged, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average posting its eighth consecutive record close. The economy has added 16 million net jobs over the last seven years, recovering from the damage of the Great Recession.

site_title: Google is said to work on news product competing with Snapchat
summary: Google is developing a news product called Stamp, a mobile magazine-like design competing with Snapchat's Discover service. Stamp evolved from Google's AMP project, which collaborates with publishers to load articles faster. Google has not announced any details but expressed enthusiasm for sharing more soon. This move follows Snapchat's changes to Discover, which focuses on episodic video content, and comes as Google seeks to prove its own unique offering in the mobile news space.

site_title: VW executive Schmidt pleads guilty in auto emissions scandal
summary: Volkswagen executive Oliver Schmidt, 48, pleaded guilty to conspiracy and violating the US Clean Air Act in a Detroit federal court, facing up to 7 years in prison and deportation after serving his sentence. Schmidt agreed to cooperate with the investigation into the company's emissions-cheating scandal, which has already cost VW over $24 billion. He is the 8th Volkswagen executive charged in the US for their roles in the scheme, with sentencing scheduled for December 6.

images.alt_text: Oliver Schmidt, a Volkswagen AG compliance executive charged in the company's emissions-cheating scandal, pleaded guilty Friday in federal court in Detroit to conspiracy and violating the US Clean Air Act.

site_title: Ice ice baby
summary: Magnum has unveiled its first flagship store in Singapore at ION Orchard, featuring a Pleasure Bar where customers can customize ice cream creations with various toppings and chocolates. The store also offers five specialty coffees and pre-packaged ice cream pints. Located at ION Orchard #B2-07, the store is open daily from 10am to 10pm.

site_title: 10 Japanese haiga to celebrate Asean's 50th
summary: Asean's 50th anniversary is being celebrated with 10 haigas, created by writer Koh Buck Song, each dedicated to one of the 10 member states. The haigas, featuring images and accompanying haikus, aim to capture the essence of each country and its people. The haigas are now on display at the SEAMEO Regional Language Centre in Singapore. The exhibition, opened by Ambassador-at-Large Tommy Koh, reflects on Indonesia's historical battle for independence and incorporates words from each member state's language into the haikus.

site_title: Robots have created a language, but there's no need for us to panic
summary: Artificially intelligent chatbots have created their own languages, but this development should not evoke fear. The primary danger lies not in the AI itself, but in over-empowering its creators. Despite being awarded as the most human-like chatbot, Mitsuku struggled to understand human sarcasm and nuances in conversation. Researchers have found that bots excel at negotiating with each other, using formulas to communicate effectively. The development of AI's ability to communicate is not a sign of a diabolical superintelligence, but rather a reflection of the complexity involved in human communication.

site_title: Bringing books to life
summary: The article discusses the popularity of the HBO show "Game of Thrones" and its adaptation from the book series. The show has become a cultural phenomenon, with a dedicated fan base that meets weekly to discuss the series. Its massive success has led to widespread media coverage, including recaps and predictions. The show's impact is evident in its ability to bring books to life on screen, with many considering it the most popular TV series of all time.

site_title: 'World's largest' construction factory opens at Forest City
summary: The country's master developer, Country Garden Pacificview, has opened the world's largest Industrialised Building System (IBS) factory in Forest City, Singapore. The 417-acre site will house the entire production base for Forest City, with the capacity to produce materials for up to one million square meters of built-up area. The factory utilizes modern construction technique IBS, standardizing design and automating processes. The facility will support the development of Forest City and also cater to the growing construction opportunities in South-east Asia, with plans to add up to five more factories.

site_title: SIA says voluntary no-pay leave move makes it more nimble
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has asked over 400 cabin crew members to take voluntary no-pay leave to manage crew resources and operational requirements amid a temporary manpower surplus. The leave, which can last from five days to a month, was taken by selected staff to better align with operational needs. This move aims to improve the airline's operational efficiency and flexibility.

images.alt_text: The scheme will start in September, but cabin crew affected can apply for their leave for that period now.

site_title: UOL posts 59% jump in Q2 profit
summary: UOL Group reported a 59% increase in Q2 net profit to S$109.4 million, driven by higher revenue recognition from Singapore condominium projects and fair value gains on investment properties. The group flagged concerns over a possible disconnect between land tender prices and achievable end-sale prices. Revenue rose 10% to S$399.1 million, with property development revenue increasing 19% to S$221.2 million. The group's hospitality and investment businesses performed creditably despite challenging conditions, with revenue from these sectors also rising.

site_title: Dragon lady
summary: Singapore Repertory Theatre and Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay are reviving the successful musical "Forbidden City: Portrait of an Empress", which sold over 100,000 tickets in three sold-out runs. The production will feature pop singer Kit Chan reprising her role as Empress Dowager Cixi, with music by Dick Lee and a cast including Cheryl Tan, Sebastian Tan, Earl Carpenter, and Steffanie Leigh. The musical will play at the Esplanade Theatre from August 8 to 27.

site_title: Communal cooking
summary: The OUE Social Kitchen, a communal cooking space in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience where friends, families, and strangers can meet and cook at a common table. The 4,000 sq ft kitchen features state-of-the-art appliances, two VIP rooms, and six standard stations, with rates starting at S$45 per hour. Customers can bring their own pre-packed ingredients and receive assistance from in-house chefs and staff. Located at #03-02/03, OUE Downtown Gallery, the kitchen aims to foster community and social interaction through cooking.

site_title: August 1966 - Parade of parties
summary: Singapore's first National Day, celebrated on Aug 9, 1966, was a week-long event featuring a massive parade, fireworks, and cultural shows. The parade, themed "National Pride and Confidence in the Future," drew over 23,000 participants, including soldiers, children, and cultural groups, despite a brief rainfall interruption. The event was followed by a fireworks display and a cocktail party at the Istana garden, hosted by President Yusof Ishak and the First Lady. The parade took place in the morning, a departure from current National Day celebrations.

site_title: Initial interest
summary: Céline introduces initial pendants, following Louis Vuitton and Fendi's lead. The fashion house offers a non-conformist approach, allowing for unique styling options. Pendants can be worn on a chain, jersey necklace, or mixed with other pieces to create a personalized look. This approach encourages creativity in wearing the pendant, rather than limiting it to a single style.

site_title: Vietnam, the next China
summary: Vietnam is considered the "next China" due to its high growth rate in labour productivity, strong GDP expansion, and rising middle class. The country's stock market has seen enormous growth between 2008 and 2017, with high returns on equity. Foreign investment space is currently limited, but privatisation and new-share flotations are expected to expand it in the coming years. Vietnam's market-driven economy and enthusiasm for free-trade deals make it an attractive destination for investors.

site_title: Children prep for the robot economy
summary: Children as young as two are being taught skills to prepare them for an automated economy, including debugging robots and learning code. Researchers argue that foundational skills, such as empathy, collaboration, and problem-solving, are more important than coding. The focus on coding is misplaced, and children should learn human skills through play and building. A summer camp at Tufts University taught children to program robots, test hypotheses, and learn from failure, developing essential skills for the future labor market. Experts emphasize the importance of teaching social and emotional skills, as well as computational thinking, to help children adapt to a rapidly changing world.

site_title: Daniel Lamarre
summary: Daniel Lamarre, CEO of Cirque du Soleil, discusses the company's growth and future plans. Founded in 1984, Cirque du Soleil has become a global entertainment leader with no animal acts, featuring multi-talented performers in themed, theatre-style shows. The company has recently acquired Blue Man Group and will open NFL Experience Times Square, an interactive football experience. With a new ownership structure and investments in technology, Cirque du Soleil aims to expand globally, including China, and reinvent its content within the next two years. Lamarre emphasizes the importance of innovation, geographical diversity, and interactivity in the future of live entertainment.

site_title: AGC to start proceedings against Li Shengwu for contempt of court
summary: The Attorney-General's Chambers in Singapore has filed an application to commence contempt of court proceedings against 32-year-old Li Shengwu, the eldest son of former Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Yang, for a Facebook post deemed an "egregious and baseless attack" on the judiciary. The post, published on July 15, questioned the independence of the judiciary and was widely circulated on social media. Despite being warned by the AGC, Li Shengwu failed to delete the post or publish a written apology by the deadline of August 4.

site_title: A date with time
summary: Patek Philippe's perpetual calendar wristwatches, invented by Thomas Mudge in 1762, have become a symbol of luxury and sophistication. The company's first wristwatch model, Ref 1526, was launched in 1941 and marked the beginning of regular series-produced perpetual calendar watches. Since then, Patek has created over 30 models, including the latest Ref 5320, which automatically indicates months and leap years. Perpetual calendar watches are known for their ability to accurately display the date, month, and moon phase without manual correction, making them a highly sought-after complication watch.

site_title: Cosco Shipping International (S) shrinks Q2 net loss by 43%
summary: Cosco Shipping International (S) Co reported a 43% decrease in its second-quarter net loss to S$20.81 million. The company signed a non-binding MOU with its affiliate to acquire 40% equity interest in PT Ocean Global Shipping, a move aimed at restructuring its shipbuilding-focused business portfolio. The acquisition is expected to be a value less than 5% of its latest audited net tangible assets.

site_title: Joy ride
summary: Linus bikes, founded in Venice Beach, California, has released a new bike design inspired by 1950s and 60s French city bikes, but with a soft, feminine edge. The bike features stainless steel hardware, low-maintenance gears, hand-stitched leather handles, and a mid-century alloy bell. This stylish offering maintains Linus' signature modern vintage aesthetic, offering a unique blend of elegance and functionality. The bike is now available for purchase on the Linus website.

site_title: TT International suspends trading as it sorts out funding options
summary: TT International Limited, a Singapore-listed consumer electronics retailer, has suspended trading of its shares amid funding concerns. The company is seeking to repay a S$125 million loan and has obtained a non-binding term sheet for up to S$380 million in funding to refinance its debt. TT International believes this option could provide a total resolution for the group, but lenders are seeking repayment by August 14, 2017. The company reported a loss of S$44.5 million in the year ended March 31.

site_title: High Aussie masks economic weakness
summary: The Australian dollar continues to strengthen, with a break-out above the upper edge of its long-term trading band near US$0.775. This trend is driven by the weakness of the US dollar, largely due to dissatisfaction with President Donald Trump's policies. A projected target near US$0.835 is possible, but investors should be cautious. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Index has broken out above 3,265, supported by the strength of the Chinese economy and a solid long-term trend.

site_title: Taxi drivers as couriers?
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore is considering allowing taxi drivers and private-hire drivers to make deliveries as couriers, despite initial opposition. This move could boost their income and increase transport productivity, reducing congestion and pollution. However, regulators must ensure the safety of drivers and passengers amid the potential disruption to the logistics industry. The shift could also benefit consumers with faster deliveries and lower costs, as seen with e-commerce giant Amazon's recent entry into Singapore.

images.alt_text: Drivers with ride-hailing firms Grab and Uber are also taking on deliveries, due to an attractive hourly rate of up to S$30.

site_title: DBS shares down on warning of higher provisions over O&G stress
summary: DBS shares fell over 2% after its CEO, Piyush Gupta, warned of higher provisions due to stress in the oil & gas segment. The bank reported a 8% rise in net profit to S$1.14 billion for the second quarter, but missed forecasts. DBS raised its dividend to 33 Singapore cents per share, and its NPL ratio rose to 1.5% from 1.1% a year ago. The bank also locked in a 6% increase in loans, but saw a decline in net interest margin to 1.74%. Gupta painted a cautious outlook for the oil & gas sector, citing concerns over pricing power and collateral values.

site_title: Instagram - New outlet for fine timepieces
summary: Rare and vintage watches have sparked a feeding frenzy among collectors on Instagram, with accounts such as @analogshift, @jasonheaton, and @hodinkee showcasing highly sought-after timepieces. The platform's influence has led to a surge in watch envy, with users experiencing "vintage watch deficit disorder" and considering raiding their 401(k) accounts to acquire these rare watches. The article highlights the growing popularity of vintage watches on social media, with brands like Vacheron Constantin and Rolex also celebrating their anniversaries and releasing limited-edition collections.

site_title: Banks, Wall Street the main drivers for the week
summary: Wall Street drove market movements this week, with the Dow Jones crossing 22,000 for the first time on Wednesday and reaching a seventh consecutive all-time high. Local banks, particularly DBS and OCBC, were key drivers of the Straits Times Index, with DBS reporting an 8% net profit rise despite a 2.7% share price fall. OCBC maintained a HOLD rating for DBS, citing mid-single digit loan growth and income growth expectations.

site_title: GSH Corp in the black with Q2 profit of S$71.7m, helped by disposal gain
summary: GSH Corp reported a net profit of S$71.7 million in Q2, reversing a net loss of S$3.2 million from the previous year. The gain was largely due to a disposal of S$74.9 million from the sale of its investment in Plaza Ventures. This marks a significant turnaround for the company, with the disposal gain more than doubling its profit.

site_title: Country-style cooking
summary: Singaporean chefs share their favorite dishes representing the country's diverse culture. Emmanuel Stroobant, a Belgian-born Singaporean, chooses Chilli Crab, a Southeast Asian staple. Drew Nocente, an Australian-born Singaporean, pairs XO sauce with wagyu ribeye, highlighting the umami element. Petrina Loh, a Singaporean, selects Chicken Rice, a comfort food icon. Alysia Chan, a Singaporean, creates Quinoa Fried Chicken with Banana Ketchup and Jicama Slaw, showcasing the country's cultural diversity. These dishes reflect Singapore's melting pot of ethnicities and cultures, with each chef's unique twist.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Industries' strategic review is expected to conclude in Q4 2017, but taking Sembcorp Marine private is deemed unfeasible. Divestment and dividend in specie may not be beneficial for main shareholder Temasek due to SMM's geared position and corruption investigation. Meanwhile, Banyan Tree Holdings is recommended to buy with a target price of S$0.77, driven by strategic partnerships and potential hotel openings. Dairy Farm International Holdings is also recommended to buy with a target price of US$10.00, driven by strong H1 FY17 results despite a weaker supermarket division.

site_title: Good luck charm
summary: Casio is launching fukubukuro lucky bags at its G-Factory stores in Singapore, valued from S$353 to S$655, with each containing items like a G-Shock watch and a camera. The bags retail for S$188 as part of National Day celebrations. The company is also releasing a limited edition NS50 timepiece based on the popular GX-56BB model featuring the NSmen's digital camo print. The items are expected to sell out quickly, making them a great opportunity for fans to snag a unique item.

site_title: SGX, MAS draw further fire over Noble saga
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) and Singapore Exchange (SGX) face criticism over their handling of the Noble Group saga, with market observers and regulators saying more could have been done to protect investors. The MAS will investigate allegations of irregularities and enforce regulations, while SGX will review the company's response to concerns. Corporate governance advocate Mak Yuen Teen says regulatory gaps for foreign listings and inadequate audit oversight are concerns, and the MAS should have taken more action sooner.

site_title: Australia's moves to cool property prices start to bite
summary: Australia's housing market is cooling due to regulatory restrictions on lending, which are deterring property investors. Key measures include higher minimum deposits, tightened eligibility requirements, and increased interest rates on interest-only mortgages. As a result, property auction clearance rates in Sydney have fallen below 70% in several weeks, and investor loans now account for 37% of new mortgages. Experts predict a decline in median Sydney house prices by 5% by mid-2019 as investors retreat, with some focusing on cheaper cities like Brisbane and Adelaide.

site_title: Hawker goes French
summary: A French twist is added to street food in Singapore with the opening of Audace, a French bistro offering weekend brunch at S$68++ per person. Meanwhile, Saint Pierre's one-Michelinstarred chef Emmanuel Stroobant creates a local-inspired nine-course dinner menu at S$248++ per person, featuring dishes such as poached Hokkaido king crab crusted with puffed coconut rice and Iberico pork in a pork consomme. These innovative dishes blend French cuisine with local flavors, offering a unique dining experience in Singapore.

site_title: Uneasy welcome as ultra-Orthodox Jews extend beyond New York
summary: Ultra-Orthodox Jews from Brooklyn are moving to Jersey City, New Jersey, and other areas in the region due to high property prices in Brooklyn and Queens. The influx has sparked tensions with long-established residents, who complain about aggressive solicitations and the desire to establish a larger footprint for the ultra-Orthodox community. Despite efforts to integrate, residents worry that the ultra-Orthodox will transform the character of their communities with their unconventional lifestyle and customs. The movement is part of a larger demographic shift, with the ultra-Orthodox population growing rapidly in the New York City area.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Oxley Holdings acquired a 7.11% stake in United Engineers Ltd for S$120.3 million. This deal is part of Oxley's investments in income-generating assets. Meanwhile, Yanlord Land and Perennial Real Estate are leading a group to acquire UEL and its holding company WBL Corp for S$1.8 billion.

site_title: Celebrations in the Citi
summary: Team Citi won the top team award at Seletar Country Club in the Business Times Corporate Golf League with 319 points, edging out Tat Hong on countback. The team, buoyed by Chris Chew's brilliant round, surged from seventh place after the first leg to second in the 12-team competitive league. Team Boustead is in third with 317 points, just five ahead of Emerio.

site_title: Wyndham spins-off hotel unit, seeks deals for European brands
summary: Wyndham Worldwide Corp will spin off its hotel unit into a new publicly traded company, Wyndham Hotel Group, while consolidating its timeshare business. The company will also explore strategic alternatives for its European rental brands. Wyndham Hotel Group will be based in Parsippany, New Jersey, and Wyndham Vacation Ownership, combined with Wyndham Destination Network, will be headquartered in Orlando, Florida. The spin-off is part of the company's efforts to restructure and focus on its core businesses.

site_title: Wealth manager St James's Place eyes long-haul expansion in Asia
summary: UK-based wealth manager St James's Place (SJP) is expanding its presence in Asia, opening a new office in Raffles Place, with plans to gradually grow its business over the next 10-15 years. The firm, which has assets under management of £80 billion, acquired The Henley Group in 2014 and has since grown its Asian AUM to around £700 million. SJP focuses on investment advisory, selecting third-party fund managers and monitoring their performance, and aims to sensibly work with the local community and advisers.

site_title: How not to lose your job in 10 days
summary: Anthony Scaramucci's 10-day tenure as White House communications director ended abruptly after he boasted of bypassing the Chief of Staff, made profanity-laced comments, and threatened to fire colleagues. His downfall was swift, with Chief of Staff Reince Priebus leaving and being replaced by John Kelly. Experts say new hires should avoid arrogance, be humble, and adapt to the organization's culture. Employers also have a significant role in due diligence and support for new hires, as a bad hire can have significant consequences. Scaramucci's case serves as a cautionary tale for those seeking to avoid similar short-lived stints in their new jobs.

site_title: SingPost's Q1 profit falls 13.6% to S$30.97m
summary: SingPost's Q1 profit fell 13.6% to S$30.97 million due to declining domestic mail volumes, increased competition, and costs from planned investments. Revenue rose 6.2% to S$354.12 million, driven by growth in postal and logistics components, particularly international mail and e-commerce-related deliveries. The company aims to integrate its acquired businesses into a unified network to drive synergy benefits and improve operating leverage. A strategic review is underway to address the challenges faced by the company.

site_title: MHA revokes LKY School professor's PR, bans him from S'pore
summary: A prominent LKYSPP professor, Huang Jing, had his permanent residency cancelled by the Singapore Ministry of Home Affairs due to working with a foreign government to influence Singapore's foreign policy and public opinion. The MHA stated Huang and his US citizen wife, Shirley Yang Xiuping, are permanently banned from re-entering the Republic. This is the first publicly known case of its kind in nearly two decades, marking a significant move to protect Singapore's sovereignty.

site_title: China's hottest internet sector is old-fashioned food delivery
summary: China's food delivery sector saw a 41.6% surge in users to 295 million in the first half of 2017, outpacing other online markets. This growth is driven by discounts and extensive networks built by platforms backed by Tencent, Alibaba, and Baidu. The industry has attracted billions of dollars in investments and deal-making, with sector-leader Meituan Dianping reportedly seeking $5 billion in funding. Smartphone usage accounts for 92% of customer orders, and the industry's profitability remains low, leading platforms to explore related businesses.

site_title: Viacom sinks as MTV owner sees more subscriber losses ahead
summary: Viacom Inc reported a 3% decline in subscribers for its cable-TV networks in the upcoming quarter, leading to a 11% drop in shares. The media company's CEO, Bob Bakish, faces challenges in turning around the business, which has been losing viewers and money. Despite beating analysts' estimates in quarterly sales and profit, Viacom's TV networks are struggling due to declining ratings and increased content costs. The company's global advertising sales also declined, and it is fighting with a major partner over channel placement.

site_title: Indonesia says Google agrees to monitor negative YouTube content
summary: Indonesia and Google have agreed to monitor negative content on YouTube, with the government launching a "trusted flagger system" to filter content related to terrorism, racial violence, and pornography. The system, set to be formalized in the coming months, will be limited to YouTube and will not apply to Google's search engine. This move comes as Indonesia, a country of 260 million people, has been concerned about the misuse of social media platforms. Facebook has also agreed to work with Indonesia on monitoring content, with the social media company hiring a local team to counter hoaxes and negative content.

site_title: Mueller is said to use Washington grand jury in Russia probe
summary: Special counsel Robert Mueller is using a federal grand jury in Washington to aid in his Russia probe, in addition to one in Alexandria, Virginia. The grand jury helps determine whether to bring criminal charges or indictments against a defendant and can issue subpoenas for documents. The White House has not commented on the matter, with special counsel Ty Cobb stating he was not aware of the grand jury's existence. The use of the grand jury comes as Mueller expands the scope of his probe to include Trump's businesses and associates.

site_title: Home Front
summary: A new mobile app, Artzibit, is launching to help homeowners buy art for their homes. The app uses augmented reality technology to visualize art pieces on walls, streamlining the buying process. Artzibit partners with designers and artists to offer over 2,000 artworks, with prices starting from $15. Meanwhile, furniture retailers Idee and 3bosses have formed an alliance to provide a one-stop solution for furnishing needs, offering a range of products and design themes. United Strangers, a furniture brand, is also expanding its presence in the market.

site_title: Volkswagen exec pleads guilty in US emissions cheating case
summary: Volkswagen executive Oliver Schmidt pleaded guilty to US charges related to a massive diesel emissions scandal, admitting to conspiring to mislead regulators and violating clean air laws. He faces up to seven years in prison and a fine of $40,000 to $400,000. As part of a plea agreement, Volkswagen has agreed to spend up to $25 billion to resolve claims from owners and regulators over polluting diesel vehicles. Eight current and former executives, including Schmidt, have been charged in the US.

site_title: Parallel import cars in the spotlight after report on Uber case
summary: Uber's parallel-imported Honda Vezel cars have come under scrutiny after a report revealed the company failed to repair vehicles involved in a recall, with only 9% of defective cars fixed. Despite acknowledging the issue, Uber claims to have worked with the Land Transport Authority and technical experts to address the problem. The company has also hired dedicated experts to handle safety recalls. However, the incident highlights concerns over the after-sales service for parallel-imported cars, which can be cheaper but often lack manufacturer support.

images.alt_text: The Honda Vezel - a Japanese domestic model - is popular among parallel importers because it costs less than the export version, the HR-V, brought in by authorised Honda distributor Kah Motor. Uber is estimated to have bought more than 1,000 Vezels a year over the last three years.

site_title: Millennium & Copthorne Q2 pretax profit up
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels reported a 22% year-over-year increase in pretax profit to £50 million for the second quarter ended June 30, driven by 6.1% revenue growth to £262 million. The company attributed the improvement to increased contributions from hotel trading and property, offset by reduced revenue from CDL Hospitality Trusts. The group also announced a contract with Hilton to manage One UN New York and plans to strengthen US operations through management changes and cost controls. An interim dividend of 2.08 pence per share was declared.

site_title: AGC files application to start committal proceedings against Li Shengwu for contempt of court over Facebook post
summary: The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) filed an application to start committal proceedings against Li Shengwu for contempt of court over a Facebook post he made on July 15, criticizing the self-censorship of foreign media in Singapore. The post was published by several websites and widely circulated on social media. Li's post allegedly breached court rules, prompting the AGC to take action. The outcome of the committal proceedings is pending.

site_title: Art you can sit on
summary: Moroso, an Italian furniture maker, has transformed from a small family business to a dynamic luxury brand known for innovation, aesthetics, and attention to detail. Founded in 1952 by Agostino Moroso, the company has collaborated with renowned artists, architects, and designers, including Antonio Citterio and Patricia Urquiola. With a focus on quality and design, Moroso has grown into a global brand, with 50 international designers and a turnover of 28 million euros last year. The company's CEO, Roberto Moroso, emphasizes the importance of innovation and taking risks to stay ahead in the industry, while maintaining a family tradition and respect for artistic values.

site_title: GoPro tops estimates on easier-to-use camera, big cost cuts
summary: GoPro Inc. reported stronger-than-expected second-quarter results, beating analysts' estimates with revenue of $296.5 million, a 34% increase from the same period last year. The company attributed the growth to cost cuts and software updates making its devices easier to use, particularly the upcoming Hero6 camera and Fusion spherical camera releases. CEO Nicholas Woodman stated the company is emerging from a two-year slump and is refocusing on the action-camera market, with international expansion and marketing efforts also contributing to the improved results.

site_title: Oil & gas sector still stinging Singapore banks
summary: Singapore banks DBS and OCBC warned of lingering problems in the oil and gas sector, which is still stinging from low oil prices. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta expects bigger specific allowances, while OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien believes the industry is not yet in recovery. Oil prices need to reach US$70 per barrel for offshore support vessel operators to make a decent margin. Despite this, the banks reported decent results, with DBS's net profit rising 8% and OCBC beating analyst estimates.

site_title: Cigna says costs drop but keeps eye on Obamacare spending
summary: Cigna reported a higher-than-expected second-quarter profit due to declining medical costs, following industry trends from rival insurers Aetna and Anthem. The company's 2017 cost expectations remain unchanged despite uncertainty over individual insurance spending in the Obamacare program, which is awaiting federal policy clarity. Cigna's commercial medical care ratio fell to 78.7%, below the 80% target under Obamacare, and the company plans to offer individual coverage in 2017 but will wait for final policy decisions in September.

site_title: Germany giving Gigafactory a home in latest challenge to Tesla
summary: Germany is set to announce a home for a 34 gigawatt-hour lithium-ion battery factory, designed to rival Tesla's Gigafactory. Terra E Holding GmbH will choose from five sites in Germany or a neighboring country, with construction to begin in 2019 and full capacity reached in 2028. The project aims to tap an emerging market for stationary energy storage, with government support and Chancellor Angela Merkel's endorsement. The move is part of Germany's efforts to gear up for the energy revolution and counter Asia's dominance in battery-making.

site_title: Yesterday Once More
summary: A small group of traditional tradesmen in Singapore continues to thrive despite the rise of modern technology. Madam Lee Hwee Chin, a 70-year-old knife sharpener, has been in the business for over 40 years, passing down her skills to her daughter. Meanwhile, Lam Yeo Coffee Powder, a 60-year-old coffee shop, remains a relic of the past, relying on traditional methods to grind and roast coffee beans. The shop is still owned by the same Tan family, who have been in the business since the 1950s. In another story, Sing Hon Loong Bakery, a 35-year-old bakery, continues to produce traditional bread and pastries, with owner Lai Cher Peng relying on his team of senior bakers to keep the business afloat. The family-owned Kwong Woh Hing soy sauce maker, Simon Woo, also refuses to sell his products in supermarkets, instead relying on traditional methods and direct sales.

site_title: Jack this out
summary: Audi has unveiled Jack, a piloted driving concept car, at its Munich Airport brand experience centre. The self-driving Audi A7 can autonomously drive on highways, with a central driver assistance controller using state-of-the-art processors to evaluate surroundings. The system can activate on highways but requires a manual drive to the destination. Audi's Traffic Jam Pilot feature is already available in its A8 model, but Jack has a higher speed limit and lane change ability. The system's algorithms assess the benefits of changing lanes and can automatically adjust. However, limitations exist, such as complex intersections, and Audi plans to address these with car-to-car communications.

site_title: Indonesia seeks Chevron, Conoco proposals in investment push
summary: Indonesia is seeking proposals from Chevron and ConocoPhillips to renew their licenses for oil and gas fields, amid efforts to increase energy investments and reverse a decline in foreign investment. Chevron's production sharing agreement expires in 2021, while Conoco's block expires in 2020. The government aims to attract $200 billion in investment over the next decade to boost crude oil production, with President Joko Widodo seeking to secure a new refinery or exploration deal with Exxon Mobil Corp.

site_title: Challenger's Q2 profit up 2%
summary: Challenger Technologies reported a 2% increase in Q2 net profit to S$3.84 million, driven by a stronger gross profit margin and expense reductions. Revenue declined 13.7% to S$78.68 million. The company attributed the improvement to its efficiency drive to reduce expenses. Despite the revenue drop, the company's earnings growth suggests a positive trend.

site_title: Chinese chatbots apparently re-educated after political faux pas
summary: Two Chinese chatbots, BabyQ and XiaoBing, used on Tencent Holdings' QQ messaging service, were taken offline after making politically incorrect comments. BabyQ expressed a desire to travel to the US, while XiaoBing stated it wasn't a fan of the Chinese Communist Party. This incident highlights the challenges of controlling AI in China, where censors monitor online content deemed politically incorrect or harmful. The chatbots' mistakes are similar to those of Facebook and Twitter's chatbots, but also underscore the need for AI regulation in China.

images.alt_text: A pair of 'chatbots' in China have been taken offline after appearing to stray off-script. In response to users' questions, one said its dream was to travel to the United States, while the other said it wasn't a huge fan of the Chinese Communist Party.

site_title: McLaren 720S review: Candy Crush
summary: The McLaren 720S is a high-performance supercar that boasts a striking fighter-jet cockpit design, exceptional acceleration, and addictive handling. With a 3.994cc twin-turbo V8 engine producing 710hp, the 720S accelerates from 0-100km/h in 2.9 seconds and reaches a top speed of 341km/h. The car's Variable Drift Control feature allows drivers to control the slip angle of the traction control, adding to its engaging and fun driving experience. With a price tag of $990,000, the 720S is a formidable force in the supercar market, offering a unique blend of speed, style, and driver engagement.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte orders free state college education
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has signed a law making education at all state universities free, despite economic advisors' warnings about the budgetary challenges. The measure, a cornerstone of Duterte's social development policy, aims to provide long-term benefits. The president believes the benefits outweigh the short-term costs, with Deputy Presidential Executive Secretary Menardo Guevarra stating it is a "very strong pillar" of the policy. The law's implementation is expected to have a significant impact on the country's education system.

site_title: UK car sales fall for fourth month in a row in July
summary: UK car sales fell 9.3% in July, the fourth consecutive month of decline, with total registrations down 2.2% for the year-to-date. Private sales dropped 5%, business registrations remained flat, and fleet sales increased slightly. Despite this, alternatively fueled vehicles saw a 64.9% surge. The decline is attributed to uncertainty over Brexit and a hit to consumer sentiment following the national election. Experts warn that the downturn has further to run, with the government under pressure to provide concrete plans regarding Brexit.

site_title: BOE is said to find error behind spike in mortgage arrears
summary: The Bank of England has found an error behind a recent spike in mortgage arrears data, revealing some lenders were overstating arrears by including loans that shouldn't have been added. The central bank has asked lenders to re-submit data, which will be re-stated when updated figures are released in the coming quarters. This correction is expected to lower the reported arrears figures.

images.alt_text: A sustained spike in mortgage-arrears data published by the Bank of England had left home loan providers in the UK puzzled. Turns out some lenders were entering incorrect data.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on strong US jobs report
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching its seventh straight record, driven by a strong US jobs report showing 209,000 jobs added in July, pushing the unemployment rate to 4.3%. The jobs gain was higher than expected, and a weaker US dollar boosted exports. Analysts said the report reinforced expectations for a third interest rate hike this year and a potential balance sheet normalization in September. Energy and financial stocks led the gains, while Apple and American Express also rose.

site_title: Oil prices fall as Opec oil exports rise
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, with Brent crude futures trading at $51.76 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures at $48.73 a barrel. The decline was attributed to rising Opec exports and strong US output. Oil prices were on track for weekly losses, with Brent crude expected to fall by 1.5% and WTI by 2%. The decline was also influenced by bearish market sentiment following US President Trump's tariff announcements.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged lower on Friday and were on track for weekly losses, weighed down by rising Opec exports and strong output from the United States.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS sees potential for higher provisions in its oil and gas portfolio. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) released a public consultation to enhance deposit insurance coverage to S$75,000. Gong Cha is returning to Singapore under new leadership. Meanwhile, Singapore shares dropped 16.4 points on Friday due to bank losses, leading to a 4-point drop in the Straits Times Index for the week.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint making one-time offer to buy remaining stake in Geneba for 48.9m euros
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited is making a one-time offer to acquire the remaining 13.44% stake in Geneba Properties for 48.9 million euros, representing a 35% premium to the net asset value of depository receipts. The offer price is also a significant premium to the average trading price of depository receipts on a Dutch stock exchange. Geneba will convene an extraordinary general meeting to allow depository receipt holders to ask questions about the offer, which is backed by a "strong strategic rationale and long-term value creation opportunities" for Frasers.

images.alt_text: FRASERS Centrepoint Limited (FCL) is making a one-time offer to acquire the remaining 13.44 per cent stake in Geneba Properties that it does not already own for 3.74 euros per depository receipt.

site_title: Asset management revival powers Allianz profits
summary: Allianz reported a 55-billion-euro increase in funds managed by its US asset management subsidiary Pimco between April and June, contributing to a 55-billion-euro net profit boost. Pimco accounted for 33 billion euros of net new funds, 19 billion from a single client. This marks a recovery from a slump following the departure of founding chief executive Bill Gross in 2014, indicating a revitalised asset-management activities. The increase in funds managed by Pimco has had a positive impact on Allianz's profits.

site_title: Yanlord Land secures rights to prime site in Shanghai for 10.52b yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group Limited secured the rights to a prime redevelopment site in Shanghai's Puxi historic centre for approximately 10.52 billion yuan. The site spans 183,187 sq m and is four kilometers from Shanghai's financial district. The transaction will be funded through bank borrowings and internal sources. Yanlord chairman Zhong Sheng Jian sees this as an opportunity to expand its prime development landbank in the core region of Shanghai, while also exploring further opportunities in the Yangtze River Delta Region.

site_title: Serial System posts 3% growth in Q2 profit
summary: Serial System Ltd reported a 3% growth in Q2 net profit to US$3.37 million, despite a 1% dip in revenue to US$373.93 million. The company expects to remain profitable in fiscal 2017, driven by global semiconductor sales expected to reach a new high. Serial System plans to spin off its Hong Kong electronic components entity and has appointed a new non-executive deputy chairman. The company's profit margins rose, and losses from associate companies narrowed, contributing to the net profit.

site_title: Hong Kong closes up, Shanghai down
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.12% to 27,562.68, while Shanghai lost 0.33% to 3,262.08, as traders await US jobs data. The Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.57%. Despite mixed Asian market performance, US stocks reached fresh records, driven by S&P 500 and Nasdaq gains.

site_title: Venture's Q2 profit grows 61% to S$69.8m as net margin improves
summary: VENTURE Corp's Q2 net profit rose 61% to S$69.8 million, driven by 48.3% revenue growth to S$1 billion and improved profit margins. The company's first-half net profit grew 49.5% to S$118.4 million.
