Looking ahead, Venture expects uncertainty due to geopolitical tensions and customer consolidations, but has made progress in strategic and operational initiatives.

site_title: Japan Tobacco to buy Indonesian 'kretek' cigarette firms for US$677m
summary: Japan Tobacco Inc. agreed to buy Indonesian "kretek" cigarette firms PT Karyadibya Mahardhika and PT Surya Mustika Nusantara for US$677 million, giving it a bigger footprint in the world's second-largest tobacco market. The deal, valued at US$1 billion including debt, is part of Japan Tobacco's efforts to acquire tobacco businesses in emerging Asian markets. The acquisition aims to expand its presence in Indonesia, a key market for kretek cigarettes.

site_title: UOL posts 59% jump in Q2 profit
summary: UOL Group Limited reported a 59% jump in net profit to S$109.4 million for the second quarter, driven by higher revenue from condominium project Principal Garden and fair value gains on investment properties. Group revenue rose 10% to S$399.1 million, with property development contributing 55% of the revenue. Despite concerns over a possible "disconnect" between land tender prices and achievable end-sale prices, the group's deputy CEO noted that the hospitality and investment businesses performed creditably.

site_title: Macau land row rattles casino bosses ahead of 2020 licence talks
summary: Macau's government has taken a firm stance in disputes with land developers, seizing over 100 plots under a 2013 law aimed at rooting out corruption and better utilizing idle land. This approach has raised concerns among casino executives, who fear it may signal a tough negotiating stance in talks to renew their gaming licences, set to expire in 2020. The government has said it will analyze options for licence renewals, potentially leading to a new public bidding process, which could impact casino operators such as Galaxy Entertainment Group and MGM China.

site_title: Singapore shares finish week lower weighed by bank losses
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) finished the week lower, weighed down by losses in local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB. Despite Wall Street's seventh consecutive all-time high, the STI dropped 16.4 points, a 4-point decline for the week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average crossed 22,000 for the first time, driven by low VIX Index levels and confidence in investors.

site_title: UK publisher Pearson axes 3,000 more jobs
summary: Pearson, a British publisher, has cut an additional 3,000 jobs as part of its cost-cutting drive, accounting for 10% of its global workforce. The job cuts are part of its efficiency plans launched in May, aiming to generate £300 million in annual savings. The company lowered its interim shareholder dividend by 72% and previously removed 4,000 jobs in a restructuring in 2016. Pearson's operating profits rebounded to £16 million in the first half of the year, contrasting with a loss of £286 million the previous year.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank shares slide on money-laundering accusations
summary: Commonwealth Bank shares dropped 3.9% to A$80.70 after being accused of "serious and systemic" breaches of money-laundering rules in a landmark legal case. The bank faces fines of up to A$18 million per breach if convicted. AUSTRAC, the financial intelligence agency, alleged 53,700 breaches of laws against money laundering and terrorist financing. The case casts a shadow over the Australian banking sector, with analysts warning of reputational damage and potential financial penalties.

site_title: LKY School professor Huang Jing banned, has PR cancelled, for being agent of influence for foreign country
summary: A Singaporean professor, Huang Jing, has been banned from the country and had his PR cancelled for allegedly working as an agent of influence for a foreign government. The Ministry of Home Affairs stated that Huang used his position at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy to advance a foreign country's agenda, providing "privileged information" to influential Singaporeans and recruiting others to aid his operations. Huang's permanent residency was cancelled, and his entry and re-entry permits were revoked, marking the first publicly known case of its kind in nearly two decades.

site_title: Blaze rips through Dubai skyscraper The Torch
summary: A fire broke out on the 65th floor of Dubai's The Torch skyscraper, prompting an evacuation of residents, but no casualties were reported. The blaze, which started at 12:45am, was extinguished by 2:58am. This is the second fire to hit the tower in as many years, following a 2015 inferno that caused extensive damage. Authorities have implemented tougher rules to minimize fire risks, following a series of tower blazes in the emirate.

site_title: Jardine Matheson's H1 profit more than doubles to US$2.08b
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings' net profit for the six months ended June 30 more than doubled to US$2.08 billion, driven by a surge in fair value change of investment properties. Underlying profit rose 20% to US$765 million, and revenue increased 8% to US$19.4 billion. The company declared an increased interim dividend of 40 US cents per share. Despite strong first-half performance, the group chairman expects tempered profit growth in the second half due to fewer residential completions and price competition in automotive markets.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng's Q2 profit down on reduced margins, higher expenses
summary: Chip Eng Seng's Q2 net profit plummeted 94.3% to S$819,000, down from 2.3 cents a year ago, due to reduced margins and higher marketing and distribution expenses. Revenue fell 9.3% to S$212.6 million, and the company's net asset value per share decreased to 120.25 Singapore cents. The construction division won a tender for S$110.8 million and lifted its order book to S$538.4 million, but the company expects Singapore's rental market to remain challenging.

site_title: Cyber expert who stopped 'WannaCry' attack arrested in US on hacking charges
summary: Cyber security researcher Marcus Hutchins, 23, was arrested in Las Vegas on hacking charges related to malware code "Kronos" that stole online banking credentials and credit card data. Hutchins, credited with helping to neutralize the WannaCry ransomware attack, faces six counts and was indicted along with an unnamed co-defendant. The indictment alleges Hutchins profited from Kronos between 2014 and 2015, with victims in multiple countries. Hutchins' arrest was unrelated to WannaCry and some experts questioned the charges, citing a need for government intent to further a crime.

site_title: Sterling up after biggest daily loss in month, outlook wary
summary: Sterling recovered from its largest daily loss in a month, edging 0.2% higher to 1.316, after the Bank of England kept interest rates at record lows and lowered growth and inflation forecasts. The pound briefly reached an 11-month high of $1.3267, following a 4.5% rise over six weeks. Analysts expect Brexit-related headlines to drive sterling's movement, with a cautious outlook from the Bank of England and ING strategists.

site_title: Singapore Q2 GDP to be released on Aug 11, 8am
summary: Singapore's Q2 GDP data will be released on August 11 at 8am, following an advance estimate of 2.5% year-on-year growth in the three months to June. The detailed report will include sectoral performance, sources of growth, inflation, employment, and productivity.

site_title: Cosco Shipping International (S) shrinks Q2 loss by 43%
summary: Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) reported a 43% decrease in its Q2 net loss to S$20.81 million, primarily due to lower cost of sales and administrative expenses. The company's loss per share decreased to 0.93 Singapore cents, compared to 1.64 Singapore cents in the previous year. Gross profit surged 80% to S$20.76 million, while turnover declined 31% to S$524.74 million. The company also announced a proposed acquisition of a 40% equity stake in Jakarta-based PT Ocean Global Shipping, to be funded by divesting its stake in yard-operating units.

images.alt_text: Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) Company slashed its second quarter net loss by 43 per cent to S$20.81 million mainly on lower cost of sales and administrative expenses.

site_title: The magic behind many unicorn startups: complex stock contracts
summary: A study by business professors at the University of British Columbia and Stanford University found that about half of private companies valued at over $1 billion, known as unicorns, rely on complex stock mechanics to achieve their high valuations. These mechanics, such as liquidation preferences and ratchets, can inflate valuations by up to 94% and 56% respectively, often at the expense of employees and early shareholders. The study highlights the need for more transparency in valuing private businesses and suggests that investors should carefully review contractual terms.

site_title: Hogwarts comes to Hunan: Chinese officials sacked for casting spells
summary: Two Chinese officials, a former county housing official in Hunan, have been sacked for practicing superstitious activities, including casting spells and attending geomancy courses. They were accused of using these activities to aid promotions and were expelled from the ruling Communist Party. The officials had claimed business expenses for the courses, which cost around $10,916 each. Both will be further investigated for suspected criminal acts.

site_title: 56-year-old man who robbed Western Union outlet in Ubi arrested
summary: A 56-year-old Singaporean man has been arrested for robbing a Western Union outlet in Ubi Avenue 1 on Tuesday. He was apprehended along Pasir Ris Drive 6 on Thursday. No further details about the incident or the suspect's motivations are available.

site_title: GSH's Q2 earnings leap to S$71.7m from loss; revenue soars 72.9% to S$30.6m
summary: GSH Corporation reported a significant turnaround in its Q2 earnings, with a net profit of S$71.7 million, compared to a net loss of S$3.2 million in the previous year. Revenue soared 72.9% to S$30.6 million, driven by a disposal gain of S$74.9 million from the sale of Plaza Ventures. Earnings per share reversed to 3.66 Singapore cents, and net asset value per share grew to 21.2 Singapore cents. The company plans to pay a special dividend of one Singapore cent per share and has strengthened its balance sheet.

site_title: Skills Frameworks for food services and retail sectors launched
summary: Singapore has launched Skills Frameworks for the food services and retail sectors, aiming to support training and career development. The frameworks provide information on career pathways and emerging skills, supporting industry transformation and innovation. Employers can access grants and training subsidies to help offset costs and encourage adoption of new technologies. A two-day career fair featuring over 1,200 job vacancies is also being held to promote job opportunities.

site_title: Two Qantas planes turn back to Australia over safety concerns
summary: Two Qantas flights, an Airbus A380 and a Boeing aircraft, were forced to turn back to Sydney due to mid-air mechanical issues. The Airbus A380, en route to Dallas, experienced issues with retracting wing flaps, while the Boeing aircraft had a cracked window pane. Both flights returned to Sydney for further inspection and maintenance, with one flight being the longest on the network. The incidents raised concerns about the safety of Qantas' international flights.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as exporters slip
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.38% due to a strengthening yen against the US dollar. The decline was attributed to soft US data and a new report on the Trump administration's Russia probe. The Topix index also dropped 0.15%. This marks a close to a weak week for Tokyo stocks, with the benchmark index ending at 19,952.33.

site_title: RBS plans to make Amsterdam its EU base after Brexit
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) plans to establish Amsterdam as its EU base after Brexit, aiming to employ around 150 staff in its trading division NatWest Markets. The move follows the bank's acquisition of ABN Amro in 2008. RBS CEO Ross McEwan stated that the Amsterdam unit will continue to operate smoothly post-Brexit, despite the current staff being "just a handful." The bank's decision aims to ensure continuity in trading operations amidst the UK's exit from the European Union.

site_title: DBS sees more provisions ahead in oil and gas portfolio
summary: DBS Bank's CEO Piyush Gupta said specific provisions for its oil and gas portfolio could be S$300 million next year due to asset quality pressures. The bank has a S$7 billion exposure to oil and gas support services, with S$5.4 billion to smaller players lacking pricing power. Meanwhile, DBS sees a strong pick-up in housing activity, with new mortgage bookings at its highest in five years, accounting for 28.7% of the housing loan market.

site_title: Hot stock: DBS tumbles on CEO's warning of more provisions for its O&G portfolio
summary: DBS Group shares fell 2.7% on Friday after CEO Piyush Gupta warned that provisions for its oil and gas portfolio could reach S$300 million next year. This is lower than the previous guidance, causing a 59-cents drop to S$21.49. The drop was largely due to investor concerns over increased provisions, leading to a 2.31% decline.

site_title: European shares slip weighed by Swiss Re; RBS up
summary: European shares slipped 0.1% on Friday, tracking a decline in Swiss Re, the world's second-largest reinsurer, after missing profit estimates. However, Royal Bank of Scotland rose 3.5% after its first-half profit. Nearly two-thirds of MSCI Europe-listed companies have released results, with 61% beating or matching expectations. The Stoxx 600 index is on track to end the week flat, following two straight weeks of declines.

site_title: MAS proposes enhancement of deposit insurance coverage to S$75,000
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed enhancing the Deposit Insurance (DI) Scheme to increase coverage to S$75,000 from the current S$50,000. The move aims to restore the percentage of fully insured depositors to above 90%, in line with international norms. The public consultation will end on September 4, and MAS plans to achieve a targeted DI Fund size of 30 basis points of total insured deposits by extending the build-up period to 2028 and revising annual premium rates to 2.5-8 basis points.

site_title: Li Shengwu responds to AGC over Facebook post
summary: Li Shengwu, the eldest son of Lee Hsien Yang, has responded to the Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) over a Facebook post he made on July 15. The AGC claimed the post was an attack on the Singapore judiciary and in contempt of court. However, Li Shengwu denied the allegations, stating the post was not an attack on the judiciary. The dispute highlights the tension between the Lee family and the government, with Li Shengwu's post sparking controversy over the handling of his family's assets and potential influence over the judiciary.

site_title: Australia shares falter as CBA falls nearly 4%, NZ steady
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Friday, led by a 3.8% drop in Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) shares after it was accused of money laundering by the government. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,720.6. Despite the loss, the benchmark index still finished the week 0.3% higher after two consecutive weekly declines.

site_title: LSE's new Brexit plan to protect London financial-hub status
summary: London Stock Exchange Group Plc has launched a Brexit strategy to protect London's financial hub status. The program will engage with British and European officials to guide them on Brexit's impact on markets and prevent financial-market fragmentation. LSE's goal is to maintain continuity of cross-border financial services. The company's clearing unit, LCH, reported a 31% increase in total income in the first half, and investors remain confident in LSE's growth prospects. The European Commission recommended direct oversight of non-EU clearinghouses, but LSE aims to maintain its position as a key financial hub.

site_title: Millennium & Copthorne Q2 pre-tax profit up 22%; declares interim dividend of 2.08p
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) reported a 22% increase in pre-tax profit to £50 million in the second quarter, driven by 6.1% revenue growth to £262 million. The company declared an interim dividend of 2.08p per share. Despite improved results, Chairman Kwek Leng Beng noted "continuing pressure" on hotel profitability, particularly in North Asia and New York, where the region is underperforming. The company aims to strengthen its US operations through management changes and new contracts.

site_title: Noble Energy results beat, but output forecast drags on stock
summary: Noble Energy Inc posted a surprise quarterly profit, excluding special items, driven by rising crude prices and cost cuts. The company reported a second-quarter loss of $1.5 billion, but its shares fell 4.7% due to a tepid production forecast of 340,000-350,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, below Wall Street's expectations. Noble's capital spending for the year is forecast to be at the top end of its range, with most going to US shale operations.

site_title: Toyota Q1 net profit up 11% to 613 billion yen, boosts FY forecast
summary: Toyota reported a 11% increase in Q1 net profit to 613 billion yen ($7.6 billion), driven by vehicle sales growth in Japan and the US. The company lifted its annual earnings forecast to 1.75 trillion yen, up from 1.5 trillion yen. Operating profit fell 11% due to currency fluctuations. Toyota's previous annual profit had been its first drop in five years, attributed to customer incentives in the competitive US market.

site_title: Thai economy seen growing 3.5-3.6% this year: Finance Ministry
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3.5-3.6% this year, driven by investment in infrastructure projects, according to Finance Minister Apisak Tantivorawong. This growth is attributed to government projects that will also attract private investment. The forecast surpasses last year's 3.2% growth rate, although still lags behind regional peers.

site_title: RBS reports first-half profit as recovery gathers pace
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) reported its first-half profit of £939 million, following a £2 billion loss in the same period last year. The bank, which has not made an annual profit since 2007, is in discussions with the Dutch central bank to conduct its trading business in the Netherlands. RBS is behind its rivals in returning to profitability and faces outstanding legal problems, including a settlement with the US Department of Justice over mis-selling of mortgage backed securities. The bank's core capital ratio rose to 14.8%.

images.alt_text: Royal Bank of Scotland on Friday said it posted a profit in the first half of 2017 following a £2 billion (S$3.6 billion) loss in the same period last year amid hefty restructuring and legal costs.

site_title: Gong Cha to return to Singapore
summary: Gong Cha, a bubble tea brand, is returning to Singapore under the leadership of Kang Puay Peng, the ex co-founder and managing director of Mr Bean. Royal Taiwan Tea, the company behind Gong Cha, aims to revive the brand to its former glory. The new CEO's appointment marks the first step in this endeavor.

images.alt_text: Bubble tea brand Gong Cha announced its return to Singapore, this time under the leadership of Kang Puay Peng, the ex co-founder and managing director of successful soya milk brand Mr Bean.

site_title: Firefighters extinguish blaze in Dubai residential skyscraper
summary: Firefighters in Dubai successfully extinguished a blaze in the 79-storey Torch residential skyscraper, forcing occupants to evacuate their homes. The blaze, which started on the 67th floor, spread to lower levels and was brought under control by 4:00am local time. No injuries were reported, and the government is working to provide shelter for those affected. This is the second major fire at the tower since 2015, when hundreds of people were evacuated from a previous blaze.

site_title: Japan June nominal and real pay fall year-o-year, a blow to consumption
summary: Japan's workers experienced a decline in wages in June, with nominal cash earnings falling 0.4% year-over-year and real wages dropping 0.8%, the largest decline since 2015. Base compensation rose 0.4% and overtime pay decreased 0.2%. The decline in real wages threatens consumer spending and inflation, posing a challenge to Japan's economic recovery.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks bounce off 4-week low; end down for the week
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded from a four-week low on Friday, closing 0.4% higher due to domestic institutions buying into bargains. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) ended the week 0.2% lower. Foreign investors sold technology firms, while local institutions added 213.6 billion won worth to their portfolios. Construction shares rose 1.2%, and LG Electronics jumped 5% in late trade. The South Korean won strengthened against the US dollar, closing at 1,125.0 to the dollar, up 0.3% from the previous day.

site_title: Hong Kong opens flat after new Wall St high
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Friday, despite a new Wall Street record, due to regional market declines ahead of US economic data. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.01% to 27,527.47, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.11% and 0.05% respectively. The flat opening was attributed to regional market declines, with US stocks continuing to edge towards fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: South Korea spy agency admits attempting to rig election
summary: South Korea's National Intelligence Service (NIS) has admitted to attempting to rig the 2012 parliamentary and presidential elections by organizing cyber warfare units to manipulate voters. The agency hired civilians to spread pro-government opinions and suppress anti-government views on social media platforms. The investigation found that the NIS also ordered the press to be muzzled and opposition politicians to be under secret surveillance. The admission comes amid ongoing corruption and abuse of power investigations, including the impeachment of former President Park Geun Hye.

site_title: Ascott appointed to operate two new serviced residences
summary: Low Keng Huat has entered agreements with The Ascott Limited to manage two new serviced residences, Citadines Balestier Singapore and lyf Farrer Park Singapore, both set to open in 2021. The developments will be funded by internal funds and borrowings from financial institutions, with no expected impact on the company's financials for the current year. Citadines Balestier Singapore will feature 166 units, including studios and one-bedroom apartments, while lyf Farrer Park Singapore will have 240 units, including co-living features and a social kitchen.

site_title: Firefighters extinguish blaze in Dubai residential skyscraper
summary: Firefighters in Dubai successfully extinguished a blaze in the 79-storey Torch residential skyscraper early Friday morning. The blaze, which started on the 67th floor, forced occupants to evacuate and showering burning debris down the sides of the building. No injuries were reported, but the tower was evacuated and authorities are providing shelter for those affected. This is the second major fire at the structure since 2015, and the Dubai government is working to address the issue. Firefighters put out the blaze by around 4am, and the exterior of the building showed no signs of fire by then.

site_title: Angry Trump says Russia ties at 'very dangerous low'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that relations with Russia have reached an "all-time and very dangerous low" after reluctantly approving sanctions against Moscow. The sanctions, which target the Russian energy sector, were passed by Congress despite Trump's criticism of the legislation. Russia has retaliated with measures to cut diplomatic staff in the US and has accused Trump of showing weakness. The move comes amid ongoing investigations into alleged collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 presidential election.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks pull away from lows, but on track for losing week
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.2% in early trade on Friday, edging away from four-week lows, but still on track for a second straight losing week. The Kospi index closed at 2,392.20 points. The construction sector, which fell 1.7% on Thursday, rose 1.5% and helped limit gains. Foreign investors sold tech shares, while the South Korean won rose 0.3% against the US dollar due to US political uncertainties.

site_title: Oxley buys 7.11% of UEL for S$120.3m, but will not be making competing offer for UEL
summary: Oxley Holdings acquired a 7.11% stake in United Engineers Limited (UEL) for approximately S$120.3 million, purchasing 45.3 million shares through open market transactions. The investment aligns with Oxley's objective of acquiring income-generating assets. No competing offer was made for UEL.

site_title: Malaysian PM Najib under pressure over French sub deal
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak faces renewed pressure over a 2002 submarine deal worth nearly $1.6 billion, after a close associate was charged in France with alleged kickbacks. Abdul Razak Baginda, who advised Najib at the time, denies wrongdoing but was charged with corruption and misappropriation of corporate assets. Suaram, a Malaysian rights group, urges Malaysian authorities to take action, calling for Najib to answer for the deal.

site_title: MAS responds to Iceberg on Noble Group
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has responded to Iceberg's accusation that regulators failed to prevent Noble Group's financial woes. MAS stated it will take enforcement actions if it finds any violations of regulations through its investigation. The regulator also vowed to probe potential law breaches referred to it by Iceberg Research, which criticized the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and MAS for allowing Noble to raise funds despite questions over its balance sheet.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.77 points to 1,772.67. The market saw 24.6 million lots traded worth RM10.5 million, with 79 gainers outnumbering 44 losers.

site_title: Surprisingly fleet-footed giant tortoise escapes Japan zoo... again
summary: A 55kg female giant tortoise escaped from the Shibukawa Animal Park in Japan for the second time in less than two weeks. The 35-year-old tortoise, with a "gentle" disposition, was seen on security cameras walking out of the main entrance on Tuesday morning. It was last spotted 150m away from the zoo on July 21. Zoo staff are searching for the reptile, which is allowed to walk freely inside the park during opening hours, and are concerned about its safety as it may eat grass and potentially cause harm.

site_title: Pope "loves China", Vatican official says on trip to China
summary: Pope Francis has expressed goodwill towards China, stating he "loves China" and hopes the country has a great future, according to a Chinese state-run newspaper. This comes amid strained relations between the Vatican and China, where Catholics are divided between loyalists and those in the government-controlled church. The Pope aims to heal a decades-old rift, but disagreements over senior clerical appointments and the Vatican's ties with Taiwan remain obstacles.

images.alt_text: Pope Francis "loves China" and the Vatican hopes China has a great future, a Chinese state-run newspaper on Friday cited a visiting Vatican official as saying, in an expression of goodwill despite strained relations between the two.

site_title: Australia slams brake on property investors and prices cool
summary: Australia is experiencing a slowdown in its housing market as regulators impose restrictions on property investors, including minimum deposits and increased interest rates on interest-only mortgages. The measures, aimed at ensuring the financial system can weather a property downturn, are also expected to make it easier for first-time buyers to enter the market. As a result, home prices in Sydney and Melbourne, two of the world's most expensive cities, are cooling, with price growth slowing to 2.2% and 4.2% respectively. Experts predict a decline in median Sydney house prices by 5% by mid-2019.

images.alt_text: Property investors, who have helped stoke soaring home prices in Australia, are being squeezed as regulators impose restrictions to rein in lending.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday due to a stronger yen, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 0.41% and the Topix index down 0.34%. This decline follows a rally in Singapore stocks, which notched a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, US stocks reached fresh records despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariffs.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday as exporters fell on a stronger yen.

site_title: SingPost's Q1 net profit slides 13.6%
summary: SingPost reported a 13.6% decline in Q1 net profit to S$31 million, from S$35.9 million a year ago. Revenue rose 6.2% to S$354.1 million due to growth in postal and logistics segments. Underlying net profit fell 24.7% due to lower mail volumes and increased competition. Free cash flow improved to S$32 million, and the company declared an interim dividend of 0.5 cents per share.

site_title: Australia plane plot directed by 'senior' IS commander: police
summary: Australian police allege a senior Islamic State commander directed a group of Australian men to build a bomb for an Etihad Airways flight out of Sydney. The improvised explosive device was to be smuggled onto a July 15 service, but the attempt was aborted before reaching security. Two men have been charged, with a third still being questioned. The alleged plot was orchestrated by a "senior member of the Islamic State" based overseas.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% up on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 2.69 points to 3,345.61. The gains came on the back of mixed US markets overnight, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq falling due to technology stocks, while the Dow Jones edged up to a record high. Investors await US jobs data, expected to show a 10th consecutive decline in unemployment to 4.3%.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks opened 0.1 per cent higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 2.69 points to 3,345.61 as at 9 am, on the back of mixed US markets overnight.

site_title: Air France extends no-fly zone around North Korea
summary: Air France is extending its non-flyover zone around North Korea after a missile test, with the zone now 100km wider. The move comes after a missile fell into the sea 100km from a flight's trajectory on July 28, with 323 people on board. Air France stated the distance was "not bringing into question the safety of the flight" and that the plane passed off without incident. The precautionary measure follows similar incidents, such as the downing of Malaysia Airlines MH17 in 2014.

site_title: Laos leaning away from China and towards Vietnam
summary: Laos is shifting its focus away from China and towards Vietnam under the new leadership of President Bounnhang Vorachit and Prime Minister Thongloun Sisoulith. The country is seeking to strengthen diplomatic ties with the US and improve relations with the West, driven by growing dissatisfaction with Chinese dominance and high-handed business practices. Trade talks with the US have begun, and Laos has strengthened ties with Vietnam, with both countries investing heavily in the country. The move is seen as a strategic shift, with Laos aiming to exercise its autonomy and avoid behaving like Cambodia, a country closely aligned with China.

site_title: With a bit of love, Japan's Subaru soars in US while rivals falter
summary: Subaru Corp, Japan's 6th largest automaker, reported a 17.5% rise in quarterly operating profit to 119.3 billion yen, driven by a 12.3% jump in US sales. This success contrasts with its rivals, who have been impacted by a slowing US car market. Subaru's unconventional marketing strategy and focus on sedans have contributed to its growth, bucking the trend of preferring bigger vehicle models.

site_title: Struggling US dollar awaits US jobs report for potential relief
summary: The US dollar dropped to a 2-1/2-year low against the euro and a seven-week trough against the yen due to weak US data and uncertainty about the Federal Reserve's policy tightening. The dollar has been struggling throughout the week, with a grand jury investigation into Russian election meddling and the release of the Institute of Supply Management's manufacturing index adding to market concerns. The US jobs report, set to be released later, is expected to provide potential relief for the dollar.

site_title: Toyota, Mazda said to jointly build US$1.6b US plant
summary: Toyota Motor Corp and Mazda Motor Corp are reportedly nearing a deal to jointly build a $1.6 billion US factory in Michigan, with the capacity to produce 300,000 compact cars and crossovers per year. The facility will create 4,000 jobs and be operational by 2021. The partnership is seen as a response to President Donald Trump's pressure to build more vehicles in the US, and will also facilitate joint development of electric-car technology. Toyota may purchase a 5% stake in Mazda, which will invest in its Japanese peer.

site_title: Uber leased more than 1,000 defective Honda cars in S'pore that were fire-prone: WSJ
summary: Uber leased over 1,000 defective Honda cars in Singapore that were prone to fires, despite being aware of a recall. The vehicles were used in Uber's auto-lending program, which borrowed capital from Goldman Sachs and other banks. After a car burst into flames in January, Uber took swift action to fix the problem and worked with Singapore officials. The company acknowledged it could have done more and vowed to proactively respond to vehicle recalls to protect users' safety. Uber had previously settled a US Federal Trade Commission lawsuit over alleged violations of its leasing program.

site_title: Macron's popularity slumping, poll shows
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's popularity has slumped to 36% in a YouGov poll, down seven points from his election in May. The poll, conducted on July 26-27, found 49% of respondents have a negative view, a 13-point increase. Macron's centrist government has implemented public spending cuts, and critics say his communication style is becoming unpopular. Experts attribute the decline to the public's perception of his austerity policies, citing a "Hollywood-like style of communicating" to bring in spending cuts.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust's DPS down 4% for Q2
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 4% drop in distribution per stapled security to 0.97 Singapore cents for Q2 2017. Net property income fell 1.4% to S$23.15 million, while gross revenue declined 1% to S$25.88 million. Revenue per available room for hotels fell 1.3%, and for serviced residences, it dropped 5.7%. The trust expects a competitive operating environment in the next few quarters, with its serviced residences expected to be impacted more due to soft demand from the corporate segment.

site_title: Singapore-listed TT International suspends trading as it sorts out funding options
summary: Singapore-listed consumer electronics retailer TT International has suspended trading of its shares as it sorts out funding options. The company, being restructured since 2010, is facing creditors' demands for repayment of a S$125 million loan facility. TT International has obtained a non-binding term sheet for up to S$380 million in funding to refinance debt, pending satisfactory due diligence. The company believes this option would provide a total resolution for the group, but is seeking an extension of time to repay its debt. Trading will remain suspended until further notice.

site_title: Europe: Earnings buoy shares but DAX hurt by Siemens
summary: European shares rose 0.08% to 378.93 points, driven by solid company earnings, but Siemens' 3.1% slide in the DAX index hindered the German blue chip's performance. Despite this, strategists upgraded German stocks to 'outperform' due to the euro's rise, creating an unmerited valuation gap. Earnings updates from UniCredit, Bic, and Next also supported the market, with nearly two-thirds of MSCI Europe companies beating or meeting analyst expectations, pointing to a 22% second-quarter earnings growth.

site_title: GIC, Macquarie funds offer to buy Philippines' EDC shares for up to 64.5b pesos
summary: A consortium led by Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC and Macquarie Infrastructure Management has offered to buy approximately 31.7% of Philippine renewable power producer Energy Development Corp (EDC) for up to 64.5 billion pesos. The proposed investment, valued at up to $1.75 billion, would represent a 21.8% premium over EDC's closing price. EDC's parent company, First Gen Corp, will retain control with a 60% voting stake. The tender offer will run from August 10 to September 18.

site_title: Star Wars lands in the heart of Orchard Road
summary: ION Orchard in Singapore will be transformed into a Star Wars galaxy starting September 1 as part of a 10-day festival celebrating the hit sci-fi franchise. The event, called Star Wars: Experience the Force, will feature pop-up experiences, installations, and a virtual reality experience with BB-8. A Padawan Training ground will be set up for kids, while a Millennium Falcon installation will be on display. The festival is supported by the Singapore Tourism Board and The Walt Disney Company Southeast Asia, and will run until September 10.

site_title: China in talks to sell electricity to Myanmar amid warming ties
summary: Myanmar is in talks with China to buy electricity, amid warming ties between the two countries under Aung San Suu Kyi's leadership. The energy-hungry nation seeks to repair relations strained by a previous government's blockage of a China-backed dam project in 2011. China's appetite for the hydro project has decreased due to an economic slowdown, leaving Yunnan province with a surplus of power. The talks come as China seeks to increase its influence in the region.

site_title: The Ascott to invest S$170m to develop co-living space at Funan integrated project
summary: The Ascott, a serviced residence operator, will invest S$170.3 million to develop a co-living space at the Funan integrated project in Singapore. The 9-storey property, named lyf Funan Singapore, will span 121,000 sq ft and open in 2020. This is part of The Ascott's 50:50 global fund with Qatar Investment Authority, which has committed US$600 million (S$809 million) to acquisitions. The investment includes acquiring land and developing the Singapore flagship of Ascott's lyf brand.

site_title: Brexit-wary Bank of England leaves rates on hold, cuts growth forecast
summary: The Bank of England kept interest rates at a record low, citing Brexit uncertainty and its impact on the economy. Governor Mark Carney warned that the economy's growth could be slowed, potentially leading to a rate hike. The Bank now forecasts 1.7% economic growth this year and 1.6% in 2018, down from previous forecasts. The pound fell to a nine-month low against the euro and shares rose. Investors pushed back their expectation of the first interest rate hike to December next year, citing a wary tone from Carney about Brexit.

site_title: Oil retreats on concerns about Opec oversupply
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday as cautious buying dried up after US crude rose to near $50 a barrel. Benchmark Brent crude settled at $52.01 a barrel, while US light crude fell to $49.03. Opec crude oil exports reached a record high in July, driven by African exports, but high production and robust US demand have limited price gains. Analysts predict prices will remain in the low to mid $50s for the remainder of 2017, citing a major rally as unlikely.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank sued for alleged money laundering breaches
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia has been sued by the government's financial crime agency, Austrac, over 53,700 alleged breaches of money laundering and terrorism financing laws. Austrac alleges the bank failed to report suspicious transactions and didn't monitor customers to mitigate risk, allowing drug rings to move the proceeds of crime through the bank's automated cash deposit machines. The case is the latest crisis to engulf the bank, which has been hit with a tax to plug the budget deficit and faces calls for a Royal Commission into the financial industry.

site_title: Inspired by the soul of motion
summary: Mazda redesigned its fortunes by adopting a new design direction called "Kodo" in 2011, focusing on "soul of motion" and drawing inspiration from animals. The design chief, Ikuo Maeda, rallied the 200-strong design department around this philosophy, encouraging them to think like artists. Mazda gave designers more influence than usual, allowing them to work closely with engineers to achieve a 50:50 weight distribution in the MX-5, a successful collaboration that benefited both departments. This approach helped Mazda turn its fortunes around and create more beautiful designs.

site_title: German carmakers in emissions deal to avert ban on diesel vehicles
summary: German carmakers agree to overhaul engine software on 5.3 million diesel cars to reduce pollution, aiming to repair industry's reputation. However, environmentalists deem the plan insufficient and vow to press ahead with legal action to ban polluting vehicles. Chancellor Merkel's government faces pressure to crack down on vehicle pollution ahead of the national election. The agreement comes as the UK and France announce plans to ban diesel and petrol vehicles, and Tesla launches its first mass-market electric car, further increasing stakes for German manufacturers.

site_title: How hot weather in changing climate affects airline flights
summary: High temperatures due to climate change are affecting airline flights, particularly in hot regions. Weight curbs are being implemented on flights taking off during the hottest parts of the day due to reduced air density, which impacts aircraft take-off performance. Research suggests that major airports worldwide will experience more frequent weight restrictions, with potential effects on airline costs and global transportation systems. The frequency and intensity of extreme heat events and coastal flooding are projected to increase, posing significant challenges for airports and the aviation industry.

site_title: US: Dow edges to record, Nasdaq drops ahead of jobs data
summary: US stocks finished mostly lower on Thursday ahead of the key US jobs report, with the Dow narrowly edging to its seventh straight record close. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose less than 0.1% to 22,026.10, while the S&P 500 shed 0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.4%. Analysts expect the jobs report to show a 181,000 job gain and a 4.3% unemployment rate, which could boost the odds of a Federal Reserve rate hike.

site_title: How can Singapore produce formidable entrepreneurs?
summary: Singapore can produce formidable entrepreneurs by focusing on the efforts of entrepreneurs themselves, rather than solely relying on government support. The government's existing support for entrepreneurs and startups is crucial, but it's the entrepreneurs who must take the lead and put in the effort to succeed. This includes adopting a "great" vision, being street-smart, and embracing failure and uncertainty. By letting young entrepreneurs experience entrepreneurship and failure early, and avoiding straddling strategy, Singapore can cultivate a culture that fosters innovation and world-class entrepreneurs.

site_title: Study explores link between homelessness and rent hikes
summary: A study by Zillow found a significant link between rent hikes and homelessness in major US cities. The study discovered that for every 1% increase in rent, approximately 83 people become homeless. However, the relationship between rising rents and homelessness varies greatly depending on the location, with cities like New York seeing around 3,000 homeless individuals for a 5% rent increase. The study highlights the need for targeted policies to address homelessness, particularly in areas with rapidly increasing rents.

site_title: Wells Fargo insurance scandal draws New York subpoenas
summary: New York regulators have sent subpoenas to Wells Fargo's vehicle lending unit and bank consultant Oliver Wyman related to practices involving collateral protection insurance. The bank has admitted to potentially pushing thousands of car buyers into loan defaults and repossessions by charging them for unwanted insurance. Wells Fargo may pay up to $80 million to affected clients and has already started making restitution. Customers have filed lawsuits, alleging the bank bilked millions of dollars from unsuspecting customers.

site_title: Little eatery with an endearing appeal
summary: Restaurant Gaig, a Singaporean branch of the one-Michelin-starred Spanish eatery, has opened its doors in Stanley Street. The restaurant is led by Esteve Garcia Vilanova, who trained at the original Restaurant Gaig in Spain. The menu features authentic Catalan dishes, including fideua, paella, and patatas bravas. Despite some dishes being under-seasoned, the restaurant's endearing appeal and sincere desire to share its culture make it a must-visit. The restaurant's commitment to using high-quality ingredients and traditional recipes shines through, making it a standout in Singapore's dining scene.

site_title: Appetite for faster growth could fuel cross-border deals in S-E Asia: report
summary: A report by Kroll and Mergermarket suggests that South-east Asian regional corporates seeking faster growth could lead to increased cross-border merger and acquisition (M&A) activity in the region. In 2016, intra-regional deals reached a value of US$18.9 billion, a fourfold increase from the previous year. Although 2017 started slowly due to economic uncertainty, the report expects a pick-up in M&A activity for the rest of the year. This trend could repeat, potentially mirroring the 2016 figure.

site_title: Big Pharma seeks patients in India's remote corners
summary: Global pharmaceutical companies, including Eli Lilly & Co and Novartis AG, are expanding into India's remote regions to understand healthcare needs and capture market share in the growing diabetes and heart disease market. These areas, which comprise 70% of the population, are considered the final frontier for the international drug industry. Companies are taking a longer-term approach to establish a presence in these areas, aiming to capitalize on the increasing demand for pharmaceuticals.

site_title: HDB resale prices continue to dip but volumes are up
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore fell 0.6% in July from the previous month, following a 0.2% decline in June. Despite this, resale volumes increased by 1.8% from June and 12.2% from the same period last year. Experts attribute the decline in prices to increased negotiating power for buyers, while rising volumes are expected to support prices. The overall resale price index for HDB flats is down 1.6% year-on-year, and 12.2% below its peak in April 2013.

site_title: Challenges abound for Iran's nuclear deal with the West
summary: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani is set to begin his second term amidst growing controversy over the country's 2015 nuclear deal with the West. Tehran claims a US sanctions bill contravenes the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), and has proposed countermeasures, including limiting International Atomic Energy Agency monitoring. The deal's future is under threat from US President Donald Trump, who has expressed opposition to the agreement and imposed new sanctions. Despite economic growth, Iran faces high unemployment and a sluggish industrial sector, which may lead to domestic public backlash unless the economy improves.

site_title: Hyflux sinks into the red with S$25.1m Q2 loss; revenue plunges 65% to S$81.8m
summary: Hyflux Ltd reported a net loss of S$25.1 million in its second quarter, down from a net profit of S$2.6 million in the same period last year. The company's revenue plummeted 65% to S$81.8 million due to a weak Singapore power market and the Tuaspring Integrated Water and Power Plant, which remains classified as Held for Sale. This marks a significant decline from the previous year's profit, highlighting the company's struggles.

site_title: Fears of SoftBank default jump as Son mulls Charter takeover
summary: SoftBank Group Corp's debt burden could balloon further if it pursues a bid for Charter Communications Inc. The company has lined up up to $65 billion in financing, increasing concerns among investors about its ability to manage debt. SoftBank's debt-to-earnings ratio is about 5.67, more than double its telecom peers. The yield premium on its perpetual bonds has surged, and credit-default swaps could rise to 200 basis points if the company takes on significant debt for the acquisition. Investors are skeptical about the move, citing it as not aligned with SoftBank's strategic plans.

site_title: Sculpting your own success
summary: Mazda's focus on design has led to record profits, with the Japanese brand booking new profit records for three consecutive years. In 2017, Mazda saw impressive results, including a 3.6% increase in production volume for the first six months of the year, reaching 784,056 cars and commercial vehicles. This overhaul of its design approach has contributed significantly to the company's success, suggesting that a clear direction in design can have a direct impact on a company's bottom line.

site_title: NEC to plough over S$100m into Asia-Pacific, largely for R&D
summary: NEC Corporation is investing over S$100 million in the Asia-Pacific region over the next five years, mainly for research and development. The company has set up its first Advanced Centre for Experimentation (ACE) in Singapore, which aims to boost global R&D strengths. The facility will allow co-creation of solutions and provide a "living lab" for proof-of-concepts in areas like public safety, transportation, and healthcare. NEC plans to train over 50 individuals in research, data science, and engineering roles, and develop cutting-edge technologies for end-user clients.

site_title: New website aims to track Russian-backed propaganda on Twitter
summary: A new website, "Hamilton 68," has been launched to track Russian-backed propaganda on Twitter, part of efforts to diminish Moscow's ability to meddle in US and European elections. The website, built by researchers with the Alliance for Securing Democracy, analyzes 600 Twitter accounts identified as spreading Russian propaganda. The site was launched amid concerns that Russia will attempt to interfere in the 2018 congressional elections and 2020 presidential election. US intelligence agencies have previously warned of Russia's attempts to discredit Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton and help Republican candidate Donald Trump win the 2016 election.

site_title: Instagram says younger users spend 32 minutes a day on its app
summary: Instagram's younger users (under 25) spend an average of 32 minutes per day on the app, while those 25 and older spend 24 minutes daily. The "Stories" feature, launched a year ago, is credited for the growth in engagement. This contrasts with Snapchat, where users spend over 30 minutes per day, potentially surpassing Instagram in terms of time spent. The new statistics may impact advertisers, who value users spending time on apps beyond quick checks. Instagram's usage metrics have not been updated since 2014.

site_title: Big and green
summary: BT, a Singapore-based business newspaper, has launched a Telegram channel for daily updates. The channel offers weekday updates and special content on weekends. Meanwhile, property prices in Singapore are under scrutiny, with a Q3 condo launch wave expected to test demand for projects above S$3,000 psf. US mortgage rates have risen for the first time in five weeks, while Manhattan rents reached a record high. In other news, a South Korean hotel and retail portfolio was acquired by Goldman Sachs, and UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries' Q2 profit down 36%
summary: Sembcorp Industries' Q2 net profit fell 36.1% to S$55.3 million, despite a 23.2% increase in revenue to S$2.28 billion. Higher refinancing costs for a power plant in India eroded profit margins. The group's board announced an interim dividend of three Singapore cents, down from four cents last year. CEO Neil McGregor said the company will be disciplined on costs and cash flow while capturing opportunities, and a strategic review will be concluded by the fourth quarter. The review will assess the entire business, with a focus on the utilities division.

site_title: Snacks giant picks new CEO as tastes change, revenue falls
summary: Mondelez International, maker of Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers, has appointed Dirk Van de Put as its new CEO, succeeding Irene Rosenfeld in November. Van de Put, previously head of McCain Foods, will bring experience in frozen food and global operations to the role. The appointment comes as Mondelez faces declining revenue and changing consumer tastes, with its share price down 2.3% this year. The company has also faced pressure from activist shareholders to cut costs and improve profit.

images.alt_text: Mr Van de Put spent six years as the head of McCain, one of the world's largest makers of frozen potato products, during which time the company said it experienced record growth.

site_title: Young workers in Singapore 'won't have enough for retirement'
summary: Young workers in Singapore face a significant risk of retirement income shortfall despite high private savings. A study by the International Longevity Centre UK found that the average earner in 24 out of 30 high-income economies will struggle to afford retirement. In Singapore, workers need to save 12% of their annual earnings, but only 29% of respondents said they were saving for retirement. The pension system relies heavily on private savings, leaving those with low earnings vulnerable to poverty in retirement.

site_title: Laos leaning away from China and towards Vietnam
summary: The Trump administration is strengthening ties with Laos, shifting the country's stance away from China and towards Vietnam. Following the leadership change in April 2016, Laos' new President Bounnhang Vorachit and Prime Minister Thongloun Sisoulith are crafting a new foreign policy, emphasizing strengthening diplomatic ties with the US and Vietnam. The retirement of pro-China officials and growing dissatisfaction with Chinese domination have contributed to Laos' tilt towards Vietnam. Trade talks between the US and Laos are underway, and the two countries are cooperating on health, bomb clearance, and other issues.

site_title: Fitbit stepping up cost-cutting amid US$58m Q2 loss
summary: Fitbit Inc reported a US$58m Q2 loss despite a smaller-than-expected revenue drop, with quarterly revenue falling 40% to US$353.3m. The company is stepping up cost-cutting efforts and is on track to launch its smartwatch for the holiday season, which is expected to turn the business around. Fitbit's shares rose 4.7% in extended trading, despite falling 31% this year. The company's chief executive, James Park, stated that 2017 is a transition year and the second-quarter results give confidence that Fitbit can achieve its full-year guidance.

site_title: Uber wants rival's exec quizzed again in trade-secrets lawsuit
summary: Uber has asked a judge to order Alphabet CEO Larry Page to submit to additional questioning in a trade-secrets lawsuit against the ride-hailing company. Page spent four hours testifying last month, but his lawyers claim he was ill-prepared and evaded questions about Anthony Levandowski, a former Google engineer accused of stealing trade secrets. Page's testimony was marked by frequent use of the phrase "I don't recall," and he claimed he didn't know about the details of Levandowski's compensation structure. Uber's lawyers contend that Page is a key witness for their defense, while Waymo's lawyers argue that Page was not adequately prepared and that his lawyers obstructed the process.

site_title: Sheng Siong will need bigger footprint to fend off fresh competition
summary: Sheng Siong, a local Singaporean supermarket chain, faces increased competition from Amazon Prime Now, which launched in the country on July 27. Amazon initially struggled with demand, stopping orders on its first two days, but the company aims to deliver in two hours. Sheng Siong's smaller inventory of 20,000 items compared to the average 50,000 items in a supermarket may make it harder for the chain to compete with Amazon's high margins and wider product selection. This could potentially impact Sheng Siong's market share.

site_title: CapitaLand's Q2 net profit leaps 97% to S$579.3m
summary: CapitaLand's second-quarter net profit soared 97% to S$579.3 million, driven by higher revaluation gains from investment properties and divestment gains. Revenue fell 12.3% to S$992.4 million, mainly due to lower contributions from development projects in Singapore. The company's operating profit after tax and minority interests grew 20.5% to S$206.8 million. Despite revenue decline, the company remains focused on achieving its long-term return on equity target of 8-12%.

site_title: US retail Reits struggle despite high occupancy
summary: US retail REITs face struggles despite high occupancy rates, with mall owner GGP Inc shelving plans to explore asset sales following a hit to its stock. CEO Sandeep Mathrani stated that staying the course would produce the best long-term results for shareholders. The industry is under siege from e-commerce, with brick-and-mortar retailers searching for relief.

site_title: Dialect shows and more for senior citizens' arts festival
summary: Singapore's Silver Arts 2017 festival will return for its sixth edition from September 1-24, featuring over 80 artists and 38 programmes across 20 venues. The festival aims to promote the well-being of seniors through the arts, targeting 42,000 attendees. This year's lineup includes nearly 70 senior talents, diverse performances such as Hokkien music, Malay theatrical play, and a sixties English rock concert, and reprisals of famous monologues. Organized by the National Arts Council, the festival will run for four weekends.

images.alt_text: Brian Richmond will host Rocking Good Times, a concert celebrating the sounds of the swinging sixties. Three popular bands from that era will perform: rhythm and blues act Pest Infested, hit-makers Trailers (above), and psychedelic blues pioneers The Straydogs.

site_title: UniCredit CEO defies doubters with surprise profit surge
summary: UniCredit CEO Jean Pierre Mustier defied expectations with a surprise second-quarter profit surge, reaching 945 million euros. The bank's net income beat analyst predictions and improved capital, with a common equity Tier 1 ratio of 12.8%. UniCredit aims to boost net income to 4.7 billion euros by 2019 through a slimmed-down business and growth in fees and commissions. The sale of Poland-based Bank Pekao and reduced risk-weighted assets contributed to the profit increase.

site_title: Why Bordeaux dominates the wine market
summary: Bordeaux wine dominates the market due to its exceptional quality, with two benchmark wines, Château Lafite Rothschild 2003 and Château Latour 2002, showcasing its prestige. Both wines demonstrate a unique personality and command respect, despite not being in their best vintages. The author's experience with these wines highlights the importance of a great Château producing a wine worthy of its reputation, regardless of the vintage. Second wines of top Châteaux, such as Les Forts de Latour and Carruades de Lafite, also offer great value and quality, demonstrating that neglecting or scoffing at second wines can result in a loss of appreciation.

site_title: Swiss bank Julius Baer opens UK offices to seize on Brexit nerves
summary: Swiss private bank Julius Baer is opening three new UK offices in Manchester, Leeds, and Glasgow, as well as a small team in Belfast, Northern Ireland, in response to Brexit uncertainty. The move aims to capitalize on the concerns of wealthy residents seeking banking services. The offices will be staffed with around 30 employees, marking an expansion of Julius Baer's UK presence from its current London office.

site_title: Jakarta seeks proposals from Chevron and Conoco
summary: Indonesia's Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Ignasius Jonan is seeking proposals from Chevron and Conoco to renew their licences to operate oil and gas fields. Chevron's production-sharing agreement expires by 2021, while Conoco's block expires in 2020. The government aims to attract $200 billion in foreign investment to increase crude oil production. Chevron and Conoco must submit proposals for competitive fiscal terms, investment-friendly policies, and legal certainty to continue operating in the country. A decision on the licences could reassure prospective investors and support President Joko Widodo's goal of boosting energy investments.

site_title: BOE keeps rates at record low, cuts wage and growth forecasts
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) kept interest rates at a record low of 0.25% and cut its forecasts for growth and wages due to the impact of Brexit on the economy. The central bank now expects Britain's economy to grow by 1.7% this year, down from its previous forecast of 1.9%. The BOE also lowered its forecasts for wage growth in 2018 and 2019 to 3% and 3.25%, respectively, citing uncertainty around Brexit. Governor Mark Carney stated that a rate hike is not imminent, but the central bank reiterated that it could need to tighten monetary policy over the forecast period.

images.alt_text: Uncertainty around Brexit would weigh on Britain's economic growth potential, says Mr Carney.

site_title: Dollar recovers some ground ahead of jobs data
summary: The US dollar partially recovered from its 21/2-year low on Thursday ahead of jobs data, rising 0.2% to 93.02 on a trade-weighted basis. The dollar gained against commodity-linked currencies like the Australian and Canadian dollars, but the euro rose to a 21/2-year high of 1.1910 against the dollar due to expectations of the European Central Bank scaling back stimulus. The euro is expected to close 2017 higher than its start, despite a Reuters poll showing risks skewed in favor of the single currency.

site_title: Mixing music and politics
summary: Legendary Australian rock band Midnight Oil has reunited for a world tour, selling out shows globally. The group, consisting of Peter Garrett, Rob Hirst, Jim Moginie, Martin Rotsey, and Bones Hillman, is touring in support of their 30th-anniversary album "Diesel and Dust." The tour, named "The Great Circle," will take the band to Singapore, the US, and Canada, with a focus on sustainability and environmental causes. The group has practiced over 170 songs for the tour and will offset their carbon footprint and support local environmental organizations.

site_title: STI tracks Dow futures, finishes weaker
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended Thursday 5.88 points weaker at 3,342.92 due to weakness in three banks. Despite the Dow Jones Industrial Average's record close above 22,000 on Wednesday, the STI was largely unaffected. Genting Singapore reported a net profit of S$143.3 million in its second quarter, with analysts raising their target prices. The Dow futures were down 15 points at 5pm, with Rabobank noting that the weaker US dollar and US stock market may not immediately filter through to the economy.

site_title: Neymar to seal record 222m euro move to PSG
summary: Neymar is set to finalize his world record 222 million euro move from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain (PSG), earning him around 30 million euros a year. The 25-year-old's transfer saga, which included stops in the US, China, and the Middle East, will end in Paris, where he will be welcomed by his new teammates. Neymar's departure from Barcelona marks a significant shift for the club, which had been trying to keep him, and his move is seen as a major coup for PSG, which aims to challenge top European clubs like Barcelona, Real Madrid, and Bayern Munich.

site_title: ASLAN shares down almost 40% 2 months after Taiwan listing
summary: ASLAN Pharmaceuticals, a Singapore-based biotech firm, has seen its shares drop nearly 40% two months after listing on the Taipei Exchange (TPEx) due to a decline in the Taiwan biotech market. The company raised NT$1 billion in its IPO, with shares trading at NT$40.50, down from the offer price of NT$68.92. CEO Carl Firth attributes the decline to macro reasons, including a rotation out of biotech and into tech, and expects a rotation back into the sector later this year. Despite the decline, ASLAN remains focused on building long-term shareholder value and has made positive news announcements.

site_title: China readies measures against US amid trade spat
summary: China is preparing measures against the US amid a deteriorating trade relationship, following a potential US investigation into intellectual property violations. China has had countervailing measures ready, singling out soybean imports as a potential lever to exert influence. State media has signaled a strong response to any US trade measures, and experts predict a cautious, proportional response from Beijing to avoid a trade war ahead of the 19th Party Congress.

site_title: Tesla burns through cash as CEO stays hot on electric future
summary: Tesla burned through $1.16 billion in cash during the second quarter, mainly due to increased spending on capacity for its Model 3 sedan and boosting battery output. Despite this, CEO Elon Musk remains optimistic about the company's electric future, citing hundreds of thousands of Model 3 deliveries and solar roof installations. The company's stock surged 7.4% after the close of regular trading. Musk plans to raise capital through a debt offering, which could be as much as $1 billion, to fund further growth and production expansion.

site_title: LTA may change rule on barring cabbies from courier services
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore may reconsider its rule barring taxis and private-hire vehicles from courier services, after previously expressing strong opposition. The LTA has stated that it will monitor recent trends to determine if the regulations need to be reviewed. This move comes as the use of ride-hailing services for deliveries becomes increasingly popular.

site_title: Hampstead disappoints on lack of chemistry, plot
summary: The 2017 film Hampstead, starring Diane Keaton and Brendan Gleeson, tells the story of an unlikely friendship between an American widow and a reclusive vagrant living in a makeshift hovel in a London park. The film follows their blossoming romance as they navigate a plot to evict the vagrant from his home, which is slated for luxury apartment development. Despite its picturesque setting, the film is marred by wooden dialogue, lack of chemistry between the leads, and a predictable plot, resulting in a disappointing and harmlessly fluffy experience.

site_title: The next green mile
summary: Singapore explores alternatives to fossil fuel-powered cars, as global efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions intensify. France, UK, India, and Germany plan to ban the sale of petrol and diesel engines by 2040, 2030, and 2025, respectively, in line with the Paris Climate Agreement. The push comes as air pollution poses health risks and the world transitions to cleaner energy sources. In Singapore, startups like QuikBot are partnering with FedEx to deploy robots for deliveries, while electric vehicle manufacturers like Tesla and BYD face pressure to reduce emissions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers have updated their forecasts for Genting Singapore, Sunningdale Tech, and BreadTalk Group. Genting Singapore's target price increased to S$1.35 due to higher-than-expected margins and gaming revenues. Sunningdale Tech was upgraded to a "buy" rating with a target price of S$2.62, driven by strong order momentum and efficiency gains. BreadTalk Group's target price was increased to S$1.83, but its rating was downgraded to "neutral" as the market has already priced in near-term growth.

site_title: Cyberattacks the latest nasty surprise for shareholders
summary: Cyberattacks are increasingly targeting companies, causing losses in earnings and operations. Major corporations, including Mondelez, Merck, FedEx, A.P. Moller-Maersk, and Reckitt Benckiser, have been affected by the "NotPetya" worm attack, disrupting operations and causing delays. Experts predict that cyberattacks will become a common occurrence, with potential economic losses comparable to natural disasters. The attack highlights the inadequacy of current cybersecurity measures, with many businesses struggling to protect themselves from such attacks.

site_title: Trump's dream: Impeach me, please!
summary: US President Donald Trump has a history of self-destructive behavior, including tweets that deepen the country's divisions. Despite his approval rating dropping to 36% in early July, Trump remains driven to be the center of attention, making it harder for his new chief of staff, John Kelly, to restrain him. This behavior poses a risk of impeachment, and Trump's recent actions suggest he may be playing to a dwindling base of support rather than seeking to heal the country's divisions. Trump's compulsion for attention may be his greatest challenge in his presidency.

site_title: The age of autonomy
summary: Audi's "25th Hour" project aims to create a future where self-driving cars free drivers from road attention, allowing for more time. The luxury brand's A8 model already features an AI-powered traffic jam pilot system, and rival BMW plans to launch a self-driving car, the iNext, by 2021. The market for autonomous cars is expected to be worth $96 billion by 2025 and $290 billion by 2035, with companies like Delphi and Volvo also racing to develop autonomous technology.

site_title: Davinder steps down as Drew & Napier CEO
summary: Senior Counsel Davinder Singh has stepped down as CEO of Drew & Napier LLC, Singapore's top law firm, to become the firm's new executive chairman. Cavinder Bull SC replaces him as CEO, with Jimmy Yim SC and Sushil Nair also taking on new roles. The move is seen as a "natural progression" and "not representative of a leadership crisis," with the firm focusing on growth in areas such as dispute resolution and international arbitration. The changes signal a transition for the firm, which is known for its high-profile cases and arbitration expertise.

site_title: Defensive Cabinet line-up won't set Japan on a fresh course ahead
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in Japan has reshuffled his Cabinet, largely maintaining the status quo, with no new faces or fresh ideas to set the country on a new course. The move is seen as a defensive strategy to avoid further embarrassment and boost his plummeting popularity. The world is currently lacking inspiring leadership, with the US under President Donald Trump, China's President Xi Jinping being the only notable example of visionary leadership, but even his vision is uncertain. Japan's economic policies, focused on domestic reforms, are likely to fail due to the country's insular retreatism and narrow nationalist outlook.

site_title: The Wonder Woman halo effect
summary: London-based leather designers Whitaker Malem and Paddy Whitaker, known for their work on Wonder Woman's iconic armor, have seen a surge in success following the film's release. The duo's designs have been featured in various fashion magazines, including New York magazine, and have been worn by celebrities such as Rihanna and Joan Severance. Their atelier in East London has become a hub for their creative work, with a focus on personal fine art pieces, including a wall sculpture featuring male and female bodies in leather. A solo show, Leather Unbound, is set to open at Gallery Liverpool this fall.

site_title: Kim Heng stands to recoup US$9.6m vessel purchase in one year
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings' executive chairman Thomas Tan expects the US$9.6 million investment in three vessels to break even within a year, with each vessel generating revenue for 270 days. The vessels were acquired at a "steep bargain" price compared to their valuations, and the group has secured a vessel loan and unused IPO cash to fund the purchase. Kim Heng posted a net loss of S$2.79 million in the first quarter, but the group has pledged to continue managing its cash flow prudently and has refrained from over-leveraging.

site_title: Electric cars giving global metals markets a shock
summary: The shift to electric vehicles is affecting global metals markets, with demand for metals used in combustion engines set to fall and that for batteries expected to soar. Companies like Glencore, Freeport-McMoRan, and First Quantum Minerals are likely to benefit from the trend. Lead demand is seen as a risk, but analysts expect a gradual decline, while aluminum prices are rising due to supply curbs in China. Platinum demand is also expected to increase, driven by fuel-cell vehicles. The industry is at risk from the shift away from fossil fuels until commercialization of alternative technologies is proven.

site_title: Autonomous systems you can buy today
summary: Several car manufacturers have introduced advanced driver assistance systems available for purchase. BMW's Active Cruise Control with Stop & Go and Lane Keeping Assistant, Mercedes-Benz Drive Pilot, and Volvo's Pilot Assist offer semi-autonomous features. These systems enable features such as traffic jam assistance, lane guidance, and speed limit adherence. While not yet fully autonomous, these technologies reduce driving stress and make driving more convenient. They are available on various luxury vehicle models, including the BMW 5 Series, Mercedes-Benz E-Class and S-Class, and Volvo S90, V90, and XC90.

site_title: Armed, but not very dangerous
summary: The Dark Tower movie, directed by Nikolaj Arcel, is a 95-minute adaptation of Stephen King's epic novel, condensed for a TV serial. The film follows Roland Deschain (Idris Elba), a lone Gunslinger, as he battles his nemesis Walter O'Dim (Matthew McConaughey) to prevent chaos in the multiverse. The story introduces 14-year-old Jake Chambers, who becomes entangled in the battle, and explores themes of good vs. evil. Despite being an abridgement of the novel, the film is a likable, PG-13 teen-friendly diversion featuring strong leads, but may leave fans wanting more.

site_title: Abe plays safe in Cabinet reshuffle to ride out leadership crisis
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe attempted a Cabinet reshuffle to shore up his position amidst a leadership crisis, but analysts say it will do little to boost government popularity ratings, which have slipped below the "danger" level of 30%. Abe retained key ministers, including Finance Minister Taro Aso, and brought back others, while appointing former administrative reform minister Taro Kono as foreign minister. The reshuffle is seen as a defensive move to avoid further embarrassment and may focus on more popular priorities such as women's rights and education.

images.alt_text: Mr Kono, whose appointment as foreign minister was a surprise, is known for his outspoken views.

site_title: Rosé maker to Queen Elizabeth II said to eye deal for Spain's Chivite
summary: Sogrape Vinhos SA, a Portuguese winemaker, is bidding for Spain's 370-year-old J Chivite Family Estates SL, with Cavas Castillo de Perelada SA also making a binding offer. The sale could value Chivite at 25 million euros to 35 million euros, including debt. Chivite is majority-owned by Spanish banks and still retains 20% ownership by its founding family. The sale is being managed by Project Phoenix, a joint venture targeting companies with high debt loads.

site_title: CapitaLand to remain aggressive but disciplined in land bidding: CEO
summary: CapitaLand CEO Lim Ming Yan said the company will remain "aggressive but disciplined" in its land bidding for Singapore's residential market, despite missing out on a $1.132 billion Bidadari site tender. The company's bid of $958.1 million translates to a breakeven price of about $1,700 per square foot, indicating potential higher launch prices. Lim emphasized the need for competitive bids and balancing risk-reward in investing in Singapore's market, which is currently liquidity-driven and capital-market driven.

site_title: Toronto renters finding it hard to lease a home
summary: Toronto renters face extreme difficulty in leasing homes due to record-high rents, driven by home prices that have doubled since 2008. With the average rent exceeding $2,000/month and a two-week rental supply, potential tenants are resorting to online dating profiles to attract landlords. New rental rules in Ontario have limited construction, exacerbating the shortage. Desperate renters have resorted to driving around the city, posting ads, and even moving to outlying neighborhoods, highlighting the city's severe housing crisis.

site_title: Sunac to raise US$1b to refinance debts
summary: Chinese property developer Sunac China Holdings Ltd plans to raise US$1 billion from banks to refinance its debts. The company will issue US$400 million of senior notes due in 2020 and US$600 million due in 2022. The fundraising aims to optimize its debt structure, following recent high-profile deals including a 43.8 billion yuan purchase of theme parks and tourism developments from Dalian Wanda Group. Sunac has 90 billion yuan of cash on hand and has been making deals amid regulatory scrutiny over potential credit risks.

site_title: Tourists-in-jeopardy farce that relies on poop jokes and boob gags
summary: Comedian Amy Schumer stars alongside Goldie Hawn in the comedy film Snatched, directed by Jonathan Levine. After being dumped on the eve of their vacation, Schumer's character Emily convinces her mother Linda to join her on an exotic getaway to Ecuador, where they get abducted for ransom by a notorious gangster. The film features a mix of humor, including poop jokes and boob gags, but Schumer and Hawn's comedic timing help elevate the material. Despite a broad and scattershot plot, the film has some genuinely funny moments and a supporting cast. Rating: C.

site_title: Taiwan protests Indonesia deportations of suspects to China
summary: Taiwan has issued a protest to Beijing over Indonesia's decision to deport 22 Taiwanese fraud suspects to China, citing concerns over the lack of cooperation and the potential impact on cross-border crime investigations. The move comes amid strained relations between Taiwan and China.
