The choice pits the top global financial centers against each other, with London offering easier listing requirements and New York appealing due to its relationship with Prince Mohammed and US President Donald Trump. A listing in either city could give a boost to London's reputation as a financial center, but Brexit may tarnish its appeal.

site_title: Share buybacks tumble as STI hits new highs in market rally
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) hit new highs in a market rally, with share buybacks in July falling 48.1% year-on-year to S$26.7 million. This is the fifth straight month OCBC had the highest buyback consideration, totaling 8.2 million shares. The STI rallied 16.1% in price over the past 12 months, generating a total return of 20.4%. This marks a decline in share buybacks, which have been driven by the market rally.

site_title: IPP Financial Advisers fails in appeal for lower CCS penalty
summary: The Competition Appeal Board (CAB) has dismissed IPP Financial Advisers' appeal to reduce its fine of S$239,851 for violating Singapore's competition law. The fine was imposed in March 2017 for collectively pressuring a competitor, iFAST, to withdraw a 50% commission rebate offer on its website. The CAB found that the object of the "infringing conduct" was to prevent a new competitor from entering the market and providing a cheaper alternative product, resulting in the prevention of competition. The other nine financial advisory firms also paid their fines within two months.

site_title: Sunningdale Q2 profit more than doubles to S$8.2m
summary: Sunningdale Tech Ltd, a Singapore-based precision plastic component manufacturer, reported a 115.3% surge in Q2 net profit to S$8.2 million, driven by growth in automotive and IT segments. Revenue rose 6.6% to S$177.6 million. CEO Khoo Boo Hor attributed the results to operational efficiency and streamlining, while the company gradually adds capacity to its manufacturing facilities in China and Malaysia. Earnings per share jumped to 4.36 Singapore cents, and an interim dividend of 2.5 Singapore cents per share was declared.

site_title: ISOTeam in JV to launch next generation bike-sharing business
summary: ISOTeam Ltd, a Singapore-based company, has announced a joint venture with Sean Tay and Andy Tay to launch SG Bike Pte Ltd, a next-generation bike-sharing business. The initial capital of SG Bike is S$1 million, with ISOTeam holding 51% stake. The service will start operations this month with 1,000 bicycles at public housing estates, bus-stops, and MRT stations. The bike-sharing system will utilize virtual docking stations with GPS and geo station technology for easy bike location. SG Bike aims to reach 50,000 users by mid-2018.

site_title: Switch to proactive approach in tackling cybercrime, protecting smart nation drive
summary: Cybercriminals are becoming increasingly sophisticated, targeting vital data in healthcare, finance, and public sectors, with the global economy estimated to lose $445 billion annually due to cybercrime. To combat this, technology companies must prioritize cybersecurity and collaborate with governments and organizations. The use of Machine Learning (ML) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) is becoming more prevalent in detecting and responding to cyberattacks. A proactive approach is needed, with a focus on robust cybersecurity infrastructure and information-sharing platforms, as cybercrime is not bound by geography or jurisdiction and requires a unified approach to prevent damage to economies and smart cities.

site_title: More disruption ahead for hospitality sector
summary: The Singapore government's decision to halve the minimum rental period for private homes from six months to three months may disrupt the hospitality sector. While the move benefits consumers, it poses challenges for serviced residence operators and hotels, which may struggle to compete with private rental homes offering similar services at lower costs. The revised rule is part of a global trend, with cities worldwide reviewing their rules due to the rise of home-sharing platforms. Hospitality players will need to adapt to the changing landscape and find ways to differentiate their services to retain customers.

site_title: Trendy coffee at US$4 a cup revives long-neglected African industry
summary: African coffee production, which has declined by three-quarters since the 1970s, is experiencing a resurgence due to increased demand for high-quality, specialty coffee from Western consumers. The premium pricing of African coffee, such as Kenyan and Rwandan beans, is driving sales and potentially benefiting farmers. However, production remains under threat due to urbanization, population growth, and conflicts, with many young Africans opting for more profitable careers. As a result, trading houses are investing in African markets to capitalize on the niche demand for single-origin coffees.

site_title: Work visa scheme for foreign entrepreneurs enhanced
summary: Singapore's EntrePass scheme for foreign entrepreneurs will be enhanced starting August 3, 2017, to attract global startup talent. The new assessment criteria include business network, key achievements, and entrepreneurial and investment track record, replacing existing four innovation criteria. The scheme also removes the S$50,000 paid-up capital requirement and extends validity from one to two years. The goal is to strengthen Singapore's tech startup ecosystem, create jobs, and promote local startups.

site_title: Amazon China partner tells users to stop using illegal VPNs
summary: A Chinese partner of Amazon, Beijing Sinnet Technology Co Ltd, has instructed users to stop using illegal VPNs to bypass the "Great Firewall" of China, following Apple's removal of VPN services from its Chinese app store. The government has banned all unapproved VPNs, citing the need for internet control. Amazon has stated it is complying with local laws, but Sinnet's directive is seen as a move to enforce compliance.

site_title: Playful Prince Philip, 96, performs final royal solo engagement
summary: Prince Philip, 96, performs his final solo royal engagement, marking a significant milestone in his long-standing presence at official royal functions. The Duke of Edinburgh is known for his humor, which has both endeared him to some and led to controversy. Despite his reputation for bluntness, Prince Philip has been a constant support to the royal family, particularly Queen Elizabeth II, who has credited him as her strength and stay. Born in 1921, Prince Philip has had a storied career, including serving in the Royal Navy and pursuing his passion for sailing and science.

site_title: New sales tack in US, China suit Hugo Boss Q2 results
summary: Hugo Boss reported a 2% increase in US sales and a 14% jump in Chinese sales, beating second-quarter expectations. The company's net profit rose fivefold to 57.6 million euros, driven by restructuring efforts and price cuts in China. Hugo Boss shares rose 5% and were among the top risers on the Stoxx Europe 600. The company confirmed its outlook for stable sales in 2017 and a low double-digit percentage increase in net income, with plans for growth in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Yancoal plans US$2.5b equity raising for Rio Tinto coal mines
summary: Yancoal Australia Ltd, backed by China's Yanzhou Coal Mining Co, plans to raise US$2.5 billion in equity to purchase Rio Tinto's Australian coal assets. The deal, valued at US$2.69 billion, will make Yancoal Australia's largest pure-play coal producer and give it a stake in the owner of two Newcastle terminals. Two Chinese investment groups have committed to US$1 billion, with Glencore contributing US$300 million. The deal comes amid concerns over environmental impact and regulatory hurdles, but analysts say the financing side of the deal looks solid.

site_title: Halcyon Agri reports Q2 profit of US$1.7m
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a Q2 net profit of US$1.7 million, reversing a loss of US$8 million in the previous year, due to benefits from its merger with GMG Global and Sinochem International Corporation's natural rubber assets. Revenue more than doubled to US$527.7 million, driven by increased sales and higher natural rubber prices. The company has classified its stake in Siat SA as assets for sale and is reviewing its global portfolio for strategic investments and acquisitions to drive growth.

site_title: Humana shares gain as 2018 Medicare Advantage outlook improves
summary: Humana Inc reported a 4.5% increase in shares after announcing a higher percentage of customers in its most profitable Medicare Advantage plans for 2018, reversing a previous estimate of 37%. The company expects 74% of customers to be in higher-rated plans, up from 78% in 2017, and raised its full-year earnings forecast. This news offset potential downside risk for 2018 and was attributed to strength in the Medicare Advantage business.

site_title: No go for Americans planning N Korea trip
summary: The US government has barred Americans from visiting North Korea, the first time in years that the State Department has taken such strong measures. The ban comes amid rising tensions between the US and North Korea, following the death of University of Virginia student Otto Warmbier, who was convicted of trying to steal a propaganda poster from his hotel in Pyongyang. The restriction, which will take effect 30 days after being listed in the Federal Register, aims to prevent future detentions of US citizens by the North Korean regime.

site_title: StarHub Q2 profit falls 21%; revenue dips 1.1%
summary: StarHub, Singapore's second-largest telco, reported a 21% decrease in Q2 net profit to S$85.7 million, down from S$108.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 1.1% to S$579.1 million. The decline was mainly due to lower revenue from mobile, broadband, and Pay TV services. However, the company's Ebitda fell only 6.1% to S$180.3 million. StarHub declared an interim dividend of four Singapore cents per share, down from five cents in the previous year.

site_title: Singapore dollar surge leaves market expecting pullback in H2
summary: The Singapore dollar has surged over 6% against the US dollar this year, reaching its strongest quartile of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) policy band. Analysts expect a pullback in the second half of the year, with some predicting a decline to 1.42 and 1.44 in the next three months. The MAS is expected to maintain its neutral stance for its SGD NEER policy at its next review in October, and the US Federal Reserve's balance sheet reduction and interest rate hikes are seen as factors contributing to the expected decline.

site_title: GIC-linked China lending platform to sell US consumer debt in Asia
summary: Dianrong, a Chinese peer-to-peer lending platform, is launching FinEX Asia, a global platform to sell US consumer debt to Asian investors through offices in Singapore and Hong Kong. The platform, backed by a $220 million injection from Singapore's GIC, aims to source consumer loans from the US and provide investors with a fixed monthly return of 5-12%. FinEX Asia has already attracted $25 million in investments from Asian institutional and certified investors within its first month of operations.

site_title: World stocks higher as Apple pushes Wall Street past 22,000
summary: US stocks rose above 22,000 for the first time, driven by Apple's strong quarterly earnings results, which saw a 6% surge in shares. Despite geopolitical uncertainties, corporate earnings dominated, with European markets recovering from morning lows. However, disappointment in the banking sector, particularly in France and the UK, held back gains. Key events this week include the Bank of England's interest rate decision and the US non-farm payrolls data.

site_title: Deutsche Bank may shift half its UK jobs
summary: Deutsche Bank plans to shift almost half of its 4,000 UK positions to Frankfurt and Berlin, with most jobs moving next year. The relocation is part of the bank's Brexit plans, with Germany's financial centre attracting significant banking jobs. Frankfurt and Dublin will receive a large share of relocated positions, while the UK will retain some jobs, including its headquarters. The move is part of the bank's efforts to maintain its European presence despite the UK's exit from the single market.

site_title: US: Dow tops 22,000 points for 1st time as Apple shares surge
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average surpassed 22,000 points for the first time in opening trading on Wednesday, driven by a 6% gain in Apple shares. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also reached new highs. The strong earnings report from Apple contributed to the rally, which marked the sixth-straight record close for the Dow.

site_title: South Asia in race to be global LNG hotspot as Dhaka enters market
summary: South Asia is poised to become a global liquefied natural gas (LNG) hotspot, with Pakistan and Bangladesh set to join India as major consumers. The region's demand for LNG could reach 80-100 million tonnes per year by the mid-2020s, making it the world's second-largest import region after Europe. Analysts attribute the surge to the region's fast-growing population, strong economic growth, and soaring energy demand. Bangladesh plans to import 2,500 million cubic feet of LNG per day, equivalent to 17.5 million tonnes per year, by 2025, while Pakistan aims to import 50 million tonnes per year by the mid-2020s.

site_title: Hip coffee at US$4-a-cup revives African industry left behind
summary: African coffee farmers are benefiting from a surge in demand for high-quality, specialty coffee, with prices rising to nearly double those of similar supermarket products. This renewed interest may help offset declining output, which has fallen to three-quarters of its 1975 levels due to factors such as urbanization, population growth, and competition from cheaper varieties. As a result, trading houses are increasing their presence in African markets, and some companies are even buying up local coffee specialists to capitalize on the growing demand for single-origin coffees.

site_title: Seoul to impose capital gains taxes to curb home speculation
summary: South Korea plans to implement capital gains taxes on owners of multiple homes starting from April 2018 to curb speculation in the housing market. Those with two homes will face a 10 percentage point additional tax on top of the current tax rates, ranging from 6% to 40%. The move aims to rein in speculators who policymakers blame for stoking a housing market bubble in Seoul and other parts of the country.

site_title: Soh saw weak case against him but believed he would be charged nonetheless, court told
summary: A Singaporean man, John Soh Chee Wen, accused of masterminding the 2013 penny stock crash, told a remisier before his arrest that he believed investigators had a weak case against him but would still charge him. Soh's lawyers are now seeking all relevant documents and recordings to support his bail application, arguing that the prosecution's selective presentation of evidence is unfair. The court has adjourned the case to August 8, with Justice See Kee Oon considering the arguments made.

images.alt_text: "The case against me is very weak," Soh says, according to a transcript read in court

site_title: UK construction growth falls to 11-month low
summary: The UK construction industry experienced a 11-month low in growth in July, with the Markit/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 51.9 from 54.8 in June, below forecast. This decline was attributed to a lacklustre economy outlook and heightened political uncertainty.

site_title: Tesla fending off worker complaints on pay, safety
summary: Tesla is facing escalating worker complaints about pay and safety at its California factory as a unionization drive gains momentum. The company, preparing to release quarterly results, has faced production delays and is trying to speed up delivery of its mid-priced Tesla 3. Despite plans to build 100,000 vehicles this year, worker complaints are a challenge for Tesla. The union drive comes as the company tries to expand its operations, including the launch of robotaxis in California and Arizona.

site_title: Global traders have little to fear in hints of a freer yuan
summary: China is considering widening the trading band of its yuan currency, allowing for greater flexibility in the market. This move would help retain monetary independence and open up its capital account, but risks quicker declines in the yuan. Despite previous devaluations, the market has stabilized, and the spot rate has rarely moved more than 0.5% on either side of the fixing. Experts say the time is right for a freer yuan, citing a stable economy and increasing support from officials and media for further reforms.

images.alt_text: When China blindsided traders in August 2015 with the steepest yuan devaluation on record, the reaction in global markets was swift and painful: Emerging-market equities collapsed into a bear market, oil plunged and the S&P 500 Index began a slide that would spiral into its worst month in three years.

site_title: Far East Orchard's Q2 profit plunges 97.3%
summary: Far East Orchard Limited reported a 97.3% plunge in Q2 net profit to S$1 million due to a slump in joint venture profits and weaker hospitality performance in Perth, Australia. Group revenue slipped 19.4% to S$36 million. The company plans to grow its hospitality businesses by increasing management contracts, acquiring strategic assets, and divesting properties to recycle capital for higher-yielding opportunities.

site_title: Delphi Automotive raises full-year profit, revenue forecasts
summary: Delphi Automotive Plc raised its full-year profit and revenue forecasts, citing strong second-quarter performance and growth prospects in electrification and safety systems, including those for self-driving vehicles. The company expects full-year adjusted earnings of US$6.55 to US$6.75 per share, up from its previous forecast of US$6.40 to US$6.70 per share. This transformation is driven by the "heart of our strategy," according to CEO Kevin Clark.

site_title: Sanctions gap lets Western firms tap Russian frontier oil
summary: US sanctions imposed on Russia in 2014 to restrict Western companies from developing "shale" oil resources inadvertently allowed companies like Statoil and Rosneft to tap "limestone" formations, which are technically similar and also require fracking. This loophole risks undermining the sanctions' goal of preventing Russia from developing unconventional oil resources. Norway's Statoil and British major BP are helping Rosneft develop these resources, with potential yields estimated in the billions of barrels.

site_title: US is said to plan probe of China on intellectual property
summary: The US is planning to investigate China over alleged intellectual property violations, with a possible probe starting in the coming days. The investigation, authorized by section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, aims to address concerns that China is trying to become a world leader in technologies such as microchips and electric cars. The probe could lead to increased tariffs on Chinese products or the rescission of licenses for Chinese firms. This move marks a new strategy for the Trump administration, following recent tensions in trade relations between the two countries.

site_title: Wal-Mart puts new scrutiny on suppliers with chemicals push
summary: Wal-Mart has joined the Chemical Footprint Project, a program that rates companies on their use of chemicals. The retailer is one of two dozen companies participating, including Johnson & Johnson and HP Inc, to create a standard modeled on carbon-footprint scores. The move aims to help companies root out hazardous substances from products sold to consumers, responding to growing pressure from consumers checking ingredient labels and pushing companies to eliminate chemicals like formaldehyde and phthalates.

site_title: Genting Singapore boasts Q2 turnaround
summary: Genting Singapore reported a Q2 net profit of S$143.32 million, a turnaround from a loss of S$10.54 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue increased 24% year-over-year to S$596.08 million, driven by higher rolling win percentage in the premium player business. Operating profit rose to S$225.61 million, up from S$47.19 million. The company attributed the improvement to its gaming business, which contributed to the increase in revenue and operating profit.

site_title: BOJ 'no longer setting deadline for inflation target'
summary: Bank of Japan board member Yukitoshi Funo stated that the central bank no longer has a binding timeframe for meeting its 2% inflation target. The BOJ has postponed the target six times since 2013, with the latest revision pushing it back to 2019/20. Despite this, Funo said the bank still aims to hit the target at the earliest possible date, but does not need a set timeframe. The BOJ's inflation target remains distant, and Funo emphasized the importance of structural reforms, private-sector efforts, and fiscal measures to achieve sustainable price rises.

site_title: Germany's car bosses bid to head off diesel ban with software patch
summary: Germany's major car manufacturers, including Volkswagen, Daimler, and BMW, have proposed a software patch to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions by 25-30% in 5 million vehicles, amid threats to partially ban diesel vehicles in cities due to deadly smog. Critics say the measure is a "stop-gap fix" and not a long-term solution, while environmentalists demand EU-wide transparency and recall details. The offer comes as the sector faces a crisis, with a court ruling that a partial ban on diesel vehicles is effective in clearing the air of poisonous emissions, and public opinion sways in favor of an outright ban.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing PMI up marginally in July
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded for the 11th consecutive month in July, with a PMI reading of 51.0, up 0.1 from the previous month. The electronics sector, which has expanded for 12 consecutive months, showed robust growth. New orders, exports, and factory output improved, while inventory levels decreased and employment contracted. The PMI reading indicates sustained growth in the manufacturing sector for the year.

site_title: More employers should get on board improved terms for contract workers
summary: Singapore's Second Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo has launched a tripartite standard for improved employment terms for contract workers. The standard aims to address wage and benefit disparities between contract and full-time employees. Almost 300 employers have signed up for the new standard, covering 15% of the 170,000 contract employees. The initiative includes standards on leave benefits and termination notice periods, with four more sets to be rolled out by the end of the year. The goal is to minimize inequalities and disparities between contract workers and full-timers, with the ultimate aim of creating a more progressive employment landscape.

site_title: Smartphone sales slip as top vendors consolidate market share
summary: Global smartphone sales declined in the second quarter of 2017, with market leaders Samsung and Apple consolidating their positions. Samsung maintained the top spot with 79.8 million handsets and a 23.3% market share, while Apple held the second spot with 41 million iPhones and a 12% share. Huawei, Oppo, and Xiaomi rounded out the top five, with overall sales lower than a year earlier, but the top five vendors showing positive growth. Despite this, the survey notes that smaller vendors will continue to struggle in the market.

site_title: Gold slips from seven-week high as investors look to Fed
summary: Gold prices slipped from a seven-week high on Wednesday, falling 0.1% to $1,267.10 an ounce, as investors took profits and sought riskier assets amid strong European economic growth and rising US stock markets. Doubts about a quick US interest rate hike and anticipation of payroll data on Friday supported prices. The US dollar remained near 14-month lows, while US bond yields rose slightly, reducing expectations of a rapid rate hike.

images.alt_text: Gold edged down from a seven-week high on Wednesday as investors took profits following a recent rally, with strong economic growth in Europe and rising US stock markets encouraging a shift to riskier assets.

site_title: "Concrete Jungle Book" musical swaps bare necessities for harsh realities
summary: A new musical adaptation of "The Jungle Book" titled "The Concrete Jungle Book" is set to open at Edinburgh's Fringe Festival, offering a gritty portrayal of life in an urban jungle filled with homelessness, drugs, and knife crime. The show, inspired by Rudyard Kipling's fables, features a homeless young refugee as the central character Mowgli, who navigates a dilapidated landscape of tower blocks and street gangs. The production incorporates high-energy grime and rap music and addresses dark themes of violence and addiction, aiming to raise awareness about the harsh realities faced by homeless youth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks closes higher as Shanghai slips
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.24% to close at 27,607.38, driven by strong Apple results, while Shanghai slipped 0.23% to 3,285.06. The Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.70% to 1,869.32. The gains in Hong Kong were despite investors taking profits, as Shanghai's decline followed a fifth straight record close on Wall Street.

site_title: Russia takes over US compound in Moscow in retaliation over sanctions
summary: Russia took over a summer-house compound in Moscow leased by the US embassy in retaliation for new US sanctions. The compound, used by diplomatic staff and hosting embassy parties, was emptied and secured with a metal padlock after US employees cleared out their belongings. President Vladimir Putin ordered the US to cut 60% of its diplomatic staff in Russia by Sept 1, and Russia will seize a dacha country villa and a warehouse. This move is seen as a display of defiance by Putin to voters at home.

site_title: BreadTalk posts 61.9% jump in Q2 profit
summary: BreadTalk Group posted a 61.9% jump in net profit for Q2, reaching S$2.11 million, driven by an 18.7% rise in other income and reduced interest and administrative expenses. Revenue declined 1.5% to S$147.57 million. The group attributed its earnings growth to streamlining existing portfolios and identifying new growth opportunities, positioning it to rise above the challenging retail environment. A tax-exempt interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share is recommended for the first half of 2017.

site_title: StanChart shares slide on lack of dividend, revenue recovery
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 93% rise in half-year underlying pretax profit to $1.8 billion, but its shares fell as it failed to resume dividends. The bank avoided losses from private equity and bad loans, but underlying loan impairments decreased. CEO Bill Winters said the bank is positioned for growth, but faces a challenge to increase revenues. The bank will not resume dividend payments, instead revisiting the issue at the end of the year. Shares fell 5% in London following the results announcement.

site_title: Trump signs Russia sanctions bill into law: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a bill imposing new sanctions on Russia into law, following a vote by the US Congress that overrode a potential presidential veto. The sanctions punish Russia for interference in the 2016 presidential election and other perceived violations. Despite conflicting signals from the administration, Trump signed the bill, which also includes sanctions on Iran and North Korea. The move comes after US intelligence agencies found that Russia interfered in the election to help the Republican candidate.

site_title: Cityneon hires Cirque du Soleil's former director of creations
summary: Cityneon Holdings has appointed Welby Altidor, former director of creations at Cirque du Soleil, as its group chief creative officer. Altidor joins Cityneon after Lucrum 1 Investments, led by CEO Ron Tan, acquired 52.51% of shares for S$115.61 million. Altidor brings 16 years of experience to the role, having worked on over 15 productions at Cirque du Soleil. His appointment aims to transform Cityneon's creative projects and new business ventures, with a focus on creating extraordinary live experiences and recruiting outstanding talents.

site_title: Trump boxed in on health subsidies after legal win for states
summary: A federal court ruling allows 17 states and the District of Columbia to join a lawsuit challenging President Donald Trump's decision to end critical Obamacare subsidies. The subsidies, worth $175 billion over 10 years, reimburse insurers for offering reduced deductibles and co-pays to lower-income people. The ruling makes it harder for Trump to unilaterally discontinue the subsidies, which could upend health insurance markets and increase premiums for insurers. Lawmakers and the insurance industry have urged the president not to cut off the subsidies, citing concerns about the impact on millions of Americans relying on the payments.

site_title: Monetary Authority of Singapore's first managing director Michael Wong Pakshong dies
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced the death of its first managing director Michael Wong Pakshong, who passed away at 86. Wong Pakshong served from 1971 to 1981, laying the foundations for the MAS as a central bank and integrated financial regulator. He helped steer the MAS through turbulent years, establishing a robust regulatory and supervisory regime that became a hallmark of the central bank. Wong Pakshong's leadership also contributed to Singapore's development as an international financial centre. The MAS conveyed its condolences to his family.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed as banks push STI higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 10.6 points to 3,348.8 on Wednesday, driven by gains in all three banks. Trading was mixed, with 245 rises and 204 falls, amidst cautious but firm sentiment. The market's reaction to Wall Street's fresh all-time high was muted, as investors had already anticipated the rally. The low VIX Index, measuring future volatility, also contributed to the steady gains.

site_title: US exploration firm offers to resume MH370 search, families say
summary: A US seabed exploration firm, Ocean Infinity, has offered to resume the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 for free, with families of passengers expressing hope that governments will respond favourably. The Boeing 777 disappeared in 2014 with 239 people aboard, and analysis suggests it may have been deliberately diverted out over the Indian Ocean. Authorities have received the offer, but no decision has been made on whether it will be accepted. The search area has been narrowed to less than 25,000 sq km, and families are awaiting a response from governments involved.

site_title: UK construction growth drops to 11-month low: PMI
summary: Britain's construction industry saw its growth drop to an 11-month low in July, according to a survey, with new orders and business volumes declining for the first time since August 2016. The Markit/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 51.9, below forecasts. This mixed signal may impact Bank of England policymakers meeting to set interest rates, as the sector accounts for around 6% of British economic output. Weaker order books and rising construction costs have raised concerns about an extended soft patch for the construction sector.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech Q2 earnings surge to S$8.2m
summary: Sunningdale Tech Ltd reported a 115.3% surge in its Q2 net profit to S$8.2 million, driven by growth in automotive and IT segments. Revenue rose 6.6% to S$177.6 million, while earnings per share jumped to 4.36 cents. The company declared an inaugural interim dividend of 2.5 cents per share and saw its shares finish 0.5% up at S$2.05.

site_title: Asia: Apple, global economic data fuel rally
summary: Asian stocks rose for a fifth consecutive day, fueled by Apple's strong quarterly results and benign global economic data. The Dow reached a new all-time high, while the Nikkei and Shanghai edged ahead. However, US economic data was mixed, with a flat inflation rate and a slight slowdown in manufacturing activity. The dollar recovered from recent losses, and oil prices fell after a surprise increase in US crude stocks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.48 points to close at 1,770.61 on Wednesday, driven by a 1.8 billion lots traded worth RM1.75 billion. The market saw 384 gains and 446 losses. This news is unrelated to the provided articles and seems to be a standalone report about Malaysia's stock market performance.

site_title: OUE C-Reit's Q2 DPU falls 15.4%
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a 15.4% decline in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.15 Singapore cents, down from 1.36 cents in the year-ago period. Income available for distribution edged up 0.6%, while gross revenue and net property income decreased 3.2% and 1.3%, respectively. The company's units ended 0.7% higher at S$0.73. This marks the second consecutive quarter of decline in DPU for OUE C-Reit.

site_title: GLP appoints Evercore Asia to replace ANZ as independent financial adviser
summary: Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) has appointed Evercore Asia as its new independent financial adviser, replacing ANZ following a clarification from the Securities Industry Council of Singapore. This change comes after ANZ's appointment last month to advise GLP's independent directors on a S$3.38 per share offer. The move aims to address concerns over ANZ's independence.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q2 profit surges
summary: Genting Singapore reported a significant surge in its Q2 profit, with net profit jumping to S$172.71 million from S$18.85 million a year ago. Revenue increased 24% to S$596.08 million, driven by higher rolling win percentage in the premium player business. The company's lower sales cost also contributed to the strengthened bottom line.

site_title: StarHub's Q2 profit down 21% at S$85.7m
summary: StarHub, Singapore's second-largest telco, reported a 21% decrease in net profit to S$85.7 million in Q2, down from S$108.6 million last year. Revenue also decreased by 1.7% to S$579.1 million. For the half-year, net profit dropped 21.2% to S$158.8 million. Earnings per share fell to 5 cents from 6.3 cents last year. The company declared an interim dividend of 4 cents per share, down from 5 cents last year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore dollar has gained over 6% against the US dollar this year, making it one of the strongest currencies in South-east Asia, according to DBS Bank. The EntrePass scheme for foreign entrepreneurs will be enhanced to attract global startup talent starting August 3. GIC led a $220 million funding round for Chinese peer-to-peer lending platform Dianrong. The Competition Appeal Board upheld a $239,851 financial penalty for IPP Financial Advisers. The Ministry of Health will provide additional funding for Traditional Chinese Medicine research and development.

site_title: Commerzbank swings to loss in Q2 on weak markets, restructuring
summary: Commerzbank reported a net loss of 637 million euros in Q2 2017 due to weak markets and restructuring charges of 807 million euros. This exceeded analysts' expectations of a 584 million euro loss. Despite this, the bank expects a slightly positive net result for the financial year 2017. CEO Martin Zielke stated that the bank has made progress in its strategy and booked provisions for personnel reductions early.

site_title: China Taisan requests share trading suspension, cites talks with potential investor
summary: China Taisan Technology Group has requested a trading suspension, citing discussions with a potential investor for a fundraising exercise. This comes after the Singapore Exchange queried the fabric manufacturer about its financial results for the first quarter of 2017. The company will make an announcement once the talks are finalized.

site_title: Oil down 1% on surprise rise in US inventories, high Opec output
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Wednesday, with US crude dropping below $50 per barrel due to rising US inventories and high Opec output. US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $48.63 per barrel, while Brent crude dropped to $51.29 per barrel. Despite Opec's pledge to cut output, production reached a 2017 high of 33 million barrels per day. Analysts warn that the global market remains oversupplied, and a rebound is unlikely until 2018 or later.

site_title: Football: Neymar tells Barcelona teammates 'he is leaving'
summary: Neymar informed Barcelona teammates he is leaving the club, following the club's new coach Ernesto Valverde's reign. The Brazilian's potential world record move to Paris Saint-Germain moved closer, with PSG reportedly willing to pay Neymar's 222 million euro buyout clause. Barcelona may not accept the payment due to PSG's alleged failure to comply with UEFA's financial fair play rules. The club has threatened to report PSG to UEFA, and La Liga president Javier Tebas has vowed not to accept the payment.

site_title: SocGen litigation cloud lingers over international growth
summary: Societe Generale's second-quarter net income fell 28% to 1.06 billion euros due to increased legal provisions for past misconduct, including a US probe into trade sanctions. The bank's trading revenue dropped less than peers, driven by demand for structured products. Despite this, profit from international retail banking and financial services jumped 30%, and the bank's common equity tier 1 ratio rose to 11.7%. CEO Frederic Oudea said the bank aims to put past litigations behind it as quickly as possible, with no significant developments on outstanding cases.

site_title: Jeffrey Brotman, who co-founded Costco in 1980s, dies at 74
summary: Jeffrey Brotman, co-founder of Costco in the 1980s, has died at 74. Brotman, a lawyer-turned-entrepreneur, helped establish the warehouse-style shopping chain, which now has 736 stores globally. He served as Costco's chairman for decades and was a director on Starbucks' board in the 1990s. The company did not disclose details on who would replace him as chairman. Brotman's passing comes after decades of success in revolutionizing the retail industry with Costco's no-frills approach to shopping.

site_title: North Korea's ICBM fires up fears in South for US alliance
summary: North Korea has fired an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) that has raised concerns in South Korea about the US alliance's ability to protect the country from potential attacks. The US has a security guarantor role for South Korea, which has 28,500 US troops stationed to defend it from North Korean threats. The missile test extended the range of North Korea's weapons to much of mainland US, sparking fears that American cities could be in danger. This has heightened tensions between the US and North Korea, with implications for Washington's geopolitical strategy in Asia.

site_title: Australia shares slip on weaker oil, commodities; New Zealand crawls up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 5,741.7 points, weighed down by weaker oil and commodity prices, and a sell-off in financials. Oil majors Woodside and Origin Energy slipped 1% and 1.5% respectively. New Zealand's benchmark rose 0.4% to 7,759.45 points, driven by gains in healthcare stocks.

site_title: Hugo Boss reports first US growth in two years
summary: German fashion house Hugo Boss reported better-than-expected second-quarter sales and net profit, with a 2% rise in US sales for the first time in two years and a 14% jump in China. The company attributed the growth to a restructuring plan, including closing loss-making stores and cutting prices in China. Net profit jumped fivefold to 57.6 million euros, beating analyst forecasts. Hugo Boss aims to return to growth and expects sales to rise more strongly than the market from 2019 and beyond.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets diverge at open
summary: Europe's stock markets opened with divergent performances, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.1% and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.3%, despite a strong record close on Wall Street. Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.1% as Asian stocks benefited from Apple's stronger-than-expected results and benign economic data. The divergence in European markets follows a fifth consecutive record close on Wall Street, with bullish sentiment boosted by strong economic data.

site_title: ANA profit jumps on budget carrier boost
summary: ANA Holdings' quarterly net profit soared to 51.1 billion yen (S$628.7 million) for April-June, a 669% increase from the previous year. The profit gain was mainly due to the inclusion of Peach Aviation as a consolidated subsidiary after ANA increased its stake in the budget carrier to 67%. ANA's sales and operating profit also rose 11.7% and 80%, respectively, while the company left its full-year forecast unchanged, expecting a new record of 125 billion yen.

site_title: Honda's new model launches, SUVs help it outsell Toyota in China
summary: Honda outsold Toyota in China for the first seven months of 2017, selling 757,970 vehicles compared to Toyota's 732,900. Honda's strong SUV offerings and new model launches, including a redesigned Civic car, contributed to the sales success. Industry experts attribute Honda's achievement to its fresher product lineup and discounts on older models. Toyota is expected to regain its lead once it refreshes its product lineup, with a redesigned Camry sedan and China-version of the C-HR SUV expected to be launched soon.

site_title: Italy, France still split over Fincantieri bid for STX shipyard
summary: Italy and France failed to reach an agreement on Fincantieri's bid for the STX shipyard, with Italy insisting on a majority stake. The two nations will continue negotiations into September, aiming to make progress on the deal by then. Italy expressed "deep regret" over France's stance, while both sides agreed to focus on Franco-Italian naval cooperation and STX talks by September 27.

site_title: Paintball to military spa offered to lure EU bank regulator after Brexit
summary: The European Union's top bank regulator, the European Banking Authority (EBA), is set to relocate from London due to Brexit. Eight cities, including Frankfurt, Brussels, Paris, Dublin, Warsaw, Prague, Vienna, and others, are competing to host the 189-employee agency with offers ranging from military spas to paintball. Frankfurt is seen as the frontrunner, with Paris and Dublin also in the running. The EBA's relocation will be decided by the European Commission by November, with the goal of minimizing disruption for the agency's staff and families.

site_title: Priced out from home market, Chinese swoop in to buy Thai real estate
summary: Mainland Chinese buyers are snapping up properties in Thailand due to being priced out of the market in big cities. Thai developers report a significant increase in sales to Chinese buyers, with 60% of Raimon Land's foreign buyers now coming from China. The upper-middle-class Chinese buyer, who cannot afford property in more expensive countries, is also driving the trend, with two-thirds of buyers looking at properties under $250,000. Bangkok and seaside destinations like Phuket and Pattaya are top choices for Chinese buyers.

site_title: Samsung heir takes stand to deny corruption charges
summary: Samsung heir Lee Jae-Yong took the stand in his corruption trial, denying allegations of bribing the former President Park Geun-Hye's confidante to secure favors and ease a 2015 merger deal. Lee, 49, claims he was not aware of the confidante's existence until recently and that Samsung was pressured to pay without seeking policy favors. Lee and four other Samsung executives are accused of bribing Choi Soon-Sil with millions of dollars, while Choi has taken blame for approving a payment to finance her daughter's equestrian training.

site_title: Two former Thai PMs acquitted over 2008 protest deaths
summary: Thailand's highest court acquitted two former prime ministers, Somchai Wongsawat and Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, and two former police officers of negligence charges over their role in a 2008 crackdown on anti-government protesters that killed two people. The court ruled that authorities had a responsibility to clear the protesters because they had not remained peaceful, and that the defendants bore no direct responsibility for the deaths. The acquittal comes as part of a decade of instability in Thailand, marked by frequent bouts of political violence and military coups.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.47% to 20,080.04, driven by the Dow's fifth straight record close and better-than-expected Apple results. The Topix index also climbed 0.36%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in US markets, despite ongoing trade uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Lufthansa profits soar in second quarter
summary: Lufthansa reported a 69.3% increase in net profit to 740 million euros in the second quarter, driven by increased passenger demand and lower fuel costs. The airline's operating profit reached 1.0 billion euros, with revenue at 9.3 billion euros. Lufthansa's cargo unit returned to profitability, while its maintenance and catering divisions continued to grow. The airline aims to maintain its competitive edge with "continuous structural improvements," despite challenges from low-cost rivals. Full-year operating profits are forecast to be higher than 1.75 billion euros.

site_title: Mining giant Rio Tinto half-year net profit almost doubles
summary: Rio Tinto reported a 93% jump in first-half net profit to US$3.31 billion, driven by rising commodity prices. Underlying profit increased 152% to US$3.94 billion, narrowly missing analyst estimates. The company returned US$3 billion to shareholders, including a large interim dividend payout of US$2 billion. Rio's shares closed 0.17% down ahead of the result, benefiting from the rebound in iron ore prices. The company expects to come into more cash with the sale of its Australian coal assets.

site_title: Man opens fire at LA Chinese consulate, kills himself
summary: A man opened fire at the Los Angeles Chinese consulate on Tuesday morning, killing himself. The shooting occurred around 6am, before the consulate was open, with numerous rounds impacting the building. The man was found dead in his car from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Authorities did not immediately identify the gunman and typically do not release information about suicides. This incident is not related to a 2011 incident at the same building, where a naturalized US citizen from China was arrested after opening fire.

site_title: Germany makes last-ditch effort to rescue diesel at summit
summary: Germany's government and car industry chiefs meet at an emergency summit in Berlin to address the country's diesel emissions crisis. The industry, which accounts for over half of Germany's trade surplus, faces criticism for its role in the scandal. In exchange for political support, automakers are willing to upgrade existing vehicles to lower their pollution. The summit aims to agree on measures to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions by at least 25% in Germany's 15 million diesels, with the companies expected to bear the majority of the estimated 5 billion euros in costs.

site_title: Amazon China partner tells users to stop using illegal VPNs
summary: Amazon China partner Beiqi Chengshi Group has instructed users to stop using illegal VPNs to bypass the Great Firewall, following Apple's removal of VPN services from its Chinese app store. The move comes as the Chinese government has passed laws banning unapproved VPNs, citing the need for rules governing cyberspace to mimic real-world border controls.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.82 points to 1,768.95, opening higher on Wednesday. The index saw 86 gainers and 56 losers, with a total trading volume of 34.3 million lots worth RM12.2 million.

site_title: EntrePass scheme enhanced to attract global startup talent
summary: Singapore's EntrePass scheme will be enhanced to attract global startup talent starting August 3. The new criteria will assess applicants beyond existing innovation criteria, including entrepreneurial and investment track record, business network, and key achievements. The removal of the S$50,000 paid-up capital requirement and extension of the EntrePass validity period from one to two years will also support global entrepreneurs. The enhanced scheme aims to strengthen Singapore's tech startup ecosystem and position it as a leading startup location. The Ministry of Manpower, Ministry of Trade and Industry, and partner agencies will work together to evaluate applications.

site_title: Competition appeal board upholds financial penalty for IPP
summary: The Competition Appeal Board upheld a S$239,851 financial penalty for IPP Financial Advisers, stemming from an anti-competitive agreement with other financial advisers to pressure iFAST Financial into withdrawing a 50% commission rebate offer on competing life insurance products. The agreement led to iFAST withdrawing the offer just days after its launch. The appeal to reduce the penalty was dismissed, with interest and costs also being imposed.

site_title: Hong Kong opens higher, Shanghai edges down
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.51% to 27,680.19, driven by positive earnings results and a Wall Street high, while Shanghai edged down 0.13% to 3,288.52. The moves came as US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Cabbies, private-hire drivers cannot do courier jobs: LTA
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has clarified that taxi and private-hire drivers are not allowed to be couriers or deliverymen for goods if there is no passenger on board, as per regulations. This rule aims to maintain the primary purpose of these vehicles as passenger transport services.

images.alt_text: Taxi drivers and private-hire drivers are not allowed to be couriers or deliverymen for goods if there is no passenger on board, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) said on Tuesday.

site_title: Sing dollar too strong: DBS currency strategist
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) is considered too strong, according to DBS Bank senior currency strategist Philip Wee, as it has gained over 6% against the US dollar (USD) year-to-date. The SGD's nominal effective exchange rate (NEER) is in the strongest quartile of its neutral policy band, which is inconsistent with Singapore's lackluster economic data. Despite this, foreign reserves have increased to $266.3 billion in June 2017, the highest since 2013. Wee predicts USD/SGD to stabilize between 1.3370 and 1.3820 in the second half of 2017, with the SGD likely to weaken from Q2 2018 to 1.36 to 1.42.

site_title: MAS launches Payments Council chaired by its MD Ravi Menon
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a Payments Council, chaired by MD Ravi Menon, to promote seamless payments solutions and drive the adoption of e-payments in Singapore. The council brings together industry leaders to encourage collaboration, promote interoperability, and develop strategies to make e-payments simple, secure, and accessible for all Singaporeans. The MAS aims to transform Singapore into an e-payments society through initiatives such as facilitating PayNow and introducing unified point-of-sale terminals. The council will advise MAS on payments-related policies and make recommendations for two years.

images.alt_text: A PAYMENTS council - comprising 20 leaders from banks, payment service providers, businesses and trade associations - will be established to help Singapore transform into an e-payments society, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced on Wednesday.

site_title: GIC leads US$220m funding round for Chinese P2P firm
summary: Chinese peer-to-peer lending platform Dianrong raised US$220 million from investors led by Singapore's GIC Pte Ltd to expand its operations in China and other countries. The funds will be used for automation, research and development, and potential acquisitions. Dianrong has previously received backing from Standard Chartered's private equity arm and Tiger Global Management. The company aims to grow beyond China's crowded P2P market and explore new technologies, including blockchain-based supply-chain financing.

images.alt_text: Chinese peer-to-peer lending platform Dianrong said on Wednesday it raised US$220 million from a group of investors led by Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC Pte Ltd, looking to step up research of new technology as it expands across China and explores ventures in other countries in the region.

site_title: How China's risk crackdown will hit Manhattan's property market
summary: China's risk crackdown on capital outflows and leverage is affecting the global property market, particularly in the US. A Morgan Stanley report predicts an 84% slump in Chinese overseas property investment this year and an 18% drop in 2018. Manhattan is a concern, with 30% of transactions involving Chinese parties in 2017. The crackdown is expected to disproportionately affect office properties in the US, UK, Hong Kong, and Australia. As a result, the market may experience significant losses, with the most vulnerable being the US and UK real estate sectors.

site_title: As Spain's economy booms, its government keeps slowing down
summary: Spain's government is struggling to keep up with the country's booming economy, with the parliament approving only four laws this year. The minority administration led by Mariano Rajoy is facing criticism for its slow pace, with many laws delayed or made minor tweaks. This highlights the weakness of the government as it struggles to get things done, despite the country's economic growth.

site_title: MOH provides additional funding to develop TCM sector in Singapore
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has allocated S$5 million for the Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) sector, including a TCM Development Grant and funding for service providers to adopt IT solutions and R&D activities. The goal is to enhance the operational efficiency and encourage continual learning among TCM practitioners. Applications for the grant will open in January 2018.

site_title: China's yuan pulls back from 9-1/2-month high after modest US dollar gains
summary: China's yuan retreated from a 9-1/2-month high after the People's Bank of China lowered its official guidance following a modest US dollar gain. The yuan opened at 6.7258 per US dollar and was trading at 6.7263 by midday, easing off its best levels since October. This move came after a modest bounce in the US dollar, which pulled back the yuan from its strongest level since October.

site_title: New Zealand opposition leader in sexism row over baby plans
summary: New Zealand opposition leader Jacinda Ardern faced a sexism row after being asked about having a baby and its potential impact on her chances of becoming prime minister. Ardern responded by saying women should be judged on their qualifications, not their baby-making plans. Human rights commissioner Jackie Blue stated that asking such questions breaches the Human Rights Act and is unacceptable in 2017. An online poll showed 65% of respondents backed Ardern, with many commenting that the debate was a "retrograde" and sexist notion that women's primary role is motherhood.

site_title: Apple beats profit estimates, boosting shares
summary: Apple reported stronger-than-expected results for the fiscal third quarter, with a 12% profit increase to $8.7 billion and a 7% revenue rise to $45.4 billion. The company sold 41 million iPhones, and shares rose over 5% to $158.12 in after-market trades. Apple highlighted the growth of its services revenue and the fact that 61% of revenue came from outside the US, while China revenue slipped 10% from the previous year. Despite facing competition in the smartphone market, Apple delivered a strong quarter with 17% growth in earnings per share.

site_title: Malaysia seizes nearly US$1m in trafficked wildlife at airport
summary: Malaysian authorities seized nearly US$1 million in trafficked wildlife at Kuala Lumpur International Airport, including 23 ivory tusks valued at RM275,000 and 300.9 kg of pangolin scales worth RM3.9 million. The shipments, shipped from Nigeria and the Democratic Republic of Congo, were sent to fake addresses and their recipients could not be traced. The seizures are part of a series of wildlife trafficking seizures in Asia, with conservationists singling out Malaysia as a major transit point for endangered species.

site_title: New Zealand job growth falls in Q2, reinforces central bank's neutral stance
summary: New Zealand's job growth unexpectedly fell by 0.2% in Q2, contrary to forecasts, while wage growth remained at 0.4% on a quarterly basis. The unemployment rate dropped to 4.8%, but economists attribute this to a decline in the participation rate rather than increased job creation. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is likely to keep interest rates on hold, as wage growth remains sluggish and the central bank seeks to boost inflation. The data reinforced the bank's neutral stance on monetary policy, with some economists predicting rates may remain low until 2020.

site_title: Stocks to watch: K1 Ventures, OUE H-Trust, NeraTel
summary: Investment firm K1 Ventures reported a 6.7% increase in net profit to S$149.98 million for the year, with a dividend per share leap to 6.5 Singapore cents. OUE Hospitality Trust's second-quarter results saw a 31.8% rise in distribution income to S$21.81 million. NeraTel secured S$14.9 million worth of new contracts.

site_title: At 96, Prince Philip begins his retirement
summary: Prince Philip, 96, begins his retirement after a lifetime of public service by Queen Elizabeth II's side. He attended a parade of Royal Marines at Buckingham Palace, marking the end of 22,219 solo public engagements since the queen's coronation in 1952. Philip will still attend engagements with the queen from time to time, but his individual programme of public engagements has ended. The queen continues to carry out a full programme of official engagements, with her son Prince Charles and grandson Prince William taking on more royal duties.

site_title: Trump close to decision on addressing Chinese trade practices
summary: US President Donald Trump is close to a decision on addressing China's unfair trade practices, with an announcement potentially made this week. Trump is considering encouraging US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to initiate an investigation under the 1974 Trade Act's section 301, which allows the president to impose tariffs or trade restrictions to protect US industries. The move comes amid long-standing US grievances over Chinese trade practices, including steel dumping and intellectual property theft.

site_title: Gold edges away from 7-week high as US dollar steadies
summary: Gold prices edged lower on Wednesday as the US dollar steadied, after reaching a seven-week high in the previous session. Investors took profits amid downbeat US data, and analysts predict limited upside for gold prices in the coming week. "The upside looks a little bit limited," said ANZ analyst Daniel Hynes, citing both increased net long-positioning and selling on exchange-traded funds.

site_title: Sponsors may be tempted by Olympics return to Los Angeles
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has awarded the 2028 Summer Games to Los Angeles, a move that may boost the IOC's lucrative contracts with top sponsors like Visa and Coca-Cola. The decision, announced after a two-way contest with Paris for the 2024 Summer Games, is rare for the IOC. Sponsors, including US-based multinational companies, contribute over $1 billion to the games each four-year cycle, and the 2028 host city will not be determined until 2021. The Los Angeles hosting the 2028 Summer Games could provide a financial boost for the IOC's top sponsors.

site_title: Workplace fatalities, injuries down in first half of 2017; occupational diseases up: MOM
summary: Workplace fatalities and injuries decreased in the first half of 2017, with 19 fatalities and 6,151 injuries reported, down from 24 fatalities and 6,769 injuries in the second half of 2016. However, occupational disease cases increased from 341 to 467 cases, with noise-induced deafness being the top occupational disease, accounting for 42% of cases. The manufacturing sector accounted for the majority of workplace injuries and diseases. Despite the overall improvement, falls remained the top cause of major injuries.

site_title: China expels anti-graft inspector from party for corruption
summary: China's anti-graft watchdog has expelled a senior inspector, Zhang Huawei, for corruption. The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection found Zhang had abused his position to receive bribes, damaging the commission's reputation. Zhang's case will be referred for prosecution. The CCDI has been cracking down on corruption within its own ranks, following a campaign to expose malfeasance. The move comes as Beijing considers sweeping changes to its anti-graft architecture, aiming to create a National Supervision Commission.

site_title: US Senate confirms Christopher Wray as FBI director
summary: The US Senate confirmed Christopher Wray as the new FBI director on Tuesday, three months after President Donald Trump fired his predecessor James Comey. Wray, a 50-year-old former Justice Department prosecutor, was chosen for the post after promising to maintain the agency's independence. He faces a challenging task, particularly reassuring the FBI's 30,000 employees of his commitment to their independence. Wray's first challenge will be to navigate the agency through the ongoing investigation into Trump's ties to Russia and the appointment of independent prosecutor Robert Mueller as a special counsel.

site_title: Lawsuit accuses Fox of concocting 'fake news' for Trump
summary: A lawsuit accuses Fox News of fabricating "fake news" to advance Donald Trump's agenda and discredit speculation of campaign collusion with Russia. The suit, filed by Fox News contributor Rod Wheeler, alleges a May 16 article falsely claimed DNC staffer Seth Rich was the source of leaked emails, not Russian hackers. The lawsuit claims Fox News included "fabricated" quotes from Wheeler, who was told by Trump supporter Ed Butowsky that the president wanted the article published. Fox News denies involvement and says the article was retracted due to internal investigation.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened flat on Wednesday, dropping 0.63 points to 3,337.57, despite US stock gains overnight. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a record high, and Apple's earnings surged 6% to an all-time high. Around 62.5 million shares changed hands, with 63 gainers for every 45 losers. The market followed other regional indices, including Japan's Topix and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index, which also fell.

site_title: Former Brazil President Lula faces sixth trial for corruption
summary: Former Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva faces a sixth trial for corruption, related to a kickback scheme that sent Brazil's economy into chaos. Lula, already found guilty of corruption, is accused of accepting 1 million reais in exchange for political favors. The "Car Wash" investigation has led to over 100 convictions, including four former presidents, and current leader Michel Temer. Lula's innocence has been repeatedly proclaimed, and a guilty verdict could bar him from running for president next year.

site_title: At least 29 killed in Afghan Shiite mosque attack
summary: At least 29 people were killed and 63 wounded in a suicide bomber and gunman attack on a packed Shiite mosque in Herat, Afghanistan. The attack, claimed by the Islamic State group, is the latest in a series of assaults on Afghanistan's minority Shiite population. The assault occurred around 8pm local time and was described as a "terrorist attack" by police, with two terrorists involved, one wearing a suicide vest. The attack was condemned by Afghanistan's national unity government, which called on Muslim Afghans to stand united against terrorism.

site_title: Former Japanese defence minister Onodera to take post again
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will appoint Itsunori Onodera as defence minister in a Cabinet reshuffle scheduled for Thursday. Onodera, who previously held the post from 2015-2017, will replace interim minister Fumio Kishida. The move comes amid regional instability, including North Korea's missile tests and China's assertive stance in the South China Sea. Onodera's appointment aims to stabilize Japan's defence policy ahead of key elections in the country.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will appoint Itsunori Onodera as defence minister in a Cabinet reshuffle scheduled for Thursday, NHK television reported on Wednesday.

site_title: US: Dow ascends to record high and nears 22,000
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a record high and neared 22,000 on August 1, 2017, driven by gains from Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and other banks. Apple rose 0.89% ahead of its quarterly report, while the S&P 500 information technology index is up 22% year-to-date, leading other sectors.

site_title: SoundCloud is said close to sale of stakes to Raine, Temasek
summary: SoundCloud Ltd is close to selling stakes to the Raine Group and Temasek Holdings, a move aimed at stabilizing the music-streaming service. The deal, which could close by the end of this week, comes as the company explores raising money to sustain operations. SoundCloud, founded in Stockholm and now based in Berlin, has failed to generate significant revenue despite attracting over 175 million users. The company laid off 40% of its staff earlier this month and closed offices in San Francisco and London. Terms of the deals were not immediately available.

images.alt_text: SoundCloud Ltd is close to selling stakes to the Raine Group and Temasek Holdings, deals that would help stabilise the owner of the popular music-streaming service, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Investors should keep an eye on US political turmoil
summary: US stock market defies logic with record-breaking performance, despite stagnant economic outlook and partisan gridlock. The Philadelphia Fed's Partisan Conflict Index is at an all-time high, but experts attribute the market's buoyancy to factors such as liquidity, "buy-in-anticipation" mode, and the Fed's willingness to intervene. However, heightened political conflict could eventually lead to a loss of confidence and major market losses. For now, investors should remain cautious but continue to ride the market, as it appears to be operating in a state of "buy-in-anticipation."

site_title: Tennis: Federer to make first Montreal appearance since 2011
summary: Roger Federer, the world number three tennis player, announced he will participate in the upcoming ATP event in Montreal, marking his first appearance at the tournament since 2011. This will be his first tuneup event for the US Open, starting on August 28, and his first visit to Montreal in six years. Federer, who recently won his 19th Grand Slam singles title at Wimbledon, expressed his excitement to return to the Canadian hardcourt event, where he seeks his third crown. His 36th birthday will also be celebrated in Montreal on August 8.

site_title: Europe's biggest oil refinery shut for two more weeks
summary: Europe's largest oil refinery, Shell Pernis in Rotterdam, will remain shut for two more weeks due to a power station fire and a gas leak. The refinery, which processes 400,000 barrels of petroleum products daily, closed on Monday for security measures after the fire broke out on Saturday. Firefighters controlled the blaze, and an investigation is underway. The refinery is expected to restart operations in the second half of August, pending repairs to the power station and a new flare-off system to minimize impact on nearby residents.

site_title: White House admits Trump 'weighed in' on son's Russia statement
summary: The White House confirmed that Donald Trump weighed in on a misleading statement about his son's meeting with a Kremlin-connected lawyer, casting doubt on claims he knew nothing about the 2016 campaign. White House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders stated that Trump "weighed in, offered suggestions, like any father would do." This admission deepens Trump's entanglement in the Russia investigation, raising questions about his involvement in the matter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.41% to 20,067.56, driven by reports of strong corporate earnings and the Dow's fifth straight record close. The Topix index also rose 0.40%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Tillerson: US-Russia ties could still get worse
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson warned that US-Russia ties could worsen despite a planned meeting with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov. Relations remain divided over Ukraine, sanctions, and Syria. A bill to tighten sanctions is set to be signed by President Donald Trump, and Russia has ordered the US diplomatic mission in Russia to cut hundreds of staff. The meeting comes as a special prosecutor investigates potential Trump campaign collusion with Russia. Tillerson stated that the sanctions bill has made attempts to thaw ties "more difficult."

site_title: Spicer said to stick with plan to leave Trump Administration
summary: Former White House press secretary Sean Spicer will not return to his administration job despite Anthony Scaramucci's departure as communications director. Spicer, who resigned in July, had planned to leave at the end of August. He will remain as the de-facto communications director until then. Spicer has been involved in controversy, including admitting to meeting with a Republican donor who forwarded an unsubstantiated conspiracy theory. He had claimed to be unaware of the story when asked about it by reporters.

site_title: Banks may be hit with additional capital needs of US$30-50b after Brexit
summary: Banks in the US may face additional capital needs of $30-50 billion after a hard Brexit, equivalent to 15-30% of their current capital in Europe, according to a report by Oliver Wyman Inc. This could lead to increased operating costs of $1 billion and potentially drive 35,000 financial services jobs from Britain. The loss of privileged access to the EU's single market could fragment the European wholesale-banking market, making it less profitable for banks.

site_title: China pollution regulators slam Minmetals units for rule violations
summary: Chinese pollution regulators have accused state-owned China Minmetals Group's subsidiaries in Hunan province of repeatedly violating pollution rules. An audit by the Ministry of Environmental Protection found non-ferrous metals producers, mostly units of Minmetals, failed to address the issues. The move is part of Beijing's drive to force corporate offenders to comply with environmental regulations. The audit's findings are the latest in a series of actions taken by Chinese authorities to enforce pollution controls and promote environmental accountability.

site_title: US dollar index hits 15-month low on Fed, political uncertainty
summary: The US dollar index fell to a 15-month low against a basket of major currencies on Tuesday, amid US economic data and political uncertainty. The dollar briefly touched 92.777, its lowest since early May 2016, due to weak US construction spending and auto sales. The Fed's policy outlook remains uncertain, with a 46% chance of a rate hike in December, according to traders' bets. The dollar's decline persists, with investors consolidating positions and market concerns about future interest rate hikes.

site_title: You don't need to pay top dollar for a hearing aid
summary: A recent study found that over-the-counter sound-amplification devices, which sell for around $300-$350, are nearly as effective as hearing aids costing $1,900. The study suggests that these devices can be a more affordable option for consumers with mild to moderate hearing loss, and a proposed bill in Congress aims to regulate and standardize them. The FDA would set safety standards and make the devices available without a prescription or medical exam. The bill has bipartisan support but is opposed by hearing aid manufacturers and gun owners who argue it infringes on their Second Amendment rights.

site_title: Straits Times Index - 5 must know facts
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) is celebrating its 50th anniversary, marking a milestone in its history. The STI, which tracks the performance of top 30 stocks listed on the Singapore Exchange, has a diverse composition of local and regional companies. It has a yield of 3.4% and is one of the highest dividend yields across Asia. The STI is also investable, with several exchange-traded funds (ETFs) available that track its performance. The index has provided sustainable and healthy returns, making it attractive for long-term investors seeking a sustainable dividend payout.

site_title: We Make Financial Planning Simple and Transparent!
summary: iFAST, a financial services company, aims to make financial planning simple and transparent. Founded in 2000, iFAST believes in integrity, innovation, and transparency, and has received industry recognition for its commitment to transparency. The company seeks to overcome consumers' fears of adviser-assisted financial planning by providing transparency in fees, commissions, and information. By empowering clients to make informed decisions and offering comprehensive training for advisers, iFAST aims to rebuild trust and provide personalized financial planning services.

site_title: Capturing the growth of global disruptors
summary: A new investment fund, the LionGlobal Disruptive Innovation Fund (LGDIF), allows individuals to invest in a diversified portfolio of globally successful disruptors, including companies like Facebook, Alibaba, and Tesla. To qualify, companies must challenge existing business models, have proven innovative ideas, and demonstrate stability and consistency in their business performance. The fund uses a five-factor fundamental investing methodology to identify potential disruptors with strong growth prospects. By investing in LGDIF, individuals can potentially benefit from the long-term growth of these companies, which are driving significant trends in various industries.

site_title: Building on strong foundations
summary: Mr. Chan Kong Leong, CEO of Suntec REIT, outlines his plan to take the REIT to the next level, focusing on strengthening its fundamentals and building on its strong foundations. Despite challenges from online retailing and the office market, Suntec REIT is performing well, with a 99.4% committed occupancy rate in Singapore and a growing presence in Australia. The REIT is also hedging against interest rate hikes, which it expects to have minimal impact on its Singapore dollar returns.

site_title: Oil, financials get European shares off to firm start in August
summary: European shares rose on Tuesday, recovering from two straight months of losses, with corporate earnings reports driving the gains. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6% and blue chips gained 0.9% as oil stocks surged after BP's earnings beat forecasts. The European second-quarter earnings season is nearing its halfway mark, with 60% of MSCI Europe firms meeting or beating analysts' expectations. British companies, particularly aerospace and defense firms, were top gainers, while lenders and financials also contributed to the gains.

site_title: BNP Paribas to expand property business in UK
summary: BNP Paribas has agreed to acquire UK property services group Strutt & Parker, expanding its UK property business. The deal, set to be completed in September 2017, will triple the UK unit's revenue and staff to 1,500. The acquisition comes amid concerns of job losses in the UK due to Brexit, with the housing market slowing and demand for rental commercial properties leveling off. Combined annual revenue will be £165 million. The deal will broaden BNP Paribas' services in the UK rural market and residential property.

site_title: Chevron House up for sale for over S$700m
summary: Deka Singapore is selling its Chevron House office-cum-retail property in Raffles Place for over S$700 million, with an expected price of S$2,700 per square foot. The 32-storey building, completed in 1993, has a 99-year tenure and is 98% occupied. The sale comes as the office investment market has improved, with sentiment shifting from oversupply to buyer-friendly conditions. The property's renovation potential has been evaluated, and its sale is expected to attract Singapore and foreign investors, potentially garnering higher yields after refurbishment.

site_title: French carmaker moves swiftly to stamp authority on Opel, Vauxhall
summary: PSA Group, the French carmaker, has completed its 2.2 billion euro takeover of Opel and Vauxhall, becoming Europe's second-largest carmaker by sales. General Motors is selling its loss-making European operations to PSA, which will help the French company achieve economies of scale through building over five million vehicles. PSA has installed new management at Opel and Vauxhall, aiming to unlock synergies and generate a positive operational free cash flow by 2020.

site_title: Ransomware common problem for SMEs in Singapore: report
summary: A survey by Malwarebytes found that 35% of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore experienced a ransomware attack in the last year, with 21% forced to cease operations immediately. The majority of ransomware attacks in Singapore result in downtime of over 9 hours, equivalent to a full working day, with 61% of affected SMEs experiencing this. Despite being a top concern, only 9% of SMEs in Singapore are confident in their ability to stop ransomware attacks.

site_title: Using technology to collaborate on DNA testing
summary: Asia Genomics, a molecular diagnostics company in South-east Asia, has seen remarkable growth and quadrupled its staff from 20 to 70 people in the past year. The company uses Dropbox Business to manage its highly technical teams, enabling secure collaboration and data protection across departments and countries. With Dropbox, Asia Genomics promotes a collaborative work culture, reduces unnecessary emails, and streamlines marketing materials for technology partners and doctors.
