The Business Times Corporate Golf League, sponsored by Audi and others, continues to gain popularity among corporate golfers.

site_title: Tough love leader
summary: AIA's new group chief executive Ng Keng Hooi has taken over from Mark Tucker, who left the company due to the initial shock and surprise from the market. Ng, a seasoned industry insider with close to four decades of experience, acknowledges the pressure of filling big shoes but is excited about the challenge. He prioritizes people development, citing AIA's success in building its own people and conducting rigorous reviews twice a year to identify suitable candidates. Ng emphasizes the importance of domain knowledge, proven success, and cultural fit in the organization. He aims to improve agents' productivity and grow the Million Dollar Round Table (MDRT) members, and is committed to being a "tough leader" who is respected and sometimes loved by his people.

site_title: Kasparov notches first win in brief return to chess
summary: Russian chess legend Garry Kasparov made his first win in 12 years at a tournament in St Louis, Missouri, beating Le Quang Liem in a 9-game match. Kasparov, 54, also lost two games, and his performance has not surprised experts who predicted stiff competition from younger players. The tournament's format will change to a blitz round-robin format. Kasparov, a 15-time world champion, is currently tied for last place. His comeback was seen as a brief return to chess after a decade of retirement.

site_title: The placemaker
summary: Sean Chiao, President of AECOM's Asia-Pacific region, emphasizes the importance of public, open spaces in urban design, stating that they should be part of a city's smart infrastructure. He cites his experience in redesigning Jinji Lake in China's Suzhou Industrial Park, which was initially a farmland, into a vibrant waterfront hub. Chiao believes that open spaces can create value for the long-term, foster a sense of community, and improve quality of life. He argues that cities must prioritize public spaces, not just for aesthetic purposes, but also for their role in shaping a city's identity and character.

site_title: Croesus' Q4 DPU up as acquisitions drive growth in revenue
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a 19% year-on-year rise in Q4 income available for distribution to 1.27 billion yen, driven by acquisitions, including Fuji Grand Natalie and Mallage Saga. The trust's DPU increased to 2.01 Singapore cents, up from 1.70 cents a year ago. Gross revenue rose 11.9% to 2.99 billion yen, while net property income edged up 0.1% to 1.441 billion yen. For the full-year, gross revenue surged 28.6% and net property income rose 16.2%.

site_title: Australia proposes stronger money laundering rules, includes bitcoin
summary: Australia has proposed a bill to strengthen its money laundering laws, including bringing bitcoin providers under the remit of Austrac, the government's financial intelligence unit. This would be the first stage of reforms to the Anti-Money Laundering And Counter Terrorism Financing Act. The bill also aims to bolster Austrac's investigation and enforcement powers, following recent accusations of breaches by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The move is seen as a response to increasing concerns about money laundering and terrorist financing in the country.

site_title: Marvel's battle-scarred The Defenders find teamwork tough
summary: Marvel's The Defenders, a Netflix series, premieres with a team-up of Luke Cage, Iron Fist, Jessica Jones, and Daredevil to battle a threat to New York. The group initially struggles to work together due to their individualistic pasts, but a larger danger forces them to band together. Filmed in New York, the show explores internal conflicts and the city's culture, setting it apart from other superhero series. The Defenders marks the first time the four characters unite, led by Alexandra (Sigourney Weaver) and connected to the conglomerate The Hand.

site_title: European cities need more money and powers to improve security: Nice mayor
summary: The mayor of Nice, Christian Estrosi, has called for European cities to receive more funding and powers to enhance security after recent attacks in Barcelona and Nice. Estrosi plans to convene European counterparts in September to discuss ways to improve security and review national and European legislation. He believes that mayors, not national authorities, are initially confronted with violence and should have more control over public areas. Estrosi has allocated €30 million to protect potential target areas in Nice and urges more financial support to address the new threats.

site_title: Nestle, Unilever, Tyson and others team with IBM on blockchain
summary: Nestle, Unilever, Tyson, and other major food companies have partnered with IBM to explore the use of blockchain technology to track food supply chains and improve safety. The companies will share data and run trials, including Kroger, Dole, and Wal-Mart, to test the technology's effectiveness. Blockchain can quickly identify the source of potential contamination and make it easier to track the movement of food products. The partnership aims to build an ecosystem for the technology and could potentially reduce the cost of recalls.

site_title: The economies of sharing
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

The sharing economy has transformed the way people work and consume goods and services in Singapore. Platforms like GoGoVan and Grab enable individuals to offer services or goods to others, often at a lower cost. While the sharing economy has brought benefits, it also raises concerns about regulation, social norms, and externalities. Economists argue that the rise of ride-sharing services may not reduce traffic congestion, as drivers may still use their cars without passengers. Policymakers must balance the benefits of the sharing economy with the need to protect existing businesses and mitigate disruption.

site_title: Best World shares plunge 12%; SGX issues query
summary: Shares of Best World International, a direct seller of skincare and wellness products, plummeted 12% on Tuesday after China's regulators announced a crackdown on pyramid schemes. The company attributed the decline to a Bloomberg report on concerns about the crackdown, stating that its China business remains unaffected. Best World emphasized its compliance with Chinese laws and regulations, and assured that its business practices are transparent and governed by strong principles.

site_title: Asia's biggest budget airline trains crew to spot human traffickers
summary: AirAsia, Asia's largest budget airline, is training 5,000-10,000 staff to spot human traffickers, becoming the first airline in the continent to combat the issue. The training, in partnership with US-based Airline Ambassadors International, aims to identify signs of trafficking, such as young women or children under control, mistreatment, or fear. The move follows UN pressure to tackle human trafficking, with an estimated 46 million people living in slavery, and profits thought to be around $150 billion. AirAsia plans to roll out the training at its four main hubs in Asia.

site_title: Trump again cites dubious Muslim execution story after Spain attack
summary: President Donald Trump tweeted that General John "Black Jack" Pershing's forces executed 49 Muslim insurgents with bullets dipped in pig's blood in the Philippines in the early 1900s, effectively eliminating radical Islamic terrorism for 35 years. However, historians have widely debunked this account as apocryphal. Trump's tweet sparked criticism, with many questioning his understanding of history and his stance on radical Islamic terrorism.

site_title: Hatten Land's Q4 net profit up almost 200%
summary: Hatten Land's Q4 net profit surged 199% to RM59.7 million, driven by the local government's assistance scheme and higher progressive sales from its projects. Revenue rose 24% to RM130 million, with earnings per share increasing to 4.35 sen. For the full year, net profit fell 87.3% to RM8.72 million due to one-off non-operating expenses. The company has approximately RM662 million in unbilled revenue to be recognized over time.

site_title: Home Depot extends winning streak,yet Wall Street shrugs
summary: Home Depot extended its winning streak by topping Wall Street's profit estimates for a 13th consecutive quarter, but its shares slipped less than 1% due to high expectations and concerns about a potential weakening US housing market. Sales grew 6.3% and the company raised its full-year earnings forecast, but investors remained cautious. Despite the strong results, Home Depot's stock fell 3.9% to $148.26, and analysts noted that the company is struggling to please shareholders.

site_title: 4 partnerships forged to give Belt & Road a boost
summary: The Singapore Business Federation has launched partnerships with four organizations to boost the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). The partnerships include a memorandum of understanding with Chinese Enterprises Association, Pacific International Lines, PSA International, and IBM Singapore to develop blockchain-based supply chain solutions and a BRI Connect Platform. The English version of the Belt & Road Digital Portal has also been launched to provide a regional perspective on the initiative, meeting increasing demand for BRI-related news. The partnerships aim to increase trade connectivity and tie-up opportunities offered by BRI.

images.alt_text: In its third year, the SBF-hosted Singapore Regional Business Forum focused on exploring trade connectivity and tie-up opportunities offered by BRI.

site_title: LTA seeks proposals to develop on-demand public bus services
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has launched a tender to develop on-demand public bus services that optimize routes and schedules based on real-time commuter demand. The trial will allow commuters to request pick-ups and drop-offs at any bus stop, potentially reducing wait times. Three areas have been identified for the trial, and the LTA will assess the feasibility of this service to optimize resources and costs. The trial is expected to begin in 2018, with the LTA continuing to run scheduled bus services in the meantime.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTV) Q1 FY17 revenue and Ebitda met estimates, supported by a 7% year-on-year appreciation of the Taiwan dollar. Cable TV subscribers remained stable. Phillip Securities Research maintains a "buy" recommendation with an unchanged target price of S$0.64. Wheelock Properties reported a 3.4% year-on-year increase in profit after taxes, driven by higher sales from Scotts Square and the Fuyang City project. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "buy" recommendation with a fair value estimate of S$2.27. Golden Agri-Resources reported a 100% year-on-year increase in core net profit, driven by higher crude palm oil prices, but maintains a "hold" recommendation.

site_title: Europe's tainted eggs hurting future trade for Netherlands
summary: Europe's tainted eggs, contaminated with the insecticide fipronil, are hurting trade from the Netherlands, the region's top egg exporter, and may spur other countries to increase domestic production. Supermarkets in Germany, the UK, and Switzerland have pulled products off the shelves, and the European Commission plans to discuss food safety issues. The Netherlands lost 502 million euros in exports in 2016, and the incident may lead to countries promoting domestic egg production, rather than relying on imports.

site_title: N-E Asia tensions: markets wise to show nervousness
summary: Financial markets have been slow to recognize the growing tensions in North-east Asia, instead focusing on Western diversions such as the Trump presidency and Brexit. However, investors have begun to shift their assets out of the dollar and into gold and currencies like the Swiss franc, and stocks are feeling the pain. The underlying cause of the tensions is the US's continued attempts to influence events in the region, with some experts warning that a pre-emptive strike against North Korea may be imminent. Markets are wise to show nervousness, as the situation poses an acute danger of nuclear catastrophe.

site_title: Pacific Radiance narrows loss, starts restructuring
summary: Pacific Radiance, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine group, reported a 86% year-over-year reduction in Q2 loss to US$8.05 million. Revenue declined 13% to US$17.51 million due to lower charter rates of its offshore support vessels. Despite a narrowing gross loss, the company faces challenges, including a cash flow crunch and operating conditions remaining uncertain. Pacific Radiance has appointed advisers to review its capital structure and develop a restructuring plan to sustain its operations.

site_title: Shadow over Hong Kong property leaves Singapore developers ahead
summary: Hong Kong's property stocks are cheaper than Singapore's, but face a higher risk of a housing crash due to its high prices. Analysts see a potential slump in Hong Kong's market, while Singapore's market is expected to rise 5% in 2018. Singapore developers' shares are more attractive, with lower discounts to net asset value and better affordability. A 70% divergence in home prices between Singapore and Hong Kong is due for a reversal, with Singapore's residential prices forecast to rise and Hong Kong's to drop.

site_title: China issues order to implement UN sanctions on North Korea
summary: China's Commerce Ministry issued a ban on several imports from North Korea, including coal, iron ore, and seafood, effective from Tuesday, in line with UN sanctions announced this month. The move is in response to UN sanctions approved on August 6. The Chinese government stated that cargoes already on their way to China will be cleared by customs before the UN sanctions deadline. This ban follows a 30-day implementation period after the UN resolution was approved.

site_title: Markets calmer but not breathing easy yet
summary: US officials downplay the threat of war with North Korea, with Defense Secretary Jim Mattis stating that war would be "catastrophic". Markets in Asia recover from the previous week's selling, with the Singapore Straits Times Index rising 0.88% and the Hang Seng gaining 1.36%. Analysts expect North Korea to remain a key issue, but investors are reassessing the situation, with some seeing safe-haven assets like gold and the Japanese yen as potential hedge. The US and South Korea are set to proceed with joint military exercises, further escalating tensions.

site_title: Gold slips as US dollar steadies; North Korea headlines in focus
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to $1,286.39 per ounce as the US dollar steadied near two-month highs. Investors remained cautious amid North Korea tensions, despite the absence of recent developments. US gold futures fell 0.12% to $1,292.4 per ounce. The steady US dollar countered gold's recent gains, but investors continued to monitor the Korean peninsula for any escalation.

site_title: It's time patent trolls were put out of business
summary: US patent trolls have increased patent infringement lawsuits by a factor of 10 since 2000, mainly targeting small businesses and startups. Economists found that anti-troll laws passed by 32 states since 2016 led to a 2% increase in employment at small, high-tech companies and a 14% increase in venture-capital funding. However, the issue of patent trolls may not be limited to NPEs, as large companies like Apple and Google have also filed questionable patents, stifling innovation and job growth in the US startup ecosystem.

site_title: Catastrophe bonds: blockchain settlement is neat and efficient
summary: Catastrophe bonds, also known as cat bonds, have seen a surge in issuance and risk capital, with over $10 billion issued in 2017 and nearly $30 billion outstanding. These bonds, which transfer risks from the issuer to investors, have outperformed traditional asset classes, including equities, bonds, and private equity. The use of blockchain for settlement in cat bonds is a new and efficient method, allowing for quick and transparent transactions. This technology can also act as a hedge against insurers, providing a backup system for settling risks in the event of a catastrophic event.

site_title: Net short US$ position at its largest since 2013
summary: US dollar speculators hold largest net short position since 2013, totaling $10.23 billion, according to Commodity Futures Trading Commission data. This is a significant increase from the previous week's $5.32 billion. The dollar's value has been hurt by geopolitical tensions in Washington and diminished expectations of accelerated rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The dollar index has fallen 8.9% this year, and the euro has gained 12.4% against the dollar, reaching its largest long position since May 2011.

site_title: Close connections - past and present
summary: Singapore and India have a strong relationship marked by close trading and cultural ties. The two countries have numerous air connections, with seven daily flights between Chennai and Singapore, and several joint ventures in the airline industry. India is one of Singapore's major trading partners, with Singapore being the largest or second-largest investor in India, according to recent statistics. Major Singapore companies, such as Temasek and Sembcorp, have significant investments in India, offering attractive returns for portfolio investors.

site_title: Neymar offers to pay US$2.5m fine to Brazil tax authorities
summary: Brazilian football star Neymar is willing to pay a US$2.5 million fine to settle tax evasion allegations in Brazil. Neymar's lawyer, Marcos Neder, stated that the process has lasted over three years and the player aims to move forward with his new life with Paris Saint-Germain. Neymar's transfer buyout from FC Barcelona was a record US$261 million. The agreement would end the fight with Brazilian authorities, allowing Neymar to focus on his professional career.

site_title: Tensions over N Korea could roil markets this week
summary: Tensions between the US and North Korea are expected to impact financial markets this week, with stock and bond prices dropping and the value of the US dollar decreasing. Analysts warn of a potential correction in financial asset prices, citing the uncertainty of a North Korea-centred crisis. Experts predict further turmoil if the crisis escalates, with some suggesting it could be triggered by a long-overdue correction in financial asset prices. The crisis has already led to increased geopolitical tensions in East Asia, with the US and China playing a significant role in the situation.

site_title: Ivory Coast's battle of the beers turns bitter
summary: In Ivory Coast, the beer market is witnessing a fierce competition between market leader Solibra and newcomer Brassivoire, with both breweries launching aggressive marketing campaigns. Since Brassivoire's arrival in 2016, the company has gained a significant share of the market, and its owner Heineken is now gearing up to take more. Concerns have been raised about the impact of this marketing war on impressionable youngsters, with some groups calling for responsible advertising practices. The breweries have promised to address the issue, but analysts predict that the battle for market supremacy will continue.

site_title: AI service helps tourists enjoy Japanese folk dancing
summary: An AI-powered service, Awa-odori AI Concierge, is now available in Tokushima, Japan, until August 16, 2017. The online service uses artificial intelligence to provide tourists with information about the traditional dance parade, awa-odori, and other tourist spots and local specialty foods in the prefecture. It can interpret informal Japanese expressions and respond to inquiries in both English and Japanese. The service is offered on the websites of the Tokushima prefectural government, tourism association, and international exchange association, aiming to assist the estimated one million tourists who visit during the festival season.

site_title: Chinese aircraft fly over Taiwan in weekend of drills
summary: Chinese military aircraft carried out two rounds of drills over Taiwan on August 12-13, 2017, flying past its southern tip and around its north near Japan. The drills, which included bombers, transport aircraft, and fighter jets, were monitored by Taiwan's forces, which responded appropriately with no cause for alarm. China has been increasingly asserting itself in territorial disputes and has warned that any moves towards Taiwan's formal independence could prompt an armed response. China has yet to comment on the drills.

site_title: Short-term thinking a killer in the long run
summary: The article highlights the need for corporate sustainability and long-term thinking in the face of climate change. Short-termism, driven by CEO tenure and market pressures, is a major obstacle to sustainable investment. However, companies that embed corporate strategies with sustainability are finding it to be a powerful tool for reinvention. The article argues that companies should adopt a new narrative to motivate change and that leaders, including CEOs and politicians, must prioritize long-term environmental sustainability. Ultimately, companies and nations that successfully find solutions to climate change will reap strategic advantages and do the world a service.

site_title: Fable that's a love letter to the redemptive power of creativity
summary: The indie comedy Brigsby Bear, starring Kyle Mooney, tells the story of a man-child who was abducted at birth and raised in an underground bunker watching a fictional children's TV series, Brigsby Bear Adventures. When he's rescued, he discovers the show was a hoax and sets out to complete the series with the help of new friends, finding solace in creativity and connection. The film is a heartwarming fable about the redemptive power of creativity and a skewering of pop-culture obsessives, showcasing Mooney's deadpan sincerity.

images.alt_text: In Kyle Mooney's movie Brigsby Bear, a young man learns the startling truth behind his favourite television show.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. An Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are expanding cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Energy hedge funds look to spreads, margins
summary: Energy hedge funds are shifting their focus from commodity trading to other strategies, such as refining margins and calendar spreads, as the industry continues to dwindle due to stagnant oil prices. Despite losses, some funds, like RCMA Asset Management's Merchant Commodity Fund, are performing relatively well, with US$190 million in commodities. Refining margins have increased sharply, driven by heavy demand for distillates, and are expected to remain healthy globally. However, commodity hedge funds have declined 2.8% and 0.9% in 2017 and 2016, respectively.

site_title: Producer prices record biggest drop in 11 months
summary: US producer prices dropped 0.1% in July, the largest decline in 11 months, indicating moderation in inflation. This could delay a Federal Reserve interest rate increase, with Fed Chair Janet Yellen citing "special factors" for the low inflation readings. The labor market remains near full employment, with initial jobless claims increasing 3,000 to 244,000. The data suggests the Fed may delay raising rates until December, contrary to its previous plans to start shrinking its portfolio next month.

site_title: Decision on Chinese buyout of Chicago exchange delayed
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission has delayed a decision on a Chinese-led group's proposed buyout of the Chicago Stock Exchange, which would put the 135-year-old exchange in the hands of investors led by China's Chongqing Casin Enterprise Group Co. The decision, which was expected by a Wednesday deadline, will be reviewed by commissioners, potentially setting up a vote at an unknown date. The move delays a takeover that has drawn opposition from lawmakers and President Donald Trump, who criticized the deal on the campaign trail.

site_title: Trump's language on North Korea carries dire risks: analysts
summary: US President Donald Trump's recent verbal assault on North Korea, warning of "fire and fury like the world has never seen," has raised concerns among analysts that it could provoke the unpredictable regime into a nuclear attack. Critics say Trump's language is similar to North Korea's own bombastic rhetoric, which could escalate tensions and increase the risk of miscalculation. The US needs to avoid "escalating rhetoric that risks provoking the very attack we seek to deter," experts warn, as North Korea's first ICBM test brought Alaska within its range, and its second extended that to much of the US mainland.

site_title: Generic drug prices falling, but are consumers benefiting?
summary: Generic drug prices in the US are declining, contrary to rising brand-name medication costs. The trend, which began in 2010, is driven by increased competition among generic manufacturers and wholesalers. Prices for some generic drugs, such as Lipitor and Plavix, have fallen to as low as $10 per month. However, overall drug spending remains on the rise due to high-priced new treatments. Consumers may not notice a significant drop in prices, as many generic drugs are already affordable, and those with health insurance typically pay a fixed copayment.

site_title: MTI narrows GDP forecast for 2017; MAS keeps policy stance neutral
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) has narrowed its full-year GDP forecast for 2017 to 2-3% from an earlier estimate of 1-3%, driven by a more confident economy and improved growth in the second quarter. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has kept its neutral monetary policy stance, citing stable growth and inflation prospects. The manufacturing sector continues to drive growth, with the electronics and precision engineering clusters leading the way. However, the labour market remains weak, and downside risks such as increased protectionism and monetary policy normalisation still exist.

site_title: Nam Cheong gets writ of summons, statement of claim from AmBank
summary: Nam Cheong received a writ of summons and statement of claim from AmBank in the High Court of Malaysia, dated August 7, regarding RM70.4 million (S$22.4 million) debt owed as of July 30. The company is reviewing the summons and seeking legal advice while continuing restructuring discussions with AmBank and other lenders. Nam Cheong remains committed to restructuring and engaging with stakeholders, despite the development.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened lower on August 9, 2017, following Tokyo's decline amid North Korea tensions. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.34% to 27,761.03, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.12% to 3,277.81. This was ahead of China's July inflation figures release.

site_title: Indonesia's June retail sales rise 6.3% y-o-y: survey
summary: Indonesia's retail sales in June rose 6.3% from the previous year, accelerating from May's 4.3% growth. This is slower than the 16.3% growth in June 2016. Retailers forecast a 3% contraction in July sales due to falling demand after the Eid al-Fitr festivity.

site_title: Bungalows in the sky
summary: High-end penthouses in Singapore have seen significant growth in value and exclusivity, with prices reaching over S$128 million for a 17,642 sq ft unit. Ultra-high net worth investors and foreigners are major buyers of these luxury residences, which often feature superior finishes and equipment. The term "penthouse" has a certain prestige attached to it, exuding exclusivity, scarcity, and snob appeal. While some developers have adopted a more conservative approach, others continue to offer large, luxurious penthouses in prime locations. The Singaporean government's planning restrictions, including a limit on building heights, are unlikely to impact the market's trend towards ultra-luxury residences.

site_title: Heeton's Q2 earnings nearly triple to S$10.6m
summary: Heeton Holdings' Q2 net profit nearly tripled to S$10.56 million, driven by a S$7.8 million fair-value gain from investment properties. Revenue rose 35% to S$18.95 million, and earnings per share increased to 3.25 Singapore cents. The company reported a 40% increase in net profit to S$13.12 million for the six-month period. Heeton plans to explore opportunities to increase its recurring income base.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks extend recovery on bargain hunting; won slips
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.5% to 2,407.93 points on Monday, extending their recovery from four-week lows, driven by bargain hunting and better-than-expected US jobs data. The global economic signs of strength underpinned investor sentiment, stabilizing the market after a sell-off in technology and construction stocks.

site_title: Forget reflation, it's 'Goldilocks'
summary: Investors should remain positive on Asia despite near-term volatility, as the region's equities have rallied over 15% mid-year and are expected to benefit from a weakening US dollar, reform efforts in China and India, and under-positioned global investors. The USD is likely to peak in the coming year, making EM Asian equities a potential outperformer, having underperformed the US by 42% since 2011. Key opportunities include China's supply-side reforms and India's economic growth, with most global investors holding underweight positions in EM Asia.

site_title: India imposes trading curbs on suspected shell companies
summary: India has imposed trading restrictions on 162 listed entities identified as shell companies, limiting trading to once a month and curbing trading by promoters and directors. The move is part of a crackdown on illegal offshore transfers and tax evasion, following a ban on high-value currency bills. Analysts say the restrictions were unexpected and need to be based on evidence of wrongdoing. The Securities Exchange Board of India (SEBI) did not comment on the move, which has been met with shock from some of the affected companies.

site_title: The Thakral makeover
summary: Thakral Corp, a Singapore-based conglomerate, has undergone a significant transformation from its consumer electronics distribution business to the Chinese beauty market. CEO Inderbethal Singh Thakral credits the company's shift to change rather than being driven by innovation. The move was prompted by the decline of the electronics sector following the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis and the emergence of smartphones, which led to a decline in camera sales. Thakral entered the beauty and wellness market, focusing on China's growing affluent population, and has seen early results, including a small profit and rising gross profit margins. However, the company faces challenges, including competition from major players and the need to win the trust of beauty brands. Despite this, Thakral is hopeful that its repositioning in the beauty and wellness business, supported by its growth engines, will lead to better days ahead.

site_title: Contaminated eggs leave many Dutch farmers 'powerless'
summary: Dutch farmers are facing a crisis as millions of eggs suspected of being contaminated with the insecticide fipronil are being removed from shelves. The contamination has prompted supermarkets in the Netherlands, Belgium, and Germany to recall eggs, with 138 farms shut down by the Dutch food authority. Farmers are being forced to destroy their chickens or induce a moult to reduce the toxic substance, which can have hazardous effects on people's kidneys, liver, and thyroid glands. The Dutch poultry union claims the regulations are trade protectionism, while Belgian officials admit to keeping the issue secret during a fraud investigation.

site_title: Singaporean man charged with Western Union armed robbery
summary: A 58-year-old Singaporean man, Hashim Hamzah, was charged with armed robbery at a Western Union branch in Singapore. He allegedly entered the outlet wearing a helmet and mask, and robbed $4,000 using a knife. The incident occurred on Tuesday at around 10:40am.

images.alt_text: A 58-year-old Singaporean man was charged in court on Saturday with the armed robbery that took place at the Ubi Avenue 1 Western Union branch on Tuesday.

site_title: US Army calls halt on use of Chinese-made drones by DJI
summary: The US Army has ordered its members to stop using drones made by Chinese manufacturer SZ DJI Technology Co Ltd due to "cyber vulnerabilities" identified in the products. The memo, posted on August 2, requires service members to cease use, uninstall applications, and secure equipment. The decision follows studies by the Army Research Laboratory and Navy that found risks and vulnerabilities in DJI products. The Army cites classified reports as references for the order, which affects the most widely used DJI drones by the Army. The move is seen as a response to potential cyber threats.

images.alt_text: The US Army has ordered its members to stop using drones made by Chinese manufacturer SZ DJI Technology Co Ltd because of "cyber vulnerabilities" in the products.

site_title: SPH invests in Chinese tuition and education player Han Language Centre
summary: SPH invests S$8.5 million in Han Language Centre, a Chinese tuition and education player, in a 75-25 joint venture. The partnership aims to co-develop Chinese language educational programs and events. Ann Jong Juan, Han Language Centre's founder, will hold the remaining 25% stake. The initial payment of S$4.8 million will be made upon transaction completion, with the remaining balance paid when targets are achieved.

site_title: Lelong Lelong
summary: The Singapasar design-centre pasar malam returns for the third year, showcasing the best and newest collection of Singaporean-designed products, including furniture, food, apparel, and bags. The event takes place at the National Design Centre on Aug 5 and 6, from 11am to 8pm, featuring exclusive launches such as the SG52 series from Lorem Ipsum. Local designers will be selling their handmade, red and white products, including necklaces and brooches.

site_title: Gourmet Goes Local
summary: Singapore street food will be a highlight at Marina Bay Sands' Epicurean Market from Aug 11-13. The market features a "Singapore Street Food" section with traditional dishes such as rendang pipi daging, Teochew png kueh, and roti prata. The section is designed to resemble traditional shophouses and includes booths themed after different neighborhoods. Masterclasses and demonstrations will also be held, including one on char siew soh. The market also features specialty bars and a sneak preview of dishes from Lavo, an upcoming restaurant.

site_title: Metal Component issues profit warning for H1 2017
summary: Metal Component Engineering Limited has issued a profit warning for the half-year ended June 30, 2017, due to one-time costs from closing two operations in China. The company expects to report a net loss after tax. The financial results will be finalized and released on or before August 14. The closure is part of the company's consolidation and cost-saving efforts to better manage its resources.

site_title: UK dismisses 40b euro Brexit bill report as speculation
summary: The UK government has dismissed a report that the country is prepared to pay a 40 billion-euro bill to leave the European Union, with Prime Minister Theresa May's office calling the figure "speculation." Brexit supporters, including Jacob Rees-Mogg and John Redwood, have pushed back against paying any amount, citing a lack of logic and no legal obligation. The UK and EU will discuss the bill, along with the UK's border with Ireland and EU citizens' rights, in upcoming talks, with a deadline of March 2019 for a deal.

images.alt_text: There's been a shift within the Cabinet of Mrs May to a view that a transition period is unavoidable to bridge Brexit day and when a new trade accord sets in.

site_title: Trending now: the cult of the queue
summary: Millennials and Gen Z enthusiasts form long lines for limited-edition streetwear items, such as Supreme jackets and Nike sneakers, at "drops" in cities worldwide. This phenomenon, dubbed the "cult of the queue," is driven by a desire for authenticity and social status. Participants often prioritize the experience over the item itself, bonding over their shared interest in high-end fashion. Reselling has become a lucrative side business, with some individuals making significant profits by buying and selling items at inflated prices. The trend has become a global phenomenon, with enthusiasts traveling long distances to secure a spot in line.

site_title: Vietnam forecasts record foreign investment of US$16b
summary: Vietnam forecasts record foreign investment of $16 billion for 2017, exceeding $15.8 billion last year. Disbursed foreign direct investment is expected to reach a record high, while pledged foreign investment is predicted to increase to $28 billion. The country aims to boost economic growth to 6.7% this year, with the World Bank predicting a 6% growth rate until 2019. Vietnam's business-friendly environment and low wages are attracting foreign investors, despite uncertainty over the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The government has formed an economic advisory team to craft policies to boost growth.

site_title: Australia's spy agency downgrades aviation threat after bomb plot arrests
summary: Australia's intelligence agency has downgraded the country's aviation threat level to "possible" after disrupting an alleged "Islamic-inspired" plot to bring down a plane. Four men were arrested in Sydney, and one has since been released, with charges to be laid in due course. The plot involved an "improvised device" and was targeted at a commercial flight from Sydney to the Gulf. The downgraded threat level was announced by Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, who stated that the plot had been disrupted and contained. Increased airport security measures have caused delays for some air transport operators.

site_title: Seow-Leow, lah
summary: A Singaporean woman is weighing the decision of whether to hyphenate her surname after marriage, a common issue in multicultural societies. The author, marrying an "ang moh" (non-Singaporean), considers the feminist arguments against taking her husband's name, as well as her own roots and heritage. Statistics show a rise in women retaining their maiden names, and the author leans towards double-barrelling, but is uncertain after receiving a lukewarm response from her husband. Ultimately, she decides to keep her original name, citing a sense of identity and cultural connection.

images.alt_text: While statistics from Singapore aren't readily available, there appears to be a rise in women deciding to retain their maiden names in some way.

site_title: New Payments Council to plot S'pore's cashless drive
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has formed a 20-member payments council to promote a cashless society in Singapore. The council, led by MAS managing director Ravi Menon, includes representatives from tech companies like Grab, Lazada, and Sea, as well as local businesses and financial institutions. The council aims to make e-payments simple, seamless, and secure for all Singaporeans, and will focus on developing cashless payment solutions and introducing new legislation to safeguard consumer interests. The council's mission is to achieve a cashless society through interoperable and integrated e-payment solutions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, SingPost, TT International, Ascott, SIA
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported an 8% increase in net profit to S$1.13 billion for its second quarter. Singapore Post Limited's net profit declined 13.6% to S$31 million for the fiscal first quarter. TT International suspended trading of its shares amid funding issues. The Ascott Limited will invest S$170.3 million in a co-living space project. Singapore Airlines asked cabin crew to take no-pay leave to address a temporary manpower surplus.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the Singapore Institute of Surveyors and Valuers (SISV) are jointly reviewing valuation practices and the reporting carried out by real estate valuers that are engaged by listed issuers.

site_title: DBS net profit up 8% for Q2
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported an 8% increase in net profit to S$1.13 billion for its second quarter, despite lower net interest margin and trading income. Total income remained flat at S$2.92 billion. Loans rose 5% to S$302.97 billion, while net fee income increased 1% to S$636 million. Non-performing assets rose marginally to S$4.85 billion, with the non-performing loan rate increasing by 1.5%. DBS declared an interim one-tier tax-exempt dividend of 33 cents per share, up 10% from last year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares skid over 2% as housing curbs knock construction firms; techs slide
summary: South Korean shares fell over 2% on Thursday as tech stocks declined after a previous day's rally, while construction firms suffered a significant sell-off due to government-imposed housing curbs. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) dropped 2.1% to 2,377.16 points, with foreign investors mainly selling off tech shares. Local institutions sold construction shares, with the sub-index down 4.5% due to capital gains taxes and mortgage curbs announced by the government.

site_title: Young S'porean workers at risk of shortfall in retirement income
summary: Young workers in Singapore face a significant risk of retirement income shortfall despite high levels of private savings. A report by the International Longevity Centre-UK found that the average earner in Singapore needs to save 12% of their annual earnings, largely due to the pension system's inadequacy. Only 29% of respondents save for retirement, while 26% save for social care. Experts emphasize the need for a targeted state safety net to ensure everyone can enjoy an adequate income in old age, as private savings alone are insufficient to generate sufficient retirement incomes.

site_title: Sterling close to 11-month highs as BoE, services PMI eyed
summary: Sterling is trading near an 11-month high against the US dollar, driven by expectations of a Bank of England interest rate hike. The BoE's policy decision is due Thursday, with traders anticipating a signal that rates may be raised in November. The services PMI reading, due Thursday, is also being closely watched for signs of economic activity. Sterling is up 0.1% against the dollar and 0.2% against the euro, with analysts predicting a 6-2 vote to keep rates unchanged.

site_title: Chile economy, finance ministers quit
summary: Chile's finance and economy ministers, Rodrigo Valdes, Luis Felipe Cespedes, and Alejandro Micco, resigned in a crisis for President Michelle Bachelet's government just three months before presidential elections. The resignations follow a rejected $2.5 billion copper mining project and a split within Bachelet's left-center governing coalition. Valdes, who supported the project, cited a need for discipline and clear rules, but was unable to secure support from his colleagues. The move plunges Bachelet's government into crisis, with conservative Sebastian Pinera leading the election front-runner.

site_title: Halcyon Agri back in black for Q2
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a net profit of US$1.5 million for the second quarter, compared to a loss of US$8 million in the same period last year. Revenue more than doubled to US$527.7 million, driven by the benefits of its merger with GMG Global and Sinochem International Corporation's natural rubber assets. The group expects cost and revenue synergies to continue supporting its performance.

site_title: In a rich league of its own
summary: The English Premier League (EPL) continues to dominate the global football scene, 25 years after its inception in 1992. With a global reach of 212 territories and 80 broadcasters, the EPL is the most popular, watched, and entertaining league in the world. The league's massive popularity has led to a significant increase in revenue, with the 2015/16 season reaching a record £3.6 billion and projected to reach £4.5 billion in 2016/17. EPL clubs have also seen a surge in spending, with Manchester City leading the way with over £188 million spent on new players. The league's biggest names, such as Manchester United and Chelsea, are now worth billions, with Manchester United ranked as Europe's most valuable club by KPMG. The EPL's global appeal has also led to the creation of international tours and tournaments, with teams playing friendlies in North America, Asia, and other regions.

images.alt_text: THE CUP RUNNETH OVER: Why the English Premier League is the most powerful and most entertaining football league in the world by a mile.
London club Chelsea, owned by Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, won the EPL title in the 2016/17 season.
French midfielder Paul Pogba (above) is reportedly earning a weekly salary of £290,000 at Manchester United, making him one of the highest paid players in the EPL.

site_title: Facebook working to test video chat device in hardware push
summary: Facebook is working on a video chat device, its first major hardware product from its experimental Building 8 lab. The device, featuring a wide-angle camera lens, microphones, and speakers powered by AI technology, is expected to be announced at the F8 developer conference as early as next spring. This marks a new product category for the company, which could revolutionize home video conferencing.

site_title: K1 Ventures' full-year earnings up 6.7% at S$149.98m
summary: K1 Ventures' net profit increased 6.7% to S$149.98 million for the year ended June 30, driven by a divestment in Guggenheim Capital LLC. Revenue plummeted 51.7% to S$94.16 million due to a decrease in investment income. Earnings per share edged up to 34.63 Singapore cents and net asset value per share expanded to 76 Singapore cents. A final dividend of 6.5 Singapore cents was proposed, up from none in the previous year. The company's shares closed 0.7% higher at S$0.73.

site_title: Financial advisory fuels Aviva's Singapore growth
summary: Aviva Singapore reported a 57% year-on-year rise in annual premium equivalent for life business to S$90.5 million for the first half of 2017, driven by its financial advisory arm and direct sales channel. The company's value of new business grew 14% to S$77.1 million. Aviva has invested in digitalising the sales process and expanding its financial advisory arm, which is expected to significantly reduce average turnaround time for new applications. The insurer's group operating profit grew 11% to £1.47 billion.

images.alt_text: Mr Majmudar said the results reflect "promising developments on various fronts, especially in the FA space".

site_title: US consumer spending edges up; income held back by drop in dividends
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.1% in June, driven by a slight increase in personal income despite a decline in dividend payments, indicating a moderate pace of consumption growth in the third quarter. This was the first time personal income failed to increase in seven months. The core PCE price index rose 1.5% in the 12 months through June, as inflation remained under control.

site_title: Limit proxy voting in strata law? Majority back proposed changes: BCA
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has proposed changes to the Building Maintenance and Strata Management Act (BMSMA) to improve governance and transparency in strata-titled developments. Key amendments include limiting proxy voting to 2% of total lots or 2 lots, and prohibiting one person from holding multiple office-bearer posts. The changes aim to prevent domination by a single individual and improve decision-making. The proposed bill will be debated in Parliament, with over 250 respondents supporting the changes.

site_title: Foxconn could triple US investment to US$30b: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that Foxconn chairman Terry Gou is considering tripling his US investment budget to $30 billion, following the company's plans to build a $10 billion display plant in Wisconsin. This move was seen as a victory for Trump's "America First" effort to bring jobs back to the US. Trump made the remarks off-record, but did not provide further details on the potential investment. Foxconn has previously announced plans to invest $5 billion in India, and the company's CEO has discussed building three "big" plants in the US.

site_title: UK seeks interim customs union with EU to smooth Brexit
summary: The UK government proposes a "close association" with the EU's customs union for a transitional period after Brexit, aiming to maintain tariff-free, bureaucracy-light trade with the EU. Industry lobby groups welcome the move, citing concerns over potential duties, border controls, and regulatory uncertainty. However, the EU is likely to oppose the proposal, which would allow the UK to negotiate trade accords with other countries during the interim period. The UK's Brexit Secretary, David Davis, says the arrangement would be as close as possible to the current trade setup, while giving Britain the freedom to negotiate new deals.

site_title: The prescient iconoclast
summary: Economist and politician Meghnad Desai, known for his predictions, discusses Donald Trump, globalisation, and China. Desai predicts Trump's presidency, Brexit, and Theresa May's poor performance in the 2017 UK election. He views Trump as a learning curve, defining a new foreign policy stance, and notes his decisive moves, such as retaliating against Syria and North Korea. Desai is less positive on Trump's economic agenda, seeing it as populist and not progressive. He also criticizes the European Union's enlargement and the Chinese government's One Belt, One Road initiative, calling it "imperial folly." Desai believes China should focus on domestic issues rather than investing in outdated industries.

images.alt_text: "(Donald) Trump is on a learning curve, but he is doing a lot of things right. Many people don't agree with this, but he is defining a new foreign policy stance. America cannot go on doing what it has been doing, because its fiscal needs are gigantic." - Meghnad Desai.

site_title: HK's smart city plans may be just all talk
summary: Hong Kong's efforts to become a "smart city" are hindered by its reluctance to adopt the sharing economy, despite government commitments to leverage innovation and technology. The city's strict regulations on ride-hailing and bike-sharing services, as well as its refusal to adapt licensing rules for short-term accommodation services like Airbnb, have led to a lack of adoption and growth in these sectors. In contrast, neighboring Macau has partnered with Alibaba to develop its smart city capabilities. The government's inability to support the sharing economy may hinder Hong Kong's ability to achieve "smart city" status.

images.alt_text: The office of taxi-hailing service Uber Inc in Hong Kong. The government refuses to amend traffic rules that make it illegal for Uber drivers to operate. Police raided the Hong Kong offices of Uber last week and arrested five drivers for the "illegal use of vehicles for hire".
